abstract: Serenade and Speech at New-York
lead_paragraph: An unusually suggestive and brilliant display of popular sympathy and enthusiasm was last evening evoked in behalf of Maj.-Gen. DANIEL E. SICKLES. In place of the dinner which the General some days ago declined, a number of prominent citizens resolved to give him a compliment, which he could scarcely avoid appreciating and acknowledging. To this end the famous orchestral resources of Signor GRAFULA's Seventh Regiment Band were called in requisition, and a musical treat prepared, such as should render their performance memorable in the history of serenades.

abstract: SUFFOCATED IN A VAT. -- Coroner BARRETT, of Brooklyn, E.D., yesterday afternoon held an inquest on the body of a man named EDWARD MCCARWELL, who came to his death by being suffocated in a kerosene vat, on Thursday. It appears that deceased was endeavoring to clean out a large vat some 20 feet in diameter, in which was about 18 inches of kerosene. A little time after entering his dead body was fished out by a fellow workman, and Coroner BARRETT held an inquest, when a verdict in accordance with the above facts was rendered. The factory where MCCARWELL met his death belongs to R. PHALON & CO., and is located in North Fourteenth-street, near Second. Deceased was a young man and unmarried.

abstract: Enlistments, the Plan of
lead_paragraph: At this moment, when the President is calling for 800,000 volunteers, and we are about entering on another campaign of voluntary enlistments, it will not be malapropos to look a little into the ways in which other nations accomplish the same end, that we may pattern after them, if there is anything worth copying. England being the best specimen of the voluntary enlistment plan, we shall give that.

abstract: Is Drafting a Failure
lead_paragraph: Those who oppose the draft as a means of raising soldiers have stated, with loud vociferation and frequent repetition, that it was a failure, that it furnished hardly any men, and increased largely the expense of raising those actually obtained. Gov. SEYMOUR stated to the Albany Convention that it would not produce in the State of New-York 6,000 soldiers for the war; and it has been repeatedly said that every man furnished under it cost the Government a thousand dollars. Even the County Substitute and Relief Committee stated, in their report to the Board of Supervisors, that those raised in this county had cost about $1,000 a man, although they included in this, it is true, the expense of the Government in maintaining troops here while the draft was being made, as well as the expenditures of the county in consequence of the riot, -- items which were no more fairly chargeable as an expense in connection with the draft, than they would have been as items of the expenses of the election of Gov. SEYMOUR.
headline: {'main': 'Is Drafting a Failure?', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Is Drafting a Failure?', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: China, The Civil War in
lead_paragraph: The Chinese war still rages, with little prospect of being terminated. Since the Imperialists began to employ American and European officers and mercenaries, the tide of fortune has been generally against the rebellious Taepings, and they have lost several important strongholds, among which are Ningpo, Quinsan, and Wokong -- the last named, captured early in August by Maj. GORDON, occupies a commanding position on the Grand Canal, and enables its possessors to interrupt all communication between the rebel cities Loochow and Kangchow.

abstract: THE SUIT FOR BEING CHARGED WITH SHOPLIFTING. The famous shoplifting case of E.M. CURRIER against CHARLES PIERSON, of the well-known firm of UBSDELL, PIERSON  Co., of this City, and which was tried in May last, in Superior Court, has...
lead_paragraph: THE SUIT FOR BEING CHARGED WITH SHOPLIFTING. -- The famous shoplifting case of E.M. CURRIER against CHARLES PIERSON, of the well-known firm of UBSDELL, PIERSON Co., of this City, and which was tried in May last, in Superior Court, has been settled by the parties, the plaintiff, E.M. CURRIER, receiving $3,500, besides her attorney's costs, in settlement from the defendant. Attention was particularly directed to this case at the time, and it created considerable excitement in the legal circles, as well from its peculiar nature as because of the distinguished counsel engaged in it on both sides -- J.T. BRADY for plaintiff, and D. MCMAHON for defendant. On that occasion the Jury disagreed, and, as it was about to undergo a second trial, Mrs. COURRIER consented to compromise damages for her alleged grievances. The facts of this case, in brief, were simply these: Mrs. CURRIER was arrested on the supposition, strong at the time, of course, of having stolen a piece of silk from the firm, but the goods not having been found in her possession, Mr. PIERSON, on the following day, made an humble apology, which was accepted by E.M. CURRIER and husband, and they parted in a friendly manner, shaking hands, &c., as witnesses testified. Weeks after, to the no small surprise of the firm, a suit was commenced against Mr. PIERSON for defamation of character, &c., damages $10,000. Under such circumstances, $1,000 was offered, $1,500, and so on, and, finally, she accepted $3,500.

abstract: The arrival from New-Orleans of the stemship George Washington puts us in possession of interesting information concerning the troops under Gen. BANKS, who are moving through Western Louisiana, as in supposed, with the ultimate object of redeeming Texas from the rebels.
lead_paragraph: The arrival from New-Orleans of the stemship George Washington puts us in possession of interesting information concerning the troops under Gen. BANKS, who are moving through Western Louisiana, as in supposed, with the ultimate object of redeeming Texas from the rebels. The Nineteenth army corps, under Gen. FRANKLIN, had pressed forward to Opelousas, gaining that place on the 22d of October, without meeting a great deal of resistance, notwithstanding the fact that the enemy in large force of infantry, cavalry, and artillery attempted to make a stand about five miles from the town. Carrying out the policy, however, which has actuated them in all their movements so far during the campaign, they quickly retreated before our advance, and are reported to have gone to Alexandria. The headquarters of the Thirteenth (Gen. WASHBURNE) army corps, are still at Vermillionville, and all the troops are in fine health and well supplied. At New-Orleans an expedition, under Gen. DANA, composed of veteran troops, was being fitted out. Its precise destination was, of course, not divulged, but the general opinion is, that it was intended for some point on the Texas coast. The enlistment of colored soldiers was going on rapidly in the city, and the Union troops had been very successful in the destruction of salt works, tanneries and other rebel property across Lake Ponchartrain in Mississippi.

abstract: Speech at N. Y. Democratic Mass Meeting; Democratic Mass Meeting
snippet: Speech at N. Y. Democratic Mass Meeting; Democratic Mass Meeting
lead_paragraph: A grand rally of the Democracy took place last night at the Cooper Institute. The announcement that Gov. SEYMOUR would be present and address the meeting was sufficient to draw out the "friends" of that gentleman in large numbers, but though the hall was thronged the meetings outside were not comparable to the demonstrations of the Democracy when their prospects were less dismal than the present. The meeting, however, was characterized by great enthusiasm.

abstract: UNION MEETING AT GOTHIC HALL. A Union meeting was held at Gothic Hall Friday evening, for the purpose of ratifying the nominations, and hearing Gov. YATES, of Illinois, speak upon the topics of the day.
lead_paragraph: UNION MEETING AT GOTHIC HALL. -- A Union meeting was held at Gothic Hall Friday evening, for the purpose of ratifying the nominations, and hearing Gov. YATES, of Illinois, speak upon the topics of the day. S.M. GRISWOLD, Esq., Vice-President of the Fourth Ward Union Association, presided. The Glee Club of the United States receiving-ship North Carolina, were present, and sang several songs, which were enthusiastically received, after which Gen. STRONG, of St. Louis, was introduced, and addressed the assemblage in a patriotic strain, when Gov. YATES was presented. The Governor made a lengthy and able speech, in which he reviewed the part taken in this war by the West, and especially by Illinois. He enlarged upon the importance of the present struggle, and contended that it was neither the Abolitionists, nor the Republicans, nor ABRAHAM LINCOLN who brought on this war, but the Southern slaveholders, who desired to reestablish the Union upon the basis of Slavery. He expressed himself in favor of the Emancipation Proclamation, the Conscription and the Confiscation acts; and the only fault he had to find with the President was, that he was not fast enough in forcing measures for the suppression of the rebellion. As to the West, however the East might feel upon the subject, they would never permit the Mississippi River to be under the control of any Power other than the United States. The waters would be crimson with human blood, and the banks a graveyard from its source to its mouth, before they would give it up. As to Slavery, he contended that that was the actual cause of hostilities, and if it died in the prosecution of the war, he was in favor of its dying and its eternal damnation. Slavery stood in the path of the Republic. It had kept in chains four millions of human beings, and had kept up Southern pride and arrogance long enough. It had divided the churches, the Whig party, the Democratic party, and, at last, the country. He wanted peace, but peace would never come until the rebellion died, and it would never die until Slavery died. In reference to the anti-draft riots in New-York, he said that instead of going to Washington and demanding of the Government to stop the draft, every house in the City should have been reduced to the ground before the law should have yielded to the authority of a mob. After referring to the importance of the approaching election, and its effect upon other States, he concluded by recommending that the rebels should pay all the expenses of the war, and if they are not able to do so, when the rebellion was crushed, to confiscate their property and devote the proceeds to paying the wounded soldiers and providing for the widows and orphans of the patriotic Union soldiers who had fallen in battle.

abstract: Who shall Govern the City
lead_paragraph: Who shall govern New-York? It contains the extremes of society, brought together and thrown into daily contact with each other -- the very rich and the very poor. Though these classes, and all classes, have a common dependence upon each other -- are necessary to each other, and should be friends -- there has been an attempt on the part of demagogues to get up an antagonism between them. There is also in every large City a class of men unmistakably bad. The ignorant and vicious element in such communities forms a large part of their population. Great cities draw such men into them, and furnish the lairs in which they hide, and the fields in which they ply their vocations. They are the foul and dangerous animals which prowl through our streets, watching for their prey, and which make the night-side of the City so unlike its noonday character. They are the natural enemies of all wholesome government; kept under restraint by nothing but sheer force. Few suspect the existence of such a class, in any considerable or formidable number, till some interruption of government relaxes the pressure which restrains them; and when such an outbreak occurs, we can see this army of ruffians swarming forth from the cellars and the slums of the City, and strong enough to fill the streets with terror. When they rise in this form we call them "a mob."

abstract: The "State Fair" of the "Deseret Agricultural and Manufacturing Society" came off on Friday and Saturday last, and was generally considered a failure. Indeed, a gradual decline has been noticed the past two or three years, but this last exhibition was the poorest, by far, within my experience. The causes of the lack of interest and emulation it is diffcult to accurately determine, but some of them undoubtedly originate in the prize system.
lead_paragraph: GREAT SALT LAKE CITY, Friday, Oct. 9, 1863.

abstract: The charges of alleged frauds by a high official in the Custom-House, which are being made, are intended to reflect upon HENRY B. STANTON, Special Deputy Collector. The facts are stated to be these: Mr. STANTON, in his official capacity, has been requiring and taking bonds from parties who ship goods to neutral places near the rebel ports, providing against a change of destination to the latter. He has taken some 4,000 such bonds, and within a short time some of them have been abstracted. On this being discovered it was communicated to Secretary CHASE. Mr. JOURDAN, Solicitor of the Treasury, came on her and made an investigation. This resulted in tracing the abstraction to a young man, a clerk in the Custom-house. This youth had been induced to do so, it is alleged, by the parties giving the bonds, who expected, by securing them, to escape the pecuniary penalty of their violation. Of course a compensation was made for the abstraction. The bonds, however, have not been canceled, still hold good against the parties, are on record, and, if violated, can be prosecuted. Of all the transaction, until the discovery of the loss, Mr. STANTON was ignorant. The reports that he has been arrested, dismissed, &c., are entire fabrications.
lead_paragraph: The charges of alleged frauds by a high official in the Custom-House, which are being made, are intended to reflect upon HENRY B. STANTON, Special Deputy Collector. abstract: -FLOYD is dead, else we should judge by the name it was he who headed a party of thieves one day last week, jumped aboard of a boat which was snagged in the Mississippi River, drove the crew into the cabin, and demanded from the officers and passengers all the money, gold watches and other valuables they had about their persons or in their trunks. One strong argument against the theory that the present thief FLOYD was the ghost of the other, or was any relation of the family, is the fact, that after having robbed the boat and every one on it, he put the crew on a skiff and presented them with fifty dollars to pay their passage to some port.
lead_paragraph: -FLOYD is dead, else we should judge by the name it was he who headed a party of thieves one day last week, jumped aboard of a boat which was snagged in the Mississippi River, drove the crew into the cabin, and demanded from the officers and passengers all the money, gold watches and other valuables they had about their persons or in their trunks. One strong argument against the theory that the present thief FLOYD was the ghost of the other, or was any relation of the family, is the fact, that after having robbed the boat and every one on it, he put the crew on a skiff and presented them with fifty dollars to pay their passage to some port.

abstract: The well-known and gallant Fourteenth regiment of Brooklyn, late Col. ALFRED M. WOOD, now Col. FOWLER, having received a furlough of twenty days, will reach Brooklyn this evening. The Fourteenth have been in the war for over two years; have seen most active service, bearing themselves with honor and gallantry in every engagement of the many in which they have participated.

abstract: In meantime of entire neglect of all my private interests and affairs, seem to demand from me now my personal care and oversight of them; consequently I have felt constrained to tender my resignation of the position I held as Brig.-Gen. U.S. Volunteers, and which was duly accepted by the President, to take effect on the 20th inst. In thus taking leave of military life I can never forget the many agreeable associations which have attended it during my two years of service, and the kindness and respect shown me by all among whom my lot of labor has been cast, and the memory of them will be pleasant in all my future upon the earth. I desire to convey through you to all the members of my Staff the assurances of my sincere respect and friendship for them, one and all. They have been faithful in the discharge of their respective duties, and by their respectful demeanor, and prompt obedience to orders, are entitled to my thanks. I would exhort them all to continue faithful, earnest and untiring in the work of preserving our Government from destruction. This wicked rebellion will soon, I trust, be overcome and extirpated from our country, when all can resume their wonted haunts of private life and civil pursuits. I shall continue in my retirement from military life to do all I can to invigorate the ranks of our loyal army in the field battling for our national life, and to feel a lively zeal in all that concerns them in their tolls, sufferings and sacrifices, until a complete triumph of our flag and Union is secured, which will soon ensue.

abstract: Conscription, The System of; English and French method

abstract: Frankie Bragg, aged only fifteen, one of the bravest of Birgis' sharpshooters in the battle at Donelson, when dying in the hospital, was asked why he joined the army. He replied: " I joined, Mrs. S-, because I was so young and strong, and because life would be worth nothing to me unless I offered it to my country!"

abstract: The barn of SANFORD MEAD, Greenwich, Conn., was totally destroyed by fire on Tuesday night, Oct. 27. The barn was a building 30 feet by 66. It was filled with hay and grain, and about 75 barrels of apples. The sheds adjoining were also destroyed; containing fowls and a large number of farm implements. The damage is estimated at $2,000; it was insured for about $750. The fire is supposed to have been the work of an incendiary.

abstract: on New-York City Judiciary
lead_paragraph: Mr. JAMES T. BRADY has for many years enjoyed a large practice at the Bar of this City, and has, probably, done it as much credit as any other member. He has been all his life a Democrat, and is fond of boasting himself an Irish Democrat a class of politicians who pride themselves on their fidelity to their party, almost as much as their forefathers prided themselves on their fidelity to their clan. He has no sympathy, or if he has, he has always carefully concealed it, with "the opinions peculiar to Republicans," and was one of those who, down to the last hour, zealously supported the claim of the South to be allowed to govern the United States after its own fashion. Consequently his testimony in the matter of the existing condition of the Judiciary in this City possesses peculiar weight. In his speech at the Cooper Institute on Friday evening, he used the following language on this subject:

abstract: BROOKLYN CITY MORTALITY The whole number of deaths in this city last week was 130. Of these 13 were men, 25 women and 82 children. The causes were: Zymotic diseases, 11; nervous system, 26; heart and blood vessels, 8; respiratory organs, 46; digestive organs, 24; generative organs, 2; bones and joints, I; injury, 2; stillborn, 8; unkown, 1. Natives of United States, 94; Ireland, 24; Germany, 5; England, 6; unknown, 1.

abstract: ANOTHER INVITATION FOR THE RUSSIAN ADMIRAL. -- His Excellency Gov. SMITH, of Rhode Island, has sent a Deputation composed of Hon. J.R. BARTLETT, Secretary of State, and four members of his Staff, to New-York, to invite the Russian Admiral to visit Rhode Island. The Deputation will leave the foot of Whitehall-street, near South Ferry, on the steamer Henry Burden, on Monday morning, at 11 o'clock.

abstract: The arrival on Saturday of the Bremen brig Santiago, from Santo Domingo Oct. 6, gives us the only connected and authentic account of the disturbances on that island. In the various collisions between the insurgents and the Spanish troops, the advantage has been mainly on the side of the Dominicans. The towns of Santiago de los Caballeros and Puerta Plata had both been destroyed by fire.

abstract: An extraordinary case of treason has recently come to light, implicating several persons in this city, Columbus, Covington, and Newport, in conspiring to release the rebel prisoners at Camp Chase, and overthrow the State Government. The conspiracy was brought to light by United States detectives, who were supposed by the parties implicated to be spies from the rebel army, and were treated with full confidence.

abstract: In view of the importance of the election tomorrow, there should be a general suspension of business by loyal men, so that they and their employes can vote. abstract: The brig Santiago, from Port-au-Platte, Oct. 6. via Grand Turk, arrived to-day. She carried 109 refugees from Port-au-Platte to Grand Turk. The Hamburg and Bremen Consuls at Port-au-Platte were passengers to this Port, Reliable news by this arrival confirms the previous reports that after the destruction of the town of Santiago de Caballeros, the Spanish garrison, with 2,000 reinforcements, retreated to Port-au-Platte.

abstract: The Times City Article says the supply of Money yesterday, both in the Stock Exchange and Discount market, was less ample, and applications at Bank were rather numerous. The rate of discount has advanced in Hamburg from 5 to 5 1/2 cent. The cause seems obscure, as no Bullion had been taken for transmission to London. A week since the rate was 3 1/4. Gold is about 1s. 10d. dealer in London than in Paris. The English Funds were again steady yesterday, and during a short time there was a tendency to improvement. There was a rally in Greek and Mexican stock. The applications for the new Portuguese Loan are stated to amount three times the total of the whole loan.

abstract: -- The remarkable series of political triumphs which have been achieved by the Unionist party since, and including the Kentucky election in August last, is without a parallel in the history of any Administration. The Southwestern State referred to, together with the two great Western States north of the Ohio River, Ohio and Indiana, the Western State of Iowa, the Middle State of Pennsylvania, the Easternmost States of Maine and Vermont, the Westernmost State of California -- all, by stupendous majorities have elected the Union candidates, and thus sustained the Administration and the war. This, remarkable to say, has occurred in the third year of the Administration, and notwithstanding its numerous mistakes and failures. It is because the people believe it is laboring faithfully and honestly for the public weal amid prodigious difficulties, and because they know that thus they are aiding in suppressing the rebellion, and restoring the Union and peace. It now remains for New-York to step into line with the noble procession of States, and like them keep step to the music of the Union.
lead_paragraph: -- The remarkable series of political triumphs which have been achieved by the Unionist party since, and including the Kentucky election in August last, is without a parallel in the history of any Administration. The Southwestern State referred to, together with the two great Western States north of the Ohio River, Ohio and Indiana, the Western State of Iowa, the Middle State of Pennsylvania, the Easternmost States of Maine and Vermont, the Westernmost State of California -- all, by stupendous majorities have elected the Union candidates, and thus sustained the Administration and the war. This, remarkable to say, has occurred in the third year of the Administration, and notwithstanding its numerous mistakes and failures. It is because the people believe it is laboring faithfully and honestly for the public weal amid prodigious difficulties, and because they know that thus they are aiding in suppressing the rebellion, and restoring the Union and peace. It now remains for New-York to step into line with the noble procession of States, and like them keep step to the music of the Union.

abstract: At Cooper Institute
lead_paragraph: Gov. SEYMOUR has just made his third appearance as a speaker in New-York since his entrance into office. The first was at the Academy of Music, on July Fourth, when he addressed the Democracy in an elaborately prepared speech, the whole burden of which was denunciation of the Government as an insufferable tyranny, and an averment that the war, as conducted, was a dead failure. His language on that occasion seemed to be specially shaped to demoralize and depress the public mind to the greatest degree possible, and to fit it for a favorable reception of such terms of peace as LEE then in Pennsylvania, and, as was generally supposed by the Copperheads, destined to overwhelm the Federal army, might soon proffer. The fall of Vicksburgh had not been heard of, for it had taken place only five hours before; and the Governor took occasion to declare that Vicksburgh could not be taken. The news of Gettysburgh had not reached our City in any authentic shape. Every patriotic heart was harassed with anxiety. There never was so dark an hour since the rebellion began. Gov. SEYMOUR, instead of using his official and personal influence to inspire the people with constancy, and courage and cheer, seized upon the occasion to propagate distrust, despondency and despair. Considering the demands of the crisis, a more craven, faithless, vicious speech never passed human lips. Had LEE been the victor at Gettysburgh, and had the rebel flag continued to float over Vicksburgh, the consequences of that harangue of the Governor of the State of New-York would have been most mischievous, and might have been positively fatal to the National cause.
headline: {'main': 'Gov. Seymour at the Cooper Institute.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Gov. Seymour at the Cooper Institute.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- Gov. SEYMOUR doubtless thought it was a very telling point for himself, and a terrible sockdologer for the Government, to open his Fourth of July speech by saying: "Fellow-citizens! When I accepted the invitation to speak at this meeting we were promised the downfall of Vicksburgh, the opening of the Mississippi," &c., &c. But if anybody promised him this, was the promise not kept? Aye. While the sentence was rolling from SEYMOUR's lips, our troops were marching into Vicksburgh, and planting their banners on its ramparts, and the rebel army was marching out prisoners of war. He doubtless thought it a sharp thing to follow this opening remark by saying, that "in the moment of expected victory there came the midnight cry of help from Pennsylvania to save its despoiled fields from the invading foe." But, could he at that moment have looked as far as Pennsylvania and seen the rebel army flying from its soil, and from the field of Gettysburgh, he would surely have "stood before you on that occasion," as he said he did not, "as one animated by expected victories," and he surely would never have delivered that infamous speech.
lead_paragraph: -- Gov. SEYMOUR doubtless thought it was a very telling point for himself, and a terrible sockdologer for the Government, to open his Fourth of July speech by saying: "Fellow-citizens! When I accepted the invitation to speak at this meeting we were promised the downfall of Vicksburgh, the opening of the Mississippi," &c., &c. But if anybody promised him this, was the promise not kept? Aye. While the sentence was rolling from SEYMOUR's lips, our troops were marching into Vicksburgh, and planting their banners on its ramparts, and the rebel army was marching out prisoners of war. He doubtless thought it a sharp thing to follow this opening remark by saying, that "in the moment of expected victory there came the midnight cry of help from Pennsylvania to save its despoiled fields from the invading foe." But, could he at that moment have looked as far as Pennsylvania and seen the rebel army flying from its soil, and from the field of Gettysburgh, he would surely have "stood before you on that occasion," as he said he did not, "as one animated by expected victories," and he surely would never have delivered that infamous speech.

abstract: RANNEY yesterday held an inquest on the body of a soldier, aged about 33 years, named GEORGE FOSTER, who was found on the pavement early on Saturday morning, in front of house No. 179 East Twenty-second-street. The deceased belonged to the Army of the Potomac, and had just arrived in this City on a furlough of thirty days. He stopped with his sister at the above number, and during Friday night occupied a room on the fourth floor. Whether he accidentally fell or jumped from the window of that floor is not known. He was alive when found on the pavement in the morning, but died soon after being taken to the hospital. The deceased has left a wife and two children.

abstract: Speech at New-York
lead_paragraph: -- "This war will annihilate any leader, or party, or institution that stands in its way," so said Gen. SICKLES in his serenade speech, and truer words were never uttered. Niagara is not a whit more resistless than the sweeping torrent of patriotism which this war has set in motion. Whatever opposes it -- politician, party, slavery, or what not -- will go down never to rise again. The only safe place is under the battle flag.

abstract: -- The Copperhead papers are complaining bitterly of the fact that convalescent and other soldiers, from New-York, are furloughed to enable them to come home and vote. They grudge the defenders of their country this dearest right of the true patriot. For two long years these gallant fellows have been enduring privation, disease, and the rage of battle, till the graves of their comrades are crowding hill-side and plain, all to save our free institutions; and yet they themselves are held up to scorn as interlopers when they seek to exercise their most sacred right under those institutions. There never was such base injustice. It is a misfortune and a wrong, that every New-York soldier in hospital, or camp, or field, has not the opportunity to give his suffrage on the great issue now before the people. But for HORATIO SEYMOUR, who vetoed the legislative act for that purpose, all would have had this opportunity. The Government at Washington is to be praised for in some measure supplying the opportunity. None but men of evil designs find fault with it.
lead_paragraph: -- The Copperhead papers are complaining bitterly of the fact that convalescent and other soldiers, from New-York, are furloughed to enable them to come home and vote. abstract: -- In his speech of Friday evening, he who is perhaps the foremost member of the New-York Bar, and a Democrat at that, declared with a solemn adjuration to Heaven, that "if this junction of Tammany and Mozart be consummated, there will be at least two individuals in this City each of whom will own a Judge, body and soul." What must be the condition of things when such a lawyer has to protest in such language against the profanation of the sanctuaries of justice? What man, with a particle of respect for the law, can support the Judicial nominees thus pronounced the mere chattels of men who made them and mean to use them? Let every honest man vote for the honest Judges, BOSWORTH and HILTON.

Let every honest man vote for the honest Judges, BOSWORTH and HILTON.

abstract: -- A Southern gentletleman, who has recently been liberated from rebeldom by the advance of our army in Tennessee, writes us a note, in which he says that HORATIO SEYMOUR's denunciations of the Government in his Rochester speech compare painfully with the speeches of the rebel leaders to which he has been accustomed for two years past, while shut up within the rebel lines. How strange this is, if Gov. SEYMOUR be really as true and devoted a supporter of the Government and the army in their struggle for the Union, and as unflinching an opponent of the public enemy, as he pretends in some of his late speeches.

abstract: The Fall reason may be said to merge into the Winter season to-night, when Mr. MARETZEK commences his second subscription. It is -- so far as Italian opera is concerned -- the last until next year. The public has been so well satisfied with the past twelve nights, that the manager does not find if necessary to stimulate interest by new and elaborate promises. The company remain the same. "Judith," a Biblical opera, will be produced, and, perhaps, "Faust." The standard repertoire of the Academy will be illustrated by the members of Mr. MARETZEK's excellent Company; and, in some of the operas, new combinations will be effected of rare and peculiar interest. This is the case to-night in "Lucrezia Borgia," which will be cast to the entire strength of the company. Several of Mr. MARETZEK's principal artists take part in the finale to the first act -- an instance of condescension which only our popular impressario can extort from the company. Mme. MEDORI is the Lucrezia. The ole is one of that lady's greatest dramatic efforts.

abstract: -Our correspondent with the army before Charleston writes us that "nothing could exceed the exultation produced in the army on the reception of the news of VALLANDIGHAM's overwhelming defeat, unless we take into account the tremendous enthusiasm exhibited by the Ohio regiments" in the Department of the South. The same news concerning the same event has reached us from all our armies all over the South. The Ohio troops who are now toiling through Western Louisiana, who are garrisoning the distant posts on the Mississippi River, who are occupying Little Rock, fighting in the Indian Territory, and hunting guerrillas through Missouri -- those who are in the army of Gen. GRANT, at Memphis, at Corinth, at Chattanooga, Knoxville and Nashville -- those who are on the Gauley, the Potomac, the Rappahannock and along the Southern coast,-line from Fortress Monroe to New-Orleans -- have all, as the glorious news reached their respective and widely-separated posts, taken up the thunderous shout that rose from Ohio on the 13th of last month, until it has been echoed from the heart of the South, and resounded around the entire circle of the rebel Confederacy. It braced up the hearts of our gallant soldiers, nerved their arms, and inflamed their patriotism, by showing them that they had a nation at their back, and a people who appreciated their services and sustained the cause for which they were laying down their lives.
lead_paragraph: -Our correspondent with the army before Charleston writes us that "nothing could exceed the exultation produced in the army on the reception of the news of VALLANDIGHAM's overwhelming defeat, unless we take into account the tremendous enthusiasm exhibited by the Ohio regiments" in the Department of the South. The same news concerning the same event has reached us from all our armies all over the South. The Ohio troops who are now toiling through Western Louisiana, who are garrisoning the distant posts on the Mississippi River, who are occupying Little Rock, fighting in the Indian Territory, and hunting guerrillas through Missouri -- those who are in the army of Gen. GRANT, at Memphis, at Corinth, at Chattanooga, Knoxville and Nashville -- those who are on the Gauley, the Potomac, the Rappahannock and along the Southern coast,-line from Fortress Monroe to New-Orleans -- have all, as the glorious news reached their respective and widely-separated posts, taken up the thunderous shout that rose from Ohio on the 13th of last month, until it has been echoed from the heart of the South, and resounded around the entire circle of the rebel Confederacy. It braced up the hearts of our gallant soldiers, nerved their arms, and inflamed their patriotism, by showing them that they had a nation at their back, and a people who appreciated their services and sustained the cause for which they were laying down their lives.

abstract: We trust that no Union man, and no man of any party, who appreciates official integrity and personal worth, will neglect to vote for JOHN KEYSER for Register. He has held the office for one term, and has discharged its duties with ability, industry, integrity and a courtesy which has commended him warmly to all who have had any business with the office. He is a zealous and ardent Union man, and on every account, personal, official and political, deserves, what we trust he will secure, a reelection over the two Democratic candidates who are running against him.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon, the first excursion was made over the road, from Harlem Bridge to Fordham. The road is five miles long, was, commenced in May and is now ready for business. There is a general rejoicing at both ends of the route, and alone it at the improved facilities afforded -- facilities which have been long needed by the thickly populated section in winch the road is located. The cars are fitted up comfortably and handsomely, and the Directors propose, in every way, to please the public and popularize the read.

abstract: A communication was published in this paper yesterday morning, designed to affect injuriously the reelection of WM.H. ROBERTSON, the Union candidate for Judge of Westchester County, and to promote the election of his Democratic opponent. Nothing could be more unjust or unwise. Judge ROBERTSON is well known throughout the county as a man of ability and integrity, and has discharged the duties of his office in a manner to command universal approval. He is zealous in his efforts to-secure the election of Judge WHITING to be County Treasurer, for the purpose of exploring and exposing the frauds that have so damaged and disgraced the county. We trust that the, Union men of the county will see to it that his reelection is put beyond all doubt.

abstract: FIRST DISTRICT. -- Capt. B.F. WEYMOUTH is the Union nominee for Assembly in the First District. His name was received with the utmost enthusiasm in the Convention, where he was unanimously nominated. He represents the Union feeling of the country, should unite upon himself the working, active support of all loyal men in his District. He can be elected if they give this to him, for his personal popularity is great and will of itself secure him a handsome vote.

abstract: A dispatch from Fortress Monroe conveys intelligence, obtained from a Richmond paper, that our batteries on Morris Island and three of the monitors opened fire on Wednesday last upon Fort Sumter. During the first twenty-four hours of the bombardment 1,215 shots struck the fort, and seven casualties resulted to the garrison. At last accounts Gen. GILLMORE was persistently hammering at Sumter, without deigning to notice the rebel fortifications on Sullivan's and James Islands, which replied with a deliberate and steady fire.

abstract: -- We trust that Mr. PERRY, the Union candidate for the Assembly, in the Fifth District, Brooklyn, will receive the support of all who appreciate the importance of having that District properly represented, and that this will secure his election. This would not be doubtful but for the fact that Mr. CALLICOTT is running as an independent candidate against him, and that he receives the active support of the Tribune and Evening Post. What special reasons these Union journals have for opposing the regular Union nominee, against whose character, or the fairness of whose nomination no one has uttered a sillable, we are not aware. They may succeed in defeating him and in electing the regular candidate of the Copperheads. We trust, however, that there are enough loyal men in the District who realize the importance of saving it, to secure Mr. PERRY's election.

abstract: In magnificent contrast to the bankruptcy and financial lunacy which rule and ruin in Richmond, Secretary CHASE'S administration of the Treasury will show to the world a clean balance-sheet on the 1st of November. It will show the filling of Seventyfive millions of suspended requisitions. It will show the payment of every creditor of the Government, whose claim was on that day audited and established!

abstract: -The entire Police force will be on duty to-day, by order of the authorities at Headquarters, with a view to preserve the peace, and keep the way clear around the Polls, so that every legal voter may have an opportunity to deposit his vote. A large resrve force will be at Headquarters, in Mulberry-street, throughout the day, and upon the first intimation of a disturbance in any quarter of the City, a sufficient number of men will be sent to put it down immediately. We are insured that the arrangements for quelling any disturbance are ample and complete.

abstract: We have received the following letter from an Inspector of Elections, quoting the section of the Registry Law in reference to the vote of unregistered persons, and asking us whether or not the unregistered voter's affidavit requires a revenue stamp in accordance with the provision of the Tax law. Some confusion has been caused in this matter by the publication of a letter from the Assessor of the Fourth District, which gives an alleged decision of the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, to the effect that a stamp is required, and that its omission by any Inspector will subject him to a fine of $50; but a public opinion from the Internal Revenue Commissioner was received yesterday, which says that a stamp is not required, as it would be a tax on the right of suffrage; and this opinion we suppose is final, or at least will apply to the election of to-day. We append in their order the inquiry, the letter of the Assessor,and the final opinion of the Commissioner:

abstract: A few days since, the Albany Atlas and Argus published a long report of the attempts made by Gov. SEYMOUR to secure for the wounded NewYork soldiers in the front ranks of the Army of the Potomac the presence and services of Dr. SWINBURNE, who went on as agent of the State.
lead_paragraph: A few days since, the Albany Atlas and Argus published a long report of the attempts made by Gov. SEYMOUR to secure for the wounded NewYork soldiers in the front ranks of the Army of the Potomac the presence and services of Dr. SWINBURNE, who went on as agent of the State. It was stated in that article that Dr. SWINBURNE, accompanied by T.S. GILLETTE, Esq., made application to the authorities at Washington, backed up by letters from Gov. SEYMOUR and others, and were refused permission to go.

abstract: The contest between the Union candidate. Col. WOOD, and the Copperhead candidate. BENJAMIN PRINCE, will be, in all probability, very close. If good war Democrats will avoid throwing away their votes upon KALBFLEISCH, Col. WOOD's election is certain. Let all true men remember that the great issue is whether the Government shall be loyally sustained, or factiously crippled. All other questions are insignificant by the side of this. Every patriot in Brooklyn should stand by the flag, and vote for WOOD.
lead_paragraph: The contest between the Union candidate. Col. WOOD, and the Copperhead candidate. BENJAMIN PRINCE, will be, in all probability, very close. abstract: The arrival off Cape Race on Saturday evening of the steamship China and at this port yesterday of the steamships City of Washington and Germania, gives us telegraphic news to the 25th ult. and our newspaper files to the 21st. The journals furnish many interesting extracts, of which digest was published in the TIMES on Friday last, but of news, in the strict sense of the term, there is very little. The most important item is the fact that the capture of the reputed blockade-running steamer Sir Robert Peel, off the mouth of the Rio Grande, by the gunboat Seminole, is exciting attention, and is quite likely to cause as much discussion as the case of the Peterhoff. It is alleged at LLOYD's that there was not the slightest, ground for the seizure. Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER had received honors from his friends at a farewell breakfast in London, and the students of the Non Conformist College had presented him with an address. The French policy in Mexico, it was thought, would soon be stripped of its disguises by semi-official announcements in the Paris Press, to the effect that the Mexican people desire the annexation of their country to France. American affairs continue to be discussed by the London journals as well as topics cognate thereunto.

abstract: It has already been announced that Brig.-Gen. HAYS is to succeed Col. NUGENT as Assistant Provost-Marshal-General for the first ten Congressional Districts of this State. The reason for the change may be found in the fact that the Government proposes to consolidate the office of Provost-Marshal and the mustering and disbursing office formerly under the charge of Col. REEVES. The successor of Col. NUGENT is also to take charge of the recruiting business of this City under the new call of the President It was thought to be desirable that the head of these several Departments should be an officer of higher rank than Colonel, and hence the change. Col. NUGENT will probably remain here as assistant to Gen. HAYS Gen. HAYS is a Virginian by birth and a Tennessee an by adoption. He graduated at West Point in 1840. served in the Mexican War, where he was wounded, and brevetted Major for gallant conduct on the 13th of September, 1847. He was commissioned Brigadier-General of Volunteers Nov. 29, 1862. For some time past he has been President of the Court-Martial sitting at Washington, from which place he comes to assume the duties of his new post. He was present at Col. NUGENT's office most of the day yesterday making arrangements for entering upon his new duties.

abstract: FOURTH DISTRICT. -- WILLIAM H. GILSON is up as the Union candidate in the Fourth District for Senator against C.B. WOODRUFF, Copperhead. Union men -- men who are wearied of having nominations foisted upon them, men who look to the interests of the City and State -- will heartily and zealously support Mr. GILSON. He has the personal character and intelligence to merit this, to say nothing of a loyalty which will find effective expression, should he be elected.

abstract: We take great pleasure in confirming the World's statement that "eighteen thousand or thereabouts of New-York troops have been or are to be sent home to vote" at the election to-day.
lead_paragraph: We take great pleasure in confirming the World's statement that "eighteen thousand or thereabouts of New-York troops have been or are to be sent home to vote" at the election to-day. The number, we fear, is somewhat exaggerated by the indignant apprehensions of the World: we regret to say that probably not more than 10,000 of those citizens of this State who are serving their country and upholding the honor of its flag in the field, will be able to exercise their right of voting at the polls this Fall. We wish it were otherwise. We wish that every man whom New-York has sent to the army, and who yet survives the bloody ordeal of battle through which they have passed, could avail himself of this first and dearest right of the American citizen. But for Gov. SEYMOUR's veto, all could have had this privilege. As it is, -- inasmuch as Gov. SEYMOUR saw fit to insist that no citizen of New-York who had offered his life to his country should vote, unless personally present on election day in the district where he resides, -- we are heartily rejoiced that the Government takes special pains to secure to as many of these men as possible the enjoyment and the exercise of the right of suffrage. We wish they could have spared fifty thousand instead of ten. If anybody on the face of the earth has a right to vote, it is the citizen who offers his life for the salvation of his country.

abstract: Last evening was a busy one at the theatres an anxious one for the critics; and a festive one for the public at large. Why Monday should be selected by all the managers of our places of amusement for the production of their novelties surpasses our power of comprehension.
lead_paragraph: Last evening was a busy one at the theatres an anxious one for the critics; and a festive one for the public at large. Why Monday should be selected by all the managers of our places of amusement for the production of their novelties surpasses our power of comprehension. In Europe there is a very good reason for providing special attractions for that day. The poorer classes are then a little flush, and it is with them a sort of surreptitious holiday. But here everyone can afford to go to the play on all nights o the week if they are so disposed, and a novelty never rails to draw a good house whether it be produced on the first or the last day of the week. Managers, it they remembered this, might easily take an evening to themselves. Whatever one of the six it happened to be, the public would quickly recognize it as the novelty-night at their particular establishment, and the manager would receive that undivided attention from the Press which he cannot now expect. As it is, an important entertainment must frequently be dismissed with a paragraph -- and that not always of the most exact character.

abstract: The EMPIRE STATE speaks to-day. She in turn pronounces her judgment upon Faction. The whole country awaits her voice with intensest interest. Every citizen of the State, from Montauk Point to Lake Erie, ought to help give that voice a distinctness and a force worthy of her rank. Every vote ought to be cast to tell with the directest emphasis against the policy which Gov. SEYMOUR has been, with such infatuation, pursuing.
lead_paragraph: The EMPIRE STATE speaks to-day. She in turn pronounces her judgment upon Faction. The whole country awaits her voice with intensest interest. Every citizen of the State, from Montauk Point to Lake Erie, ought to help give that voice a distinctness and a force worthy of her rank. Every vote ought to be cast to tell with the directest emphasis against the policy which Gov. SEYMOUR has been, with such infatuation, pursuing. This is the paramount object. Local issues and personal considerations shrink into insignificance when compared with it. Of all matters, the question of sustaining the war, and the constituted authorities, which are conducting it, is the vital one.

abstract: The State election to-day is one which should enlist the active interest of every patriotic man of every one who desires to see the policy of the Government sustained, and the Union preserved and vindicated by an unembarrassed prosecution of the war to a successful issue.
lead_paragraph: The State election to-day is one which should enlist the active interest of every patriotic man of every one who desires to see the policy of the Government sustained, and the Union preserved and vindicated by an unembarrassed prosecution of the war to a successful issue. It is not a question of party success which is involved, it is one of national unity and national dignity. The feeling in this City on the part of the loyal is hopeful, enthusiastic; the signs indicate that its strength in this City will far exceed the anticipations of the opposition. If it would be made the duty of every loyal man to cast aside all business to-day, save that of voting himself and seeing that others vote, the result would be a blow to Copperheadism hereabouts so near a crushing one that it would never recover. All that is needed is for every loyal man to feel that to-day he has a sacred duty to perform, and to resolve to perform it.

abstract: The election in the State of New-York yesterday resulted in an overwhelming majority for the Union ticket for the Executive officers elected this year, and for the new Senate and Assembly. The majority of last year for Gov. SEYMOUR of 10,752 is more than overcome by the Union gain in this City alone, leaving the remainder of the State to figure up a majority against the party of that functionary, estimated, as we go to press, as at least twenty-five thousand.
lead_paragraph: The election in the State of New-York yesterday resulted in an overwhelming majority for the Union ticket for the Executive officers elected this year, and for the new Senate and Assembly. The majority of last year for Gov. SEYMOUR of 10,752 is more than overcome by the Union gain in this City alone, leaving the remainder of the State to figure up a majority against the party of that functionary, estimated, as we go to press, as at least twenty-five thousand.

abstract: We have private advices from Morris Island, of a nature improper for publication, but which inspire the very highest hopes of the success of the new attack on Charleston. The nature of the obstructions is now thoroughly understood. Our ignorance on this point has hitherto been the main difficulty. The obstructions are not of a character to prove any very formidable obstacle against a vigorous attack by the iron-clads. It is of course possible that we may lose one or two of these vessels in the attempt, but there is very little doubt of its success. Gen. GILLMORE's bombardment of Fort Sumter we take to be merely preliminary. It is of the highest importance that we should obtain possession of Sumter (or, at least, the island on which Sumter is built,) previously to sending in the iron-clads, as, in case of the disabling of any of our vessels, this would afford a convenient refuge. We have not hitherto taken a very jubilant view of the prospects before Charleston, but the facts now in our possession make them much brighter than they have thus far appeared.

abstract: -- The body of HUGH ROWE, a night watchman, lately employed on board the gunboat Otsego, lying at the foot of Delancey-street, was found in the water at the foot of Corlears-street yesterday. abstract: -- A gentleman named DONNEY, who has been residing in Washington Terrace, Hoboken, missed from his pocket, on Wednesday last, some United States bonds and coupons and some English silver, amounting to about $5,500. Mr. DONNEY is in ill health, and consulted with his friends, who called in the aid of Chief Officer EDWARD MONK, who arrested a girl on suspicion, 18 yesrs old, and found the whole of the property upon her. She was taken before Justice POPE, who committed her to jail to await the action of the Grand Jury.

abstract: in Great Britain
lead_paragraph: Every loyal American, whatever his opinions respecting the past words and acts of HENRY WARD BEECHER, will thank him for his work across the water. It is no exaggeration to affirm that the five speeches he has delivered -- in Manchester, Glasgow, Edinburgh, Liverpool and London -- each pursuing its own line of argument and appeal, have done more for our cause in England and Scotland than all that has been before said or written. Mr. BEECHER possesses the faculty, beyond any other living American, of combining close, rapid, powerful, practical reasoning with intense passion. His mind is always aglow with his subject, and whatever comes from it, even if does not flash conviction, is almost sure to kindle sympathy. This, combined with his marvelous power of illustration -- marvelous alike for its intense vividness and its unerring pertinency -- and with his great flexibility, whereby he adapts himself completely to the exigency of the instant, gives him a rare command over a common audience. Even those who hate, can't help admiring, and those most steeled with prejudice have to wince in spite of themselves.
headline: {'main': 'Mr. Beecher in Great Britain.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Mr. Beecher in Great Britain.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Blenker, Gen. Louis
lead_paragraph: -- Gen. Louis Blenker, who was at one time in command of the German division of the Army of the Potomac, died at his residence in New-Jersey, on Saturday last, from consumption. Gen. Blenker came to this country in 1849, and was among the first to respond in 1861 to the President's call for volunteers. He had seen considerable service in Germany, and very soon after going to the field, as Colonel of the Eighth New-York Volunteers, was made a Brigadier-General. At the first Bull Run his brigade brought up the rear on the retirement of our forces. Gen. BLENKER subsequently participated in the battle of Cross Keys, having previously served in the Mountain Department under Gen. Fremont. He was relieved of command in the Fall of 1862, and in March last was honorably discharged and mustered out of service.

abstract: -- Mr. JOHN EAGAN, the one who, during the riots of last July, by his promptitude and heroism saved the life of Mr. Superintendent KENNEDY, at the risk of his own, has just been presented with a silver tea-set as a slight testimonial for his services. The presentation was made by the highly accomplished lady of the Superintendent, Mrs. KENNEDY, who in a few words expressed her heartfelt gratitude to Mr. EAGAN for having saved the life of her husband at a time when it was as much as a man's life was worth to oppose the crowd of infuriated men who were bent upon murdering Mr. KENNEDY on the spot.

abstract: No new reports from above by telegraph. The following has been received by mail:  MISSIONARY RIDGE, Thursday, Oct. 29. The enemy have crossed a division at Brown's Ferry, three miles below Chattanooga, and are in possession of Raccoon Mountain, which they are apparently fortifying. A rapid shelling of our camps on the west side of Lookout Mountain was kept up  by the enemy to-day, our batteries replying.

abstract: -- Gen. MCCULLUM has prosecuted the work of repairing damages to the Orange and Alexandria Railroad, effected by the rebels recently, with great energy and success. Eleven miles of the road was reconstructed in seven days, and the track is laid as far as Warrenton Junction. Among the items of work performed were 653 linear feet of bridges, varying from 20 to 65 feet in height; 27,700 ties were prepared and laid sufficient to make a string of timber 45 miles long. Many cuts which had been filled were cleaned, and embankments that had been leveled were made up. The destruction of the road by the rebels was most thorough. Not half a dozen ties were left unburned. Telegraph poles were cut down and the telegraph wire destroyed. Railroad iron was twisted and bent, and in many places it was wound around trees, while heated, so that the trees had to be chopped down to recover the iron. One cut, 100 feet long and ten feet deep, was filled with trees and brush interlaced with telegraph wire and railroad iron, the removal of which was a work of great labor. It was found impossible to blow it up or dig into it in the ordinary manner, and it was found necessary to pick it out of the debris by piecemeal. -- Washington Republican, Nov. 2.
lead_paragraph: -- Gen. MCCULLUM has prosecuted the work of repairing damages to the Orange and Alexandria Railroad, effected by the rebels recently, with great energy and success. abstract: The Union State ticket prevailed yesterday by an overwhelming majority. In the City, the heavy Democratic majority of last year is cut down over thirteen thousand votes, or about three thousand more than the entire majority of Gov. SEYMOUR in the whole State.
lead_paragraph: The Union State ticket prevailed yesterday by an overwhelming majority. In the City, the heavy Democratic majority of last year is cut down over thirteen thousand votes, or about three thousand more than the entire majority of Gov. SEYMOUR in the whole State. The present State majority for the Union ticket is not yet known in its full extent of figures, but the great result and its emphatic meaning are already beyond question. Many of the Western counties, and the great Northern County of St. Lawrence, look, from the partial telegraphic returns received this morning, very like approaching the Lincoln majorities of 1860. And all make a gain on the vote of last year, while the Democratic or Seymour counties of 1862 are as invariably cut down.

abstract: The Tammany Democracy met at Tammany Hall last evening to hear the returns. Capt. RYNDERS made a speech, a young gentleman sang a song; there were earnest efforts at cheering, despite the wet-blanket returns, and after a short but, in view of all things, good-natured session, the crowd dispersed. It was not one of the old-fashioned meetings on election night which Tammany has rejoiced in, and from the ou set there was no spirit for jollification.

abstract: Rev. Dr. PEABODY has retired from the editorial chair of the North American Review, in consequence of his many other engagements, and from the conviction, long entertained, that a Quarterly like the North American should be in the charge of parties who could devote to it their exclusive attention. Dr. PEABODY will be succeeded by Prof. JAMES RUSSELL LOWELL and CHARLES ELLIOT NORTON, Esq, and the January number of the Review will be edited by these gentlemen.

abstract: -- It is expected that the China, which will probably arrive this morning, will bring Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER. It is doubtful, however, whether that distinguished gentleman will arrive so soon, as a letter was received from him recently, which was read in Plymouth Church last Sunday, stating that he had partially lost his voice, and desiring to make another speech in England before his departure, he might find it necessary to delay his anticipated return another week.

abstract: -- An inquest was held yesterday, by Coroner RANNEY, on the body of WM. ADLEE, a German shoemaker, residing at No. 346 West Thirty-ninth-street, who committed suicide by cutting his throat with a razor. The deceased had, for the last three years, been in the employ of Mr. JOHN FELSLER, as a journeyman shoemaker. The testimony given on the inquest showed that at intervals during the last two years he had manifested symptoms of insanity. On Monday night he asked permission of Mr. FELSLER to sleep in his kitchen, and yesterday morning he was found lying on the sofa, dead, his throat cut from ear to ear. The deceased was about 45 years of age. He has left a wife and several children, who reside in Germany. He was a man of good habits and character.

abstract: Our correspondent at Morris Island, under date of Oct. 30, sends a confirmation of the news published yesterday from the Richmond papers, respecting the bombardment of Fort Sumter, which was renewed on Monday, the 26th inst. Under the destructive power of our projectiles the walls were gradually crumbling, and it was believed that they would soon be completely demolished.
lead_paragraph: Our correspondent at Morris Island, under date of Oct. 30, sends a confirmation of the news published yesterday from the Richmond papers, respecting the bombardment of Fort Sumter, which was renewed on Monday, the 26th inst. Under the destructive power of our projectiles the walls were gradually crumbling, and it was believed that they would soon be completely demolished. From time to time four of the monitors have cooperated with the Morris Island batteries in the bombardment. The enemy have replied from their fortifications on Sullivan and James Islands with considerable deliberation, but were unsuccessful either in injuring our works or the garrisons. The three shells which were thrown into the City of Charleston on the 26th have not been followed by others, and the expectation of a general bombardment is, therefore, for the present disappointed. When our correspondent closed his letter at 10 A.M. on Friday last, the firing on our part was heavy and rapid, and under such a continuous shower of metal Sumter would scarcely be able in a very little while to afford even a nook for shelter.

abstract: Soon after five o'clock yesterday afternoon a frightful domestic tragedy occurred at the house No. 151 Christie-street. The particulars of the affair are as follows: FREDERICK SEREE, a German, aged about 30 years, had been for some time past living with a woman named MARY AMSLER, also a German, No. 151 Christie-street. Recently the latter has been devoting her attentions to another man. This conduct so exasperated LEREE that, yesterday afternoon, he had a quarrel with her, during which he drew a revolver and shot MARY through the arm. The ball entered near the elbow and inflicted a serious, though probably not fatal wound. MARY immediately fled from her room to the street. While she was going down the stairs she heard a report of a pistol behind her. The neighbors immediately come in and found FREDERICK lying on the floor. He had shot himself in the mouth immediately after having shot the woman. Not content with this damage to himself, he drew a razor across his throat, inflicting a ghastly wound, from the effects of which it is believed he cannot recover. Officers RILEY and BELDEN, of the Tenth Precinct, were called in, and after the wounds of the two had been dressed by Dr. WATERMAN, Police Surgeon, they were both taken to the City Hospital.

abstract: About 10 o'clock last night, a young man named JAMES PENDER, residing at No. 119 Laurens-street, while passing through Greene-street, between Prince and Houston, was shot in the thigh with a pistol in the hands of a woman named MARY JANE HOLLOWAY. The wound is not considered fatal. Detective FARLEY arrested the woman and took her to the Eighth Precinct Station-house. A preliminary examination revealed the fact that MARY JANE was trying to shoot another man at the time. PENDER was a stranger to her, and there is no pretence that she intended the shot for him. She resides at No. 113 Greenwich-street. A complaint will be made against her this morning at the Tombs.

abstract: In the sitting of the German Diet at Frankfort, on the 22d, the dispatch of Earl RUSSELL to the English Minister of the 1st Oct., was discussed. Resolutions declining to entertain the note were passed, upon the ground of Federal execution in Holstein being a matter of German home policy. A fresh English dispatch also relating to the Holstein Lauenburg question, was referred to the united Committees.

abstract: The great event in the history of festivities in New-York -- the grand fete, in comparison with which all previous ones will pale -- the Ball to the Russian Admiral and the officers of his fleet -- takes place at the Academy of Music to-night. The Prince of Wales ball and the Japanese were "occasions," but did not rise to the dignity of "events." The arrangements for the festivities of this night are characterized by the most refined taste and princely liberality. We have heretofore given an inkling of the preparations, and this morning it is timely to enter somewhat more into detail.

abstract: We understand that Col. WYNDHAM, lately in command of a brigade of cavalry in the Army of the Potomac, has not been "dismissed from the service," as has been asserted, but has simply been relieved from duty for the time being. The statement that Lord LYONS requested his removal on certain grounds is, we further learn, untrue in every particular; and the other parties who have been accused of intriguing against him are not only innocent of the intrigues and astonished at the charges, but have written him letters expressing their admiration of his courage and continued appreciation of his services.
lead_paragraph: We understand that Col. abstract: Election; Redemption of the State
lead_paragraph: New-York stands purged. There is not a trace left of the dishonor HORATIO SEYMOUR has put upon her. Her fidelity to the Union Is now beyond question. Notwithstanding the fact that she has eighty thousand staunchest Union soldiers in the field who were refused the suffrage, her majority for the Union is THIRTY-FIVE THOUSAND; and it would have been twice that, had it not been for the peculiar "friends" of Gov. SEYMOUR -- the vile dregs of the cities, steeped in ignorance and crime. The enlightened law-respecting public opinion of the State -- that element of society which carries moral power with it -- has declared itself against the Governor and for the President with a preponderance that ought to confound every decent man among the Governor's adherents. It is equivalent to a solemn finding that he stands opposed to the patriotic sentiments and moral convictions of the Commonwealth, and that he is derelict in the day that tries men's souls.

abstract: Corps Commanders
lead_paragraph: When the interior history of our military operations comes to be fully known, it will, we think, be found that it has happened to some of our heads of armies to receive praise and to others to receive blame for actions in which they themselves came in but for a small part, and the success or failure of which was really, owing to the conduct of their subordinates, and especially of the commanders of corps. It is hardly to be expected that people will take such considerations into account in their verdicts of commanders, and indeed there is seldom the means even if there were the disposition to do so. There is a savage summariness in popular judgments of military men: success is success, on whatever accident it may have turned; and failure is failure, however excellent the plans of the commander may have been. A strict justice, however, would take these into account -- would be disposed to pity rather than to censure the General whose combinations may have been defeated by inefficient, intriguing or unwilling subordinates, and on the other hand would not unduly exalt the commander whose victory may have been in great part the fruit of the happy inspiration or energetie action of able lieutenants. Without wishing, therefore, to set aside the rule which makes the result the test by which a General is to be judged, and the General himself alone responsible therefor, we say it would be gross injustice entirely to overlook the efficient causes of the result.

abstract: Capt. HARTT, of the Thirtieth Precinct, yesterday reported at Police Headquarters that at about 4 P.M. on Tuesday, a disturbance occurred at Manhattanville of a very serious nature. He says that "a band of men, numbering about 80, came into our Precinct. They were desperate-looking men, and arranged themselves along the street opposite where the polls were held. From their manoeuvering, it soon became evident that serious mischief was intended. One of the roughs, named COLLINS, dealt a powerful blow in the face of a bystander, without provocation. Officers RYAN and SULLIVAN immediately arrested him, and men began the war. All our available force was on hand. We left Sergeant PHILLIPS in charge of a sufficient force to protect the ballot-boxes and then engaged the mob, which momentarily grew larger. The conflict was fierce and, for a short time, terrible. Officers MANN, DENNISON and MCKNIGHT were each felled to the earth, being hit on the head with stones, and very severely injured. Officer OLMSTEAD was hit in the neck, but his injuries are not serious. Roundsman FRIZGERALD was shot with a pistol ball which passed through his right ear and took the skin from his cheek bone. COLLINS and one other of all the crowd were secured by the Police at that place." It is thought by the latter that the sole intention of this gang of roughs was the destruction of the ballot-boxes, and but for the timely interference of these conservators of the peace they would, without doubt have succeeded. The crowd were pursued into the neighborhood of the Central Park, and then, after a desperate fight, seven more of them were taken into custody. These prisoners gave their names as folowlows: James Brady, John Read, James Riley, John Shannon, Mathew McMann, Thomas Lyons and George Sampson. They were all arraigned and committed for examination yesterday afternoon.

abstract: A superb sword has been manufactured in this City for presentation to this gallant Western soldier, by his corps, the Thirteenth corps of the "Army of the Tennessee." It is probably the most expensive, as it certainly is, by far, the most beautiful, sword that ever was manufactured on this continent. The peacefulness of its proportions, the artistic elegance and expressiveness of the designs on its scabbard, the richly etched blade, and the general getting up of the affair gives proof of the genius of the distinguished artist who designed it throughout. The Thirteenth corps is now fighting down in Alabama, but we learn that the presentation to Gen. OGLESBY will soon take place. We understand that the sword will be on exhibition in this City for a few days before it is sent Wess.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The second performance of "Lucrezia Borgia," last evening, was as complete a success as on the first night, and the house was a perfect bouquet. abstract: We publish this morning a decision which will be of great interest to all connected with the navy. It is a decision made by Judge BETTS in the case of the prize steamers Anglia and Scotia, and involves the question of who shall participate as captors in the proceeds of the prizes. The vessels were captured in Bull's Bay, by the Restless and the Flag, two vessels which belonged to our blockading squadron off Charleston, and they, of course, were interested in the prize. Two others of our vessels, the Housatonic and Flambeau, which were enforcing the blockade off Maffitt's Channel at Charleston, sixteen miles off, made a claim to also participate in it, because they were within signal distance of the capturing vessels. The act of Congress of July 17, 1862 provides that when vessels are within signal distance of another making a prize, all shall share in the proceeds, and the question arose is to the construction of this language of the act. Judge BETTS holds that this distance must be such as would enable the vessels to communicate with each other, and render each other assistance, if necessary.

The vessels were captured in Bull's Bay, by the Restless and the Flag, two vessels which belonged to our blockading squadron off Charleston, and they, of course, were interested in the prize. Two others of our vessels, the Housatonic and Flambeau, which were enforcing the blockade off Maffitt's Channel at Charleston, sixteen miles off, made a claim to also participate in it, because they were within signal distance of the capturing vessels. The act of Congress of July 17, 1862 provides that when vessels are within signal distance of another making a prize, all shall share in the proceeds, and the question arose is to the construction of this language of the act. Judge BETTS holds that this distance must be such as would enable the vessels to communicate with each other, and render each other assistance, if necessary.

abstract: Reports were prevalent in Washington on Tuesday of fighting between MEADE and LEE, but we have received no confirmation of these rumors. It is asserted that Gen. MEADE has received imperative orders to bring on a battle, under penalty of being superseded if he fails. Referring to this matter we find the following in the Philadelphia Ledger: -- "The orders are said to have come from HALLECK; and, further, that they are backed by the President. Up to Tuesday, however, it is known there were no preparations for a forward movement on the part of MEADE; but, on the contrary, that he seemed to incline toward the maintenance of a defensive position. On Sunday and yesterday, so far as could be discovered, the rebel force along the Rappahannock had been considerably reduced, and any offensive designs on their part were, in no direction, visible."

abstract: The United States vs. The Steamer Anglia --The Same vs. the Steamer Scotia. -- BETTS, J. -- The above vessels having been captured and condemned as prize, the appropriate proceedings were taken to determine the ultimate disposition of the prize proceeds. The right to all captures vests primarily in the Government. Individuals derive no benefit from them but by means of positive, grant from the public authority. (Halleck's Laws of war, ch. 30, sec. 3, 4; 2 Wildman, International Law, ch. 9.)

abstract: From the returns thus far received there is little doubt that the aggregate Union majority will fall little short of 35,000. The Democratic majority in this City is reduced over 10,000 from that of last year. One Union Senator and four Union Assemblymen are elected. FLORENCE MCCARTHY is elected Judge of the Marine Court, over Mr. RICHARDSON, Dem. The result as to Judge BOSWORTH and MCCUNN, for the Superior Court, is yet undecided; several Districts to hear from may overcome BOSWORTH's majority. The rest of the Democratic Judiciary and County candidates are elected.

abstract: -- Dr. TAVERNER, the distinguished Professor of Elocution, has returned to this City from Europe. His great reputation as a teacher of elocution, and his remarkable skill in training public speakers in the art of oratory, have attracted such general attention that there is a proposal to establish an institute in this City, to be under his care, for instruction in this most important, but greatly neglected branch of education. It would be of great benefit to clergymen and public lecturers, as well as to political and Congressional speakers.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many or which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.
