abstract: The imperial City of the West crowned the hospitalities it has extended to its imperial guests from the East most worthily by the charming and brilliant festival which turned last night into brightest day in Irving-place. As a triumph of social art the Russian Ball will be remembered as long as any triumph of any kind can very well be in this land of things "a moment bright, then gone forever."
lead_paragraph: The imperial City of the West crowned the hospitalities it has extended to its imperial guests from the East most worthily by the charming and brilliant festival which turned last night into brightest day in Irving-place. As a triumph of social art the Russian Ball will be remembered as long as any triumph of any kind can very well be in this land of things "a moment bright, then gone forever." A palace was improvised by bridging a street, and the locale being thus provided by the managers of the ball, the world of New-York provided the rest. A throng -- which only in the extremest exigencies of the evening ever became a crowd -- a throng of men presumably brave, and of women visibly fair, assembled in one general panorama of grace, and beauty, and spirit, the best elements of our New-York life, to do honor to the representatives of the one great Empire which, alone among the leading Powers of the earth, has frankly and cordially maintained its old relations of amity and good will with the Republic in these days of trial and endurance. If a political significance must be sought for in so bright and evanescent a show, the very head and front of it "hath this extent, no more." America prefers no judgment of favor or disfavor upon the internal policy of Russia, nor does she ask from Russia any judgment of favor or disfavor upon her own internal policy. We simply recognize with the warmth and frankness which become us, the justice, forbearance, courtesy and respect with which Russia has borne herself toward us from the outset of a struggle the burden and responsibility of which are ours, and ours alone. If there be a lesson in this -- if it be true, as we believe that true it is, that the subjects of no other great European Power would now be welcomed to these shores as the sailors of ALEXANDER have been -- if to no others would we pipe, nor ask them with us to dance, it is simply that no others have cared to mourn with us in our mourning, nor have any others practiced toward us even the poor charity of a silent indifference.

abstract: The steamship Adriatic arrived at St. John's, N.F., last evening, bringing three days' later advices from Europe. The news of the late campaign in Virginia had reached England, and was exciting much attention. The London Daily News found it impossible to explain the inconsistency of LEE's advance movement upon MEADE, in the face of the fact that ROSECRANS had not been dislodged. It approved of MEADE's course in declining to deliver battle until he reached his selected field. The Times thinks the good fortune of the Union army would be extraordinary if, at length, it should achieve victory on the ill-omened field of Bull Run. The Post warns us that any serious reverse now would leave neutrals no alternative but to recognize the Confederacy. Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER was entertained at a farewell breakfast in Manchester on the 24th, and received several congratulatory addresses on his excellent exposition of the American troubles. The Continental news is interesting. NAPOLEON had received the Mexican delegation, but nothing was said between them respecting MAXIMILIAN. It was thought doubtful that the French Chambers would accede to the guarantees demanded by the Archduke. A French dispatch, dated June last, had been published, guaranteeing Austria against eventualities in case Russia refused to adopt the course suggested by the Allies in reference to Poland. The dispersion of some strong insurgent bands is reported. Arrests of important persons in Warsaw were numerous. In the Schleswig-Holstein question, the arbitration of England had been declined by Austria and Prussia.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Adriatic arrived at St. John's, N.F., last evening, bringing three days' later advices from Europe. The news of the late campaign in Virginia had reached England, and was exciting much attention. The London Daily News found it impossible to explain the inconsistency of LEE's advance movement upon MEADE, in the face of the fact that ROSECRANS had not been dislodged. It approved of MEADE's course in declining to deliver battle until he reached his selected field. The Times thinks the good fortune of the Union army would be extraordinary if, at length, it should achieve victory on the ill-omened field of Bull Run. The Post warns us that any serious reverse now would leave neutrals no alternative but to recognize the Confederacy. Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER was entertained at a farewell breakfast in Manchester on the 24th, and received several congratulatory addresses on his excellent exposition of the American troubles. The Continental news is interesting. NAPOLEON had received the Mexican delegation, but nothing was said between them respecting MAXIMILIAN. It was thought doubtful that the French Chambers would accede to the guarantees demanded by the Archduke. A French dispatch, dated June last, had been published, guaranteeing Austria against eventualities in case Russia refused to adopt the course suggested by the Allies in reference to Poland. The dispersion of some strong insurgent bands is reported. Arrests of important persons in Warsaw were numerous. In the Schleswig-Holstein question, the arbitration of England had been declined by Austria and Prussia.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen met yesterday. The Comptroller reported a balance of $2,774,929 11 in the City Treasury on last Saturday. The Comptroller sent in a communication stating that the appropriation for extending the Croton Waterworks is almost exhausted, and transmitted with it the draft of an ordinance to appropriate $230,000 more for the purpose. These were referred to the Finance Committee. The Board adjourned to 1 o'clock P.M. on Monday. The Board of Councilmen had no quorum at their meeting, and adjourned to Monday at 4 o'clock.

abstract: New-York Orphan Asylum Opened
lead_paragraph: The Asylum for Orphan Jewish Children, recently erected on Seventeenth-street and Third-avenue, was yesterday dedicated, with appropriate ceremonies, to the purpose for which it is intended. The occasion was of more than ordinary interest to the Jewish residents of New-York, and they gathered in great numbers to witness, and by their presence add importance to the act of inauguration. All the wealth and high respectability, all the beauty and the fashion of which the sons and daughters of Israel who have cast their lot in this community possess so largely recognized a share, were represented in immense force, and the number of the general multitude could not be calculeted at less than several thousands. Unlike most affairs of the kind, in which the spectators are chiefly attracted by curiosity, all in this case seemed brought together by feelings of personal pride in the success of the undertaking, and by that strong bond of sympathy which keeps a people of peculiar race and religion specially united in a land of their adoption.
headline: {'main': 'The Hebrew Orphan Asylum.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Hebrew Orphan Asylum.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: All the Confederate agents and emissaries in Europe seem either to be original Abolitionists or to turn Abolitionists soon after they commence their operations there. The Confederate Loan Agent SPENCE argued for the rebel cause through the London Times, mainly because its tendency was toward the emancipation of Southern slaves; such, also, is the line of argument adopted by Monsieur CHEVALIER in France, and by nearly all the leading newspaper organs of the rebellion in both countries. Even Mr. SLIDELL has been accused of coquetting with abolition, and of promising the Emperor that in case the Confederacy secured its independence, it would -- well, it would -- we can't exactly give your Majesty pledges what it would do -- but we can promise you it would make things all right.
lead_paragraph: All the Confederate agents and emissaries in Europe seem either to be original Abolitionists or to turn Abolitionists soon after they commence their operations there. abstract: The Navy Department has purchased of the Neptune Steamship Company in this City, five splendid propellers, all bran new. They have been received at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, and formally turned over to the representatives of the Government there. Orders have been received from Washington to prepare them as rapidly as possible for sea service, and workman are already turning them into gunboats. The following is a list of the vessels Nerius, Proteus, Glaucus and Galetea. We append a description of them, and being all alike, one description answers for all. They are built by J.B. & J.D. VAN DUSEN. They are 200 feet long, 35 feet wide, and 12 1/2 feet deep. The keel is of white oak, sided 14 inches and molded 24 inches, put together in two pieces, each 12 inches in thickness, with 4 inch coags, and thoroughly fastened with galvanized iron bolts. The bottom of the keel is 2 inches thick and fastened with galvanized iron spikes. The stem is of white oak, naturally curved, sided 13 inches and molded 25 inches outside of rabbet. The floors of white oak, double sided, 8 inches, well bolted together, and square worked. They are fastened with yellow metal bolts properly riveted. From the centre of the vessel forward 20 feet and aft 40 feet, the floors are to be filled in solid with yellow pine and cedar, well fitted and caulked on both sides. The frame and top timbers are square worked, and at top height to mold 7 inches, gradually increasing to the size of floor-timbers, and sided the same as the floor. The side and centre keelsons are 14 by 14, put together with lock-scarfs, 7 feet in length and fastened with yellow metal.

abstract: Letter on Military and the Maryland Election
snippet: Letter on Military and the Maryland Election
lead_paragraph: Gov. BRADFORD, of Maryland, wrote a letter to the President, under date of 31st ult., setting forth that rumors were current that detachments of soldiers were to be dispatched to the several counties of Maryland, not for the purpose of voting at the election, nor to suppress riotous proceedings, but to "exert some control or influence in the election." He also said he was informed that certain military orders were about to be issued, placing certain restrictions or qualifications on the right of suffrage. To all this he was opposed, and called upon the President to issue such an order as would prevent it. Mr. LINCOLN sent him the following reply:

abstract: Sufficient returns have been received to make it certain that Maryland has pronounced for the Administration, with a very large vote. Three at least out of the five Union candidates for Congress have been elected, and the Union local officers generally throughout the State. Indeed, in no State of the North, considering the opposition to be overcome, has there been a more decided victory for the Union cause.
lead_paragraph: Sufficient returns have been received to make it certain that Maryland has pronounced for the Administration, with a very large vote. Three at least out of the five Union candidates for Congress have been elected, and the Union local officers generally throughout the State. Indeed, in no State of the North, considering the opposition to be overcome, has there been a more decided victory for the Union cause. This, in itself, is a result of great significance. Thirty months ago, Maryland was prepared, through its representatives in the Legislature, to identify itself with the rebellion by the passage of an ordinance of secession. The fact that its feeling toward the Union has been completely revolutionized since that time, is proof positive of the possibility of a similar change in every disloyal State, and that the only question in the matter is simply a question of time.

abstract: We have received, by telegraph, from Washington, and publish this morning, an official list of the Union officers now confined in the Confederate States military prison at Richmond, with the places and date of their capture. This important document has recently been furnished to our Government by the Confederate authorities. Its publication will not only furnish much information, but will relieve the anxieties of many persons who are now unaware of the fate of friends and relatives who have, at different times, been captured by the rebels.

abstract: -- The vote for Sheriff of Kings County is so close that it is doubtful whether JOHN MCNAMEE, Democrat, or ROBERT W. STEELE, Republican, is elected. The friends of both claim the election by a very small majority. One party figures up STEELE's majority at nine votes, and the other claims that MCNAMEE is elected by between thirty and forty majority. It is generally believed, however, that MCNAMEE is the successful candidate, but nothing certain can be ascertained until after the official canvass. The Board of Canvassers meet next Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: -- The vote for Sheriff of Kings County is so close that it is doubtful whether JOHN MCNAMEE, Democrat, or ROBERT W. STEELE, Republican, is elected. It is generally believed, however, that MCNAMEE is the successful candidate, but nothing certain can be ascertained until after the official canvass. The Board of Canvassers meet next Tuesday.

abstract: Last night, Officer REED, of the Twenty-seventh Precinct was informed that there was a man lying dead at No. 100 Washington-street. He entered the premises, and found a man, named THOMAS BENNETT, lying dead on the floor of his apartment, with his throat cut from ear to ear. It was also ascertained that the deceased had a violent quarrel with his wife during the afternoon, and the wife was arrested on suspicion of having committed the deed. She, however, protested her entire innocence of the death, and seemed to believe that her husband had committed suicide. She was detained to await the result of the Coroner's Inquest.

abstract: The people have pronounced grandly for breaking down the rebellion by war. Now let them see to it that the Government has the means wherewith to do it. Mere voting, without corresponding action, would be hardly less than a mockery. If VALLANDIGHAM and WOODWARD and SEYMOUR had been elected, there might have been some consistency in hesitating to respond to the call of the President for more men. Such results might have been plausibly held out as such a condemnation of the war policy of the Administration, as to make any further increase of the army inexpedient. But the people having sanctioned the policy, are bound to aid in its consummation. The same ardor which they have exhibited at the polls, they should now apply to the raising of volunteers. If this be done, the supply of the three hundred thousand called for by the President will be soon realised, and the breaking down of the rebellion will be an object not simply successfully voted for, but successfully fought for -- not merely an accepted policy, but an accomplished fact.

abstract: Judiciary Election, Hopelessness of; His election
snippet: Judiciary Election, Hopelessness of; His election
lead_paragraph: If MCCUNN had been defeated on Tuesday, owing to the accidental division of the Democratic forces, a large portion of the public would have relapsed into the comfortable conclusion that an elective Judiciary is not so bad after all, and that if the "respectable people would only work," the elevation of an unfit candidate to the Bench could always be rendered impossible. In fact, one of our cotemporaries assured us, only two days ago, that if we have bad Judges, it is chargeable rather to the voters than to the system under which the voters work, and that if those who are most interested in keeping the Bench pure would only go to the polls, all would be well. The reelection of Judge BOSWORTH would have confirmed us in the delusion, and we should have gone on as before, hoping that "something would turn up," and that somehow or other, Providence would take care of our institutions.

abstract: Edward Morrison and Andrew Soher vs. James S. Sturges and Thomas T. Sturges. -- In this case, reported in the TIMES of the 6th, the Court held that inasmuch as the money claimed to have been overpaid by mistake was paid to a clerk of defendants and by him immediately paid out again, and never came into defendants hands, that plaintiffs could not recover against the defendants as principals, but must proceed against the clerk. Complaint dismissed.

abstract: Moffat, John, Inventor of Moffat's Bitters
snippet: Moffat, John, Inventor of Moffat's Bitters
lead_paragraph: JOHN MOFFAT died yesterday at his residence in this City, No. 32 East Seventeenth-street. He was seventy years of age. Mr. MOFFAT was the inventor of "Moffatt's Life Pills" and the "Phoenix Bitters," which became of world-wide popularity, and from the sale of which he accumulated over one and a half million dollars. He retired from business, but about a year since resumed it. Mr. MOFFAT was personally well known, and much respected.

abstract: Last evening -- Tuesday, Nov. 3 -- was an important era in the history of Cleveland. On that evening the closing link in the broad gauge line of the Atlantic and Grent Western Railway was completed; Cleveland and New-York were placed in direct and unbroken communication with each other, and for the first time a train of cars made up on the Long Dock, opposite New-York, came through direct to Cleveland. This, we think, is an event of no ordinary importance.
lead_paragraph: Last evening -- Tuesday, Nov. 3 -- was an important era in the history of Cleveland. This, we think, is an event of no ordinary importance.

abstract: The rapid extent to which the Petroleum trade of the country has increased within a few years past has added materially to our national wealth, and has probably contributed more than any other source to swell our national commerce. American rock-oil is now exported to almost every quarter of the globe. From the first of January until the close of October, 1862, there were 5,195,481 gallons shipped from New-York alone. For the same period this year New-York has exported 15,503,166 gallons; Philadelphia, 4,268,244 gallons; Boston, 1,604,846 gallons; Baltimore, 806,961 gallons. The increase of the New-York trade from over five to over fifteen million gallons in a single year, may be taken as a fair average of the increased shipments of the other ports, and shows how rapidly the traffic is being developed. In round numbers, the total value of the exports from the ports above named, from Jan. 1 until the close of last month, will not fall short of ten millions of dollars; so that hereafter Petroleum is fairly entitled to rank among the staples of the country; and Pennsylvania, which for the past three years has yielded almost two million bbls. annually, according to the best estimates, may claim the largest share of credit for having swelled the commerce in this article to its present dimensions.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- FLOTOW's "Martha," last evening, was excellently rendered by Mr. MARETZEK's company. Miss KELLOGG was in admirable voice, and the remaining artists of the quartette supported her to the best advantage. The house was unusually full and brilliant, attracted partly by the opera and partly by the decorations "used at the Russian Ball." These latter are a curiosity. They should be seen. To-day is the opportunity, at the matinee. The entire opera of "Lucia" will be given, and the second act of "Martha."

abstract: Our Paris correspondent gives some information concerning the rams that are being built in French ports for that great sea-king the Emperor of China, (alias JEFF. DAVIS) and he makes the positive statement, which we doubt not is based upon the best authority, that "the sailing of these ships will be stopped by the French Government." This last statement is directly opposed to the assertions of English journals on the subject; but we usually find that the statements made in the London journals concerning French policy toward this country are utterly unreliable.

abstract: The points and forces of action, at the present moment, are the army of Gen. GRANT, with, its three great columns, under Gens. BURNSIDE, THOMAS and SHERMAN, at Knoxville, Chattanooga and Tuscumbia -- the army of Gen. MEADE, which is still on this side of the Rappahannock, and the minor armies of Gens. GILLMORE and BANKS, the former of which is pounding away at the rebel works in Charleston Harbor, and the other of which is engaged in operations in Western Louisiana, whose nature and object are not very easily comprehended by a mere observer. Viewed as a whole, there is thus much greater simplicity in the operations upon the theatre of war than there has been at previous times, and no one, either here or abroad, need have any difficulty in intelligently of ollowing up the campaigns of the various Generals. If there be action during the month in Virginia, it will most likely be Gen. MEADE who will take the initiative; if there be action in Tennessee, it will most likely be the rebels who will take the initiative. At Charleston, all that the rebels can do is to defend themselves; in Louisiana and Texas, all that the rebels can do is to fall back, and still farther back, as Gen. BANKS advances -- if he advance.

abstract: The United States vs. The Ship Picayune. -This was an information filed to forfeit two-sixteenths of the vessel as being owned by inhabitants of the State of Louisana, under the Act of Congress of July 13, 1861, and the proclamations of the President dated April l5, and August 16, 1861. The vessel was seized under the process. After the return of the process by consent of the District Attorney the two-sixteenths was bonded in the sum of $3,125, its appraised value, by John H. Brooks, the master, with the condition that "claimants have the right to surrender the two-sixteenths in the same condition as when bonded, at any time previous to the forfeiture of the said bond for value."

abstract: The rumors that the peace which has lately reigned supreme over the Army of the Potomac would soon be broken, do not seem yet to have been verified. Our army has not changed its position, and the rebels still hold the river line from Sulphur Springs to Falmouth, with LEE's headquarters at Culpepper. Our cavalry remain at the front, and report that the enemy have the north bank of the Rappahannock strongly guarded, evidently intending to dispute our advance. Guerrillas or robbers infest the woods in the vicinity of our camps, making it hazardous for small parties to move beyond the camp lines.

abstract: Preparations are being made in naval circles for the reception of another fleet of men-of-war, which are reported to have left Cronstadt and Sebastopol on the 18th ult. It is said to consist of four line-of-battle ships, four first-class steam-frigates, and four smaller vessels. A squadron of eight vessels had sailed from Russian ports between the 1st and 14th, which was supposed to be destined for the United States, but as it has not arrived here, persons qualified to judge conjecture that it has gone to the South Atlantic, to winter on the coast of Brazil. Two or three other vessels, it is said, have sailed to the Indian Ocean.

abstract: From the latest returns of the recent election we are inclined to believe that the Union majority will vary very little from 35,500. A revised calculation shows that in the composition of the State Legislature the Unionists will have twothirds of the Senate but not of the House. From present indications the Senate will stand Union 22, Democrats, 10; and the Assembly, Union 82, Democrat's 46.

abstract: Banks Township, Carbon County, Pennsylvania, is a mining region of little note, yet a district lively with work, and embracing within its narrow circuit some of the richest coal orchards in Pennsylvania. Perched on the very highest portion of land in the State, in a cold and desolate ragion, peopled only by Irish, Welsh and German miners, and the few agents and owners of the mines, but little that transpires below ever comes up here.

abstract: A SAFE BLOWN OPEN -- THREE BURGLARS ARRESTED. -- Sergt. GAY, of the Twenty-first Precinct, while patroling Fortieth-street, near Third-avenue, at an early hour yesterday morning, heard a loud noise, as though an explosion had taken place, in the vicinity. Believing that burglars were at work, he at once gave the alarm, rap, and a sufficient number of Policemen were speedily on hand to surround the whole block. Search was made, and the coach manufactory of M. GEORGE FIELDING, situated at No. 132 East Forty-first-street, was found to have been entered by burglars, and a safe on the premises had just been blown open. An examination showed that about $300 in money had been abstracted. Three men, who gave their names as JOHN COOLEY, JAMES SHAY and JAMES MAGEE, were found secreted in an adjoining yard. They were taken into Custody and held for examination. A number of burglars' implements were also found by the Police.

abstract: Wm. H. Stiles et al. vs. Wm. A. Bride et al. -- In this case the plaintiffs are importers of cloths, and the defendants merchant tailors. Defendants bought certain goods from the plaintiffs, to be used in the manufactory of custom clothing. When purchasing the goods they were represented to be first-class goods of fast colors, and on these representations they were taken. After the goods were made up complaints came in from defendants' customers that the goods were shoddy and the colors faded. Defendants had paid for them in part, but refused to pay the remainder, and this suit is brought to recover the remainder. The Court held that the representations as to quality did not constitute a warranty, even though defendants bought such goods without examination trusting to plaintiffs' good faith, and as there was no allegation of fraud on the part of plaintiffs the jury were directed to bring in a verdict for plaintiffs for $1,857 14.
lead_paragraph: Wm. H. Stiles et al. vs. Wm. A. Bride et al. -- In this case the plaintiffs are importers of cloths, and the defendants merchant tailors. Defendants bought certain goods from the plaintiffs, to be used in the manufactory of custom clothing. Defendants had paid for them in part, but refused to pay the remainder, and this suit is brought to recover the remainder. The Court held that the representations as to quality did not constitute a warranty, even though defendants bought such goods without examination trusting to plaintiffs' good faith, and as there was no allegation of fraud on the part of plaintiffs the jury were directed to bring in a verdict for plaintiffs for $1,857 14.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon the City and harbor was visited by one of the severest storms we have had in this locality for several years. About one o'clock a strong wind set in from the west, which in less than an hour increased to a violent gale. So suddenly did the storm come up that many of the craft in the harbor were entirely unprepared to meet it, and in consequence drifted about the Bay in the wildest confusion. Three lighters were dismasted on the North River, and a schooner, while trying to reach the Atlantic Docks, lost all her sails. The ship Atmosphere, bound for Liverpool, was struck by the gale, and although she was being towed by a powerful tug, went on to Coenties' Reef. The vessel was subsequently got off without much damage. A man was capsized in a small boat near Governor's Island, and it is supposed was drowned, as no one was seen to go to his assistance. The Russian steam "clipper," (so ranked in the Russian navy,) Almaz dragged her anchor and came near going on shore at Castle Garden. Fortunately the vessel had steam up, which saved her from disaster.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon the City and harbor was visited by one of the severest storms we have had in this locality for several years. About one o'clock a strong wind set in from the west, which in less than an hour increased to a violent gale. Three lighters were dismasted on the North River, and a schooner, while trying to reach the Atlantic Docks, lost all her sails. The ship Atmosphere, bound for Liverpool, was struck by the gale, and although she was being towed by a powerful tug, went on to Coenties' Reef. The vessel was subsequently got off without much damage. A man was capsized in a small boat near Governor's Island, and it is supposed was drowned, as no one was seen to go to his assistance. The Russian steam "clipper," (so ranked in the Russian navy,) Almaz dragged her anchor and came near going on shore at Castle Garden. Fortunately the vessel had steam up, which saved her from disaster.

abstract: In the beginning of this war, nothing could be heard from Southern trumpeters but songs of the self-sacrificing of the blue blood of the South.
lead_paragraph: In the beginning of this war, nothing could be heard from Southern trumpeters but songs of the self-sacrificing of the blue blood of the South. Of how the kid-gloved exquisite, and the owner of five hundred negroes, had shouldered the musket, and marched side by side with the bone and sinew of the seceded States. It was claimed that they were fearfully in earnest, and were showing it practically by laying down their pink-tinted and musk-scented persons on the altar of their country. Months went by, and gradually, this line of brag faded out. Their Press was filled with advertisements for substitutes, and it was plain that the chivalry were beginning to find out that life in camp, under arrogant officers, was not exactly suited to their constitutions. Very soon after, the very same Press was rampant upon exemptions, declaring that more than half of those who had managed to crawl out from their army were liable for service, and that the laws against, desertion were a dead letter, because the deserters were of the wealthier classes. The Richmond Enquirer was especially severe upon these kid-gloved soldiers who had got enough, declaring that they should be made especial examples of, and hanged, drawn and quartered instantly. In spite of all this, the flower of chivalry continued to withdraw itself, until the rank and, file was left as bare of the aristocratic taint as a French mob in the days of the downfall, of LOUIS XVI., the blue blood having retired quietly to its luxurious home, there to await the coming of the victorious Yankees, and by loyal professions secure its "crop." The example of enlistment was good, as far as it went, and succeeded in deluding into the unholy strife the laboring population of the country; that part which did not go in by its own consent being taken, anyhow, by conscription, but its effect did not last, and very soon the poor dupes saw that they had been sold, cheaply sold, to an oligarchy afraid to trust its precious carcase where it would send them. For over a year this fact has been patent to the rank and file, of the Confederate army, and they feel, now, that instead of fighting side by side with statesmen and millionaires, they are simply a band of poor men battling for the rich, who are sitting at home, preparing for the time when the grand smash shall come, that they may quietly slip out of the back door. This is the true history of that Southern chivalry which has a bit of lively romance, was supposed to throw itself into the breach, and for the sake of liberty, and a divorce from the tyrannical mudsills, break down at a blow, all those distinctions of caste, to uphold which, they had been fighting all their lives a battle they have now shifted on to the shoulders of these poor dupes.

abstract: The new Congress, in place of the one dissolved by President JIMENEZ, was to have opened on the 25th inst. The Belgian charter for the making of a cut road from San Jose, the capital to the head navigable waters of the Serapiqui River, whose waters flow into the Atlantic, having fallen through, the Costa Rican Government contemplate taking the work into its own hands. Now the produce around the capital and in the interior has to be taken to Punta Arenas, on the Pacific, by land 75 miles, thence to Panama, 500 miles by water, then across the railroad to Aspinwall for shipment to Europe and the United States. The distance by the road proposed and by the river to Greytown, on the Atlantic, is about 125 miles. Still, the steam route to Panama will always probably be as quick, and perhaps as cheap as the new route proposed.

abstract: Hon. GEORGE OPDYKE has persistently adhered to his long since publicly expressed determination not to be considered a candidate for reelection for a position which he has filled with so much ability, fidelity and honor. He has courteously but positively refused the solicitations more formally and recently made of him, and will retire, having won the approval and respect of men of all parties for an official course pursued with "but a single eye to the public good." Mr. OPDYKE's career as Mayor has elevated the good name of the City as well as protected and enhanced its best interests. It was thought that Gen. DIX could be prevailed upon to be his successor, but other duties interfere and he declines. The nomination unanimously tendered to ORISON BLUNT. Esq., it is thought will be accepted. Mr. BLUNT is known throughout the City as an active business man, and a hardworking and conscientious public officer. His connection, as President, with the Supervisors' Exemption Committee tested his willingness to labor and his fidelity to serve the public interest, has made him a most enviable repute.

abstract: HUNTING. Extravagant reports of a superabundance of game in the neighboring forests, have succeeded in getting up a furore among amateurs and pot-hunters. Traps and shot-guns, shot, powder and caps, since Monday, have been in demand, the first mentioned article, being wholly confined to the denizens of the suburbs, and first hand speculators in fresh fish and game.
lead_paragraph: HUNTING. -- Extravagant reports of a superabundance of game in the neighboring forests, have succeeded in getting up a furore among amateurs and pot-hunters. Traps and shot-guns, shot, powder and caps, since Monday, have been in demand, the first mentioned article, being wholly confined to the denizens of the suburbs, and first hand speculators in fresh fish and game. The number of amateur sportsmen, old and young, who may be seen every morning, with double-barrel guns and capacious, gamebags swinging over their shoulders, seems unusually, and, for the times, marvelously large. Judging from the condition in which most of them return, and the striking flatness or unnatural stuffedness of their gamebags, it would appear that the game must be either shockingly scarce, or their skill deplorably defective. In the best event, however, hunting with powder and shot is an expensive amusement, as each charge costs about a dollar and a half, to say nothing of the wear and tear of scarce shoe-leather and valuable homespun, in a day's tramp. Where the Government furnishes the ammunition, it is a different thing. Otherwise, economy would resign the whole imperial realm of Nimrod to the knights of the net and trap.

abstract: Speeches of; Perils of the Future
snippet: Speeches of; Perils of the Future
lead_paragraph: The plan of operations which the Copperheads have now fixed upon, seems to be, judging from Gov. SEYMOUR'S recent speeches, and particularly the last one, to avoid all direct opposition to the war, or even to the maintenance of the army, but by dwelling upon the apparent difference in the degree of advantage which various States derive from the Union to assist in that "disintegration of the North," which the Southern Press counts upon as the surest agent in securing peace. The formation of the Union was, as the world knows, rendered possible only by the spread amongst the people of the conviction that all would enjoy greater safety, happiness, and prosperity in it than out of it. This was at that time made comparatively easy by the fact that the country was fresh from an experience of the working of the old Confederation -- a body whose existence was made manifest mainly by the establishment of a debating club at Washington. Everybody then knew by actual experiment that Disunion meant weakness, disorder and degradation, and that standing alone, even the most powerful of all the States was no better, and no more respected, than any petty principality.

abstract: The French frigate Panama, arrived on Friday from Vera Cruz, having on board Gen. FOREY, lately commanding the French invading army in Mexico. The arrival of Marshal FOREY effectually disposes of the reports that have come from Havana, respecting his death of yellow fever. Gen. FOREY, we believe, has not yet come on shore. His stay here will be brief as he intends to reach France with the least possible delay.

abstract: The War in
lead_paragraph: The last Oriental mail brought bad news from New-Zealand to our British relatives. The Anglo-Maorian war has assumed an alarming aspect. The Colonists are now almost reduced to the necessity of fighting for their hearths and altars. The native forces, to the number of over 7,000 warriors, are in the vicinity of Auckland, and a general rising of all the tribes is apprehended. To repel this great danger, every civilian capable of discharging military, duty, whether in garrison or in the field, has been called out. Yet, even including the regular troops, the entire force at the disposal of Gen. CAMERON for active operations against the natives, does not exceed 3,000 men. With this little army, however, that enterprising officer determined to transfer the seat of war from Taranaki to the country of the Waikatos. About the middle of July he accordingly pushed on to the Maungatawhirri Creek, which is esteemed the boundary line between the aboriginal and European territory. Having crossed this creek, he advanced a short distance, and then ordered his troops to throw up redoubts in a commanding position. Hardly had these works been completed, when large bodies of natives were observed hovering around as though they meant to attack them. But seeing the General disposed to anticipate their design, they retired to a line of rifle-pits, which they had dug on the neighboring heights for protection, and there awaited his onset. As the British approached, the Maories saluted them with a heavy fire, which for a moment checked their advance; but, on Gen. CAMERON taking the lead in person, the soldiers rallied, and, carrying the rifle-pits with a rush, they put the enemy to flight, and pursued them to a distance of six miles from the battle-field. In this action the natives lost one hundred men, among whom were seven or eight chiefs of distinction, one of them uncle to the Maori King. The result of the conflict did not, how ever, prove of such importance to the colonists as might be supposed. On the contrary, it gave the Maories a lesson from which they were not slow to profit. Placing no more reliance on rifle-pits, they adopted, a new mode of warfare, for which their forest-crowned hills are admirably fitted, arid which will be more formidable to the Europeans than any other they could devise. The new strategy consists in placing ambuscades in the almost impenetrable brushwood which underlies their forests, and assailing their foes from thence. The efficacy of this system of warfare has been already tried and demonstrated. On the 1st of August Gen. CAMERON, at the head of 700 men, went on a reconnoitering expedition to the village of Paparod, where a large body of natives was said to be collected. After a fatiguing night march, he reached the village, but found it entirely deserted. Then he advanced into the forest in search of the enemy. Nor had he far to proceed. As his soldiers treaded their way through the brushwood, a risk fire was suddenly opened on the leading files by an invisible foe. This was at first returned by the British, but evidently with such little effect that the General, rather than sacrifice his men in a hopeless contest, ultimately ordered a retreat, and had the mortification to see the exulting savages issuing from their lair, and following in the footsteps of his discomfited troops.

abstract: The Corricre Sicitiano of Palermo relates the following anecdote, which may contain a useful hint for our own Provost-Marshals: "An officer in command of a detachment having received information, that a young conscript had concealed himself in a villa, proceeded thither, and stated the object of his visit to the lady of the house, who immediately affirmed that he was mistaken, and produced her two daughters, as the only inmates of the house.
lead_paragraph: -- The Corricre Sicitiano of Palermo relates the following anecdote, which may contain a useful hint for our own Provost-Marshals: "An officer in command of a detachment having received information, that a young conscript had concealed himself in a villa, proceeded thither, and stated the object of his visit to the lady of the house, who immediately affirmed that he was mistaken, and produced her two daughters, as the only inmates of the house. The officer, after a minute search, finding no one else, told the lady that one of her daughters must be the delinquent. The lady protested against this insinuation, but the officer, recollecting the judgment of Solomon, intimated, to the two young ladies that they must both go with him to the barracks. At this announcement, one of the young ladies blushed, and the other -- grew pale, and thereby discovered the trick. The officer at once requested the pale lady to put on clothes of the other sex, and to follow him to his regiment."

abstract: Brig.-Gen. HAYS, the new Assistant Provost-Marshal-General, has entered upon the duties of his post, and is perfecting the arrangements for the combination of the two offices lately held by Col. NUGENT and Col. REEVES, The Provost-Marshal's office will remain at No. 106 Leonard-street, as heretofore, and the disbursing office in Walker-street. Col. NUGENT will continue in his department as an assistant to Gen. HAYS. None of the subordinates of either department have been removed, and probably will not be. Gen. HAYS, in addition to his duties as head of the combined offices above-mentioned, is also to have a general supervision of the recruiting of volunteers for the first ten Congressional Districts, under the late call of the President. The arrangements for recruiting are not yet perfected, but soon will be. It was proposed at first that the General Government should appoint two prominent citizens for each Congressional District to act as general recruiting agents in conjunction with two others to be appointed by the Governor of this State. They were to select proper men as recruiting officers, subject to the confirmation of the Assistant Provost-Marshal-General. Brig.-Gen. HAYS, however, is of the opinion that it will be better to leave the recruiting business open to free competition, and allow anybody to furnish recruits, and receive the premium therefor, which is $25 each for all recruits who have seen service, and $15 for new volunteers. He has written to Washington, proposing this plan, but an answer has not yet been received. It is also proposed that the officers who come on from the Army of the Potomac to obtain conscripts for their regiments, of whom there are about 150 now at Riker's Island, should be allowed to come to the City and recruit for their several regiments, in which case the premiums would be paid to the volunteers instead of to the recruiting officer. The bounties offerred for volunteers are very large and cannot fail to secure an abundance of recruits when the arrangements are perfected and in working order. Each volunteer will be allowed to select his own regiment from among those now in service, which, to many men, will be by no means the least among the many inducements to enlist.

abstract: The funeral of Col. CHARLES RIVERS ELLET, late commandant of the First regiment Mississippi Marine brigade, took place yesterday afternoon, at 3 o'clock, from the residence of Mr. J. WAINWRIGHT, No. 627 Vine-street, and was largely attended by the many personal friends and acquaintances of the deceased, including a number of his comrades in arms. The interment took place in Laurel Hill Cemetery. Col. ELLET was a son of Col. CHARLES ELLET, of this city, well known as a civil engineer of great accomplishments, and who originated the idea of constructing the formidable "rams" used with such effect in the present war. Col. ELLET died suddenly at Bunker Hill, Illinois, of disease contracted while in the service of his country. He was born in this city in 1840, and, but for his untimely decease, would have achieved an enviable reputation in the military world. The brigade commanded by Col. ELLET was engaged in several most important operations along the Mississippi River, among others the ridding of the banks of that stream of many of the guerrilla bands that infested it. During the latter [???] of May, 1863, the forces landed at the town of Austin, thirty-five miles above Helena, and the officers of the brigade were fired upon from the the houses of that place soon after landing. After the disposal of a rebel guerrilla force in the vicinity, Col. ELLET ordered the destruction of the town, which was soon accomplished, and the rebel haunt broken up. During the operations of Gen. GRANT at Vicksburgh, Col. ELLET's command rendered him a great deal of assistance in keeping open his communications. -- Philadelphia Inquirer, Nov. 7.

abstract: DEATH OF A WOMAN FROM SUFFOCATION. RESULT OF THE CORONER'S INQUEST. About eight o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in the three-story brick building, No. 548 Eighth-avenue, occupied on the first floor by Mrs. CAROLINE MEYERS as a millinery and fancy goods store.
lead_paragraph: DEATH OF A WOMAN FROM SUFFOCATION. -- RESULT OF THE CORONER'S INQUEST. -- About eight o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in the three-story brick building, No. 548 Eighth-avenue, occupied on the first floor by Mrs. CAROLINE MEYERS as a millinery and fancy goods store. It originated in the rear room of this store, and spread with great rapidity throughout the entire building. On the third floor an aged lady named Mrs. LEAH LEVI occupied rooms, and so speedily did the flames ascend that she was suffocated and burned to death, notwithstanding the prompt action of the firemen aided by some citizens [???]n the neighborhood. When the fire was subdued her body was found in a position which indicated that she was lying on a lounge at the time she was overtaken by the smoke and flame.

abstract: plan of recruiting; Hoffman, Recorder, Reelection of
snippet: plan of recruiting; Hoffman, Recorder, Reelection of
lead_paragraph: Anything emanating from the Executive of a State that has done so much to crush out this rebellion as Indiana, is always worthy of more than ordinary attention. In this view especially, Gov. MORTON'S late plan, submitted to the War Department, is deserving of notice. The Governor proposes a method for filling up depleted three years regiments in this way: That propositions shall be made to those regiments now in the field, which have been reduced to the lowest numerical standard, or those which are the oldest organizations, calling upon three-fourths of their members to reenlist. Should they do so, the regiment is then to be brought home and furloughed, both officers and men, for such time as the Governors of their respective States see fit, for the purpose of recruiting. This rule to be repeated until each regiment has undergone the furlough, and been recruited, the reenlisted men receiving the $100 bounty, which will then be due, as well as the $402 awarded to veterans.

abstract: The Conductors and Drivers of the various City roads have had a meeting, and most of them have signed a respectful petition to the great City railroad monarchs, requesting that their wages may be raised from $1 50 to $2 per day. They are honest, trusty men; if they were not they would not occupy the positions they do. They work in all weather, in all hours -- fourteen and fifteen hours a day -- for seven days; no holidays, no Sabbath for them, for not ten cents an hour, wages that a Five-point darkey would turn up his nose at. We hope that this petition will be granted; there is no reason why it should not be; if it is refused, we hope the City will tax these roads $500 a car, per annum, until they discover that it is the best policy for rich, money-making corporations to pay their employes at least as large an amount of wages as the poorest day laborer asks and receives. Why, what is $2 per day, in such times as these, when everything is up to almost famine prices? It is nothing at all. Really, we hope that GEORGE LAW and the other men of vast wealth, will not hesitate a moment to inaugurate a more liberal policy to men who earn every cent they will get, even at the wages of $2 per day.

abstract: The Navy Department has just issued a General Order, stating the result of the Naval General Court-Martial, recently assembled at Philadelphia, and which tried Acting Volunteer Lieut. J.W. KITTEREDGE, of the navy, on the charge of "maltreatment of an ordinary seaman, subject to his orders." The specification set forth that on or about the 14th day of June, in the year 1863, on board the U.S. steamer Wamsutta, in Sapello Sound, Acting Volunteer Lieut. J.W. KITTEREDGE, being then in command of the steamer, maltreated GEO. F. HUGHES, an ordinary seaman, subject to his orders, by striking him in the mouth with a loaded revolver and otherwise inflicting illegal punishment upon the said HUGHES," and, on which charge Lieut. KITTEREDGE was found guilty and sentenced by the Court to be dismissed from the naval service. The sentence having been approved, Acting Volunteer Lieut. KITTEREDGE is accordingly dismissed from the service and will hereafter cease to be regarded as an officer of the United States Navy. Secretary WELLES, in promulgating this order, says: "The Department trusts that this example will have the proper effect both on the officers and seamen of the navy, admonishing the one that the law framed for the purpose of protecting seamen from a wanton or tyrannous abuse of authority, shall not be violated with impunity, and giving seamen to understand that while they find their officers held to a strict account for the exercise of authority, they in their turn will be expected to discharge their duty and conform to the requirements of discipline with readiness and cheerfulness."

abstract: The town was excited yesterday afternoon by a rumor of the surrender of Fort Sumter to Gen. GILLMORE. Such an event is, of course, among the earliest probabilities, but in this instance we are inclined to doubt. There is no better foundation for the rumor than a dispatch from Philadelphia announcing the arrival there of the transport Salvor, direct from Hilton Head.
lead_paragraph: The town was excited yesterday afternoon by a rumor of the surrender of Fort Sumter to Gen. GILLMORE. Such an event is, of course, among the earliest probabilities, but in this instance we are inclined to doubt. There is no better foundation for the rumor than a dispatch from Philadelphia announcing the arrival there of the transport Salvor, direct from Hilton Head. The Captain of this vessel says that it was generally believed at Hilton Head on Monday last that Fort Sumter was in our possession and garrisoned by a Pennsylvania regiment. Camp rumors are notoriously not to be depended on, and we can see no reason to make an exception in favor of this from Hilton Head. We are sure that an agreeable fact of such importance as the surrender of Fort Sumter would have been made known officially before this, if it had happened as long since as last Monday. But if any confirmation of our opinion of the incorrectness of the report were needed, we find it in the telegrams of the Richmond papers received at Fortress Monroe. Charleston dispatches as late as Thursday say that the bombardment of Fort Sumter was then furiously progressing.

abstract: Mr. C.S. SHANAHAN, for a long time connected with the New-York Press, and one of the best linguists of this City, will deliver a lecture upon the subject of the French invasion of Mexico, on Tuesday evening, Nov. 10, at Dodworth's Hall, No. 806 Broadway. The lecture is a repetition of one heretofore delivered upon the same subject, and which has attracted the attention of many of our prominent citizens, from the ability with which it was treated. All who desire to become acquainted with a subject of such vital importance to the future of the Mexican as well as the American Republic, should be present. Gens. SICKLES, MEAGHER, GRAHAM and others have accepted an invitation to attend the lecture.

abstract: A special meeting of the Common Council of Jersey City was held Friday, at the Common Council Chamber, to take action in reference to offering a suitable bounty, whereby the quota of 603 men may be raised on the last call within the prescribed time, in order to avoid a draft.
lead_paragraph: A special meeting of the Common Council of Jersey City was held Friday, at the Common Council Chamber, to take action in reference to offering a suitable bounty, whereby the quota of 603 men may be raised on the last call within the prescribed time, in order to avoid a draft. Thirteen of the eighteen members were present, and the President, Alderman CLARKE, occupied the Chair. After the object of the meeting was explained, Alderman COX offered a resolution that the sum of $200 be paid to each volunteer to fill the quota of Jersey City; authorizing the issuing of City Bonds sufficient, and also, that the Mayor and one Alderman from each Ward be appointed to superintend the opening of recruiting offices, &c.

abstract: The intelligence of the advance of the Army of the Potomac, coming as it does with such happy omens and actualities of preliminary success, will thrill the public nerve with pleasurable surprise.
lead_paragraph: The intelligence of the advance of the Army of the Potomac, coming as it does with such happy omens and actualities of preliminary success, will thrill the public nerve with pleasurable surprise. The move itself -- at a time when so much hangs upon our activity in Virginia -- is very gratifying; the captures are large enough to make a brilliant bulletin; and the strategic advantages already gained are very great. The movements of Gen. MEADE have, for some days past, been shrouded in obscurity, but it is obvious, from the line of march he has taken up, and the points at which he has thrown his army upon and across the Rappahannock, that he does not again mean to try the route by Culpepper and the upper Rapidan, the disadvantages of which had become so apparent. The army passed the Rappahannock at the railroad crossing and at Kelly's Ford, the same point at which HOOKER's main force crossed for the Chancellorsville campaign. This indicates a purpose of advance by the Fredericksburgh line. There is no fear, however, that our army will need, this time, to undergo such an ordeal as it has twice gone through in getting possession of its frowning heights, for the position in which Gen. MEADE has planted his army lakes Fredericksburgh in reverse. He will now be able also to obtain his supplies by way of Aquia Creek, a route entirely clear of guerrillas. Gen. MEADE has effected the passage of the Rappahannock in a very handsome manner. Everything now depends on the operations of the next few days. A single march will bring him to the old Chancellorsville battle-ground. The Army of the Potomac has never yet been able to stay more than three or four days south of the Rappahannock. It is fair to expect better luck this time.

abstract: After the elections of last Fall had gone against the Administration, the Copperhead organs in this City, as well as elsewhere, were in the habit of informing the President that if he were a Prime Minister of England he would, with a popular majority against him, be compelled to vacate his seat in favor of somebody who would bring the policy of the Government into complete accordance with the national will, as expressed at the polls. As, however, he was not a Prime Minister in England, and as the Constitution made him sure of his seat for at least four years, no matter what the country might think of his doing, he was requested to do the next best thing to resigning, by giving up his own opinions and adopting those of the Opposition. He was told that it was his duty, therefore, morally, though not legally, to undo all that he had done that was objectionable in Democratic eyes -- to cancel the Emancipation proclamation, to put a stop to the enlistment of negroes, to nullify the Confiscation act, and to appoint Gen. MCCLELLAN General-in-Chief with plenary powers. Failing this, Mr. JAMES BROOKS released the army from service and the public from its allegiance; and the "lecturers" who, in those halcyon days, diffused "political information" from the Democratic headquarters, gave everybody leave to do whatever seemed right in his own eyes.
lead_paragraph: After the elections of last Fall had gone against the Administration, the Copperhead organs in this City, as well as elsewhere, were in the habit of informing the President that if he were a Prime Minister of England he would, with a popular majority against him, be compelled to vacate his seat in favor of somebody who would bring the policy of the Government into complete accordance with the national will, as expressed at the polls. abstract: Mr. MARETZEK announces a new, production this week. It will be brought out on Wednesday, and is the "Judith" of Maestro PERI. The subject is a Biblical one, and has been treated in a masterly manner by the composer, who, although comparatively unknown here, enjoys a good European reputation. To-night, Mme. MEDORI will give her grand impersonation of the priestess in BELLINI's "Norma." It is her best role, and will suffice, undoubtedly, to fill the house. The Russian decorations will, we suppose, be removed. The sooner the better. They were not of a character to add brilliancy to an art establishment.
lead_paragraph: Mr. MARETZEK announces a new, production this week. It will be brought out on Wednesday, and is the "Judith" of Maestro PERI. abstract: The United States transport Fulton, from Charleston Bar, arrived Sunday morning, makes the following report: On the 5th inst., when off Wilmington, at 7 A.M., the look-out at the fore-topmasthead made cut a suspicious steamer, painted entirely white and burning soft coal, three points on the port bow; immediately gave chase, which resulted in her altering her course several times; we following her, and after a short time discovered that she was throwing cargo overboard, which confirmed our first suspicions that she was a blockade-runner. There was also in sight a fore-and-aft[???]rigged gunboat, five points on our port bow. She remained in sight for a short time, when we lost sight of her astern. At 10 A.M. made a sidewheel gunboat on the port beam (afterwards ascertained to be the Keystone State.) About this time we fired three shots at the chase from a twenty-pound Parrott gun, falling short of the mark. At 11 A.M.made a sidewheel gunboat, (afterward ascertained to be the Nansemond,) three points on the port bow, also in pursuit. From this time until 4 P.M. continued in pursuit, gradually widening the, space between us and the gunboats, and bearing the chase, when, after having fired fifteen shots, some of which passed entirely over the object, and others striking quite near, and after leaving our competitors far astern, the prize hove to. At this time the Keystone State was about ten miles astern, and the Nansemond about five miles. When the prize hove to a prize crew, in charge of our first officer and the Purser, was immediately sent on board, and a hawser from our stern attached to the prize -- now ascertained to be the steamer Margaret and Jessie, of Charleston, from Nassau, N.P., for a Confederate port. The gunboat Nansemond arrived alongside the prize about half an hour, and the Keystone State about one hour after our hawser was made fast to the prize. This steamer is a valuable vessel, of about 800 tons burden, and has on board an unusually valuable cargo.

At 10 A.M. made a sidewheel gunboat on the port beam (afterwards ascertained to be the Keystone State.) About this time we fired three shots at the chase from a twenty-pound Parrott gun, falling short of the mark. At this time the Keystone State was about ten miles astern, and the Nansemond about five miles. abstract: JENNIE BROWN and MARIA SICKLES, alias Gentle Annie, bad a dispute in Howard-street at a late hour on Saturday night, which resulted in a fight between the parties. Gentle Annie was so much injured by her antagonist, who kicked her with such violence in the breast and abdomen as to produce severe ruptures. She was taken to the New-York Hospital. She is not expected to recover. JENNIE BROWN was locked up by the Fourteenth-Precinct Police to await the result of the girl's injuries.

abstract: The long-expected advance of the Army of the Potomac to offer battle to Gen. LEE, after delays respecting its supplies, was finally made on Saturday, and with gratifying success.
lead_paragraph: The long-expected advance of the Army of the Potomac to offer battle to Gen. LEE, after delays respecting its supplies, was finally made on Saturday, and with gratifying success. The commands of Maj.-Gens. SEDGWICK and FRENCH, at 2 o'clock on that day, had pressed forward to the banks of the Rappahannock, the first to the railroad crossing, and the other to Kelly's Ford, driving the enemy before them, carrying the redoubts on this side of the river, capturing nearly 2,000 prisoners and a battery of seven guns. The enemy attempted to throw an entire division across the river at Kelly's Ford, but the movement was checked by Gen. FRENCH, who by a well-directed artillery fire shattered the rebel ranks and caused them to retreat in utter confusion. Our men fought splendidly, making most impetuous and gallant charges, and our total loss will not exceed 400 in killed and wounded. At the latest advices our forces were across the Rappahannock.

abstract: - The General Agent of the Emigrant Commissioners at Castle Garden, desires to call the attention of those who may have friends among the emigrants under his charge to the necessity of their calling and leaving their places of address, that those they may be seeking may at once be forwarded to their proper destination. If this is done the liability of emigrants to be swindled or led astray by vagabonds, who constantly infest every locality in the vicinity of Castle Garden may be avoided.

abstract: the Charges Against and his Defence
snippet: the Charges Against and his Defence
lead_paragraph: If Mr. Engineer STIMERS had consulted the interest of his reputation, he would not have published the paper which, under the title of his "Defence," he has given to the public prints. Mr. STIMERS was tried before a Court of Inquiry, on charges preferred against him, by Rear-Admiral DUPONT, of language unbecoming an officer of the Navy. He was acquitted of these charges, and had he had the wit to hold his tongue, he would have come off with flying colors, in the estimation of all who knew nothing whatever about the matter. He has not had the wit to do so.

abstract: (Col. Brewster,) patriotic offer of
lead_paragraph: It will be seen by the accompanying letter, written by Col. WILLIAM R. BREWSTER, commanding the Excelsior Brigade, and addressed to the AdjutantGeneral of the United States Army, that this veteran organization offers to reenlist for three years or the war, on condition of being allowed the privilege to reorganize as mounted infantry. They also, desire to be permitted to return to New-York for a period of sixty days to recruit.

abstract: The Philadelphian tale,  Which excited the country on Saturday, to the effect that Gen. GILLMORE had captured Fort Sumter's ruins, and that the "Stars and Stripes waved over" them, etc., etc., was a little too fast.
lead_paragraph: The Philadelphian tale, which excited the country on Saturday, to the effect that Gen. GILLMORE had captured Fort Sumter's ruins, and that the "Stars and Stripes waved over" them, etc., etc., was a little too fast. The Philadelphians dated our triumph on Monday last; but we publish letters from our special correspondent as late as Wednesday, and we have rebel dispatches from Charleston as late as Thursday -- on which days the active bombardment of Sumter was going on, but the rag of the rebellion still shook its wretched figure over the ruins -- fit type of the desperate tenacity with which the rebels uphold a ruined cause.

abstract: We give in another column an important document, drawn up by the Colonel commanding the Excelsior brigade, of the Army of the Potomac, and at the instance of the officers and men of that brigade.
lead_paragraph: We give in another column an important document, drawn up by the Colonel commanding the Excelsior brigade, of the Army of the Potomac, and at the instance of the officers and men of that brigade. It is the first public indication of a movement which we know has been extensively discussed and approved among the soldiers of all our armies -- a movement to reenlist in companies and regiments "for the war" at the expiration of their present terms of service. The Excelsior brigade represents six regiments -- but its numbers have been so reduced by the casualties of service, that it has now only about 2,500 men, and of these only 1,500 are present for duty. This body of men, by their acting Brigadier-General, desire to remain in the service till the close of the war, and offer to reenlist for an additional term of three years, on the simple conditions that they be allowed to return to this City for sixty days to recruit their thinned ranks, and that, when reorganized, it be as a brigade of mounted infantry. The officers of all the regiments guarantee that their commands will all reenlist, and that by the 5th of January the brigade will return to the army 5,000 strong.

abstract: -- Pursuant to orders issued at Police Headquarters yesterday, the funeral of Policeman VAN BUREN will be attended by several detachments of the force. The services will take place at the church corner of Prince and Thompson streets, at 10 o'clock to-day. A detail of 18 men and a Sergeant from each of the 22 Precincts of this City has been made, and the men thus detailed will act as an escort to the body. The members of the Eighth Precinct will act as a guard of honor. At 9 A.M. the force will assemble in full uniform at Police Headquarters, with belts, batons and white gloves, whence they will proceed to the church. The corpse will be conveyed to New-Jersey for interment, and will be escorted to the ferry by a body of Police.

abstract: Mr. Loring's Pamphlet; on International Law
snippet: Mr. Loring's Pamphlet; on International Law
lead_paragraph: It is a matter of deep regret that so few of our public men and political leaders have made a study of International Law. Several very foolish and inconsistent positions, into which the guides of popular opinion have been betrayed during this war, might have been avoided by a more thorough acquaintance with this science. Nor is there any reason to believe that the mass of educated people on the other side of the ocean have any greater familiarity with it. In the discussions on the Foreign Enlistment act and the rams, Parliament and the Times have shown quite as much of mere popular passion, and quite as much ignorance of the precedents set in their own Courts, as our own excitable Democracy. A few writers and statesmen on either side have examined the questions now at issue in a truly legal and careful manner; and we believe we do not commit an American exaggeration when we say that the more thorough and profound the investigation is, the more clearly do the justice and fairness of our position in regard to the rebel privateers appear. Among the pamphlets which these questions of international law have called out on this side of the ocean, we do not remember to have seen one characterized by greater legal acumen and more thorough investigation than a recent brochure from an eminent lawyer of Boston, Hon. C.G. LORING, entitled "The Neutral Relations of England and the United States." Many of the letters of which the pamphlet is made up appeared in England during the Summer, and the position taken -- till then not recognized by any authority -- that the turreted rains were in their very structure "armed vessels," and, therefore, not permitted to be furnished to a belligerent by a neutral, may have had some influence on the subsequent remarks and action of Earl RUSSELL, who has at length accepted this interpretation of the Enlistment act.

abstract: Yesterday the officers of the Italian line-ofbattle-ship Re Galantuomo, which arrived here a few days ago, paid an official visit to Admiral PAULDING at the Brooklyn Navy-yard. On their arrival they were most cordially received by the Admiral and the officers of the station, who escorted them through such of the departments as they desired to see.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday the officers of the Italian line-ofbattle-ship Re Galantuomo, which arrived here a few days ago, paid an official visit to Admiral PAULDING at the Brooklyn Navy-yard. On their arrival they were most cordially received by the Admiral and the officers of the station, who escorted them through such of the departments as they desired to see. They were shown the new vessels in course of construction, and seemed much impressed with the gigantic proportions of the new fast steam frigate Wampanoag. Having inspected all the objects of interest in the premises, they visited the residence of the Admiral, where they were treated most hospitably. They remained a few hours at the yard, and then left for New-York.

abstract: Last Extremity; Desertion by France
lead_paragraph: Close upon the heels of all the other rebel disappointments comes the announcement that the French Government detains the six iron-clad rams building in its ports for the service of the Confederacy. This is practically an end of the Emperor's flirtation with our rebellion -- a final discarding. All of Mr. SLIDELL's arts with the Emperor and Empress, of which we have heard so much for the last year, have come to just this complexion at last. France, though excelling England in soft words, is found not a whit better in practical action. The same final rebuff comes from both; and there is now no reason whatever why the rage of slighted charms which the Confederacy has just vented upon the one, should not directly be followed by another fit just as cruel toward the other.

abstract: P. Furniss. -- This is an action to recover $9,000 for damages caused by water to plaintiffs' stock, through defects in the buildings occupied by them. Plaintiffs are dealers in furs in this City, and leased from the defendant the stores Nos. 64 and 66 Broadway. Some repairs were to be made on the buildings by the proprietor, and it was especially agreed that the defendant should be responsible for any defects in the roof. Plaintiffs' goods being of a delicate nature, of a class much liable to injury, they were particular about this. Some time in June last plaintiffs' entire stock of goods was most severely damaged during a severe rain storm by water coming in from innumerable leaks in the roof. The defence admit their liability to keep the roof in repair, but allege that the damage, if any, was caused, not by water coming in from the roof, but from water coming from the leads, and caused by the negligence of plaintiffs in not cleaning out the pipes, which plaintiffs were bound, by the terms of the lease, to do. Case still on.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Only a little more than five months ago, R. Dr. STORES, Judge GREENWOOD, Prof. WEET and a few other, met to form the nucleus of this Society. It was felt that the treasures of historic matter, which lay thickly strewn along the cycle of more than a century and a half, of Long Island's history in its original Indian tribes, in its Revolutionary scenes, and in the lives of its many noted and able men.
lead_paragraph: Only a little more than five months ago, R. Dr. STORES, Judge GREENWOOD, Prof. WEET and a few other, met to form the nucleus of this Society. It was felt that the treasures of historic matter, which lay thickly strewn along the cycle of more than a century and a half, of Long Island's history in its original Indian tribes, in its Revolutionary scenes, and in the lives of its many noted and able men, who have passed away, should be gathered and embodied in lasting form while within reach. This begun, the Society could extend its scope into a wider range of inquiry. The sixth regular monthly meeting was held on Thursday evening last, the President, Judge GREENWOOD in the chair. The report of Rev. Dr. STORES, Chairman of the Executive Committee, showed its progress to have exceeded any other in the history of such Societies. It engaged at once the earnest, cordial labors and received the liberal voluntary donations of the best men of all the intelligent classes of the City. It already numbers more than four hundred members. Its library contains 7,269 volumes and pamphlets, 3,000 of these being bound volumes. The library of AUBURY DICKENS, Esq., containing a full sett of Congressional documents for a long period -- about 700 volumes -- being for sale, Mr. S.B. CHITTENDEN had liberally given the $500 asked for them, and the Society would soon place them on its shelves Mr. DICKENS had rare opportunity to make a complete sett, being long Secretary of the Senate, and more than forty years resident at Washington. The Committee had been compelled to lease and add a large suite of rooms in rear of those occupied, which would be ready for the next meeting.

abstract: The Relay of the Potomac does not appear to have done any very heavy fighting since Saturday. Beyond brisk cavalry skirmishes, no engagement is reported. Gen. MEADE has steadily pressed forward his columns, and the bulk of the army is again across the Rappahanneck, in the vicinity of Culperper. Court-house. Out cavalry have reconnected to the banks of the Repidan without meeting the rebels in considerable numbers, and it begins to be generally believed at...
lead_paragraph: The Relay of the Potomac does not appear to have done any very heavy fighting since Saturday. Beyond brisk cavalry skirmishes, no engagement is reported. Gen. MEADE has steadily pressed forward his columns, and the bulk of the army is again across the Rappahanneck, in the vicinity of Culperper. Court-house. Out cavalry have reconnected to the banks of the Repidan without meeting the rebels in considerable numbers, and it begins to be generally believed at Washington that LEE's entire force is in hurried retreat to Richmond, where alone, within the fortifications of the city, the attempt to check our advance will be made. At Fredericksburgh there is no rebel force of importance. The latest telegram from our Washington correspondent informs us that heavy cavalry skirmishing had been going on all the afternoon southwest of Culpepper, in the direction of Madison Court-house, and that the only rebels this side of the Rapidan were STUART's cavalry, who are covering LEE's retreat.

abstract: The recent announcement of the last Concert at Central Park was of itself sufficient indication of Winter's approach; but, despite the glorious weather we have been enjoying, one need only to visit the beautiful grounds to realize that it is close at hand, and that a farewell for a time has indeed been said to the temple of music, the green leaves and sweet flowers. Eager expectation is now turned to the "skating," a sport which is becoming national, and those who enjoy it, and do not buy coal, are anxious that the icy finger should touch the lakes without delay. Last Winter was a succession of disappointments to skaters who relied on the parks, both public and private, and to the proprietors of the latter, their speculations proved pretty serious ones, little if any of the investments being returned to them, and cold water persistently occupying the space devoted to [???]lib ice. Expectations are high that this year Winter will play no such tricks; will early be with us and late remain, holding in freezing grasp the lakes and ponds, affording to all who seek it, and all they seek of it, skating. All the signs indicate no disappointment; bird, beast and fish are making extraordinary preparations to protect themselves from unusual cold, and their instincts seldom fail. Then, again, the presence of the "Rooshans" is suggestive, indeed, prophetic. An American Winter will certainly put itself on its good behavior, "hurry up its cakes" -- of ice -- and so demean itself as to honor our guests and cover itself with snow, ice and glory. Then will the "Rooshans" reciprocate by pirouetting as they only, 'tis said, can pirouette, on her crystal bosom, and astonish young and old America -- teaching the latter, even though they may disdain to learn, both grace and skill. In fine, 'tis thought that the buyers of skates will make safer investments this season than for years past, and what the Commissioners of the Park propose doing is anxiously awaited. That envious stream which thrust itself through the centre of the lake last Winter, must have its inquiring and destructive nose turned in another direction, broken if necessary, for even the few does that skaters might have had, were destroyed by it. If the managers of the Park will do (and we doubt not they will.) as well for the Winter Sports as they have for the Summer enjoyments, the thanks of all who appreciate out-door amusements, and their healthful tendencies, will be theirs.
