abstract: Having been unsuccessful in his efforts to secure a meeting with any of the players on the Pacific coast, WILLIAM GOLDHWAIT, "the Vermont Boy," has signified his intention of returning home immediately, and it is surmised that he has a desire to test his chances for the championship. The next contest for the much coveted emblem of superiority -- the golden cue -- is between its present holder, KAVANAGH, of this City, and PHILIP TIEMAN, of Cincinnati. It takes place on the 11th of February, and will probably be at living Hall, and fifteen hundred points up, caroms. According to the rules of the Congress of Billiard Players, it must be played on a 4-pocket, standard American billiard table made by Messrs. PHELAN & CALLENDER. This 4 pocket table, which has only been introduced for a few months, is rapidly superseding all others, and many gentlemen are ordering them to take the places of the side-pocket ones in their private residences.

abstract: E.M. ARCHIBALD, Esq., who has had charge of the British Consulate for upward of the last 10 years in this City, has sailed for London. There are various surmisings and conjectures afloat respecting this sudden move of Mr. ARCHIBALD, but all of an unsatisfactory character. That he has been summoned home is considered to be a fact. That with his intelligence, liberal views, and just appreciation of the position of our National Government and its affairs, he will enlighten his Government, his character forbids us to doubt. In the absence of Mr. ARCHIBALD, the business of the Consulate will be under the sole control and charge of PIERREPOINT EDWARDS, Esq., who efficiently discharges the duties of British Vice-Consul under Mr. ARCHIBALD.

abstract: LES has very promptly followed up his late campaign from the Rapidan to Bull Run, by an official report of its purpose and progress.
lead_paragraph: -- Gen. LES has very promptly followed up his late campaign from the Rapidan to Bull Run, by an official report of its purpose and progress. In reference to its purpose he declares that the movement was undertaken "with the design of bringing on an engagement with the Federal army." We fancy this theory states the purpose of seeking a battle with rather more determination than it really existed in his mind. It is quite possible that under very favorable circumstances LEE would have been willing to risk a battle; but that he sought it at all hazards, as he would make believe, is not true, and it would have been a piece of audacity of which he is incapable, if with his forty thousand men against a Union force of almost double that strength, he had done so. He was unable to find this favorable opportunity, and along the line of advance he not only did not seek, but he avoided battle. LEE's avowed intention was to gain the fortified heights of Centreville in advance of MEADE. In this he failed, and the failure is thus accounted for:

abstract: -- This is an action to recover $635 55, the balance of an account for a lot of beans sold by De Forest & Palmer to defendant, said balance of account having been assigned to plaintiffs. Defendant claims that the beans were sold under representations that they all conformed on the average to a sample exhibited at the time of the purchase; that they did not conform to the sample. The evidence showed that some of the beans were superior to the sample. These the defendant kept; some of them were inferior to the sample, and these defendant returned and refused to pay for. The Court held that where the sample fairly represented the average, there can be no claim for damages because some of the packages fall below the average.
lead_paragraph: -- This is an action to recover $635 55, the balance of an account for a lot of beans sold by De Forest & Palmer to defendant, said balance of account having been assigned to plaintiffs. Defendant claims that the beans were sold under representations that they all conformed on the average to a sample exhibited at the time of the purchase; that they did not conform to the sample. The evidence showed that some of the beans were superior to the sample. These the defendant kept; some of them were inferior to the sample, and these defendant returned and refused to pay for. The Court held that where the sample fairly represented the average, there can be no claim for damages because some of the packages fall below the average.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen failed of a quorum at their meeting yesterday, and adjourned to Thursday. In the Board of Councilmen a statement was received from the Comptroller of the condition of the City Treasury. The balance on hand on last Saturday was $1,[???]88,958 79. A statement was also received from the Comptroller of the expenditures from the Belief Fund during the fortnight ending on the 1st inst. The amount was $59,380 to 13,643 families, comprising 13,552 adults and 18,312 children. The fund at that date was overdrawn to the amount of $112,976 10, which will be reimbursed from the new half-million loan raised on the No. 7 bonds. Resolutions of respect to the memory of the late messenger to the Board, Mr. JOHN F. CULLIGAN, who died on the 31st ult., were offered by Mr. HAYES, and were unanimously adopted. A communication was received from the Mayor, recommending that a request of Brig.-Gen. HAYES, to remove the Park Barracks from the present location to the Battery, be granted. On motion of Mr. BRICE, it was granted on the part of this Board. After the transaction of some routine business, the Board adjourned to Thursday, at 4 o'clock P.M.

abstract: According to announcement, a meeting was held in the large hail of the Cooper Institute last evening, under the auspices of the National Freedmen's Relief Association, in behalf of the suffering contrabands in the Department of the Mississippi. That speedy and effectual measures might be taken to improve their condtion and prevent future suffering, Gen. GRANT sent Rev. A.S. ...
lead_paragraph: According to announcement, a meeting was held in the large hail of the Cooper Institute last evening, under the auspices of the National Freedmen's Relief Association, in behalf of the suffering contrabands in the Department of the Mississippi. That speedy and effectual measures might be taken to improve their condtion and prevent future suffering, Gen. GRANT sent Rev. A.S. FISKE, Chaplain and Superintendent of Contrabands in his Department, to represent to the people of the North the destitute condition of these people, and to solicit meens to provide for the comfort of the wives and children of the freedmen now in the Army of the United States. The meeting was not only large in point of numbers, but there seemed to be a depth and earnestness of feeling pervading the assembly indicative of sympathy for the sufferers and a willingness to contribute for the alleviation of their distress.

abstract: the Exchange of and Rebel Ill-treatment of them
snippet: the Exchange of and Rebel Ill-treatment of them
lead_paragraph: The accounts which are now coming in every day of the ill-treatment of the Union prisoners at Richmond, confirmed, as they are, by the appearance of the men who are exchanged, are so horrible that the Government outght at once to take measures to bring about a general exchange. Whatever the merits of the controversy between Mr. OULD and Gen. MEREDITH may be, it will hardly be maintained that it is better to let ten or twelve thousand of our soldiers be starved to death than to give way. We believe that the real matter in dispute at present is as to the number of paroles granted on each side, and the difference in the two lists amounts to something like 17,000 -- a very large number, no doubt. Considering the indifference with which the oath of allegiance is regarded by most rebel sympathizers, and the extraordinary unscrupulousness which rebel leaders have at various times displayed in their dealings with the North, it is not at all unlikely that great numbers of their paroled prisoners have gone back to duty before being exchanged. It is very probable that we are egregiously cheated in every one of our exchanges. When people are in such a state of mind that their newspapers applaud such outrages as the sack of Lawrence as a "fair blow at the enemy," and approve of murder in cold blood like that of ELLSWORTH, as a legitimate mode of carrying on war, and finally, as within the last few days, recommend that prisoners of war be put "where the cold weather and scant fare will thin them out in accordance with the laws of nature," it is hardly to be expected that they should be very nice in their regard for such an abstraction as a "parole of honor," when given to a hated enemy.

abstract: The President's Call for Volunteers
lead_paragraph: The question whether the President's call for volunteers shall be met with in the period to which it is limited, depends mainly upon the public spirit of the young men. They are the class from which alone serviceable soldiers can be obtained. "Young men for war" is the accepted maxim in all nations. Their physical vigor and endurance, their elasticity and dash, particularly fit them for the field. The loyal States are very powerful in this class of population. Notwithstanding all the drain that has been made upon them, they still contain over two millions of men between the ages of eighteen and thirty-five. A sixth part of this number, properly armed, drilled and disciplined, and incorporated with our armies already in the field, might sweep off all that remains of this rebellion before next Summer. There never was a more sacred call. Every young man who has a spark of manhood in his breast ought to give heed to it. The country has a right to the service of its stoutest arms without compelling that service; and it is far more honorable to go to the field as a volunteer than as a conscript. Many of the exemptions which the present law of Congress grants, particularly the three hundred dollar commutation, will probably be repealed before the drafting process is again applied; and there will be hereafter comparatively few chances of escaping the consequences of the lot when it is once drawn. The Government is determined to have the personal services of just so many young men as it requires -- voluntarily if it can, compulsorily if it must. It is not so much a question to the young men whether they shall go, as how they shall go -- by choice or by coercion.
headline: {'main': "The President's Call for Volunteers--The Duty of Young Men.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "The President's Call for Volunteers--The Duty of Young Men.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Among the trade movements which have recently taken place, a most important one is that of the machinists, a class of citizens valuable in point of intelligence and good character. Some days since delegations waited on the several employers and requested an advance of 25 per cent. on the wages paid, giving three days for a decision. Only a few shops acceded to the terms, and with the exception of those employed in these, at the end of the time named, the entire trade struck; thus some six thousand men are out of employment, the shops are idle, and contract and other work is lying still. The wages of machinists have been from $1 75 to $2 50 per day, five-sixths, about, getting the former price and one-sixth the latter. The movement is a unanimous and determined one, the machinists claiming that an increase is necessary because of the increased cost of living, and will not be felt by employers because of the increased price they get for work. In some of the Government contracts, it is stated, are provisions securing the contractors against loss in case of a demand such as is now made. The machinists have been the last to resort to a strike: they have never before been so united, and while their movements are characterized by good order and moderation, there is but the one determination, to have the increase. In the West the prices desired here are given, and why, it is asked, should not they be given in this City as well? To be a good machinist, a man must be well informed and intelligent; the very nature of the work requires brains; and any one knowing the trade will see that it is composed of men of more than ordinary intelligence and character. It is to be hoped that with such a class, who act from a conviction of right and justice, employers can meet, discuss the questions fairly and liberally, and that in twenty-four hours the shops will again be filled with willing labor and cunning skill.

abstract: His new campaign
lead_paragraph: The advance of Gen. MEADE, if pushed with the vigor the occasion demands, should disturb the rebel plans for an offensive campaign in East Tennessee. It was the avowed belief of the rebels, in their late advance movement in Virginia, that the destruction of the railroad would so embarrass the Union army that the season available for active operations this Fall would be consumed, and that a small force would serve to cover Richmond permitting heavy detachments to be made from the rebel force in Virginia to reinforce their army in Tennessee. It must be acknowledged that past experience quite authorized them to form this conclusion, for every one of our Virginia campaigns has been followed by a long period of quiescence. But this time they have reckoned without their host. Gen. MEADE, in place of waiting for the completion of the railroad, to enable him to resume his former front of operations on the Culpepper line, has, by a well-planned movement, effected a change of base, (that is a change of secondary base,) and planted his army south of the Rappahannock, thus transferring operation to the Fredericksburgh line, and enabling him to draw his supplies by way of Aquia Creek.
headline: {'main': "Gen. Meade's New Campaign.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Gen. Meade's New Campaign.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Gen. LEE, it is pretty evident, declines to take up the guage of battle which Gen. MEADE has urgently pressed upon his acceptance. The Army of Virginia, excepting its rear guard, have again ensconced themselves within their strong fortifications on the south bank of the Rapidan, or are making swift time toward Richmond.
lead_paragraph: Gen. LEE, it is pretty evident, declines to take up the guage of battle which Gen. MEADE has urgently pressed upon his acceptance. The Army of Virginia, excepting its rear guard, have again ensconced themselves within their strong fortifications on the south bank of the Rapidan, or are making swift time toward Richmond. The Army of the Potomac, therefore, must bear with what grace it may the disappointment of its desire to bring about a decisive engagement. Reports reach Washington, direct from Richmond, that LEE has left the care af the army with which he has been so long identified, to EWELL and HILL, and gone to Chattanooga, with the hope of relieving rebel military affairs there from the distressing state in which BRAGG has placed them, by superseding that General in command. It is also said that the rebel leaders have determined upon abandoning Virginia if MEADE makes an earnest effort to advance to Richmond.

abstract: -The girls employed in the hair-cloth factory, at Sixth-avenue -- FORTNIER, JOHNSON & MCCLOSKEY's -- have struck for an additional five cents per yard, the proprietors having refused that advance. Some three hundred girls were employed in the factory, none of whom can make, it is said, more than $2 50 per week. Many of the girls have parents to support, and this sum is wholly made quote. If any portion of the operatives now demanding increased wages, deserve more than another, the sympathy and countenance of the community, it is the female portion, never at any time properly paid, and their cost of living is now largely increased.

abstract: As regularly as the Municipal election comes round, feeble groans begin to issue from the property-holders of this City touching the increasing weight of taxation, and the growing abuses and corruption of the City Government.
lead_paragraph: As regularly as the Municipal election comes round, feeble groans begin to issue from the property-holders of this City touching the increasing weight of taxation, and the growing abuses and corruption of the City Government. A few of the more impatient write letters to the newspapers, exhorting the rich to attend to their political duties, and vote at the primary meetings and at elections. Occasionally there is an amount of indignation got up sufficient to elect an honest Mayor, or an honest Comptroller, or an honest Street Commissioner; but the character of the legislative body is never changed. The Boards of Aldermen and Common Councilmen remain, in their essential features, precisely the same. There is the same majority of ignorant, unscrupulous and greedy hackmen, grogshop-keepers, contractors and nondescripts; the same feeble and accommodating minority of divers other professions; and the same resolute determination on the part of the whole body to spend money lavishly in spite of everybody. The Mayor's veto is about as effectual in impeding their action as the City Hall clock, and the Comptroller's honesty has about the same influence over their proceedings as the opinions of a private soldier over the policy of his Government. So that, in reality, the annual spasm of our "respectable classes" does little or nothing to lessen the sum of our abuses. As the time is approaching when we shall witness another election, we think it as well to warn people that no radical change can be effected under the present system, no matter how heroically the property-holders may go to the polls. The fault is in the structure of the City Government, and no efforts of the citizens can permanently better our condition as long as it remains unchanged.

abstract: The Board of Supervisors met pursuant to law at noon yesterday, as a Board of Canvassers, to canvass the returns of the late election. Mr. LITTLE, President of the Board, was chosen Chairman. Mr. ROCHE read off the returns from the Fourth Ward. Several votes for John McCunn were allowed to John H. McCunn. The vote for Secretary of State is: St. John, 1,430, and Depew, 190; and for Judge of the Superior Court, McCunn, 1,290; Bosworth, 417. Mr. ROCHE also read the Sixth Ward returns. The vote foots up St. John, 2,237; Depew, 219; and for Superior Court Judge, McCunn, 1,879; Bosworth, 491. The Ninth Ward returns were next read. Several clerical errors, showing carelessness in writing out the returns, were discovered in the Tenth District papers, and those of the Eleventh District could not be found. It was ordered that the District Canvassers in fault should appear before the Board at noon to-day to explain the omissions and discrepencies, and that no Canvassers be paid who have not properly attended to their duties. Until these errors are corrected the vote of the Seventh Ward cannot be given complete. Mr. TWEED read the Thirteenth Ward returns. No return was made of vote for Supervisor from the Fourth District. The Canvassers were directed to appear before the Board to-day. The vote in this Ward footed up for Secretary of State: St. John, 1,673; Depew, 719; for Superior Court Judge, McCunn, 1,280; Bosworth, 1,065. The Board adjourned till noon to-day.

abstract: Farewell Breakfast at Manchester
lead_paragraph: On Saturday morning the Union and Emancipation Society entertained Rev. H.W. BEECHER at breakfast at the Albion Hotel, Manchester. The company included a large number of gentlemen of the neighborhood and from a distance. The Mayor of Rochdale took the chair, and there were present among others, Professor F.W. Newman, Mr. J.C. Dyer, Mr. Horton, (Dublin,) Rev. Dr. Massie, Mr. F. Taylor, Rev. T.G. Lee, Mr. Ernest Jones, Rev. Dr. Parker, &c. Letters of apology for absence had been received from Mr. Bright, M.P., Mr. W.E. Forster, M.P., Mr. P.A. Taylor, M.P., Mr. T. Barnes, M.P., Mr. Coningham, M.P., Mr. C. Robertson, (Liverpool,) Mr. Duncan McLaren, Professor Newth and Professor H.D. Rogers.
headline: {'main': "BEECHER'S FAREWELL TO ENGLAND.; Breakfast Speech at Manchester. Discussion of the American Question. It is selected expressly for the debut of Mme. VERA LORINI, a prima donna of unquestionable reputation in Italy. Leonore -- the role of the heroine -- is said to be one of the best in the lady's repertoire. abstract: The Board of Supervisors met at 2 o'clock P.M. yesterday. A resolution was adopted asking the Corporation Counsel to report a detailed statement of all suits pending against the County relative to taxes. Another resolution was adopted asking his opinion as to the right of the Board to remit taxes after the expiration of six months from the time they were levied, in cases where application for remission had been made prior to the expiration of the six months. A third resolution was adopted requesting the Committee on Annual Taxes to ascertain what amount was expended by the Union Defence Committee in 1861, to fit out regiments and send them to the field, with the view of asking Congress to reimburse the City for such outlays, in order to save the County from taxation in 1864 to pay the bonds upon which the money was raised. The Special Committee to recruit men for the army, under the new $2,000,000 ordinance, reported the result of the mission of a sub-Committee, consisting of Messrs. BLUNT and TWEED, who were sent to Washington last week. They went on there to ascertain if the Government would credit the men the Committee may raise on the quota claimed from the County. The Secretary of War received them graciously, and through Provost-Marshal-Gen. FRY, he conceded the guarantee desired by the Committee, that the recruits shall be credited to the County and to the Congressional Districts in which they resided at the time of their enlistment. The Committee express confidence in their ability to raise the full quota of the City by voluntary enlistment. The Board of Education sent in their estimate of expenses for 1864. The total amount is $1,789,000, of which $1,100,000 are for teachers' and janitors' salaries, and for the support of the Free Academy. The Board adjourned to Tuesday next at 3 o'clock P.M.

abstract: The annual meeting of the Firemen's Ball Committee was held on Monday evening, 9th inst., at Kilduff's, No. 1,160 Broadway. The following officers were unanimously elected for the ensuing year, President, C. GODFREY GUNTHER; Secretary, JAMES F. WENMAN; Treasurer, A.J. DELATOUR. A Committee of three, consisting of Messrs. J.L. MILLER, JOHN GARCIA and ROBERT MCGINNIS, was appointed to select a suitable place to hold the annual ball, and to make other necessary arrangements.

abstract: A Stockholm journal reports a recent speech of the King of Denmark, in which he declared his readiness, in case of his States being overpowered by Germany, to start a Republic, to consist of the Danish Isles. The King said: "I will descend from the throne to proclaim the Republic. I am convinced that no people in Europe is more fitted for the Republican sceptre than my dear Danish people."

abstract: -- It is stated by rebel journals that JEFF. DAVIS has ordered Gen. HARDEE from Demopolis, Ala., to Chickamauga, and has ordered Gen. POLK in his place. Gen. POLK, it will be recollected, is under charges preferred against him by Gen. BRAGG for disobedience of orders at the last battle-field, and the personal relations of the two officers are, in consequence, not the most agreeable. For this, it is supposed, that JEFF. DAVIS, intending to retain Gen. BRAGG in command, has removed Gen. POLK. At Demopolis he will be in the Department of Gen. JOSEPH E. JOHNSTON.
lead_paragraph: -- It is stated by rebel journals that JEFF. DAVIS has ordered Gen. HARDEE from Demopolis, Ala., to Chickamauga, and has ordered Gen. POLK in his place. Gen. abstract: The United States transport Fairhaven, which arrived at this port yesterday morning, five days from Port Royal, reports that on the 9th inst., about 6 o'clock A.M., when 20 miles E.N.E. from Barnegat, she came in collision with the pilot-boat Mary Taylor, No. 5, sinking her on her port bow, causing her to sink in a few moments in about 20 fathoms of water. Two pilots on board of the Mary Taylor and the crew, six in all, were picked up and taken on board the steamer. Before the pilot-boat went down most of the effects were saved. This is the third accident of the kind that has happened within the last 20 days. Our pilot-boats seem to be peculiarly unlucky this season.

This is the third accident of the kind that has happened within the last 20 days. Our pilot-boats seem to be peculiarly unlucky this season.

abstract: We understand that Gov. SEYMOUR has tendered to JOHN H. ANTHON, Esq., the appointment of City Judge, to fill the unexpired term (one year from the first of January next) of Judge MCCUNN, who has just been elected to the Superior Court Bench. Mr. ANTHON is a son of the late JOHN ANTHON, L.L.D., and was Assistant District-Attorney under the administration of Mr. WATERBURY. While acting as prosecuting officer he displayed the highest talents as an advocate, and a knowledge of law unsurpassed by any member of the New-York bar, young or old. In every respect the appointment is one eminently "fit to be made," and our highest Criminal Court can now boast of having two of the best Judges to be found on the Bench of this or any other State.

abstract: PRISONERS DISPOSED OF.  The captured rank and file temporarily crammed into the Old Capitol Pilson were sent yesterday to Point Lookout. Fifty-eitht more prisoners were brought up to-day. All these prisoners will soon be transmitted to Johnson's Island, off Sandusky, Lake Erie. This would indicate that the resumption of exchanges is as far off as ever.

abstract: The County Canvassers met at noon yesterday. The Eleventh District returns of the Ninth Ward, missing on the previous day, were presented from the County Clerk's office, where they had been overlooked, and hence the District Canvassers were acquitted of fault in the matter. Mr. STEWART read the returns from the Sixteenth Ward, which is a portion of the Sixth Senatorial District, where the question of the election of the State Senator is in doubt, and both the Republican and Democratic candidates claim it. It has generally been conceded to the Republican nominee. Mr. LAIMBEER, whose friends foot up a majority of about one hundred for him, while the friends of the Democratic nominee. Mr. KING, claim his election by a majority of sixty or so. Both of the candidates were on hand to witness the canvass. In their case the canvass of the votes in this Ward showed a majority of 14 for Mr. LAIMBEER. The vote for the State and County officers was about the same as heretofore published.

abstract: Clarina Turner vs. Prosper Shucking and Wilhemina Shucking. -- This is an action claiming $250 damages for an assault and battery. The plaintiff is a dressmaker doing business in Spring-street. Defendant went to the residence of plaintiff to collect a bill for work and labor. Plaintiff, it is alleged, refused to pay the bill, and struck defendant in the face. Whereupon, according to the evidence of plaintiff, defendant said she would give her "one of the _____ lickings she ever had." On the part of the defendant, the testimony showed that plaintiff struck the defendant first -- tried to choke her -- kicked her, and abused her generally, and all that was done on the part of defendant was in self-defense. The evidence showed that there was a pretty equal amount of Kicks, bites and scratches on each side. The witnesses were all women and their manner of delivering their testimony excited some laughter.

abstract: Huntingdon, Daniel; Picture, "Mercy's Dream"
lead_paragraph: The place of honor at GOUPIL's pleasant hive of art -- where Mr. KNOEDLER presides with a frank heartiness and a genial diligence that are irresistible -- has been once more surrendered to a native artist. In this instance it is the worthy President of the National Academy of Design, Mr. DANIEL HUNTINGDON, who occupies it. A famous picture of his, called "Mercy's Dream," has returned to the land of its inception, and challenges anew the admiration which it obtained in a cruder form, more than twenty years ago. The present painting is the ripe realization of an early fancy. So far back as 1841, Mr. HUNTINGDON had given ideal shape to JOHN BUNYAN's dream of Mercy and the Angel. There was a certain completeness about the picture even then, which pleased the public, and it was suggested that it should be engraved. Mr. HUNTINGDON, with a keener eye to the defects of his handiwork than to its beauties, determined to repaint the work before submitting it to the burin of the engraver. Seventeen years later this determination was carried out. It is the "Mercy's Dream" of 1858 that we now have an opportunity of seeing. The work, we may add, has been engraved, and the disposition of the engravings has been intrusted to Mr. JOHN MCCLURE, who is also the grand chamberlain of the picture, and performs all the essential courtesies between it and the public.

abstract: Patrick O'Meara vs. The Mayor, &c., of the City of New-York. -- This is an action brought to recover $5,000 damages for personal injuries. The facts of the case are that on the 21st day of January, 1863, while standing on the sidewalk in Parkrow, in the City of New-York, plaintiff was knocked down and run over by steam fire engine No. 42, and seriously and permanently injured. Said engine was being run by the parties in charge upon the sidewalk, in violation of the City ordinance. The claim for damages was duly presented to the Comptroller, but he has neglected to make any adjustment or settlement of said claim. The defendants admit the ownership of the engine in question, but deny that the persons in charge of and running said engine were their servants or agents, or that the engine at the time of the accident was in their possession, or under their control and they set up as a further defence that having by a City ordinance expressly forbidden the running of fire-engines upon the sidewalk, and by that ordinance they are absolved from all liability for accidents caused by its violation, and that they have discharged their entire duties in the premises. The Court held, that the City was liable, and directed the jury to bring in a verdict assessing the damages. Verdict for plaintiff, $750.

abstract: On Wednesday morning, at an early hour, a number of well-known Fourth Ward politicians met at a porter-house known as the "Nicoll Shades," situated at No. 48 Madison-street. After drinking and discussing politics awhile, a fight with pistols was commenced, during which a young man named JOHN CUSICK was shot dead -- the ball passing through the region of the heart. Two men, named JAMES WHITE and THOMAS BROWN, were immediately arrested by the Fourth Ward Police, on the charge of having committed the murder. An inquest was held on the body of CUSICK last evening, which resulted in fixing the charge of murder on WHITE. BROWN is held as an accessary. The affair has created much excitement throughout that neighborhood.

abstract: No steps have yet been taken by the Committee of the Board of Supervisors to carry out the plan proposed for filling up the quota of the County with volunteers. His Honor, Mayor OPDYKE, was at Washington yesterday and the Committee await his return, when they will at once commence their duties. Some $400,000 of the exemption fund remains on hand, and the balance required there is every assurance will be readily procured. Quite an enthusiasm in regard to volunteering is again arising, and there is a proposition for a mass meeting at Cooper Institute on the subject. The Committee are entering into the matter with zeal, and there is no doubt that they will so popularize the movement as to meet with success. Individual exertions of citizens will do much to aid them, and these are in many quarters already being made. Everything, at present, looks well for the quota.

abstract: William Picken vs. The Board of Education. -- The plaintiff was a builder occupying the premises in the rear of Ward School No. 18, on Fifty-first-street, and brought this action to recover damages for injury from water flowing into their premises from the sinks of the school. The complaint, on motion, was dismissed on the ground that the use and control of Public Schools vested in the Local Boards of the Wards. That the injury in question resulted from the use of the premises, and not from defects in the building, and that the Local Boards were alone responsible, being vested by law with the control of the School buildings.
lead_paragraph: William Picken vs. The Board of Education. -- The plaintiff was a builder occupying the premises in the rear of Ward School No. 18, on Fifty-first-street, and brought this action to recover damages for injury from water flowing into their premises from the sinks of the school. The complaint, on motion, was dismissed on the ground that the use and control of Public Schools vested in the Local Boards of the Wards. That the injury in question resulted from the use of the premises, and not from defects in the building, and that the Local Boards were alone responsible, being vested by law with the control of the School buildings.

abstract: Campaigning in the Southwest
lead_paragraph: Gen. GRANT's victory at Fort DONELSON carried his army to the southern limit of the State of Tennessee; his battle at Shiloh carried his army to Vicksburgh; his triumph at Vicksburgh opened the Mississippi River, and ended the war in its Valley. We believe that his next campaign, in his new field of operations, will put a period to the war in its grand features in the entire Southwest; and that it will do even more than this. Each of the previous campaigns has covered a gigantic space, and the next campaign bears upon a region equally vast with any of the past.

abstract: VISIT OF MONTREAL OFFICIALS. -- Yesterday morning, Alderman BULMER, City Attorney ROUER ROY, and CHARLES GLACKMEYER, City Clerk of Montreal, made a visit to the City Hall for the purpose of calling on the Mayor. His Honor being out of town, they were received by WM.H. ARMSTRONG, Esq., Private Secretary. They reached here yesterday, and come with the view of obtaining information in regard to our system of opening streets, and the laying out and improving the public thoroughfares and the laws relating thereto. The delegation were furnished with all the required information, and supplied with documents, State and Municipal, relating to the matter. It is their intention to visit Philadelphia and other large cities, for the purpose of comparing the different systems and adopting for Montreal the one they deem the best.
lead_paragraph: VISIT OF MONTREAL OFFICIALS. -- Yesterday morning, Alderman BULMER, City Attorney ROUER ROY, and CHARLES GLACKMEYER, City Clerk of Montreal, made a visit to the City Hall for the purpose of calling on the Mayor. abstract: FROM FREDERICKSBURGH TO BROOKLYN. -- A German lady, named BARBARA REINHARDT, called at the Forty-first Precinct Station-house, in Washington-street, yesterday afternoon, after a fatiguing journey to Jamaica, L.I., and back. She applied for lodgings. Her venerable and respectable appearance attracted the attention of the Sergeant in charge, and, in answer to a few questions, she stated that she had resided in Fredericksburgh, Va., for some years, but recently had found it necessary to leave, in consequence of the lack of business and the general impoverished condition of that neighborhood. She had eight sons, all of whom had enlisted in the Union armies, and being left alone, and without means, she finally concluded to make a journey northward in search of a surviving sister, the wife of Mr. GEORGE BRAUN, whom she learned kept a grocery-store in the City of Brooklyn. She set out from Fredericksburgh on foot, with a few dollars of Confederate money, which was useless after she left Virginia. She walked the entire distance and arrived here after a journey of thirty days. She inquired for BRAUN but could gain no information, when she understood that a man by that name lived in Jamaica, 12 miles from the city, and walked out. She inquired of every one she met but, to her great disappointment, could ascertain nothing concerning him. She was a witness of the "great battle," as she terms it, and a severe sufferer thereby, her husband having been killed by the explosion of a shell, which entered the room in which he was sitting. She formerly resided at the North. Her sons all lived in the Free States. Two enlisted in New-York regiments, two in New-Jersey regiments, and the others in regiments of other States. She also has three daughters, who live in the West, two of whom are married. The old lady has passed the sixty-sixth year of her age, and is still hale, hearty and strong. Any information of Mr. GEORGE BRAUN will be thankfully received by her at the Station-house, where she will remain for the present.

She set out from Fredericksburgh on foot, with a few dollars of Confederate money, which was useless after she left Virginia. She walked the entire distance and arrived here after a journey of thirty days. She inquired for BRAUN but could gain no information, when she understood that a man by that name lived in Jamaica, 12 miles from the city, and walked out. She inquired of every one she met but, to her great disappointment, could ascertain nothing concerning him. She was a witness of the "great battle," as she terms it, and a severe sufferer thereby, her husband having been killed by the explosion of a shell, which entered the room in which he was sitting. She formerly resided at the North. Her sons all lived in the Free States. Two enlisted in New-York regiments, two in New-Jersey regiments, and the others in regiments of other States. She also has three daughters, who live in the West, two of whom are married. The old lady has passed the sixty-sixth year of her age, and is still hale, hearty and strong. abstract: Cowdry vs. Carpenter; Order of Alienation of Property
snippet: Cowdry vs. Carpenter; Order of Alienation of Property
lead_paragraph: Nathaniel A. Cowdrey vs. Jacob Carpenter. -- On the 5th of August, 1860, the defendant sold the plaintiff a bond and mortgage of $2,000, giving him an agreement as follows: First, that he had sold to the plaintiff a certain mortgage bond for $2,000, having five years to run; that he was the owner of said bond and had a good right to sell it, and that Cowdrey acquired a good and valid title; that there were no other incumbrances or liens upon the property on which said mortgage was given, except a mortgage for $5,000, made by one Bonney to one Roe, and which embraced the adjoining property, known as the Clarendon Hotel and Garden, outhouses and other buildings, except unpoid taxes; that the order of sale under the foreclosure proceedings on said five thousand dollar mortgage shall require the other property not covered by the two thousand dollar mortgage to be first sold, and the proceeds applied to the satisfaction of said five thousand dollar mortgage; and that if this last was not done, then he was to pay said Cowdrey as liquidated damages the sum of two thousand dollars, with interest and costs, immediately after any sale was made, that the purchase was made by the plaintiff upon the truth of the statements as made.

abstract: It was reported in naval circles, yesterday, in this City, that a temporary suspension of the iron-clad vessels-of-war now building for the Government is likely to take place. It is said that all the contractors are determined to ask the interference of the Government in preventing the disasters which the strikes are likely to occasion them, by either increasing the amount of contract money to be paid for the vessels when finished, or by regulating by law the wages to be paid to mechanics. According to the contractors' story, a whole fleet of iron-clad vessels, which are not as vet completed, were contracted for over a year and and a half age, when wages and materials were 50 per cent. cheaper than they are now. They allege that the Government did not furnish the plane as rapidly as it promised to do, and also that it made alterations in the vessels which rendered it impossible to complete them in the time originally laid out for the work. They are, therefore, of opinion that the Navy Department should assist them in the present crisis. The workmen, on the other hand, assert that the employers are making a hundred per cent. on the capital sank in building the vessels, and that they do not give five for wages. They also assert that the employers have never voluntarily raised their wages, always leaving it to the last moment, when strikes made it necessary for them to have work done. They say that they do more work for the contractors in a day than the employes of the Navy-yards do for the Government in two days, and that they ought to be paid in proportion to their work. A meeting of iron-clad workers will be held in a few days in this City, and the result of the conclusions arrived at by them will be the basis of future action on their part. Some strikers on the Jersey City vessels went to work yesterday, but the mass of them held out. There are now about forty iron-clad vessels-of-war in course of construction, and the suspension of work on them would seriously embarrass the Government at a time when it needs armored vessels-of-war. Of the forty named, thirteen should be now ready to receive their crews, but cannot be so for some months, and the "strikes," of course, will put them much further back.

abstract: Brig.-Gen. CANBY, who since about the middle of July, has been in command of the United States troops in the City and Harbor of New-York, has been relieved, and ordered to Washington. Gen. CANBY succeeded Gen. BROWN here, and during command has made many warm personal friends, and won the confidence and respect of the community. He retires, carrying with him the kindliest feelings and the best wishes that can attend an accomplished gentleman and a gallant officer.

abstract: That the entire rebel infantry force crossed the Rapidan on Sunday last, leaving only reconnoitering bands of STUART's cavalry on this side to cover the front, seems now to be positively ascertained. The recrossing was less tardy than it might have been in consequence of the dashing movements of KILPATRICK's cavalry, who made waspish attacks upon the rebel rear guard at Stevensburgh, and drove it into its intrenchments across the Rapidan. The enemy's force is represented by citizens of Stevensburgh to have been twice the number of KILPATRICK's, and the retreat was disgraceful. The main body of the rebel army is now said to be encamped at Gordonsville, and there are abundant evidences of its intention to make Winter quarters between the Rappahannock and the Rapidan. The road to Stevensburgh on both sides is bordered by carefully-constructed huts in number sufficient to accommodate 50,000 men. Our cavalry are south of the Rapidan in force, reconnoitering the enemy's position, and from their best information, LEE's army, exclusive of cavalry, does not exceed 30,000 men. Gen. MEADE has issued an order congratulating the army upon the recent successful passage of the Rappahannock.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- Maestro PERI's opera of "Judith" -- produced here last evening by Mr. MARETZEK -- was a complete success. It has points of broad excellence that are calculated to please the multitude, and smaller ones which will satisfy the more exigeant taste of the profession. One of its greatest recommendations is that it introduces all the admirable artists of Mr. MARETZEK's troupe. There are opportunities for Mme. MEDORI, for Mlle. SULZER, for Signor MAZZOLENI, for Signor BELLINI, and for Signer BIACHI -- a quintette which can hardly be excelled -- which they used to the best advantage. To this circumstance, and the excellence of the music and mise en scene, may be ascribed the very complete success of the work. It will be repeated, we presume, on an early day, and we shall then take the opportunity of dwelling more fully on its merits.

abstract: Organization of Freedmen's Labor
lead_paragraph: The meeting held on Monday evening, under the auspices of the "Freedmen's Relief Association," must have at least convinced the public of one thing -- the pressing need of organization in regard to the freed blacks. The principal speaker of the evening, coming directly with authority from Gen. GRANT, stated that thousands and thousands of slave-women and children, together with infirm old men, were scattered about on the banks of the Mississippi, in rough camps, under no supervision, suffering from sickness, exposure and often hunger, and dying away in startling numbers. Their camps or settlements had no sanitary police; they were unprovided with proper clothing or medical attendance; they depended for food on the charity of the army officers, and no machinery for providing them with regular work had been contrived. Among all the dreadful scenes which have accompanied this war, probably none have exceeded in pathos and suffering some of those displayed in the "freedmen's camps," on the banks of the Mississippi.

abstract: The special dispatches from Cincinnati give an account of a singular story about two suspicious vessels discovered yesterday hovering about Sandusky Bay, supposed to be privateers fitted up by Secessionists in Canada, aided by their sympathizers there and in the United States. abstract: Brig.-Gen. GEO. J. STANNARD, who was announced in yesterday's TIMES as having been appointed to succeed Gen. CANBY in command of the United States troops in the City and Harbor of New-York, will enter upon his duties to-day. Gen. CANBY, who only received a temporary appointment to this post during the emergency arising out of the riots, returns to Washington, where he will resume his duties as military adviser in the War Department. During his brief administration in this Department, he has won hosts of friends, and he returns to Washington with the best wishes of every one with whom he has come in contact. His successor, Gen. STANNARD, is a native of Vermont, and about 40 years of age. At the first battle of Bull Run, he was Lieut.-Colonel of the Second regiment Vermont Volunteers, and has served in the Army of the Potomac from that time until the battle of Gettysburgh, where he was wounded in the leg. He received his commission as Brigadier-General of Volunteers on the 11th of March last, and commanded the Vermont brigade at Gettysburgh. He is favorably noticed in the report of Gen. MEADE, printed in yesterday's TIMES. Since his recovery from his wound he has been on duty at Fort Richmond. Maj. CHRISTENSEN and the other officers who served under Gen. CANBY in this Department will continue at their posts, and will be assisted by Lieut. HOOKER, the only member of Gen. STANNARD's Staff now remaining with him.
lead_paragraph: Brig.-Gen. GEO. J. STANNARD, who was announced in yesterday's TIMES as having been appointed to succeed Gen. CANBY in command of the United States troops in the City and Harbor of New-York, will enter upon his duties to-day. Gen. CANBY, who only received a temporary appointment to this post during the emergency arising out of the riots, returns to Washington, where he will resume his duties as military adviser in the War Department. During his brief administration in this Department, he has won hosts of friends, and he returns to Washington with the best wishes of every one with whom he has come in contact. His successor, Gen. STANNARD, is a native of Vermont, and about 40 years of age. At the first battle of Bull Run, he was Lieut.-Colonel of the Second regiment Vermont Volunteers, and has served in the Army of the Potomac from that time until the battle of Gettysburgh, where he was wounded in the leg. He received his commission as Brigadier-General of Volunteers on the 11th of March last, and commanded the Vermont brigade at Gettysburgh. He is favorably noticed in the report of Gen. MEADE, printed in yesterday's TIMES. Since his recovery from his wound he has been on duty at Fort Richmond. Maj. CHRISTENSEN and the other officers who served under Gen. CANBY in this Department will continue at their posts, and will be assisted by Lieut. HOOKER, the only member of Gen. STANNARD's Staff now remaining with him.

abstract: At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday, a resolution by Mr. HENRY was adopted, requesting the Ferry Committee to report what measures should be taken to compel the proprietors of the Hoboken Ferry, running from the foot of Hoboken-street, to run a better class of boats than they now use and at more regular times than they are now run. On resolution by Mr. MASTERSON, the Street Commissioner was requested to report why the streets are not always properly gas-lighted at night. Brig.-Gen. HAYES' request to be allowed to remove the Park Barracks from their present location to the Battery, which was granted by the Councilmen on the recommendation of Mayor OPDYKE, came up; Mr. FOX wished to postpone the subject indefinitely, which the Board refused by 9 to 6 to do, and then laid over the papers. The Superintendent of Unsafe Buildings was directed to require the walls of the Colored Orphan Asylum, burned out by the rioters, to be taken down by the owners, if they will consent to do it, and if they will not, then by his direction, as they are believed to be in a condition of danger and liable to fall at any time. In compliance with the Comptroller's request, the Board voted to transer from the account of "Interest on Revenue Bonds," the sum of $75,051 79, to distribute it as follows: To acconnt of "Police Station-houses," $5,000; to "Interest on Union Defence Fund Bonds," $51 79; to "Advertising for the Common Council," $20,000; and to "Cleaning Streets," $50,000. They also voted to transfer $8,000 from the account of "Interest on Revenue Bonds" to "Printing for the Common Council." Adjourned to Monday next.

abstract: Decision Against the Conscription Act; Decision against the Conscription Act; Pennsylvania Decisions Against the Conscription Act
snippet: Decision Against the Conscription Act; Decision against the Conscription Act; Pennsylvania Decisions Against the Conscription Act
lead_paragraph: A majority of the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania -- Chief Justice LOWRIE and Justices WOODWARD and THOMPSON, against Justices STRONG and READ -- have decided that the National Enrollment bill is contrary to the Constitution, and have granted injunctions to restrain the Provost-Marshals from proceeding with the draft. If this decision of the highest tribunal of the State is carried out, there must be either a conflict between Pennsylvania and the Federal Government, or the latter must cease to obtain any soldiers from that State, except those who may choose to volunteer. In other words, the majority of the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania has determined, so far as they are concerned, that there shall be either civil war at the North, or a relinquishment of the war against the rebellion.
headline: {'main': 'The Pennsylvania Decision Against the Conscription Act.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Pennsylvania Decision Against the Conscription Act.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: To the Editor of the New-York Times:  Within the last week I have seen several articles, both in the NEW-YORK TIMES and the Baltimore American, in regard to our paroled prisoners returned from Richmond. These accounts seemed horrible enough to have aroused the sympathy and indignation of the people, and yet, with the exception of a few persons, they were either passed by or forgotten as being among the inevitable horrors of civil war.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE, Friday, Nov. 6, 1863.

abstract: Brig.-Gen. HAYES, the new Assistant Provost-Marshal-General, went to Albany last evening to consult with the Governor in relation to the means to be adopted for recruiting volunteers in this State under the new call of the President. The Board of Supervisors have decided to offer $300 each for volunteers enlisting in the City, which, with the bounties offered by the State and General Government, will amount to $706 for all recruits who have seen service, and $600 for new volunteers. If this does not have the effect to speedily fill the quota for this City, it is pretty certain that no pecuniary inducement would accomplish that result. The only evil effect of the large bounties offered here, will be that they will induce volunteers from the country districts to come here and enlist, and thus diminish the supply in other parts of the State. This can only be remedied by the cities and towns of the interior offering similar bounties. It will also have a tendency to stop the volunteering for the new regiments which are being raised by the State authorities, as the Government bounties, with those offered by this City, only apply to volunteers for regiments now in the field. One object of Gen. HAYES' visit to Albany, is to try and devise some means of harmonizing the recruiting service as carried on by the State authorities and by the General Government. There are several new regiments now being organized in the State, to whose officers it would be a great sacrifice to be compelled to abandon their enterprise after so great an outlay of time and money. We understand that Supervisor BLUNT is about to receive the commission of Major-General of Volunteers. The appointment is made in consideration of his past services in promoting enlistments, and for the purpose of facilitating his future labors in the same patriotic cause. On its first being intimated to Mr. BLUNT he declined in advance accepting any pay for his services, and consented to receive the commission only that he might thereby become more useful and efficient in the work of furnishing recruits for the army.

abstract: Yesterday morning the employes on all the City railroads, except the Second, Third avenue and the Cross-town roads, after making one or two trips struck, left the cars, and trips were discontinued, citizens along the several routes being seriously the sufferers. The drivers and conductors demand $2 per day, instead of $1 50. The employes who had struck were assembled during the day in the vicinity of the respective depots, and although considerable feeling existed no disposition was evinced to do other than quietly "bide their time."

abstract: -- The jewelry of Miss CHASE's trosseau, from the superb engagement ring, about which some intrusive paragraphist made an item weeks since, down to the smallest shawl-pin of the outfit, has been for weeks a subject of deep speculation among the ladies. To enumerate the items, or give a detailed description of each, is consequently superfluous. The jewelry worn upon the bridal occasion consisted of a tiara of pearls and diamonds, and a bracelet and pair of ear-rings of kindred materials. The tiara has for a base a line of pearls of exquisite symmetry and exceedingly rare color. This is shaped cunningly to fit the lady's small head, swelling as it advances from either ear into a beautiful garland of orange leaves and blossoms, formed of the precious matters before suggested and meeting at the front in a deftly tied bow of brilliants, upon which rests a marvelous pearl in size and orient well worthy the old Roman appellation, unio. By a dexterous mechanical coup, this tiara is so fashioned as to furnish, as need may be, four distinct ornaments; in the first place, the true lover's knot detaches, and with its dazzling diamonds and its mammoth pearl, the largest in America, forms a unique brooch. Next the garland separates into two graceful sprays, available as head ornaments when the whole tiara is not requisite. Finally, the base line of pearls leaves its ribs of gold and becomes a necklace. The bracelet is a circlet of five rows of pearls of exemplary beauty, meeting in a head of diamond openwork, bearing a Maltese cross of brilliants, which inclose a very rare pearl. The ear-rings are pendant pear-shaped pearls, mounted in small brilliants. Since the famous diamond wedding of the Cuban magnifico, no such jewelry has been worn.

abstract: The United States Circuit Court has recently decided some important revenue questions, two of which are reported in our columns this morning. Some of them are important, not so much on account of the intricacy of the questions involved, or the amount immediately in controversy, as because they settle courses of practice at the Custom-house. The more questions which can be settled as to that business the better it is for our importing community; and some of these practices are such that one must almost wonder how they could ever have arisen, or how they were ever attempted to be defended in Court.

abstract: Orders have been sent to Chief-Engineer KING, U.S.N., who recently made a trial of the iron-clad battery Winnebago at Cincinnati, to have that vessel completed as soon as possible for active service. A list of officers has been made out by the Navy Department and forwarded to the officer in charge. The Winnebago is now thoroughly completed, and will be ready to join our active squadron in a few days. She carries a crew of a hundred men, and has two guns. The destination of the vessel is not known.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: The  drivers and conductors on several of the principal City Railroads have struck for higher wages, and as the companies have not seen fit to comply, with their demands, three or four of them were compelled to suspend operations yesterday. As a matter of course, this led to very serious public inconvenience, and for a variety of reasons the public sympathy does not, as a, general thing, go with the companies.
lead_paragraph: The drivers and conductors on several of the principal City Railroads have struck for higher wages, and as the companies have not seen fit to comply, with their demands, three or four of them were compelled to suspend operations yesterday. As a matter of course, this led to very serious public inconvenience, and for a variety of reasons the public sympathy does not, as a, general thing, go with the companies. They obtained their franchises, in the first place, by gratuitous and utterly unjust grants of the Legislature, and ought therefore to deal liberally with the public. They have nearly all of them largely "watered" their stock and made enormous profits by that process. They take very little pains to accommodate the public, cramming their cars to suffocation, recognizing no passenger's right to the undisturbed and exclusive enjoyment of the seat he has paid for, and refusing to run cars enough for the comfortable conveyance of those who wish to ride. And with all this their profits are large, their dividends on a nominal capital two or three times the actual cost of the road, are very heavy, and it is almost impossible to purchase their stock at any reasonable price.

abstract: How to Deal With Them
lead_paragraph: There is something very extraordinary in the impunity enjoyed by the guerrillas who are operating within our lines in Virginia. From "gobbling up" small parties of our men, cutting off trains, robbing sutlers, and stampeding mules and horses, these gentry have now commenced the practice of assassination on a great scale. They lie in wait in the woods, singly or in parties of two or three, and fire upon passing officers or soldiers. Every day we hear of men being shot down in this way, and the evil is steadily increasing. The woods between our front and the Potomac are said to be swarming with ruffians who make their presence known solely by robbery and murder. They are said to be "MOSEBY's men," but we believe nobody has the least knowledge whether they have anything to do with MOSEBY or not, or whether they have the smallest connection whatever with the Confederate army. There can be nothing easier than to take a musket and go into the woods and shoot at everybody who passes along the road. There is no reason why deserters, stragglers and robbers of all kinds and degrees should not rush to this mode of enriching themselves, or gratifying their bad passions; and we may be right well assured that as long as we content ourselves with the conclusion that anybody who waylays our soldiers in the vicinity of the camp is one of "MOSEBY's guerrillas," and therefore entitled to the rank and honor of an enemy, all the bad characters who invariably swarm round an army, will go into the business of lying in wait and murdering. An orderly cannot at this moment be sent anywhere outside our camp without danger to his life; the officers cannot ride between two divisions of the army without a strong escort. And yet we are not half way to Richmond. We may imagine what the state of things will be as we advance further South, and when every needy Virginian and broken-down sutler that we leave behind on our track becomes fully aware that he has only to take a shot-gun, and get behind a tree, in order to fill his pockets with greenbacks and watches, with the certainty of being treated as a prisoner of war in case he is caught.

abstract: Detachments of our infantry and cavalry this morning handsomely thrashed STUART'S cavalry near Mitchell's Station, three miles southwest of Culpepper. The rest of the army was quiet; but it is the quiet that precedes the storm. We now hold all the ground in Culpepper County that we held six weeks ago.

abstract: The rumors which, for a day or two, have blown southward from the lakes, respecting a conspiracy on the part of rebels in Canada to make hostile demonstrations against Buffalo, Ogdensburgh, and other Northern towns, seem to be entitled to more attention than wise people generally have been willing to give them. They now have the weight of official recognition. The Governor-General of Canada, in the exercise of becoming comity and international good faith, has notified our Government, through Lord LYONS, of the probable existence of a rebel plot to seize steamboats on Lake Erie, set free the 2,000 prisoners confined at Johnson's Island, and destroy the lake cities by fire. The Secretary of War has notified the officials of the threatened cities that this information has been received, and it is probable that such measures have been adopted as will effectually thwart the infamous design of the conspirators.

abstract: The arrival of the Bohemian at Father Point gives three days' later news from Europe. There had been some excitement in British naval circles respecting rumors of an attempt to be made to steal the rebel rams out of the Mersey, and that such an event was not considered altogether improbable may be inferred from the fact that war-vessels were sent to guard against it. Confirmation is brought through the London papers of the statement that the French Government has notified the builders of iron-clad vessels for the rebels that permission to prosecute the work is withdrawn, and the furnishing of cannon and munitions of war has also been prohibited. A rumor was current that the French army occupying Rome was to evacuate the Papal dominions. The Polish revolution presents no new features. Swedish and Norwegian journals are vigorous in opposition to the proposed Danish alliance.

abstract: PATRICK MURPHY, a jolly son of Erin, was placed at the bar yesterday morning charged with a felonious assault upon HENRY A. MOTT, Esq., a lawyer of this City, and son of Dr. VALENTINE MOTT. It appears that in April last MURPHY was in the employ of Mr. MOTT as coachman, and the employer desiring to dispose of his services gave him a ticket of leave. MURPHY, however, was not so desirous of going; in fact he vowed he wouldn't go, and gave his employer so to understand. On being ordered out of the the house he drew a knife and threatened to dirk his boss, whereat he received a shot in the leg from a pistol. The shot didn't hurt him much, but on its being represented to him that he would receive another shot in a more tender place unless he left, he came to the conclusion that discretion was the better part of valor and voluntarily withdrew himself from the domicil. Mr. CLINTON, counsel for the accused, tried to make it appear that his client was the assaultee instead of the assaultor, but the Jury didn't seem to see it in that light, and after a consultation of two hours they returned with a verdict of "assault with a dangerous weapon with intent to do bodily harm." At the intercession of the complainant the Court supended sentence and MURPHY was discharged on his good behavior.

abstract: The County Canvassers resumed their work at noon yesterday. The returns from the Eighteenth Ward were first taken up; those from the Sixth District were laid over for the correction of some clerical errors. This was the last Ward of the Sixth Senatorial District, where the question of the election of Senator was said to be in doubt; and although the returns were incomplete by the one District laid over for correction, the election of Mr. LAIMBEER, Republican, was conceded by the friends of his opponent, Mr. KING. Mr. LAIMBEER is elected by a majority of about 100. The Twenty-second and Twelfth Wards were next canvassed, and afterward the imperfect returns of the Fifteenth Ward, that were laid over for correction on the previous day, were presented complete and were canvassed. A correction was also made of the returns from the Tenth District of the Seventh Ward, by which MCCUNN's vote for Superior Court Judge was increased 183 over the figures reported at Police Headquarters, the Police figures being 61, and those of the official returns 244. This helped MCCUNN wonderfully. The vote between Judge BOSWORTH and he is close, several changes from the Police figures having been developed on both sides by the actual canvasss. By the Police figures and corrections the official canvass to the close of the session of the Board yesterday, the vote between the two stood thus:

abstract: Movement to join Grant
lead_paragraph: The fortunes of the moving column of Gen. SHERMAN, on its way from Vicksburgh and Memphis, to form a junction with the main body of GRANT's army, have for some time engaged the attention of those who follow military operations in the Southwest, and not always without anticipations of ill-luck. From latest accounts it is tolerably certain that this force has, by this time, reached its destination and formed a junction with GRANT's right wing at Stevenson. In order to effect this, however, it was found necessary to give up both the line by which it was intended this column should advance, and one of the prime objects it was expected to accomplish by the way. In the redistribution of Gen. GRANT's army after the capture of Vicksburgh, the Thirteenth corps was sent to Gen. BANKS at New-Orleans; a column made up of parts of the three other corps was dispatched under STEELE into Arkansas; the Seventeenth was assigned the duty of holding Vicksburgh, and the Mississippi, below Helena; the Sixteenth was given the task of guarding the Mississippi from Helena to Cairo, and the Memphis and Charleston Railroad as far east as Corinth, or, perhaps, Bear Creek, thirty miles beyond, on the Alabama line; and finally it was designed that the Fifteenth corps, under Gen. SHERMAN, should open the Memphis and Charleston Railroad, from Bear Creek as far east as Decatur, with the purpose of making this the main line of communications with Chattanooga. A glance at a map whereon the railroad lines are indicated will show that this line, after nearing the Tennessee at Iuka, runs eastward on the southern side of the river, and follows its general course as far as Decatur, where it crosses to the north side of the river, and thence continues eastward to Chattanooga, crossing again to the south side of the Tennessee at Bridgeport. It is obvious that if the portion of the line of railroad running on the south side of the Tennessee -- that is, from Memphis to Decatur -- could be reopened and maintained, it would afford an invaluable channel through which the army at Chattanooga might draw supplies. Work was accordingly commenced, and by the 1st of November the road had been opened from Corinth for forty miles, through Iuka, and across Bear Creek to Cherokee Station, Ala. No sooner was this purpose apparent, however, than a powerful rebel cavalry force, said to amount to ten thousand, under command of Gen. S.D. LEE, swarmed in the vicinity, hanging on and harrassing the flank of our force, and retiring before it, tearing up and destroying the railroad as they receded.

abstract: The first sale of lands under the act for the collection of direct taxes in insurrectionary districts is advertised to-day by the Tax Commissioners of South Carolina. Twenty-five tracts on Hilton Head Island, valued at $95,000, and a large number of houses and town lots in Beaufort, will be sold at Port Royal on the 1st of December, or from day to day thereafter until the property is sold. The Commissioners reserve a single bid on each town lot and block, to be made publicly by them of such sum as they deem advisable, of not less than one-third their appraised value. Lots not bid up to one-third their appraised value will be withdrawn.

abstract: NIBLO's GARDEN -- Mr. J. GRAU's ITALIAN OPERA COMPANY. -- Mr. GRAU's first performance since his return from Europe took place at this establishment on Wednesday evening. The house was handsomely and brilliantly attended. Mr. GRAU, although he happens to be out in the cold at present, so far as direct management is concerned, is borne in kindly remembrance by the public. At times, when operatic enterprise seemed to be dead, he sprung to the front, and by combining the scattered legions, made a goodly fight for Art. In the present instance, he has abandoned the traditions of his remarkably successful career, and has ventured upon an experiment which is always attended with danger. Instead of using the material washed ashore from wrecked managements, he has visited Europe and procured there the precise article that he needed. It is certainly an instance of the gentleman's determination, that notwithstanding the apparent impossibility of securing a house -- or if a house, then of an orchestra and chorus -- he has managed to fulfill his promise of playing in the metropolis previous to departing for the Provinces. Allowances must certainly be made for an impromptu experiment, such as that of Wednesday night. The chorus and orchestra were not what they would be if Mr. GRAU were playing here regularly. But the shortcomings in these departments did not materially interfere with the result of the night. The leading artists whom Mr. GRAU desired to introduce, were received by the public with great favor. Their success, in fact, was complete.

abstract: Reports from the Army of the Potomac say that the barbarous habit of picket-shooting has been revived by the rebels, and our men find it necessary to keep well under cover unless they are anxious to be made targets of. The enemy still present a strong front on the south bank of the Rapidan, and the river being very low, makes guarding it a task of trying difficulty. Spade operations by the rebels have been energetically resumed.

abstract: -- The Fair which has been open some time at the picture-gallery, No. 625 Broadway, will close this (Saturday) evening. This Institution was established in 1854, and is situated in Eighty-sixth-street, North River, its beneficent object being the reclamation and protection of females. It is under the care of the Sisters of St. Luke's Hospital.

abstract: Gen. FOREY commanding the French forces in Mexico, who arrived here last week, sailed for France direct; yesterday morning, in the French gunboat Panama. The slight delay, incident to the repair of the machinery of the Panama, was taken advantage of by him to make his flying visit to Niagara.

abstract: -- Sergeant POLLEY, of the Twenty-first Precinct, while going his rounds at a late hour on Thursday night, found a man who was behaving in a very disorderly manner on the corner of Third-avenue and Thirty-second-street. When the Sergeant attempted to arrest him, he was set upon by a large number of "roughs," and beaten by them quite severely. Officer LITTLE soon came to the assistance of the Sergeant, and the two finally succeeded in arresting one of the assailants. While they were taking him to the Thirty-fifth-street Station-house, the rowdies, largely reinforced, again attacked the officers, this time with slung-shot. The latter were both knocked down and severely beaten about the head. Before assistance came from the Station-house, the entire gang had disappeared.
lead_paragraph: -- Sergeant POLLEY, of the Twenty-first Precinct, while going his rounds at a late hour on Thursday night, found a man who was behaving in a very disorderly manner on the corner of Third-avenue and Thirty-second-street. abstract: There is nothing in Gen. MEADE's line of advance to and across the Rappahannock that affords any indication of the route by which he means to push his further operations. The crossing at Kelly's Ford would be made whether he proposed to move by Fredericksburgh or by Culpepper. Gen. HOOKER made it his point of crossing in the movement by Fredericksburgh, while Gen. MEADE in the last advance passed at this same point for his movement by Culpepper. In the meantime there is no reason for public impatience at the present pause in the forward movement. The object of it, doubtless, is to allow the completion of the railroad to the Rappahannock. A few days ago there were yet six miles of the road to be rebuilt. When this is done, which ought to be by the beginning of the coming week, it will afford a channel of supplies for his army, and permit a further advance. The works at Rappahannock Station, both those which the rebels had raised and the additions that have been made to them, will furnish a tete-de-pont for the crossing and security for the magazines accumulated at that point. In the fresh advance on which Gen. MEADE is about to enter, there is not so much occasion for any very recondite strategy as for an opportunity to bring the enemy to a decisive battle. The large, and sometimes even superior force of rebels that has hitherto met all our attempts to advance beyond the Rappahannock, has made manoeuvering for an advantageous position the first consideration with our Commanders. We take it that MEADE has this time the relative superiority of means to make fighting the main object of his campaign.

abstract: -- At a preparatory meeting of the Saint Andrew's Society of the State of New-York, held at the St. Nicholas Hotel on Thursday, the following gentlemen were elected officers for the ensuing year: RICHARD IRVIN, President; John T. Johnson, First Vice-President; Robert Gordon, Second Vice-President; Alex. McKenzie, William Paton, James Fraser, Robt. P. Campbell, Allan Hay, William Brand, Managers; James M. Morrison, Treasurer; Root. Dinwiddie, Secretary; Ramsay Crooks, Assistant Secretary; Alex. Elder, M.D., Physician; Rev. Dr. M.N. McLeod, Rev. Jas. K. Campbell, Chaplains.

abstract: -- The announcement is publicly made for the first time in our paper this morning, that measures have been taken here by some of our business men, to establish a bank under the recent law of Congress, on the subject of a national currency. The subscribers to the capital stock of the new bank comprise the names of the leading men of the city -- men who are hereafter to have a controlling voice in the next Chamber of Commerce. We learn that $170,000 of the capital stock has already been taken, and the books are still open for those who may wish to invest. It is quite probable that by this time next year the bulk of the currency of the United States will be furnished by these National Banks. -- New-Orleans Era, Nov. 1.

abstract: -- Col. GANTT, formerly of the rebel army and now a prisoner of war, in his admirable and powerful address pronouncing the rebellion a failure and avowing his return to his allegiance to the National flag and Constitution, suggests that Mr. SEBASTIAN, of Arkansas, resume his seat in the Senate of the United States. He has always been a loyal man, and opposed the rebellion. The State is now in the possession of the Union forces. If its civil Government were in the hands of loyal men who have taken the oath of allegiance to the Federal Constitution, there would probably be little opposition to the renewed representation of the State in the National councils. It certainly is desirable that it should be so represented as soon as possible.
lead_paragraph: -- Col.
