abstract: News from Europe, two days' later than that received by the Bohemian, was brought to Halifax yesterday morning, by the steamship Asia, and telegraphed to this City. There is nothing of extraordinary interest in the advices. A severe gale had visited England, doing some damage to life and property, but not to a serious extent. A company had been formed, under the title of the National Steam Navigation Company, of London and Liverpool, with a capital of 2,000,000 pounds, to accelerate the substitution of powerful screw-steamers for sailing vessels, in the American and other trades. Three new steamers have been already purchased, and contracts made for others, to ply between Liverpool and New-York. The rebel rams in the Mersey and LAIRD's ship-yard continue to be strongly guarded by the Government, and the possibility of the escape of the vessels is remote. A discussion of American topics, between "Historicus" on one side, and Mr. LINDSAY and GEORGE SANDERS on the other, had appeared in the columns of the London Times, and the former maintained the best of the argument. The bankruptcy of Z.C. PEARSON, resulting from his extensive and unfortunate adventures in blockade-running, was under investigation, and some singular developments had been made. The Empress EUGENIE had returned to France. At Paris, Bordeaux and Havre the Mexican Consuls had been compelled to cease their functions, and their duties are temporarily performed by the Consuls of Guatemala. The rebel pirate Georgia had arrived at Cherbourg to provision and refit. The Schleswig-Holstein imbroglio and the Polish insurrection present no strikingly new features. In Warsaw the suspected inhabitants were treated with great severity. Among the passengers by the Asia is Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER.

abstract: Although work at the Navy-yard has not been delayed in consequence of the recent labor movements, still the effect of the strike of ship-carpenters has very materially retarded the progress of work in most of the private ship-yards. They are not, however, suffering as much as shipbuilders in Jersey City, where the strike is general. In one or two instances employers have acceded to the demand of their workmen for an increase of wages, but as yet Messrs. SECOR & CO. have refused compliance. At this yard, three monitors are being built, two of which, up to the time of the dissatisfaction of the laborers, were rapidly approaching completion. The iron gunboat Mahongo, which it was thought would soon be ready for launching, will not probably go into the water before next Spring.
lead_paragraph: Although work at the Navy-yard has not been delayed in consequence of the recent labor movements, still the effect of the strike of ship-carpenters has very materially retarded the progress of work in most of the private ship-yards. abstract: -- A man named PATRICK RYAN, aged about 65 years, died at his residence. No. 647 Water-street, at 6 o'clock yesterday morning, from the effects of injuries received at the hands of a man named SULLIVAN. Coroner WILDEY was notified and will hold an inquest to-day. Dr. GEORGE B. BOUGHTON made a postmortem examination of the deceased, and found the skull badly fractured, and a large quantity of extravasated blood in the region of the brain. From evidence in the possession of the Coroner, it appears that the deceased and SULLIVAN, while engaged in street-sweeping two or three nights since, became involved in a quarrel, during which SULLIVAN beat deceased on the head with a hoe in a terrible manner. SULLIVAN has been arrested and is held to await the result of the inquest.

abstract: Delaware, The Election in
lead_paragraph: A very active political canvass is going on in Delaware for the election of a Member of Congress. Mr. SMITHERS, the Union candidate, is a man of ability, an eloquent speaker and a thoroughgoing supporter of the Government in its prosecution of the war against the rebellion. His opponent, CHARLES BROWN, is, practically, and to all intents and purposes, a Secessionist. He was formerly Collector of the Port of Philadelphia, and has but lately taken up his residence in Delaware. Public meetings, large and enthusiastic, are held in various parts of the State, and the Union men hope for a very decided victory. In another part of this morning's paper we copy from the Delaware State Journal, a speech made by Mr. RAYMOND at Wilmington on the 6th inst., in which the various points involved in the National contest are discussed. Among them are the subjects of arbitrary arrests, the object for which the war is carried on, and the question of Reconstruction. The ground taken on the latter point is, that no State can possibly release any one of its citizens from his allegiance to the National Constitution, -- and that much less can it release them all; that they are, therefore, as much in the Union to-day as they were before the rebellion broke out.

abstract: -- Col. SEYMOUR, Engineer-in-Chief of the Aqueduct, has submitted a plan to the Secretary of the Interior for changing the current of the Potomac to the Washington side of the river. It provides for the construction of a breakwater from the lower extremity of Mason's Island, to extend easterly on the flats to the neighborhood of the Long Bridge, midway of the causeway, so called. This will give a current of twenty-five to thirty feet along the Washington wharves, which will be of great service to the Government in the matter of transportation.
lead_paragraph: -- Col. SEYMOUR, Engineer-in-Chief of the Aqueduct, has submitted a plan to the Secretary of the Interior for changing the current of the Potomac to the Washington side of the river. abstract: -- The New-Orleans papers of the 4th instant announce the arrival in that city of Rev. THOMAS W. CONWAY, Chaplain of the Seventh regiment, Corps d'Afrique, from New-York, with a beautiful banner, presented to his regiment by Mayor OPDYKE, A.T. STEWART, Hon. EDGAR KETCHUM and other leading and influential citizens of New-York. Accompanying the banner was a short and stirring address to be read to the regiment on the presentation.

abstract: -- Col. HANKS, who recently arrived at the North from New-Orleans, where he has been in charge of the Louisiana freedmen, brings with him a man who is branded on the forehead with the name of his late master; a woman, whose back and shoulders are scarred with the lash of her oppressors; a preacher of the Gospel, until recently a slave; and three little white girls, with straight, light brown hair and blue eyes. They are good-looking children; indeed, one of them is very handsome. They were born in Slavery, and held as slaves until the President issued his Proclamation of Freedom.

abstract: E. W. Gantt's Denunciations of; (Letter to Arkansas People); Address to People of Arkansas on the Failure of the Rebellion and Davis' Wrong Doings
snippet: E. W. Gantt's Denunciations of; (Letter to Arkansas People); Address to People of Arkansas on the Failure of the Rebellion and Davis' Wrong Doings
lead_paragraph: We have received from Hon. E.W. GANTT, (formerly member of Congress-elect from Arkansas, but since the rebellion an Acting Brigadier-General in the Confederate service,) a pamphlet, bearing the imprint of "National Democrat print, Little Rock, Ark.," which, from its great interest as giving an inside view of rebel operations in the Southwest, and the feelings and ideas of an intelligent Southerner on the present hopeless aspect of the rebel cause, we herewith print entire. The title-page of the pamphlet is: "Address of Hon. E.W. GANTT to the People of Arkansas." It is dated "Little Rock, October 7, 1863.

abstract: In the United States District Court, now in session at Nashville, Judge CATRON, of the United States Supreme Bench, has just decided the case of A.W. PAUL against the Planters' and Union Banks of Tennessee, in favor of the plaintiff. Mr. PAUL, some time since, presented a heavy amount of the notes of these institutions for payment in par funds or specie. This being refused, he had the notes protested, and, being a non-resident, brought suit for the face of the notes and damages for their non-redemption in the United States Court. Judge CATRON awarded to him the full par value of the notes and interest from the time payment was refused.
lead_paragraph: In the United States District Court, now in session at Nashville, Judge CATRON, of the United States Supreme Bench, has just decided the case of A.W. PAUL against the Planters' and Union Banks of Tennessee, in favor of the plaintiff. Mr. PAUL, some time since, presented a heavy amount of the notes of these institutions for payment in par funds or specie. This being refused, he had the notes protested, and, being a non-resident, brought suit for the face of the notes and damages for their non-redemption in the United States Court. Judge CATRON awarded to him the full par value of the notes and interest from the time payment was refused.

abstract: The Stripping and Starving of by Rebels
snippet: The Stripping and Starving of by Rebels
lead_paragraph: The picture drawn by an eye-witness of the condition of the paroled prisoners just returned from Richmond, which was given in our last issue, though so horrible, we trust was not passed over by any of our readers. It is almost incredible that any people who ever even so much as heard the name of Christ -- any people not sunk clear down to the very lowermost depths of pagan barbarism -- should thus deliberately strip their captives of the clothing necessary to protect them from the cold, and then inch by inch starve their shivering bodies to the bone. And yet it is no more to be denied than that there is a sun above us.

abstract: -- The regular weekly meeting was held on Thursday evening -- Prof. S.D. TILLMAN, Chairman, in the Chair. At the opening of the meeting he announced that Prof. BENJAMIN GARVEE had been appointed Secretary for the balance of the year -- February, 1864. During the half hour devoted to miscellaneous subjects, a model of LEARS' stern paddle-wheel for river navigation was exhibited, as was also METHOL's regenerated furnace for steam-boilers. A new breech-loading gun, invented by a Mr. HANSON, was also exhibited and explained, and called forth a lengthy discussion, which was participated in by Commodore PORTER, U.S.N., Prof. GEVEY, Messrs.. WEYARD, ROWELL, and others. The subject was made the discussion for next Thursday evening. The regular subject for the evening, "Iron-Clads," being called, Commodore PORTER opened the discussion by stating that he had heard it reported that he was not in favor of turreted ships. He begged to inform the Association that he was in favor of them, and always had been. He exhibited a model of a turret ship, for which, in 1856, a patent was applied for by Mr. REED, an old revolutionary soldier, and was rejected by the Patent Office. Dr. RICH then read a most interesting paper on the Dunderburg, now building by Mr. WEBB. Mr. OSBORN gave a lengthy and interesting account of the Bricsson monitors and their various peculiarities. His remarks induced a lengthy and animated discussion, which was cut off at a very interesting period by an adjournment.
lead_paragraph: -- The regular weekly meeting was held on Thursday evening -- Prof. S.D. TILLMAN, Chairman, in the Chair. abstract: -- An inquest was held by Coroner COLLIN, at No. 75 Robinson-street, on the body of a woman named ANN HOGAN, who, in some unaccountable manner, fell from the fourth-story window of the above premises at an early hour yesterday morning. The deceased was about 60 years of age. She was not addicted to drink, and the manner in which the accident occurred was not satisfactorily explained on the inquest.

abstract: -- Coroner NAUMANN held an inquest, yesterday, at the New-York Hospital, on the body of MARTIN MURPHY, a native of Ireland, aged 29 years, who died from injuries received by the kick of a horse. The deceased received his wounds in CONNELL's Stables, in Thirty-fifth-street, near Broadway, where he was employed as an ostler. The jury rendered a verdict of accidental death.

abstract: United States vs. The Schooner Ezilda and Cargo. NELSON, C.J. The vessel and cargo in this case were captured about the 12th of October, 1861, by United States steamer South Carolina, while attempting to break the blockade off New-Orleans. The proof is full on this point.
lead_paragraph: United States vs. The Schooner Ezilda and Cargo. NELSON, C.J. The vessel and cargo in this case were captured about the 12th of October, 1861, by United States steamer South Carolina, while attempting to break the blockade off New-Orleans. The proof is full on this point. The vessel was taken into the service of the Government, as also some arms on board the same. The vessel and cargo were condemned in the Court below. On appeal by the claimant, the case was submitted on briefs at the April Term last, but no copies of apostles were delivered to the Court. I have taken the original papers on file, and looked into them. There does not appear to have been any claim for the cargo.

abstract: -- The New-York Infirmary for women and Children is a charitable institution which is doing a vast deal of good. Over 21,000 of those the especial objects of its care have been relieved during the past five years. It has, unobtrusingly, been doing its work of good. The trustees have purchased the property on which the Infirmary is situated, on Second-avenue, for $16,000, and have paid $9,000. They now appeal to the public for the sum required to complete the payment.

abstract: Augusta, the Slaver Ship, Case of the
snippet: Augusta, the Slaver Ship, Case of the
lead_paragraph: We notice the affirmance in the United States Circuit Court of the decree of forfeiture against the bark Augusta as a slaver. Our readers will recollect that she was a vessel fitted out by the notorious APPLETON OAKSMITH, of this City. He did not have the title to her in his own name, but had the entire charge of her, and was fitting her up ostensibly to go on a whaling voyage. The Government seized her, however, believing that she was intended to go to the African coast. Her owners gave bonds for her, and receiving her again into their possession, boldly prepared still to carry out their intention and send her to sea without any change in her fitment or alleged destination. There have been times when vessels seized for the Slave-trade and bonded, have been allowed to proceed upon their voyage, but those days are past. The Government officers, finding that the enterprise was apparently being continued, did not hesitate to seize her again, and this time the owners did not bond her, but left her in the custody of the Court till this second case should be tried. Both cases in due time were tried -- the first before Judge SHIPMAN, who decided against the vessel, the second before Judge SMALLEY, who has not yet decided either way. An appeal was taken from Judge SHIPMAN's decision to the Circuit Court, and on this appeal the District-Attorney gave evidence of the proceedings of the vessel subsequent to her being bonded until she was seized the second time; and Judge NELSON now affirms the decision, holding that these new proofs show clearly that her second equipment was for a slaving voyage, and from the relation of this to the first equipment, it was clear that that was also a voyage with that intent.

abstract: (colored,) pastor of the Israel Bethel Church, of Washington, has been appointed Chaplain in the United States army, and assigned to duty in the First regiment United States colored troops, now in South Carolina. He will proceed to his post of duty on Monday next. This is the first colored minister who has been commissioned as Chaplain. The honor has been worthily bestowed, as Mr. TURNER has labored assiduously for the elevation of his race.
lead_paragraph: (colored,) pastor of the Israel Bethel Church, of Washington, has been appointed Chaplain in the United States army, and assigned to duty in the First regiment United States colored troops, now in South Carolina. abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. BELLINI'S opera of "La Somnambula" was the attraction here last night. How marvelously fresh and charming are the melodies in this work, notwithstanding the many, many years of hackneying they have had to undergo! Would that we had more of such subjects treated in so superb a manner.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- BELLINI's opera of "La Somnambula" was the attraction here last night. How marvelously fresh and charming are the melodies in this work, notwithstanding the many, many years of hackneying they have had to undergo! Would that we had more of such subjects treated in so superb a manner. The distribution last night was in all respects good. Miss KELLOGG is one of the most graceful and charming Aminas now on the stage. The music lays easily within the best parts of her voice; her execution of it is in every respect neat, modest and effective; her dramatic rendering of the character is in the highest degree pleasing. With such strong points in her favor -- and blended, we may add, into a consisent and lovable whole -- it is not remarkable that Miss KELLOGG always achieved a new success in this part. Throughout the performance she was in admirable voice. Signor G. LOTTI was the Elvino. This gentleman's efforts have been confined heretofore to German opera. It was only in "Macbeth." under Mr. MARETZEK, that he gave the promise of a career. The sweet quality of his voice -- assisted perhaps by the entourage -- astonished and pleased every one. In BELLINI's opera he has an opportunity which he can hardly hope to better, however much his ability to seize it may improve. He succeeded remarkably. Visibly nervous, he contrived to reserve his best strength for the second and third acts, where strength is most required. There are few tenori-de-grazia now before the public with more acceptable voices than Signor LOTTI. Time and practice will accustom him to the business of the stage -- in which he is evidently inexperienced -- and study will, we are sure, reveal new beauties in a voice already so acceptable. Signor BIACHI was a good Rudolpho, and Miss FANNY STOCKTON, although too timid to do full justice to herself, sang the music of Lisa with ability. The orchestra and chorus under Mr. MARETZEK were both admirable.

abstract: -- A correspondent, who writes with knowledge, shows through our columns that unjust charges have been made against the authorities concerning the delay in the settlement of the accounts of deceased soldiers. There have been, and are delays, but some of them are unavoidable, and others are in a fair way of being prevented. The subject is one of very great interest, to a large and constantly increasing number of persons, and it is to be hoped the machinery of the Government bearing on this matter will be adjusted as soon as possible, for there is certainly much complaint.

abstract: -- The Board of County Canvassers proceeded with their business, yesterday, at noon. The votes canvassed, do not differ materially from those already published. The First, Second, Third, Fifth and Tenth Wards were completed. It seems to be pretty definitely settled that Judge MCCUNN is elected, though by very small majority. Official and unofficial returns make the vote stand as follows: BOSWORTH, 32,[???]72; MCCUNN, 32,727. MCCUNN's majority is thus 155. It is not believed that the complete canvass will materially alter these figures. The canvass may be concluded to-day.

abstract: -- B. GRATZ BROWN has been elected United States Senator from the State of Missouri. He is a man of decided ability, was one of the earliest and most zealous Republicans in the State, and is equally zealous in his advocacy of immediate emancipation. His election marks an era in the political history not only of Missouri, but of the whole country. When Slave States begin to elect Abolitionists to the Senate of the United States, we may fairly infer that the world is making progress. We trust the example of Missouri will be imitated.

abstract: -- At Springfield, Ohio, the loyal folks are manufacturing huge quantities of saur kraut for the soldiers. The News says: "Barrel after barrel of the cabbages have been cut up and packed down with salt, ready for shipment. All day yesterday a four mule team was employed in hauling in the raw material. The scene inside the room was difficult properly to describe. Ladies and gentlemen in scores were 'pitching in' with all their might to 'manufacture' the cabbages as fast as they were brought in."

abstract: -- Officers FINNEGAN and REGAN, of the Fourteenth Precinct, yesterday arrested two men, named WM. JOHNSON and WM. EPPESTEIN, on the charge of burglary. The prisoners are charged with having broken into the hostery store of Mr. A.P. BRAINARD, NO. 64 Bowery, with the intent to steal. When taken into custody, two "jimmies," a brace and bit, four racks used for carrying goods, and various other implements used by burglars, were found in their possession. They had succeeded in breaking through the rear door of the store when the officers discovered them. They were taken before Justice DODGE, at the Tombs, and committed for examination.

abstract: -- The United States gunboat Flag, Acting Master CURTIS commanding, arrived yesterday from Port Royal, which harbor she left on the 7th inst. She towed up the steamer Herald, a noted blockade-runner, which was captured off Charleston some time since. The Flag comes to this port for repairs, having been on the blockade at Charleston eighteen months. She brings a cargo of 76 bales of cotton. lead_paragraph: The World comes promptly and properly to the rescue of the Central Railroad management. As the special guardian of the Democratic interest in this State, that journal becomes necessarily the special champion of its most powerful ally. The fact that the management of the Central Road finds so zealous and eager an advocate in the organ of the Democracy, is quite conclusive as to the partisan manner in which its power is used.

abstract: A singular explanation is given by the Montreal Commercial Advertiser, a session newspaper, of the thwarted rebel conspiracy in Canada. It admits of the failure of the rebel plot, and says the Confederate Government fitted out the...
lead_paragraph: A singular explanation is given by the Montreal Commercial Advertiser, a session newspaper, of the thwarted rebel conspiracy in Canada. It admits of the failure of the rebel plot, and says the Confederate Government fitted out the steamer R.E. Lee, from Wilmington to Halifax, with a cargo to furnish funds. Thirty-six officers and three hundred men were to come overland in small parties, and meet at a general rendezvous. It was their intention to surprise the Federal garrison on Johnson's Island, liberate the prisoners, and convey them into Canada. They did not intend to violate British neutrality, but only to rescue two thousand prisoners from the wretched quarters, which were designed to kill them by slow degrees.

abstract: THE POLISH INSURRECTION. -- The Berlin correspondent of the London Herald gives a harrowing picture of the condition of Ukraine, a large and fertile province of unhappy Poland: "The Governor of that and the adjoining provinces of Volnynia and Podolia, Gen. ANNENCOFF, crushes the unfortunate inhabitants with ruinous taxes and a system of persecution of the most uncompromising and barbarous character. In the citadel of Kijow, and in the most forbidding prisons of the provincial towns, several thousands of political prisoners languish in the midst of vermin and filth of every description, with no other food than a loathsome kind a gruel, which they are forced to eat with their fingers. Torture has become an accepted means of extorting confessions. Prisoners are starved, deprived of drink until they are driven to the verge of insanity, interrupted in their sleep at frequent intervals, and often nearly flogged to death. Besides those who are in the prisons, thousands of youths, landowners, townsmen, priests, and peasants, have been exiled to Siberia, their clothes torn, their feet bare, and their arms loaded with chains. Many districts are completely depopulated; the estates of all who belong to the insurrection, or are suspected of having belonged to it, have been sequestrated, their proprietors banished or imprisoned, and their wives and children turned out to beg in the roads. The corn in many fields is still standing, the peasantry being encouraged to remain idle by the Government; all trade is paralyzed, and the merchants refuse to buy corn at a third of its value, although the cost of labor has increased three-fold. Any one neglecting to pay the Government tax of 10 per cent. has his estate occupied by the troops, and everything on it sold for mere trifles to the peasantry. Decrees rivaling each other in severity are published daily. The last orders the land-owners to give up all the corn on their estates to the Government. This, to many of them, is ruin, as the corn in his fields often constitutes the whole of the land-owner's income. All employes of Polish descent, and persons professing the Roman Catholic religion, are being transplanted into Asiatic Russia. This is part of a gigantic scheme for rooting out the Polish element from the whole of Poland, which is now being carried out over the whole of the territory occupied by Poland in 1772."

abstract: The late fight at Pine Bluff occurred on Sunday morning, the 25th ult., about 8 o'clock. The rebels attempted a surprise on Col. CLAYTON, by 4,000 rebel cavalry. The troops were commanded by Gens. MARMADUKE and CABELL. Col. CLAYTON had an hour's notice of their approach, and immediately set himself about preparing for defence.
lead_paragraph: The late fight at Pine Bluff occurred on Sunday morning, the 25th ult., about 8 o'clock. The rebels attempted a surprise on Col. CLAYTON, by 4,000 rebel cavalry. The troops were commanded by Gens. MARMADUKE and CABELL. Col. CLAYTON had an hour's notice of their approach, and immediately set himself about preparing for defence. Plenty of cotton being in a store near by the Court-house, the Colonel ordered a sufficient quantity to be used to barricade the streets surrounding the Court-house square, and having eleven cannon, planted them in position to rake the three streets leading to the centre of the city. His force was less than 700, with no infantry. The enemy attacked both places at 9 o'clock simultaneously on the southeast, south, and west sides of the city, they having come in on three different roads. On arriving at the outskirts, shells were thrown in every direction into the city, and no notice given for the women and children to leave. The bursting of the shells caused an extraordinary excitement -- women and children running from every direction to the Court-house for safety. In a few moments the rebels advanced, directing their fire upon the building. The women and children were removed under the banks of the river, where they remained exposed, throughout the cold, dreary day, until the battle was over, which was about 5 o'clock in the evening. By 9 o'clock the rebel sharpshooters had entered private houses in the vicinity of the Court-house, and commenced firing from the windows: and their artillery was thundering up and down the streets against the cotton breast-works.

abstract: A great deal or excitement has been created everywhere throughout the loyal States by the extraordinary rise in the price of coal, and it is not to be denied that there is very good reason for it, in view of the approach of Winter and the enormous addition to the cost of living that this doubling of prices makes, and yet if the public could be made aware that the increased price is the natural consequence of circumstances arising out of the present civil war, there would be a much more general resignation under the affliction.

abstract: Womens' Work and their Struggles
lead_paragraph: Among the numerous movements in various branches of labor which have been inaugurated within the past week, none is more worthy of serious and abiding notice, or sadder, than that of the working woman. We say sadder, because while almost every branch of man's work, striking for enhancement of wages, will be successful, that of women will be, as always heretofore, a fruitless effort.

abstract: CAREESO, of all the Neapolitan brigands, the monster in atrocities, continues to evade pursuit, and to mark his way with blood and pillage. Every one he meets, irrespective of age or sex, is murdered. After his defeat at Francavilla, the troops who pursued him found the bodies of fourteen of the peasantry; at another place eighteen were murdered; at Craco a portion of the band came on ten women who were washing outside the village, carried off six, and brutally violated them. At Morconi they broke into the house of a gentleman who was absent from home, and murdered his wife, another woman, and five persons besides, their respective ages being 62, 54, 49, 20, 9, 7, 4. Recently a gang of ten brigands entered the house of the parish priest of Cerchiara during the night by means of ladders, and finding him in bed, made him get up and dress himself, and then took him, together with his maid-servant, into the woods, where they shot him. The girl was allowed to return without suffering any ill treatment. The priest, it appears, had been in the hands of the brigands before, and had made his escape without paying any ransom, and it was for this that he was murdered.

abstract: The inaugural proceedings in the dedication of the ground selected for the purposes of a National Cemetery, will take place at Gettysburgh on the 19th of the present month. Attaching to this inauguration is a national interest, which possibly preludes the establishment of similar cemeteries. But the Gettysburgh Cemetery will have the prestige of priority. Its conception originated with Gov. ANDREW G. CURTIN, the fast and firm friend of the soldier, whom he assists in life, and to whose noble memory, in death, he is among the first to pay a noble tribute. By no means alone in this sympathy of feeling, he carries with him the hearts of this Commonwealth, as President LINCOLN carries with him, in this as well as in all other measures which he supports, the hearts of the nation.

abstract: Maj.-Gen. PECK made a reconnoissance of the Chowan River to near the mouth of the Blackwater, on the 6th, 7th and 8th insts., with Commodore FLUESSER, and the Whitehead, Delaware and Mann. As he was some 250 miles from Newbern, it is presumed he was waiting the cooperation of Maj.-Gen. FOSTER from Fortress Monroe. The rebels were apprehensive of some move upon Weldon, and burned the bridges near the Wicacon and other principal streams.

abstract: The War Department has established recruiting stations for colored troops at Stevenson, Alabama; and at Nashville, Murfreesboro, Gallatin, Wartrace, Clarksvilie, Shelbyville and Columbia, In Tennessee. abstract: SAD DEATH IN A SCHOOLROOM. -- Coroner RANNEY held an inquest on the body of a little girl aged about 4 years, named LOUISA SCHNEIDER, who died in her schoolroom under the following circumstances: The child for some time past has attended the Twenty-fourth-street school. It appears that it is the habit if the teachers of that school to detain after hours such of the pupils as may have been deficient in their lessons during the day. Upon the occasion in question, the deceased, with twelve other scholars, were kept in. Deceased seemed to take the punishment very seriously, and asked her teacher to allow her to go. The teacher, noticing her agitation, kindly told her that she might go as soon as she was able to spell correctly, the word "hedge." This appeared to appease her and she went to her seat. Soon, however, it was observed that the child threw her head back and was gasping for breath. The teacher took her in her arms and did all she could to relieve her, but after three or four gasps she expired. These are the facts as testified to upon the inquest. The jury rendered a verdict of death from "Syncope." Dr. RANNEY made an examination of the body, and his testimony was in accordance with the verdict. He further testified that "Syncope" might be produced by fear, excessive grief, or the heat of a room. At first there was much feeling among the relatives of the deceased; they fearing that the teacher had ill-treated, and too severely punished her for not reciting her lesson, but the evidence of the teacher and several pupils all went to show that such was not the case. The child was possessed of very fine feelings, an affectionate nature, and was greatly beloved by teacher and schoolmates.

abstract: At a late hour on Thursday night last, the fur-store of GEORGE C. TREADWELL, situated on Broadway, in the City of Albany, was entered by a gang of burglars and robbed of $3,000 worth of mufls, cloaks and capes. As soon as the burglary was discovered, the Chief of Police of the latter city telegraphed to Police Headquarters in New-York, giving notice of the robbery; that there were strong suspicions that the offenders were then on their way to this City, and asking the Detectives here to be on the watch for them. Sergt. YOUNG at once placed the matter in the hands of Detective FARLEY, and the latter gentleman, aided by several other officers who were detailed for that purpose, visited the steamboat landings and railroad depots, the lines of which communicate with Albany. Officer CLINTON, of the latter city, was dispatched hither to aid in the search. The plan at length succeeded, and when the night steamboat, Isaac Newton, arrived at her wharf yesterday morning, she was boarded by the officers, under direction of Detective FARLEY, and after a long and tedious examination, five men, who well answered the description, were found and taken into custody. In their possession there was found every dollar of the property which was taken from the fur-store of Mr. TREADWELL, on Thursday night last. The prisoners gave their names as THOMAS WEBB, CHAS. G. KOSS. WM. DOUGHERTY. JOHN BASSRON and FRANK DONALDSON. They made no resistance whatever, having been taken by surprise, owing to the complete and well concocted plans of the officers. The accused were ironed and placed on board a Hudson River railroad car bound for Albany yesterday afternoon.

abstract: There is strong hope that this rebellion will be crushed out sooner than we have heretofore hoped, from the fact -- which we learn by one of the most bitter howls of the Richmond Examiner -- that whisky has gone up again, and that not even a drink of "Commissary" can be had over a Dixie bar for less than one dollar and fifty cents. Let Northern mudsills think of it, but not drink of it, and bless the happy fate that has not left them floundering in a Richmond slough of despond. That eminent specimen of servile chivalry who was sent with fifty dollars to buy bread and whisky, and after laying out forty-nine dollars in the last, and a dollar in the first, was blamed for buying so much bread, would have a small chance just now in Richmond.

abstract: The Tammany Mayoralty Convention met at noon yesterday, and unanimously nominated FRANCIS I.A. BOOLE for Mayor. The Mozart Convention, which was in session for the purpose, promptly and cordially indorsed the nomination. Committees from both Convention -- one headed by JOHN CLANCY, Tammany, the other by BENJ. FAIRCHILD, Mozart -- waited on Mr. BOOLE, notified him of his nomination, and escorted him to Tammany Hall, where he was cordially welcomed. He modestly accented the nomination, acknowledging his obligations therefor, expressing his appreciation of the responsibilities of the position, and his determination, if elected, to assume them, and endeavor to meet them for the best interests of the public. His remarks were enthusiastically received.
lead_paragraph: The Tammany Mayoralty Convention met at noon yesterday, and unanimously nominated FRANCIS I.A. BOOLE for Mayor. He modestly accented the nomination, acknowledging his obligations therefor, expressing his appreciation of the responsibilities of the position, and his determination, if elected, to assume them, and endeavor to meet them for the best interests of the public. His remarks were enthusiastically received.

abstract: The return of Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER will be made the occasion of a welcoming demonstration in Brooklyn. He was in Boston yesterday, and is expected to be in Brooklyn on Monday. It being understood that he objects to anymore public or formal reception, his Sunday School will held its annual Festival, at Plymouth Church, on Tuesday and Wednesday of next week, when he will be present. abstract: EXPLOSION OF GUNPOWDER IN A FANCY-STORE -- THE BUILDING SHATTERED AND A YOUNG GIRL INJURED. -- About 1 1/2 o'clock on Friday afternoon an explosion occurred in the fancy-store of Mrs. LYDIA BOOTH, No. 71 Hudson avenue, near Water-street, which resulted in great damage to the building and serious injury to a young girl (a servant) named BRIDGET DUNCAN. Mrs. BOOTH, it appears, was a licensed seller of gunpowder, and had on hand, as she states, about four pounds, which she kept in the usual manner, in cans, and had them placed upon the shelves. The first floor, which she occupies, consists of a front room, in which the store is kept, and a back sitting-room. An entry, leading to the upper stories, is detached from the rooms. The building is of brick, three stories in height. Mrs. BOOTH was sitting in the back room, while the servant (the girl DUNCAN,) was cleaning the stove, when, the powder exploding, completely demolished all that was in the stove, forcing out the windows and doors tearing out the partitions and shattering the house from foundation to roof. The ceiling of the basement was torn off, and the floor of the second story was heaved up to such an extent as to turn the stove upside down and scatter everything in the room. Officers BEDELL and PEARCE, of the Forty-second Precinct, who were passing at the time, entered the building and found the girl DUNCAN lying among the ruins, frightfully burned and otherwise injured. She was at once picked up and taken to the drug-store No. 50 Hudson-avenue, where her wounds were dressed by Drs. THEALL and YOUNG. She was then conveyed to the Brooklyn City Hospital. She stated to the officers that she was alone in the store; that she was using no light, and could not account for the accident. The loss sustained by Mrs. BOOTH amounts to about $1,000, and the damage to the building about $1,000 more -- insured in the Brooklyn Insurance Companies. The basement and upper stories were occupied by a number of families, all of whom sustained some injury.

abstract: Capt. MILLS and Officer NIVEN of the Second Precinct, yesterday arrested PHILIP MARTIN on the charge of stealing $1,500 in gold and silver coin, from JOHN PETERS of Portage, State of Michigan. The complainant alleges that the accused was engaged with him in the business of mining in the West, and about two weeks ago, when an opportunity offered he stole the above sum, which was nearly all complainant was worth, and suddenly decamped. He was traced to this City by Sheriff SULLIVAN, of Houghton County, Michigan, arrested, and is now on his way back. Nine hundred dollars of the stolen money were found on his person.

lead_paragraph: The marriage ceremony between Senator (and Ex-Gov.) SPRAGUE, of Rhode Island, and Miss KATE CHASE, the beautiful and highly accomplished and eldest daughter of the Hon. Secretary of the Treasury, took place last evening, at 8 1/2 o'clock, at the residence of the bride's father, corner of Sixth and B streets. Although the contemplated nuptials have been the occasional subject of newspaper comment for some time past, yet to the public at large the definite time of the marriage was not announced until within a day or two past.

abstract: A correspondent of the Salem Register, writing from Denver City, announces the arrival there of a number of Texas refugees. They represent the condition of Texas as terrible in the extreme. Last Fall, in Wise and an adjoining county, sixty-three men were hung for the crime of devotion to their country. Gen. MAGRUDER has issued an order that all deserters shall be shot, as they tend to injure the army. Thousands of Texans are still loyal -- a loyalty that is intense in its character.

abstract: The Anglo-Japanese War
lead_paragraph: The British force which lately assailed Kagosima was more formidable, the fight more desperate, the result more tragic, than the account via San Francisco led us to suppose. This is evident both from the telegraphic report of the affair published in the London papers, and from the news in relation to it just brought by the East Indian mail. The squadron which, under Admiral KUPER, bombarded Kagosima, consisted, of two frigates and five smaller vessels. Sudden as was the advent of the British, the Japanese were not unprepared for them. The forts mounted over 90 guns, including four 150-pounders and some 13-inch mortars, mostly American. Hardly had the squadron taken up position in front of the city, when the shore batteries opened fire, which was promptly responded to by the ships, and thus began an engagement that lasted until dark. The retainers of Prince SATSUMA fought bravely, served their cannon well, and inflicted serious damage on their assailants -- for the British had, according to their own statement, thirteen killed, fifty wounded, and so many of their vessels disabled that, as soon as night put an end to the conflict, they deemed it prudent to return to Yokahama to refit. This retreat must be regarded as a triumph for the Japanese; but it was a Pyrrhic victory, since the garrison failed to save Kagosima, which, with its palaces, factories and arsenals, was a pyramid of flame at the close of the day. What became of the unfortunate inhabitants, we are not told, yet if we bear in mind that they numbered in the morning near 200,000 souls, and that the attack of the British was unexpected, we may form some idea as to their fate.
headline: {'main': 'The Anglo-Japanese War.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Anglo-Japanese War.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: American Legal Decisions, Quotations of
lead_paragraph: The ingenuity and industry with which both the English Courts and the Press have searched through the whole history of our jurisprudence for precedents to justify their action in the case of the rebel privateers, would be something admirable in any other cause. Not an allusion has been made by the Ministry or (as far as is known) by the Judges to the hundreds of cases in our reports where we have acted toward belligerents in the most liberal spirit of international comity. The Government Press has scarce ever spoken of those numerous decisions, which have given a new character of fairness and justice to international law -- all the more to be commended in that they were usually decisions against Americans and in favor of British claimants. As we have before shown in these columns, the whole direction and uniform practice of our Government and Courts have been directly against the recent ruling and practice of the English Courts with regard to assisting a belligerent with armed vessels.
headline: {'main': 'English Quotation of American Decisions.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'English Quotation of American Decisions.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Richmond Examiner congratulates the Confederacy on the conversion of the faro-banks in Main-street, of that city, into restaurants -- a conversion which it seems is rapidly being made Anything that tends to the moral elevation of that portion of the people of the United States, must be a matter of congratulation, even more so to us than to them, but still the question painfully suggests itself to us, what are they going to cook. In the present state of Confederate markets, unless these retired gamblers are allowed to makeup a little game to pluck a pigeon or two, or try a hand on a fiat fish, it is hard to see how they will get along. They certainly will not be such cannibals as to broil the king, copper the queen, or serve up the jack on the half-shell.

abstract: Atlanta is really the heart of the Southern States, and therefore the most vital point in the so-called Confederate States. The towns of Rome and Marietta, which would also fall, manufacture one-third of the horse-shoes, guns and munitions of war made in the South. The machinery for the production of small arms has been taken to Atlanta, which place has several extensive foundries. All the machinery from the foundries at Chattanooga has likewise been shipped to Atlanta. Besides it is a flourishing city, an important railway centre, and extensive depot for Confederate commissary stores, Atlanta to the South, is Chicago to the Northwest, and its occupation by the soldiers of the Union would be virtually snapping the backbone of the rebellion.

abstract: -- The death is announced of the head of one of the most distinguished Roman Catholic families in England, Mr. JOSEPH WELD, of Lulworth Castle, Dorsetshire. Mr. JOSEPH WELD was born on the 27th of January, 1777, and was the third son of Mr. THOMAS WELD, of Lulworth, the founder of Stonyhurst College. His eldest brother, THOMAS, on the death of his wife, in 1815, took orders in the Church of Rome. In 1829 Pope Pius VIII. made him a Cardinal, the first English Cardinal since the Pontificate of CLEMENT IX. Cardinal WELD transferred his estates to his brother, though he himself did not die till April, 1837. In August, 1830, Mr. WELD received CHARLES X. and the exiled royal family of France at his ancestral seat, which had previously been visited by royalty, viz.: by JAMES I., CHARLES II., JAMES II., GEORGE III., and GEORGE IV. (when Prince of Wales.) CHARLES X. and his family remained the guests of Mr. WELD for some days, till their removal to Holyrood Palace. Mr. WELD was a Roman Catholic, as his family had been for centuries, but he was a liberal and tolerant gentleman. His tenantry in Dorsetshire never felt the pressure of the religious "screw," and it was known throughout the estate that the word and the honor of "WELD of Lulworth" were pledged to abstinence from religious bigotry.
lead_paragraph: -- The death is announced of the head of one of the most distinguished Roman Catholic families in England, Mr. JOSEPH WELD, of Lulworth Castle, Dorsetshire. Mr. JOSEPH WELD was born on the 27th of January, 1777, and was the third son of Mr. THOMAS WELD, of Lulworth, the founder of Stonyhurst College. His eldest brother, THOMAS, on the death of his wife, in 1815, took orders in the Church of Rome. In 1829 Pope Pius VIII. made him a Cardinal, the first English Cardinal since the Pontificate of CLEMENT IX. Cardinal WELD transferred his estates to his brother, though he himself did not die till April, 1837. In August, 1830, Mr. WELD received CHARLES X. and the exiled royal family of France at his ancestral seat, which had previously been visited by royalty, viz.: by JAMES I., CHARLES II., JAMES II., GEORGE III., and GEORGE IV. (when Prince of Wales.) CHARLES X. and his family remained the guests of Mr. WELD for some days, till their removal to Holyrood Palace. Mr. WELD was a Roman Catholic, as his family had been for centuries, but he was a liberal and tolerant gentleman. His tenantry in Dorsetshire never felt the pressure of the religious "screw," and it was known throughout the estate that the word and the honor of "WELD of Lulworth" were pledged to abstinence from religious bigotry.

abstract: A number of scoundrels  and scallawags round town, who never were in any way connected with the army, are adopting the garb of the soldier as a conveni-...  ence in carrying on the profession of a beggar. Some of them are horrible-looking wretches; some are diseased; some have wounds, (not received in the service of the country;) some are thieves and drunkards, and most of them...
lead_paragraph: -- A number of scoundrels and scallawags round town, who never were in any way connected with the army, are adopting the garb of the soldier as a conveni-... ence in carrying on the profession of a beggar. Some of them are horrible-looking wretches; some are diseased; some have wounds, (not received in the service of the country;) some are thieves and drunkards, and most of them are "old stagers," who have been for years "plying their avocation," (as Gen. BUTLER would say,) but who hope to conceal their identity or secure greater success by figuring as used-up veterans or played-out heroes. One disgusting-looking creature, afflicted with St. Vitus' dance, traverses Broadway with open mouth and distended paw, and clad in the full rig of a high private of the Union army, though his appearance stamps him unmistakably as a member of the order of Neapolitan lazzaroni; and there are other cases nearly as bad which confront one from time to time on the streets.

lead_paragraph: As there is every reason to believe that we will soon be able to choose between the certainty of Independence, on honorable terms, and a prospect of annexation on such terms as the final action of the United States Congress may admit, it behooves us to weigh carefully the gains and risks of each alternative; and it is much to be lamented, that from the excitable character of our population, dispassionate judgment is too apt to disappear at a time like this when most needed.

abstract: The Board of Enrollment of the Sixth District, which has been in an unsettled condition ever since its organization, is at an end. The appointment of Deputy Provost-MARSHAL FARR, Commissioner LAMONT and Surgeon POWELL, have been revoked by direction of the President, and yesterday Lieut. BARGER, of Gen. HATS' office, took charge of the office. So far as the Commissioner and Surgeon are concerned, it is understood that against them there were no charges preferred of either want of capacity for or neglect of duty. It is understood that Provost-Marshal-Gen. FRY has recommended the appointment of THEODORE B. BRONSON, son of the late Judge BRONSON, for vacant Deputy Provost-Marshalship; ROBERT EDWARDS, of the Ninth Ward, as Commissioner; ALFRED L. LOOMIS, M.D., of the Sixteenth Ward, as Surgeon. What the construction of the new Board will be, however, is as yet uncertain. The following is the order assigning Lieut. BARGER, to the charge of the office:

abstract: There is no startling news from the Army of the Potomac this morning. Beyond cannonading for an hour or more in the direction of KILPATRICK's camp, near Stevensburgh, arising probably in a determination to drive off a too curious reconnoitering party of the enemy, nothing disturbed the stillness of the camps. The rain on Saturday night was incessant, but it had not greatly impaired the roads. Gen. MEADE was yesterday in Washington in protracted consultation with President LINCOLN.

abstract: Mexican news by way of Havana states that the Interventionists have been defeated recently in various engagements by the troops of the Juarez Government, and that the party of the Republic was rapidly gaining strength and the support of the people.
lead_paragraph: Mexican news by way of Havana states that the Interventionists have been defeated recently in various engagements by the troops of the Juarez Government, and that the party of the Republic was rapidly gaining strength and the support of the people. Gen. COMONFORT was at the head of the National troops. Guerrillas had attacked the mail-coach and English express from the City of Mexico to Vera Cruz, capturing all the correspondence, among which were important communications for the Mexican Commissioners now in Europe. The Franco-Mexican forces had entered upon a new campaign, and the friends of intervention are eagerly anticipating the arrival of MAXIMILIAN, whose presence they hope will restore peace by the bringing about of confidence in the stability of the new regime.

lead_paragraph: We publish this morning a most interesting and important series of rebel documents, official and unofficial, which were found on the blockade-running steamer Robert E. Lee, captured on the 9th inst., off Wilmington, North Carolina. They are very late in their dates, and furnish us most entertaining views of the rebel operations in France and England -- of their operations in the way of diplomacy, and in the way of obtaining ships, running the blockade and furnishing supplies to the Confederacy. Whether it be Mr. DE LEON exhibiting his intrigues, exposing to JEFF. DAVIS his "inmost thoughts" and begging for money -- or Mr. P., talking about poverty and "humbug" -- or Mr. STRINGER laboring to get two and a half per cent. -- or Lieut. DOWNING rollicking and in debt -- or Mr. HUSE excoriating his fellowknaves and swindlers -- or whether it be the curious exhibition of the plans and workings of the rebel "Mercantile Trading Co." -- each is notable and valuable, and will well repay perusal.

abstract: Election, the Approaching
lead_paragraph: It is, perhaps, too soon yet to look for much earnest interest in our Charter election, which is to take place two weeks from to-morrow. But there is reason to apprehend that the friends of honest administration will not make half the contest they ought. Some of the results in the late State elections, particularly the choice of the notorious MCCUNN for a high Judgeship, over such a man as Judge BOSWORTH, have sickened many good citizens of all effort against the nominations of Tammany and Mozart. The feeling is prevalent that the bad classes are bound to hold municipal power, and that it is simply labor lost to try to prevent it. It is a wrong feeling, and the action, or rather inaction, which it prompts, is in the highest degree, pernicious.

abstract: Mr. MARETZEK'S season is drawing rapidly to a close. The present is the last week but one of his Fall campaign. On the 1st of next month the Academy will be handed over to the Germans under Mr. ANSCHUTZ; they will retain it for three months. Mr. MARETZEK is, as usual, making every effort to add...
lead_paragraph: Mr. MARETZEK's season is drawing rapidly to a close. The present is the last week but one of his Fall campaign. On the 1st of next month the Academy will be handed over to the Germans under Mr. ANSCHUTZ; they will retain it for three months. Mr. MARETZEK is, as usual, making every effort to add brilliancy and variety to his final programmes. The present week will be unusually interesting. To-night we are to have "Il Trovatore"; on Wednesday "Ione"; and on Friday MOZART's masterpiece, "Don Giovanni." In this last named work all the artists of Mr. MARETZEK's troupe take part. An addition is, in fact, made to the company in order to render the cast perfect. We refer to Mmme. STRAKOSCH, who will appear as Donna ELVIRA. The remaining characters are thus distributed: Don Giovanni, Signor BELLINI; Leporello, Signor BIACHI; Count, Signor MAZZOLENI; Mazetto. Signor COLLETTI; Donna Anna, Mmme. MEDORI; Zeriina, Mlle. KELLOGG.

abstract: -The Canadian authorities have acted in extreme good faith toward our Government, in giving it notice of the projected rebel raid upon our Northern frontier. It was a thoroughly friendly act, and as such should be remembered. There seems to have been no doubt of the reality of the plot. Some hundreds of rebels, under the lead of officers, had actually arrived on Canadian soil, provided themselves with funds by the sale of cotton, which they had brought through the blockade, and were intending to liberate the rebels held by us as prisoners on Johnson's Island. There seems to be very little doubt that it was also part of their plan to destroy Buffalo, Detroit, Ogdensburgh, and other frontier towns, and to have set a rebel privateer at work among the commercial shipping of Lake Erie. The scheme was a bold one and would have done great mischief, but for the timely notice of the Canadian authorities.
lead_paragraph: -The Canadian authorities have acted in extreme good faith toward our Government, in giving it notice of the projected rebel raid upon our Northern frontier. abstract: In the nomenclature of medicine there is no disease so little thought of and yet none, when permitted to become chronic, so subtle or so fatal in its character as catarrh. It often originates in coryza,  or ordinary cold, and as such, when the inflammation is local, extending not beyond the Schniederian membrane, it is readily reached and with proper attention may be removed.
lead_paragraph: In the nomenclature of medicine there is no disease so little thought of and yet none, when permitted to become chronic, so subtle or so fatal in its character as catarrh. It often originates in coryza, or ordinary cold, and as such, when the inflammation is local, extending not beyond the Schniederian membrane, it is readily reached and with proper attention may be removed. When, however, it is neglected, the disease rapidly but silently spreads itself, and soon the patient finds himself surrounded by a web of diseases that are certain to carry him to the grave, unless he is fortunate in finding one who, knowing the gravity of his case, applies remedies that cannot fail to reach and ultimately destroy not only the parent affection, but all the attendant horrors that follow in its fiery train. From coryza, catarrh may develop itself into gravedo, attacking the frontal sinuses, and then we have what is called "cold in the head:" if from the nose and head it extends to the fauces or posterior part of the mouth, sore throat results, which rapidly spreads to the glottis and pharynx, inducing cough and hoarseness, and, following these, we have (provided the affection is not arrested) opthalmia, deafness, the paralyzation and eventual destruction of the digestive organs, and last stage of all, phthisis. Thus we have the origin and some of the phenomena of a disease which, often proceeding from cold, ends in death. The acrid matter which is secreted in the nose and head, where abscesses are formed, drops on the tongue; and thence, as it burns its way down the throat, attacks the stomach, and presently the villous coating is affected. With offensive breath, the tongue is often swollen and the skin removed, and the action of the papillae paralyzed, if not utterly destroyed. There are many other affections that originate in catarrh which it is not necessary to speak specifically of in this place, as we desire to present, in the person of one who is notorious in our City, a striking example of how far, when improperly treated, catarrh may undermine the physical constitution, and then how readily it can be made to yield to scientific treatment.

abstract: As before announced, the return of Mr. BEECHER from his tour to Great Britain and the Continent is to be celebrated by his congregation in fitting style. Never at a loss in devising resources for securing rational and positive enjoyment, there is a probability that on this occasion they will furnish the lovers of good things with a better opportunity than ever before for testing their abilities in this direction.
lead_paragraph: As before announced, the return of Mr. BEECHER from his tour to Great Britain and the Continent is to be celebrated by his congregation in fitting style. Never at a loss in devising resources for securing rational and positive enjoyment, there is a probability that on this occasion they will furnish the lovers of good things with a better opportunity than ever before for testing their abilities in this direction. At the Sunday school festival, to be held on Tuesday and Wednesday evenings of this week, and for which more extensive preparations have been made than for any former festival, the whole building is to be thrown open to the guests, and different rooms have been assigned to different features of the entertainment, so that passing from one to the other a pleasing and brilliant variety will be exhibited, well calculated to make the beholder forgetful of the flight of the passing hour. The Committee of Arrangements have spared no pains or expense to make the occasion one that shall do honor to their pastor and to Plymouth Church. The attendance of HELMSMULLER's Germania Band has been secured, and this is in itself a sufficient guaranty that the devotees at the shrine of St. Cecilia will not go away unsatisfied. FALLON's Stereoscopticon, displaying several hundred beautiful views of scenery, celebrated buildings, statuary, &c, &c., will be exhibited each evening in the main audience room. There is to be a bountiful display of flowers and evergreen wreathing and mottoes, and it is understood that an entirely original feature, in the shape of a bower about the fountain in the Sunday-school room, is preparing. It is here that the flowers are to be sold. The festival is also to serve as an opportunity for celebrating the presentation by Mr. BEECHER to the Sunday-school, before his departure for Europe, of the large painting -"The Ruins of Ancient Tusculum," by GEORGE L, BROWN, the celebrated colorist and delineator. Mr. BEECHER is expected to speak on both evenings. The annexed is the programme for Tuesday evening:

abstract: Rumors reach here to-night of cavalry fighting today on the Rapidan. Firing was heard yesterday in the direction of Stevensburgh, and again to-day in the same direction. The rebels captured a wagon train yesterday near Stevensburgh. The cause of the firing to-day is not known up to this hour, 11 P.M.

abstract: The French in
lead_paragraph: The last number of the Westminster Review contains a summing up of the history of the French expedition to Mexico, which in many places reads somewhat like a sketch of the coup d'etat of December the Second. The mixture of fraud and force by which the French army has been carried to the City of Mexico bears a pleasing and remarkable resemblance to that by which the French nation was brought under the ennobling influences of the second empire. We all remember that the nearer the time approached which had been fixed by the "brethren of the Elysec" for the overthrow of the French Republic, the louder became their expressions of devotion to the Republican Constitution. Their course with regard to Mexico was somewhat similar. The nearer they got to the work of conquest the more solemnly they assured the world that conquest was odious to them.

abstract: The plaintiff in this action keeps a boarding-house at No. 20 Union-square. Some time in April, 1863, the defendant engaged rooms and board for himself and wife from the 1st of May to the 1st of October, 1863, for the sum of $25 per week. Defendant came to plaintiff's house pursuant to said agreement, and boarded with her until July 1, 1863, when he left. Plaintiff now brings this action to recover $268 for the balance of the time, for which these rooms were engaged. The defendant admits the hiring of the rooms, but alleges that in taking them it was agreed on the part of plaintiff that he should have his breakfast at seven o'clock when he should require it, that his room was to be properly furnished and cleaned, that his room was to be put in order by the servants during break, fast hour each morning, that he was to receive prompt attention and be promptly waited upon by the servants, that the accommodations were to be satisfactory. And defendant alleges that these conditions were not complied with, but defendant's rooms were so badly cared for and cleaned, and that they were not put in order during the breakfast hour; that he could not obtain proper attendance from the servants; that when defendant first went there the table was good, but afterward it was so badly provided for that defendant found it very unsatisfactory, and left before the term for which he had taken the rooms had expired, as he claims he had a right to do.

abstract: The great gun, which has been for some months in course of construction for the navy by Mr. JOHN ERICSSON, arrived in this City a few days ago, and is now at one of the Iron Works being prepared for service. For obvious reasons we are not permitted to state its location. It is one of the most marvelous inventions of the time, and if successful, will revolutionize naval ordnance.
lead_paragraph: The great gun, which has been for some months in course of construction for the navy by Mr. JOHN ERICSSON, arrived in this City a few days ago, and is now at one of the Iron Works being prepared for service. For obvious reasons we are not permitted to state its location. It is one of the most marvelous inventions of the time, and if successful, will revolutionize naval ordnance. Mr. ERICSSON contracted, some time since, to construct some 13-inch smoothbore guns, which are to have a much greater initial velocity than any now in use. He is to receive nothing for them unless they burn over 50 pounds of powder; for every pound of powder beyond 50, Mr. ERICSSON is to receive $5,000. He is confident of being able to burn 100 pounds, and is certain of burning 75 pounds. The solid shot will weigh 220 pounds. The English 68-pounder, (of 12,500 pounds,) said by H.R.H. the Duke of Cambridge to be the most powerful gun in the English service, with 10 pounds of powder, (nearly one-fourth of the charge.) has an initial velocity of 1,800 feet per second, and, therefore, a punching power against iron plates of 27,500,000 pounds. The rifled guns, with charges of one-tenth to one-twelfth of the shots, and the 15-inch gun, with a charge of thirty-five pounds to its shot of 425 pounds, have velocities ranging from 1,100 feet to 1,400 feet per second. The 300-pounder Parrott has, therefore, a punching power of 42,000,000 pounds, and the 15-inch gun of 55,500,000 pounds. The new gun, with 75 pounds charge, (one-third of the weight) will have as great a velocity as the 68-pounder, and its punching power will be 55,000,000 pounds, or exactly double that of the English gun. With 100 pounds of powder its velocity should be raised to 2,000 feet, and its punching power will be 68,000,000 pounds. It will thus be by far the most formidable gun yet constructed. The great superiority of our new guns to those in use by foreign Powers will readily be noticed.

abstract: The Board of Canvassers met at noon yesterday and completed the canvass, with the exception of one district, the returns from which were sent back for correction on last Saturday. This district is the Tenth of the Eighth Ward. The returns are believed to be defective on the vote for Superior Court Judges, because they give no votes for Judge MCCUNN, whereas the Police reports gave him 173 votes in that district. On motion of Mr. TWEED, the Canvassers who sent in the returns were ordered to appear before the Board, at noon on Wednesday, to explain the supposed omission. Upon the settlement of this matter depends the important question whether Judge BOSWORTH or Judge MCCUNN is successful in attaining the Superior Court Bench. By the official canvass, and an allowance of 173 votes for MCCUNN in that district, he is elected over Mr. BOSWORTH by a 160 majority; but if the District Canvassers can clearly show that their returns as made are right, then Mr. BOSWORTH triumphs by a majority of 13. Judge McCUNN has been in constant attendance throughout the canvass. The passing upon these doubtful returns, footing up the tables of the canvass and making the declaration of results, are all that remains for the Board to do.

abstract: The recruiting office of the County Committee, Mayor OPDYKE, Comptroller BRENNAN, Supervisors BLUNT, PURDY, STEWART and WEED, is open at No. 240 Broadway, and ready for a rush of volunteers. The call they make is for 30,000 men. The total of Government, State and County bounty to each man is $677 -- enough to buy a farm with, almost, and for veterans an additional bounty of $100.

abstract: There is a  strong movement on foot for the nomination of Gen. Dix for mayor. It has its origin apparently in the ranks of the Democratic party, with men of position and character, who are dissatisfied with the selection made by the two wings of that party, and seek to rally the people en masse to the support of another man.
lead_paragraph: There is a strong movement on foot for the nomination of Gen. Dix for mayor. It has its origin apparently in the ranks of the Democratic party, with men of position and character, who are dissatisfied with the selection made by the two wings of that party, and seek to rally the people en masse to the support of another man. No better selection could possibly be made for the accomplishment of such an object than that of Gen. DIX. While he enjoys the confidence of the whole community as a man of high-toned integrity and of unstained honor, his course as a citizen and a soldier, since the commencement of the war has commended him most cordially to the regard and esteem of every man who loves his country better than party and than personal success. There is no man in the City, and probably none in the State, who would command a larger popular vote on his personal merits and character than he.

abstract: TWENTIETH WARD CLUB OF INDEPENDENT CITIZENS. The members of this Club, composed principally of the most prominent German citizens of this Ward, held a meeting last Friday evening at Nehring's Hall, No. 465 Eighth-avenue, for the purpose of nominating candidates for Police Justice and Councilman. The meeting was largely attended, and a unanimity of action prevailed. After the ordinary business was disposed of the President of the Club.
lead_paragraph: TWENTIETH WARD CLUB OF INDEPENDENT CITIZENS. -- The members of this Club, composed principally of the most prominent German citizens of this Ward, held a meeting last Friday evening at Nehring's Hall, No. 465 Eighth-avenue, for the purpose of nominating candidates for Police Justice and Councilman. The meeting was largely attended, and a unanimity of action prevailed. After the ordinary business was disposed of the President of the Club, LORENZO ACKERMAN, Esq., stated, in forcible and eloquent language, the necessity of nominating only those who are well known for their upright dealing and integrity of purpose, and who would command the votes of all honest citizens irrespective of party influence. Mr. ACKERMAN's remarks were, much applauded, and, at their conclusion, the Committee proceeded to business. On motion of Mr. KEINHARD, Judge QUACKENBUSH was unanimously nominated for reelection as Police Justice, and VALENTINE COOK for Councilman.

abstract: The first two of a course of lectures, to be given in the large hall of the Cooper Institute, under the auspices of the Womens' National Loyal League, were delivered last evening. The principal address was given by Mrs. GAGE, late Superintendent of Contrabands at Paris Island, S.C. This was preceded by a few remarks by Mr. GREELEY. Partially owing, doubtless, to the unpleasantness of the weather, the audience was not so large as sometimes assembles on similar occasions.
lead_paragraph: The first two of a course of lectures, to be given in the large hall of the Cooper Institute, under the auspices of the Womens' National Loyal League, were delivered last evening. abstract: On Sunday morning, about 5 o'clock, the Hendrik Hudson, on her down trip from Albany, came into collision with a schooner attached to a tow. The morning was pitch dark, and the steamer was under good headway. The schooner struck her, tearing away all the railings, guards, and many of the staterooms forward the wheel-house, smashing in the wheel-house, and ripping away the side works and some of the staterooms aft -- in short, making a wreck of one side, and punching a hole in one of the boilers. The concussion was terrific, and the passengers, of whom there was a large number, were aroused, and rushed from berths in all kinds and lengths of garments; terrified on meeting the steam, and not knowing what fate awaited them, an indescribable scene ensued among men as well as women and children. No officers of the boat made their appearance to allay the terror, and it was some time before it was ascertained that danger of burning or sinking was not imminent. But in that "some time" there was a world of agony and apprehension to all on board. There was no damage done to the steamer beyond that stated. The accident occurred some forty miles from this City, and as a precautionary measure the Hendrik was run, with the aid of the remaining boiler, near the shore into shoal water, where daylight was awaited, when the trip was resumed to New-York, reaching here at 2 P.M. The Hendrik was loaded to within two and a half feet of her guards, and had, as a reliable informant states, neither Captain or first pilot on board! She was in charge of the second pilot. If there is no error in this statement, the People's Line are guilty of a most culpable indifference to the safety of those in ousting their lives to them. The tow which had done the damage went on its way, leaving the steamer to sink or swim. The remarkable feature of the occurrence is, that no one of the many on board the steamer was injured, either by the crush or steam.

The tow which had done the damage went on its way, leaving the steamer to sink or swim. The remarkable feature of the occurrence is, that no one of the many on board the steamer was injured, either by the crush or steam.

abstract: We are much  pleased to learn that the Government has been enabled to send supplies of clothing and victuals to our suffering prisoners in Richmond. lead_paragraph: We are much pleased to learn that the Government has been enabled to send supplies of clothing and victuals to our suffering prisoners in Richmond. There is now the double duty imposed upon the country of maintaining the rebel prisoners in our hands and the Union prisoners in the hands of the rebels. Even this, however, will cheerfully be borne, rather than that the gallant men who have offered their lives, and temporarily lost their liberties, in the cause of the Union, should continue to be subjected to such inhuman atrocities as the rebel Government is practicing upon them. If they retain our prisoners during the Winter, few would have returned to us alive after its close, unless some such means of relief had been adopted.

abstract: At the time for opening this Court, yesterday morning, no Judge made his appearance, and after waiting nearly an hour the Clerk sent for Recorder HOFFMAN. The Recorder soon made his appearance, and on taking the Bench, said that the City Judge had made no arrangement with him to hold the Court this week, and as he would be otherwise engaged during the day, he had only come in to adjourn the Court. He added that some arrangement would be made by which either he or the City Judge would be present this morning. This is Judge MCCUNN's term for holding the Court, but the official vote, which is fo determine whether he is elected to the Superior Court or not, is so close as to need his constant and watchful attendance on the Board of Canvassers.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- "Il Trovatore" -- well beloved but most hackneyed of operas -- attracted a good audience last evening. There is nothing beyond this circumstance to mention. The cast was as heretofore, and the performance passed off enthusiastically. The happy creatures who warmed to the familiar strains and encored all the barrel-organ pieces, had an opportunity of hearing the fine members of Mr. MARETZEK's company to the best possible opportunity. There was not a cold to divide amongst the lot. They all sang well and acted with spirit. It is worth mentioning here that the present week is the last in which Made. MEDORI will appear. The last night of Mr. MARETZEK's season will he devoted to GOUNOD's new opera of "Faust," in which Miss KELLOGG sustains the principal role.

abstract: Shortly before 7 o'clock last evening, flames were discovered issuing from the upper floors of premises No. 32 Beekman-street. The firemen were very soon on the ground, out owing to the combustible nature of the material, the entire upper portion of the premises were soon a mass of fire. Mr. ISAAC J. OLIVER, steam job, card and fancy printer, occupied the third, fourth and fifth floors of this building, and also the front portion of the second floor. As will be seen the fire originated on his premises. His loss on stock, fixtures and machinery will probably amount to over $10,000. The office of The Irish American located in the rear part of the second story; the stock, machinery and fixtures of which were mostly destroyed. The damage could not be definitely ascertained, but it will probably amount to over $1,000.

abstract: Four days later news from Europe is received by the City of London, which, arrived at this port last evening. The advices are interesting, though mainly unimportant. The matter of the seizure of the rebel privateer Alexandra had again been before the English Court of Exchequer on the 3d inst., but the hearing was postponed to the 5th, and the London journals had renewed their discussions of the case. Among the items of English news is the information that Lord PALMERSTON is co-respondent in a divorce suit, and the subject is a fruitful topic of Email talk. LOUIS NAPOLEON's speech on opening the French chambers is reported to have been of a pacific character. He proposes a European Conference for the settlement of the Polish question. In view of the difficulties between Denmark and the German confederation on the Schleswig-Holstein question, Austria intends to send a portion of her fleet from the Adriatic to blockade the Danish ports. The state of affairs in Poland shows no change. Continued activity on the part of the insurgents was reported. The advices from Austria indicate that MAXIMILIAN is making preparations for his trip to Mexico. FRANCIS JOSEPH has decided upon authorizing such Austrian officers as may wish, to accompany the Archduke, with the view of cooperating in the military organization of Mexico, and do so with the faculty of reassuming their grade in the Austrian army on their return.
