abstract: Rev. C.C. GOSS closed, on Sunday, his series of interesting and valuable discourses on "The Moral Aspects of our City," in the Tabernacle on Broadway. "Down Town," and the agencies by which it can be elevated, was the topic of the discourse. He made Fourteenth-street the line between the two sections of our City. There are 15 Wards below and seven above. Two-thirds of the territory is above. Half of the population ate below. The increase below during the past five years has been 58,672. This increase extends to all these lower Wards except the Second, Third and Fourth, where there is a small decrease. In spite of this the speaker showed that 47 church edifices had become extinct during the past 20 years, and that in thirty instances none had been erected in their place. There is now only 123 places of worship of all kinds -- only 80 Pastors to 500,000 persons; only 25,00O are found in the churches at any one time. Thousands of the toiling who have to eke out a miserable existence on low wages, seldom attend church; they are not able to clothe themselves decently. He was glad, he said, that so many of them are striking for their rights. Mr. Goss then showed that the mortality down town was greater than up-town, caused by the crowded condition in which many lived; 6,000 families live under ground. The youth, too, are growing up immoral and dangerous. In the down-town region there are 80,000 between the ages of 5 and 15; over 51,000 of these are as yet unreached by Sunday school effort; they are the Goths and Vandals of our City. He also showed that much the largest half of our police and police expenses are down town; 80 out of the 122 engine companies are there; also all of our places of amusement, from the respectable to the immoral; thieves, gamblers, and all other vile characters lurk in secret there. After the legitimate business of the day ends, the nefarious night business begins. Cheap suburban homes, cheap railroad fare, and a practical application of the principles of the Gospel were the remedies presented for the existing evils.

abstract: Failures of the Rebellion
lead_paragraph: The Greek tragedians were fond of introducing upon the stage the hereditary misfortunes of particular families, which, for some inexpiable sin committed by one of their line, were doomed to be the victims of a Divine persecution. Whatever these unfortunate people undertook -- whatever they set their hearts upon -- was sure, before long, to turn to their destruction. Wherever they went, they were attended by an evil genius, which spread panic among their armies, disloyalty among their subjects, and disorder among their kinsmen. The ghosts of murdered relatives never left them. They took peculiar pleasure in attacking them when they were most off their guard. They incited nightmares to jump upon their stomachs when they were asleep, and insinuated poison in their cups when they were revelling in the banquet. No plan was above their power, no place beyond their reach.

abstract: -- The terrible damage to American commerce from the depredations of the rebel privateers, is the subject of a memorial to the Secretary of the Navy, signed by a number of the most eminent insurance, shipping, banking and business firms of New-York. They refer to the great loss of individual wealth, to the injury inflicted upon a valuable source of material power, to the endangering of the very existence of our mercantile marine, and to the mortification of our National pride as "citizens of the first naval Power on the earth," by a "couple of indifferently equipped rebel cruisers." They allude to the fact that while in one quarter of the year 1860, more than two-thirds of our carrying trade was in American bottoms, and but one-third in foreign vessels, only one-third of it was in American bottoms in the corresponding quarter of this year, and two-thirds in foreign ships; and in this connection they might have alluded to the large number of American ships that have been sold, for safety, during the past year to British purchasers. They refer to the "almost total absence of efficient naval force in many of the great highways of commerce," and to the "want of adequate armed vessels on prominent naval stations for protection of our ships." At the same time they compliment the Navy Department upon its "patriotic zeal and energy," and close by urging it to "give the subject the benefit of the same energy and ability which has so creditably marked the administration of the Department in all other channels of its official duties."

abstract: New-York Central
lead_paragraph: The prostitution of the New-York Central Railroad to advance the fortunes of a political party in its attitude of hostility to the National Government in the crisis of the great rebellion, is not, after all, the most serious charge against its management. Even in such case, it is possible that it might be managed with a good degree of economy, although it could not be long before political considerations would supersede all others, to the total destruction, perhaps, of the interests of the stockholders. In no other Company would such prostitution be tolerated for an instant. Should Mr. MARSH, of the Erie Road assume to enact the role of Mr. CORNING, he would not be allowed to remain twenty-four hours in his place. The long lapse of time in which the abuses of the Central have been persisted in, has, as in the case of our City Government, given a sort of prescriptive right to their continuance.

abstract: Our Paris correspondent intimates that the French Government intends to apply to our own for a recognition of the new regime in Mexico, on condition that the French leave the country as soon as MAXIMILIAN is firmly seated on the throne. We doubt the story. The question of recognizing a new Government is one which the French Emperor is not likely to broach to our Government just at present. Besides, there can be no propriety in recognizing a Provisional Government, or in recognizing any Government until it is firmly established: and after that has been done, recognition will follow as a matter of course. We do not see that we are called upon to interfere in Mexican politics at all for the present. If the Mexicans choose to establish an Empire, with MAXIMILIAN or anybody else for Emperor, we shall undoubtedly recognize that fact after it becomes a fact, but not before.

abstract: GENERAL ORDER, No. 47. The Committee in charge of the arrangements for the dedication of the National Cemetery for the freemen who fell on the field at Gettysburgh have appointed that the ceremonies shall take place on Thursday, the 19th of November, 1863.
lead_paragraph: GENERAL ORDER, No. 47. -- The Committee in charge of the arrangements for the dedication of the National Cemetery for the freemen who fell on the field at Gettysburgh have appointed that the ceremonies shall take place on Thursday, the 19th of November, 1863. The duty of specially inviting parties to participate has been left to the committee, but the attendance of the surviving Pennsylvania soldiers of the war of 1812, and of the war with Mexico, in 1846, would be so appropriate and acceptable as to justify the expression of an earnest wish that they shall be present in a body, and as a mark of respect for the memory of the dead, and as due to the solemn purposes of the day.

abstract: Militia
lead_paragraph: Whatever affects the militia of our City interests us all, and when we are apprised of any obstacle in the way of its advancement, or any danger threatening its general welfare, we hasten to its relief with as much ardor as it has hastened to defend the Union. Twice in the course of our civil war the Government has found occasion to depend upon the militia of this and the neighboring States, and its chief support in both instances has proceeded from the militia of this City. The timely aid it furnished at the commencement of hostilities saved Washington from capture and held Maryland in the line of loyal States. It has been under fire in many battles, and manifested the spirit and coolness of veteran corps. It has made forced marches, and been subjected to exposures equal in severity to any borne by the hardiest soldiers. Composed largely of men whose business interests suffer from their absence, it has never shirked its duty, but marched unhesitatingly to the field whenever an emergency demanded. It must always be remembered that its action has been voluntary, and in response to a sense of patriotic duty only. It has never been forced to the field. During the late invasion of Pennsylvania, two of our most recently formed regiments -- the Thirty-seventh and Twenty-second -- held Carlisle against a superior force and under heavy fire, and saved it from threatened destruction. All remember the relief afforded us during the riot-week of July by the intelligence that "our brave boys" were marching homeward.

abstract: -- The Government would very greatly expedite the raising of volunteers if it could assure those who may enlist now that they should receive any additional bounties that may be offered to recruits hereafter. Hitherto, a man enlisting at the outset for a specified bounty, sees others enlisting six months later receiving twice as much. This has been repeated so often, that men who intend to volunteer naturally postpone it as long as possible, in the belief that the Government will increase the bounty in proportion to its own increasing necessities. This ought to be remedied. Let a man understand that he will lose nothing by enlisting early, and volunteering will proceed with much greater rapidity.

abstract: ARREST OF A RIVER THIEF AN AMUSING SCENE AROUND THE TOMBS. Officers SULLIVAN and CORNELL, of the Harbor Police, arrested a notorious river thief named JOHN SULLIVAN, on the charge of having stolen, upon several occasions recently, large quantities of rope from vessels to the harbor.
lead_paragraph: ARREST OF A RIVER THIEF -- AN AMUSING SCENE AROUND THE TOMBS. -- Officers SULLIVAN and CORNELL, of the Harbor Police, arrested a notorious river thief named JOHN SULLIVAN, on the charge of having stolen, upon several occasions recently, large quantities of rope from vessels to the harbor. While the prisoner was going up the steps of the Tombs, in charge of the officers, he suddenly halted, and before the officers had an opportunity to see what he was doing he, the prisoner, with one dexterous movement divested himself of his shoes and his coat, and thereby released himself from the grasp of his captors. Then began a most amusing and interesting chase. The escaped prisoner darted off with the fleetness of a deer, and ran first up one street, then down another, around one entire block, then running through the middle of the street for several rods, every step he took leaving blood on the sharp stones, which had cut his bare feet almost to the bone. The prisoner was fast getting the best of his pursuers, notwithstanding their cry of "Stop thief" and the crowd of men and boys who followed close upon his heels, when a Sixth Ward Policeman caught him as he was turning the corner of Mott and Baxter streets. He was taken back to the Tombs, and after examination, locked up for trial.

abstract: Return and Reception at Plymouth Church
snippet: Return and Reception at Plymouth Church
lead_paragraph: In this day of feasts, fasts and ovations, there is nothing in an ordinary entertainment to call for more than a slight and passing notice; and, unless there be something peculiarly interesting or significant in the affair, it is not likely to receive much attention outside of the little circle who take part in it. The Metropolis has of late been dazzled by the splendor of the balls, fetes and receptions given in honor of the representatives of the Czar, and later still by a splendid banquet given at Irving Hall in honor of Admiral REYNAUD and his officers; and on Mr. BEECHER's return from his tour of several months' duration on the other side of the Atlantic, his church thought it fitting that there should be something more than words to express their congratulations upon his safe arrival among them, and in testification of their appreciation of him who has been for sixteen years their pastor. His love of children, flowers, music and sociality being well understood, it was determined that an opportunity should be presented for the gratification of these preferences in an entertainment which should bring the children together, and combine these several features appropriately and conspicuously.

abstract: At the meeting of the Board of Supervisors, yesterday, their legal adviser sent in a letter giving the opinion, in answer to a resolution of inquiry passed at the previous meeting, that they have the right to remit or reduce an uncollected tax after the expiration of six months from the time of delivering the tax books to the Receiver of Taxes, in cases where application for a remission or reduction is made to a member of the Board within that period. The Committee on the riot damage claims reported a number of claims for payment, and they were laid over; they also reported in favor of paying sundry bills for subsistence and rations furnished to various militia regiments that served during and subsequent to the riot. These bills amount to about $35,000, and are allowed at the uniform rate of forty cents a ration. Quite the largest of them is the claim of STETSON & CO., of the Astor, who put in for $9,353 25, and are allowed only $1,650 05. These bills were also laid over. The Board adopted resolutions, offered by Mr. BLUNT, condoling with Supervisor DAVIS in his bereavement by the death of his wife, and to attend her funeral on Wednesday. Adjourned to Tuesday next at 3 o'clock P.M.

abstract: Hard Up
lead_paragraph: -- It is very melancholy to see a martyr reduced to extremities. So long as his martyrdom makes him popular, there is something inspiring and heroic about it; but a professional martyr who fails is a sad sight. VALLANDIGHAM seems to be in this category, His old Democratic friends are reproaching him with having caused their defeat in Ohio. Several of the Western Democratic papers are speaking of his having adopted an "unfortunate theory" in regard to the war, with which the people do not sympathize! That is a very mild way of putting it. One of them says that it is better that "a dozen Vallandighams should go under" than that the Democratic party should be ruined by his mistakes. While the country alone suffered from his "peculiarities," these journals were quite resigned; but when the party was endangered, things wore quite a different aspect. But nothing can show the desperate and dismal condition of poor VALLANDIGHAM's fortunes better than the fact, announced by the last foreign steamer, that he has taken to writing letters to WM. CORNELL JEWETT. That's the last stage of political delirium tremens. Our neighbor GREELEY could have warned him against it.

abstract: A lady correspondent, who is a very large employer of her own sex, offers through our columns some sharp criticisms upon the present effort of the "working women" of the City to obtain higher prices for their labor. She thinks that the skilled labor of women is already well enough paid, and that their unskilled labor is paid well enough. The principal objection she makes to the high remuneration of women's work, as compared with that of men, is that the work of women at trades and in business is for them but a temporary expedients -- marriage being the proper aim and end of their life -- after which incident their working, for a livelihood ceases; while with men, after that event, the ordinary avocations are not only continued, but there is a necessity for still greater efforts. The point, we confess, is very neatly and well taken. Notwithstanding the correctness of the position; as a general principle, there can be no doubt that the present rise in the cost of living, for women as well as for men, makes it imperative that there should be a corresponding increase in the rate of remuneration of the industrial women of the City.

The point, we confess, is very neatly and well taken. abstract: -- Senator SPRAGUE and his lovely bride left the Fifth-avenue Hotel yesterday afternoon, en route for Providence, R.I. The sudden departure of the bridal party has caused some disappointment to many of their friends in this City, who had made arrangements to offer them the compliment of a serenade. The fire in the hotel on Monday night compelled a postponement to last evening, but the honored guests had left. During their stay, in the City they have, of course, been the subject of much gossip, the ladies of the hotel having read all about the bridal trousseau -- the robes, the pearls, the diamonds, the lace, the silver, and all the magnificent gifts of this Millionaire Wedding -- displayed an anxiety to investigate the toilettes of the lady for themselves, and a general curiosity in regard to all those little matters in the personal appearance of a bride of two days, which possess such a fascinating interest for the fair sex. They will probably pass through the City again in a few days, when the gentlemen who proposed to give them the musical treat will have another opportunity.

abstract: FOR THE NORTH ATLANTIC BLOCKADE SQUADRON. -- The United States steamer Newbern sailed from this port yesterday, for the North Atlantic blockade squadron. She had on board an immense cargo of stores and provisions, and a number of passengers, among whom were many officers and some sailors. The crew of the Newbern has not been increased, notwithstanding the narrow escape they recently had of being captured by rebel prisoners on board. The following is a list of the Newbern's officers: Acting-Master and Executive Officer, R.Y. Hollery; Acting-Master, J.H. Richardson; Acting-Ensigns, Milton Webster, Chas. Millet, and C.H. Lawyer; Acting-Assistant Surgeon, John F. Cobb; Acting-Assistant Paymaster, J.H.C. Cushing; Captain's Clerk, Thos. J. Benjamin; Paymaster's Clerk, Henry Y. Stoole; Engineers -- Acting-First-Assistant, Isaac Maples; Acting-Second-Assistant, John E. Cooper; Acting-Third-Assistants, Francis C. Lomas, Samuel Hoffman, R.C. Raney; Acting-Master's-Mates, Geo. abstract: The Rochester Democrat publishes statistics of the apple crop of Monroe County, N.Y., this year, showing that 135,000 bbls. were shipped from Rochester, and 66,500 bbls. from Charlotte. Of the amount shipped from Rochester, about 22,000 bbls. passed through the canal warehouse of FISH, ELLISON & CO. The tables' figures swell the grand total to nearly 400,000 bbls. shipped from Monroe County this season.

abstract: The Supervisors' Committee to procure volunteers under the last call of the President have organized by selecting Mr. ORISON BLUNT as Chairman, and Mr. CORNELIUS CORSON, Clerk. The choice of Mr. BLUNT was made with hearty unanimity, he having given the utmost satisfaction as Acting-Chairman...
lead_paragraph: The Supervisors' Committee to procure volunteers under the last call of the President have organized by selecting Mr. ORISON BLUNT as Chairman, and Mr. CORNELIUS CORSON, Clerk. The choice of Mr. BLUNT was made with hearty unanimity, he having given the utmost satisfaction as Acting-Chairman of that body when they acted under the former $2,000,000 ordinance, as the "County Substitute and Relief Committee." Mr. BLUNT is an indefatigable worker, and possesses the qualifications of large practical experience and keen foresight, besides a thorough knowledge of human nature, to aid him in the discharge of his very responsible duty. His sagacity penetrates men and their motives in pubic affairs with extraordinary facility. Few men in the enjoyment of the wealth he has amassed by long years of unceasing industry and activity would consent to labor as he does, in the discharge of his official duties; but a thorough love of country and an earnest desire to be of aid to it in its existing crisis prompts him to the most zealous devotion to obtain men for the army. In addition to his duties as Chairman of this Committee, which will soon become onerous and require a large share of his time, he spends the greater part of each afternoon and evening in investigating the riot claims.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon a most outrageous homicide was committed by a driver of one of the "Dry Dock" line of stages. The victim was Mr. HUGH LANCEY, residing at No. 335 Tenth-street, a gentleman over 55 years of age. The driver is well known among his associates by the name of "Dutch Smith." What his real name is did not transpire.

abstract: A writer in the Manchester Examiner sums up an elaborate review of the Cotton crop prospects for 1864 thus: "First, that the production of Cotton in other countries than the Southern States of America is steadily increasing, the imports of 1864 exceeding probably those of 1862 by one million of bales, thus lessening exclusive dependence upon one source of supply; secondly, that the three countries which have shown the most eager desire to contribute to this result -- Egypt, Turkey and Italy -- possess advantages in climate, soil and facility of access to the English market which enable them to compete successfully with the Southern States of America, not only in quality, but also in cost of production. The writer is confident that in a few years the coast of the Mediterranean will furnish an annual supply of two millions of bales. Of India he does not take so hopeful a view. So long as high prices prevail she may furnish a considerable quantity of Cotton; but when this stimulus is withdrawn, and the day of competition returns -- as return it will -- then, it is thought, will she descend to her former subordinate position in the Cotton markets of the world. This result, he says, will be owing to the inferiority of her staple, the imperfection; of her agriculture, the ignorance of her ryots, the frauds of her middle-men, and the indifference of her rulers.

The writer is confident that in a few years the coast of the Mediterranean will furnish an annual supply of two millions of bales. Of India he does not take so hopeful a view. So long as high prices prevail she may furnish a considerable quantity of Cotton; but when this stimulus is withdrawn, and the day of competition returns -- as return it will -- then, it is thought, will she descend to her former subordinate position in the Cotton markets of the world. This result, he says, will be owing to the inferiority of her staple, the imperfection; of her agriculture, the ignorance of her ryots, the frauds of her middle-men, and the indifference of her rulers.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- "Ione" was played here last night, with unusual success. The four artists to whom the principal roles were intrusted have seldom been in such excellent voice. Mme. MEDORI was superb, and Signor MAZZOLINI fairly excelled himself. These artists -- and Mlle. SULZER and Signor BELLINI, who in their roles were equally good -- received the unusual honor of a double recall before the curtain, after the second act, and again after the third. The opera in every respect was admirably rendered.

abstract: The New-York Historical Society celebrated its 59th anniversary on Tuesday evening. Notwithstanding the inclemency of the weather, the rooms of the Society in Second-avenue, were crowded with a distinguished and appreciative audience, including an unusually large proportion of ladies. The exercises of the evening were opened by a prayer from the Rev. Dr. OSGOOD. Some routine business was then transacted, including the election of several gentlemen as resident and corresponding members, and after a few introductory remarks the President presented the Hon. ERASTUS C. BENEDICT, of this City, who delivered the address of the evening. His subject was "Early American History," chiefly in relation to its effect, upon American character. The speaker gave an interesting account of the early settlement in Virginia, New-York and New-England, bringing to light many new illustrations of the character and habits of the Colonial settlers. He was listened to with marked attention throughout, and at the close of his address received the thanks of the Society. After some further remarks from members present the meeting adjourned.

lead_paragraph: The recent decision of the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania throws a rather unexpected light on that remarkable letter which Gen McCLELLAN hastened to write too late in support of Judge WOODWARD. Our readers will recollect that the General had talked with the Judge and found that their views agreed, and one of the points upon which they agreed was that the Judge was "in favor of the prosecution of the war with all the means at the command of the loyal States." A great many men puzzled over that sentence. They felt as they read it that there was something wrong about it, because if it was to be understood as it fairly meant on the face of it, the only logical conclusion from it must be that both General and Judge should heartily support Gov. CURTIN, who was also heartily in favor of the prosecution of the war by every means in our power, instead of joining themselves with a party which indorsed every man who desired to hinder and disturb the Government in the prosecution of it.

abstract: Last evening closed the festival at Plymouth Church, and concluded the cordial welcome by the scholars to Rev. Mr. BEECHER. There was the same profusion of flowers, the wreathing wore the same rich green appearance, the canaries still poured forth their flood of song, while the emblems and mottoes seemed to lose none of their significance or appropriateness by being viewed a second time. In the Sunday School-room, the fountain and the bower surrounding it had lost none of their attractiveness, continuing to be a special object of admiration. It may not be improper here to state that the fountain, presented by a lady to the Sunday School at their first festival, is permanently located in this room. In its sparkling jet of limpid water, it must always be suggestive of the purity of which it is typical.

abstract: Julius Soeffler, by Bernard Soeffler, his Guardian vs. Claude P. Vuargnoz. -- This action is brought to recover the sum of $3,000 damages for personal injuries inflicted upon plaintiff in consequence of an assault by defendant upon him. The plaintiff alleges that on the 14th day of November, 1862, defendant violently assaulted him at the house No. 99 Franklin-st., struck him several blows, and held him by the throat, from which plaintiff suffered these injuries. The defendant denies the assault, and says that on the day in question plaintiff commenced fighting and quarreling with defendant's son, and in order that they might not injure each other, defendant took hold of plaintiff to separate them, using for that purpose only the necessary force.

abstract: In the matter of the habeas corpus in the case of Alexander Rankin, an old merchant of this City, committed by Police Justice Dowling to the Bloomingdale Asylum as a lunatic, Dr. Brown made return that the state of the patient was such as to prevent his attendance in Court. The counsel for the relator demurred to the return on the ground that one Police Justice had no power to commit a person to the Lunatic Asylum. The Court held that this question was open for consideration. On the suggestion of Mr. Shaffer, counsel for the relator, the Court appointed Drs. Francis L. Harris and Isaac Taylor to visit Mr. Rankin at the Bloomingdale Asylum, to investigate the facts as to his alleged insanity, and make report to the Court on the 25th inst.

abstract: The steamship Teutonia, with one day's later news from Europe passed Cape Race last evening. From a brief telegraphic summary we learn that the U.S. gunboat Kearsage had been notified to leave Cork harbor in 24 hours, but her commander prolonged his stay for the purpose of watching the blockade-runners in that port. The Alabama is reported to be cruising in the Bay of Bengal. The Poles had met with reverses in Volhynia. Grand Duke CONSTANTINE was to be relieved of his office of Governor of Poland by Gen. BERG, for the purpose of traveling abroad. The Spanish Cortez was opened on the 4th inst. The Liverpool Cotton market continued in a depressed state. Consols were quoted at 92 5/8@92 3/4.

abstract: LECTURE BY JUDGE KELLY, OF PHILADELPHIA. The next lecture in the course of the Women's Loyal National League will be delivered by Judge KELLY, of Philadelphia, at the Cooper Institute, on Friday evening of this week.
lead_paragraph: LECTURE BY JUDGE KELLY, OF PHILADELPHIA. -- The next lecture in the course of the Women's Loyal National League will be delivered by Judge KELLY, of Philadelphia, at the Cooper Institute, on Friday evening of this week. Judge KELLY is one of the most able and eloquent members ever sent to Congress by Pennsylvania. He bore a conspicuous part in all the discussions of the last three sessions, and was ever found on the side of justice, humanity and freedom. We hope he will have an audience worthy of his rare merits as a public speaker.

abstract: The County Canvassers met at noon yesterday, but immediately adjourned to 10 o'clock this morning, out of respect to Supervisor DAVIS, whose wife's obsequies were to take place at 3 o'clock P.M., and which the Board, as Supervisors, had resolved the day before to attend. Judge MCCUNN, with his counsel, and counsel for Judge BOSWORTH, were present to argue the question of allowing any alteration to be made in the returns from the Tenth District of the Eighth Ward, in case the District Canvassers should acknowledge the returns they have already made to be incorrect. The clerks to the County Canvassers figure out a majority of twenty-two for Judge BOSWORTH, and if the supposed defective returns are canvassed as they are now rendered to the Board, he will be declared elected. Then Judge MCCUNN doubtless will take legal proceedings to supersede Judge BOSWORTH by proving that votes were actually given for him in the District mentioned. On this fact he will claim that the returns were invalid, and that therefore the votes for Judge BOSWORTH ought not to have been allowed. These points gained would, it is believed, give him the election. The Canvassers, who are the best judges, will adhere to the returns as made by them. If MCCUNN goes to law in the attempt to recover an honor that votes did not confer upon him, he will receive a second condemnation which will give Mozart a riddance that they will thank their deities for. Mozart took MCCUNN because they had to, and "Phernandy Wud" never swallowed a more nauseating pill than his faith compelled him to in this man's nomination. He did swallow it, and so did Mozart, and all hands are heartily ashamed of it. Not one wanted to see him elected, and hence every one is satisfied.

abstract: The New-York and Harlem Railroad Company vs. The Forty-second-street and Grand-street Ferry Railroad Company; The Seventh-avenue Railroad Company vs. The Sixth-avenue Railroad Company; The Same vs. The Eighth-avenue Railroad Company. -- These cases were all argued before the Supreme Court. General Term, yesterday. The principal question involved was the right of the Legislature, after giving certain franchises to one Company to build a road over a certain route, to give to another road a right to run over the same or a portion of the same route. Decision reserved.

abstract: Wixcox, >amp;c., vs. Lee; Good Sold
lead_paragraph: Horatio R. Wilcox and Joshua Draper vs. Uriah M. Lee et al. -- This was an action to recover for goods sold to the defendants. In addition to a denial, the defendants, Ripley & Hoyt, set up a former action in the Marine Court, and a judgment thereon on a question of fact as a bar to this action. Evidence was introduced to prove the sale of the goods and the partnership of the defendants. The defendants proved that Hoyt nominally retired from the firm in February, prior to the purchase, but that the title of the firm remained as before; also that Hoyt continued to act at the place of business and kept his name up. It was not shown that any notice of dissolution was received by the plaintiffs or their agent. The goods were sold on a credit of eight months, and before the expiration of the credit the plaintiffs sued in the Marine Court.

abstract: -- Maj.-Gen. SICKLES has accepted the invitation of the Committee on Volunteering of the Union League Club to visit their club-house this (Thursday) evening, at 8 o'clock. They also propose to aid in recruiting in other ways.

abstract: A meeting of the Board was held last evening, the President in the Chair. The minutes of the last meeting were read and approved. A report from the Finance Committee was adopted. That from the Executive Committee of the Free Academy was laid over. The Special Committee, appointed to consider the subject of an increase of the salaries of teachers and other employes coming under the jurisdiction of the Board, reported in favor of an addition of 20 per cent. to the remuneration now paid to Principals, Vice-Principals and teachers, whose attendance is constantly required to carry on the business of the schools, and of 14 1/2 per cent. to that of additional teachers, janitors, &c. A similar Committee appointed to consider an increase in the salaries of professors, teachers, janitors, &c., engaged at the Free Academy, also reported favorably. Mr. FARR moved that both reports be laid upon the table, which was lost. Mr. SMITH explained that the rate of increase was intended to be left in the discretion of the local Boards of Trustees, they being restricted only from adding to any salary more than 20 per cent. After some little discussion, resolutions giving Ward Trustees the power indicated, and also specifically increasing the salaries of all engaged at the Free Academy, of evening school teachers, and of the immediate attaches of the Board of Education, were passed by an average vote of 24 to 4. Mr. A.V. STOUT made some remarks on the justice of increasing salaries at the present-time, and moved that the salary of the Clerk of the Board be also raised $500. Mr. FARR opposed the resolution, on the ground that he ardently desired to retain the present efficient Clerk in his position, but that if they went on increasing his salary from time to time, it would soon be so high that none but politicians would have a chance of obtaining it, After discussion, the resolution was adopted by 22 to 5. The Board then adjourned.

abstract: The arrest of Hon. J.R. GIDDINGS', United States Consul-General at Montreal, on charge of kidnapping, which was briefly announced by telegraph yesterday morning, was caused by the efforts of an unscrupulous fellow, hailing from this City, who managed to get himself arrested by the Canadian authorities, for having been concerned in the draft riots here last Summer. The Canadian detective who arrested him proved over-zealous in the matter, went to Mr. GIDDINGS for a note to Police Superintendent KENNEDY, of this City, simply saying he had a prisoner, and wanted pay for delivering him here, which Mr. GIDDINGS gave him, without asking any questions, and upon which the arrest of Mr. GIDDINGS is based. The whole thing is a groundless, flimsy, "confidence" affair, by which a rogue hoped to achieve a successful swindle. According to the Montreal papers, there is not the slightest ground on which to base the charge.

abstract: Echeveria vs. Barney, Revenue
lead_paragraph: Manuel Echeveria et al. vs. Hiram Barney. -- NELSON, C.J. -- This suit is brought to recover back an excess of duties paid under protest on an importation of wool, lead in bars, goat skins, and cotton, in the Spanish bark Teresita, by the plaintiffs, from Matamoras, Sept. 4, 1862. The duty paid and protested against was a discriminating duty of 10 per cent., claimed under the third section of the Act of 5th of August, 1861. The first and second sections of that act imposed certain duties on articles specially enumerated in each section.

abstract: Husted vs. Husted; Certiorari--Custody of a Child
snippet: Husted vs. Husted; Certiorari--Custody of a Child
lead_paragraph: In the Matter of the "Certiorari" on Petition of Peter V. Husted to Remove Proceedings on Habeas Corpus in Matter of Application of Amelia A. Husted for Custody of Adelaide M. Husted, an Infant. -- In this case a writ of habeas corpus was granted and the matter came up before Justice Clerke for a hearing. The defendant Husted made return that he had not the custody of the child and therefore could not produce her. This return was traversed by the relator, and after a protracted hearing, Judge Clerke held Husted guilty of a contempt in making a false return, fined him $100, and committed him to jail for twenty days and until the fine should be paid. The matter now comes up on certiorari to review the proceedings had before Mr. Justice Clerke. Just before the commencement of the argument Mrs. Husted was served in the Court-room with a complaint in a suit for divorce. Judge Dean moved to quash the writ, on the around that the proceedings below were merely interlocutory and not a final decision, and that the proceedings were still pending in the Court below; that the man had kept out of the way, and had never been committed to jail or arrested, and that a writ of certiorari only issued upon a final adjudication, which in this case had not been had; that Husted must first be arrested, and then he had his remedy by writ of habeas corpus. Judge SUTHERLAND said that he had no doubt but that Judge Dean was right, but as there seemed to be some doubt in the minds of the other members of the Court, the decision on the motion to quash the writ would be reserved.
headline: {'main': 'The Husted Case Can a Writ of Certiorari Issue Before Final Adjudication?; SUPREME COURT GENERAL TERM. Before Justices Sutherland, Leonard and Barnard.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Husted Case Can a Writ of Certiorari Issue Before Final Adjudication?; SUPREME COURT GENERAL TERM. abstract: Walsh vs. Washington Marine Insurance Co.; Scuttling by Captain
snippet: Walsh vs. Washington Marine Insurance Co.; Scuttling by Captain
lead_paragraph: Edwin Walsh vs. The Washington Marine Insurance Company. -- This action is brought to recover on an insurance policy on the ship Senator. The Senator sailed from this port, loaded with grain, and was lost at sea on the 27th of August, 1862, as is claimed by plaintiff, during a heavy gale. The ship was insured in five Companies. Only one, the Neptune, has paid the amount of its policy without contest. Suits are pending against the others. The defence allege that the vessel was so old and unseaworthy that she cropped to pieces; that she was not lost in a gale, but foundered in ordinary weather from weakness and being overloaded. The amount involved is over $35,000. The Captain of the Senator has been arrested, charged with scuttling the ship. The case has occupied the Court for several days. The evidence of well-known sea-captains, and of the plaintiff himself, was given at great length to show the seaworthiness of the vessel at the time of sailing. On the part of the defence the mates of the Senator were examined. The second mate, Mr. Thompson, testified that before sailing part of the cabin furniture, spare sails, cordage, &c., were sent ashore. That part of the lower hold was not stowed; that she commenced making water the evening of the first day out and on the fifth day she had five and a half feet of water in the hold. They had, in his opinion, no rough weather -- nothing more than a good stiff breeze. On the fifth day the master of the ship asked Thompson to go among the men and frighten them in regard to the condition of the vessel. In consequence of what Thompson told them, the men went aft to the Captain and it was decided to abandon the vessel. At that time the weather was calm and pleasant. The first mate was also examined and testified that with the assistance of the Captain he had scuttled the ship, although in the protest he swore that she was lost through the stress of weather. The witnesses for the defence were subjected to a rigid and lengthy cross-examination by plaintiff's counsel.

abstract: Thaddeus Hyatt vs. John Scudder, impleaded with Ellis B. Harned. -- This is a final hearing in equity for an infringement of the patent granted to Thaddeus Hyatt for vault covers, dated April 3, 1855, now so generally used in this City. The cause was argued by counsel on both sides. His Honor decided the suit in favor of Hyatt, sustaining the validity of the patent, and allowed a perpetual injunction to issue against the defendant.

abstract: From Havana, Nov. 14, we have interesting details of the movements and possible operations of the French army in Mexico, and the opposing Mexican forces. The French army, which is about to commence a new campaign, is said to number 18,000 men, while the available force under JUAREZ is variously estimated at from 12,000 to 20,000 men. From San Domingo the news is that the insurgents were being beaten in many small engagements, but the new Captain-General, VARGOS, was not very confident of entire and speedy success.

abstract: European War, the Symptoms of a
snippet: European War, the Symptoms of a
lead_paragraph: We have private advices from Russia, through one that cannot be mistaken, that the Czar is making preparations for war on an unprecedented scale, in respect to the recruitment of men, the replenishment of munitions, the construction of invulnerable vessels, the building of new forts and the strengthening of old ones, and in respect to everything needful for the mightiest defensive conflict. It is also declared that the national feeling among the people is daily becoming intenser and more warlike, and that the determination to sustain the Emperor in his high-toned foreign policy is universal.

abstract: The steamship Persia, at this port, from Liverpool, on the afternoon of the 7th inst., brings us two days, later advices. In addition to the destruction of the ship Bold Hunter, which has been already announced, the American ship John Watt has been destroyed by the pirate Georgia, and we are told that shortly before the Georgia put into Cherbourg she boarded upward of ninety vessels. We may, therefore, soon expect to hear, of more ravages upon our commerce. The application in Court of Exchequer for a new trial in the case of the gunboat Alexandra was granted on the ground of misdirection of the Judge, and the verdict of acquittal being in direct opposition to the evidence. In the matter of the ship Sir Robert Peel, whose seizure for alleged violation of the blockage of Matamoras, caused much stir in commercial circles, an agent has been dispatched by "Lloyd's Salvage Association," to inquire into the circumstances, and claim the ship and cargo. The blockade of Matamoras is now admitted to be effective by Paris authority, and a notice was posted in the Underwriters' Room at Liverpool advising no more shipments to that port. By order of the Government, whom rumor says, is a prospective customer for the Laird rams, the value of El Toussin has been fixed at £106,000, and the El Monnassir at £80,000. From the Continent, the most interesting news is the text of LOUIS NAPOLEON's speech at the opening of the French Chambers. It is a document of more than ordinary length, and there appears to be some difficulty on the part of the journals in interpreting its meaning -- some regarding it as being indicative of peace, and a minority as significant of the very reverse. The Polish question presents no new feature. Earl RUSSELL had addressed a note to the British Ambassador at St. Petersburgh, saying that the British Government did not wish to prolong the correspondence with the Russian Cabinet for the mere purpose of controversy, and a copy of the dispatch was given to Prince GORTSCHAKOFF. MAXIMILIAN it is thought will leave for his Kingdom of Mexico about the 1st of February prox.

abstract: About 1 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning, an affray occurred in front of No. 87 Walker-street, between three Italian musicians and some Germans -- the latter making the assault -- in the course of which a German named JOHN STUNN was fatally stabbed by VINCENT DE NUBILLO, an Italian. The latter was arrested, but the Coroner's jury rendered a verdict that he had acted in self-defence.

abstract: At a meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday, the Croton Aqueduct Board sent in a communication in regard to the construction of a storage reservoir in the valley of the Croton River. The subject was referred to a Special Committee, and Messrs. JEREMIAH, HARDY and OTTIWELL were appointed.
lead_paragraph: At a meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday, the Croton Aqueduct Board sent in a communication in regard to the construction of a storage reservoir in the valley of the Croton River. The subject was referred to a Special Committee, and Messrs. JEREMIAH, HARDY and OTTIWELL were appointed. The Comptroller sent in communications recommending transfers of $5,000 from the account of "Charities and Correction" to the City Inspector's Contingent Fund, and $10,000 from "Mount Morris-square" to "Lands and Places." The first proposed transfer was passed favorably, and the other was laid over. President WALSH gave notice that at the next meeting he should move to discharge the Special Committee on the subject of directing the Comptroller to pay the Hackley contract laborers the amount due them from such funds as the Comptroller holds to which Mr. HACKLEY's assignees are entitled, because the Committee had not yet acted upon the matter, and some of the workmen were much in want of the sums owing to them. The Board adjourned to Monday at 1 o'clock P.M.

abstract: Last evening at a meeting of the Loyal League Club at their rooms, in Union Square, Maj.-Gen. DANIEL E. SICKLES made a speech of considerable importance, in which he reviewed the relations of the army to the country at large, and offered some valuable suggestions on the subject of recruiting. The speech was warmly applauded, and will not be without a beneficial effect at this particular juncture of our National affairs.

abstract: The steamship Creole, Capt. THOMPSON, arrived yesterday morning from New-Orleans, bringing dates to the 10th inst. Further accounts from the Teche country concerning the attack on WASHBURN's column represents our whole loss in killed and wounded and taken prisoners at 677. The Indiana Sixty-seventh was captured almost entire; the Sixtieth Indiana and Ohio Ninety-sixth lost largely. The rebel force was as five to one. We only excelled them in artillery, by means of which, at short range, it is thought, we killed a large number of the enemy. It is reported that the Thirteenth army corps, now in the Teche country, is ordered back to Memphis.

abstract: -- JOHN REARDON. President of the "Dead Rabbit" association, was arrested yesterday for a felonious assault upon Officer MAHONEY, of the Sixth Precinct. He was also arrested on a second warrant for a brutal and unprovoked assault upon another party. REARDON, some time since, resigned as a policeman to avoid being turned out. He was indicted for a felonious assault -- firing three shots at a man -- was allowed to plead guilty to a simple assault before MCCUNN, who fined him six cents.

abstract: Address at Dedication of Gettysburgh Cemetery
snippet: Address at Dedication of Gettysburgh Cemetery
lead_paragraph: It was appointed by law in Athens, that the obsequies of the citizens who fell in battle should be performed at the public expense, and in the most honorable manner. Their bones were carefully gathered up from the funeral pyre, where their bodies were consumed, and brought home to the city. There for three days before the interment, they lay in state, beneath tents of honor, to receive the votive offerings of friends and relatives, -- flowers, weapons, precious ornaments, painted vases, (wonders of art which after two thousand years adorn the museums of modern Europe,) -- the last tributes of surviving affection. Ten coffins of funereal cypress received the honorable deposit, one for each of the tribes of the city, and an eleventh in memory of the unrecognized, but not therefore unhonored, dead, and of those whose remains could not be recovered. On the fourth day the mournful procession was formed; mothers, wives, sisters, daughters, led the way, and to them it was permitted by the simplicity of ancient manners to utter aloud their lamentations for the beloved and the lost; the male relatives of the deceased followed; citizens and strangers closed the train. Thus marshalled they moved to the place of interment in that famous Ceramicus, the most beautiful suburb of Athens, which had been adorned by CIMON, the son of MILTIADES, with walks and fountains and columns; whose groves were filled with altars, shrines and temples; whose gardens were ever green with streams from the neighboring hills, and shaded with the trees sacred to Minerva, and coeval with the foundation of the city; whose circuit inclosed

abstract: Speech at Dedication of Gettysburgh Cemetery; Cemetery; Dedication of the; Speech at Dedication of Gettysburgh Cemetery; Dedication of the
snippet: Speech at Dedication of Gettysburgh Cemetery; Cemetery; Dedication of the; Speech at Dedication of Gettysburgh Cemetery; Dedication of the
lead_paragraph: The ceremonies attending the dedication of the National Cemetery commenced this morning by a grand military and civic display, under command of Maj.-Gen. COUCH. The line of march was taken up at 10 o'clock, and the procession marched through the principal streets to the Cemetery, where the military formed in line and saluted the President. At 11 the head of the procession arrived at the main stand. The President and members of the Cabinet, together with the chief military and civic dignitaries, took position on the stand. The President seated himself between Mr. SEWARD and Mr. EVERETT after a reception marked with the respect and perfect silence due to the solemnity of the occasion, every man in the immense gathering uncovering on his appearance.

abstract: South and North
lead_paragraph: -An article recently published in Richmond on the Confederate cavalry, says that the cavalry arm of their service has recently become an "object of distrust, if not of contempt," and admits the great superiority and higher effectiveness of the Northern cavalry. It was of their cavalry that the rebels boasted loudest during the first year of the war. The ferocious Southern horsemen, the centaurs of the Southwest, were to trample down the greasy mechanics, small-fisted farmers, and mudsills generally, like weeds in their path. They were to ravage and play havoc all around. We in the North were inclined to tacitly admit the rebel superiority in this branch, and kept rather quiet about our cavalry at first, though there were some things, like TOMPKINS' charge through Fairfax Court-house, and ZAGONYI's charge at Springfield of which we felt justly proud. But two years have made a very great change. We have now a splendid body of cavalry, though not nearly as powerful as it ought to be; and during the bygone Summer and Autumn, they have met the rebels in a hundred fights of varying magnitude, from the great battle in June on the Rappahannock, down to hand-to-hand encounters between a half-dozen men, and in nearly every one of these actions the rebels have been worsted, as has been shown from time to time in the thrilling "Cavalry Record" of our correspondent, Mr. PAUL, and as the rebels themselves have at last reluctantly confessed. And now they are forced to own that the Southern cavalry, whose exploits were to be so terrible, have become an "object of distrust, if not of contempt."

abstract: Speech on Return from England; Address at Dedication of Gettysburgh Cemetery; Cemetery Dedication
snippet: Speech on Return from England; Address at Dedication of Gettysburgh Cemetery; Cemetery Dedication
lead_paragraph: We devote a broadside of this morning's TIMES to the publication of two orations which we are sure will command the attention of the day. And not of this day only. Elaborate and finished discourses from two such men as EDWARD EVERETT and HENRY WARD BEECHER, upon topics of such great National interest as those they discuss, will not lightly be passed over, much less ignored altogether, by any intelligent citizen. Mr. EVERETT's theme is the "Battle of Gettysburgh," and the occasion is the dedication of that historic field as a National Cemetery. Mr. BEECHER's discourse was upon his recent tour in Great Britain -- his experiences there, and his views as regards British feeling and policy toward this country.

abstract: East, the Situation in
lead_paragraph: The news from East Tennessee this morning is late and important. There seems to be no doubt but that the rebels are operating in considerable force against BURNSIDE from the Southwest, and that this force is a part of BRAGG'S army, detached for that especial purpose, and commanded, probably, by LONGSTREET. The dispatch speaks of the advance of the enemy as being made by the Kingston Road. Kingston, like Knoxville, is on the north bank of the Tennessee, but owing to a great bend in the river lies almost due west from the latter place, and distant about fifty miles. We have had no account of its occupation by the rebels, and they have probably avoided it, as it is too far to the left of their line. It now seems that the rebels, after compelling our troops to evacuate Loudon, on the river, thirty-five miles southwest of Knoxville, two weeks ago, crossed at that place and moved upon Knoxville. following the line of the railroad and bringing np supplies via Cleveland, Tenn. Knoxville has been the headquarters of Gen. BURNSIDE ever since he entered East Tennessee, and it is reported to be strongly fortified. It should not surprise any one if some of the ground in that section is yielded when threatened by a heavy force. Gen. BURNSIDE has been clearing out and occupying a district of country two hundred miles long by nearly one hundred broad, and his troops have been necessarily widely scattered. Sudden concentration is, therefore, a matter of supreme necessity, and some points heretofore held must be temporarily abandoned.

lead_paragraph: The County Canvassers met at 10 o'clock, yesterday morning, and the matter of the returns from the Tenth District of the Eighth Ward was immediately brought up. Anticipation of an interesting discussion upon it had attracted a crowd of spectators larger than the room would accommodate, so that, when it was well filled, the Sergeant-at-Arms guarded the door against the further incoming of any persons but those connected with the Board. Of those in attendance, there was a good sprinkling of politicians, including Ex-Mayor WOOD and his bother BENJAMIN, CHARLES S. SPENCER, Alderman MCCOOL, and others of minor political importance, besides counsel to represent both Judges BOSWORTH and MCCUNN. Messrs. BURRILL, JOHN GRAHAM and WM.C. NOYES appeared for Judge BOSWORTH, and Messrs. CLINTON and LEVI S. CHATFIELD for Judge MCCUNN.

abstract: The country looks with anxiety but without impatience, for a prompt and vigorous movement of the Union armies. The feeling is universal that we have men enough in the...
lead_paragraph: The country looks with anxiety but without impatience, for a prompt and vigorous movement of the Union armies. The feeling is universal that we have men enough in the field to whip the rebels, and that every consideration of the public good demands that an effort be made to bring the war to a close this year. We do not mean by this that there will be no more fighting, -- that the rebellion will be wholly subdued and the Union completely restored within that time. But it is believed that when the great rebel armies under LEE and BRAGG shall have been defeated, it will be found impossible to supply their places by others equally numerous and equally formidable, and that, so far as large operations are concerned, the war will have been substantially closed. There will continue to be local fights, and in many portions of the Southern States the spirit of the rebellion will continue to break out in hostile demonstrations against the Government. But these will be matters of secondary consequence, and can either be readily crushed or safely left to wear themselves out.

abstract: The County Canvassers met at noon yesterday, as per adjournment on Thursday. The lobby was speedily filled after the doors were opened, but some time elapsed before the Board were fully assembled. The Chairman, Mr. LITTLE, called the Board to order at 12 1/2 o'clock, when Mr. TWEED stated that the Corporation Counsel had prepared an opinion, in reference to the inquiry of the Board, which he had promised to send in by 12 1/2 o'clock, but as it had not arrived he moved that a recess be taken for half an hour. The motion was carried and the recess was taken.
lead_paragraph: The County Canvassers met at noon yesterday, as per adjournment on Thursday. The lobby was speedily filled after the doors were opened, but some time elapsed before the Board were fully assembled. The Chairman, Mr. LITTLE, called the Board to order at 12 1/2 o'clock, when Mr. TWEED stated that the Corporation Counsel had prepared an opinion, in reference to the inquiry of the Board, which he had promised to send in by 12 1/2 o'clock, but as it had not arrived he moved that a recess be taken for half an hour. The motion was carried and the recess was taken.

abstract: We have nothing new to offer on the "food question." The people must now rely for relief upon the action of Congress and the prowess of our armies. If Congress can adopt an effective plan for reducing the redundant currency, and compelling producers, by judicious legislation, to part with some of their hoarded supplies to pay a tax in money, as well as a tax in kind, the markets will, no doubt, be better supplied in future. But, after all, our main reliance rests upon the armies who are now confronting the hosts of the enemy. If they attain that success which every one hopes for, the reclamation of territory and restoration of general confidence, will do more to replenish the markets and cause a reaction in prices, than any financial measure which Congress may adopt.

abstract: We have always agreed with the author of Eothen that "this subject of 'woman' is so splendid, so terrible, so enchanting, so vast, and, in short, (to use the language of the polka dancers,) so 'catholic' that perhaps no...
lead_paragraph: We have always agreed with the author of Eothen that "this subject of 'woman' is so splendid, so terrible, so enchanting, so vast, and, in short, (to use the language of the polka dancers,) so 'catholic' that perhaps no imaginable treatment of it would ever seem quite satisfactory." Since Madame DEMOREST's communication of Wednesday, we feel it more than ever. She has quite satisfied us that we did not do the subject justice. We understand now what we wonder we never thought of before, that girls work to marry, and don't marry to work -- and that, consequently, their work is not worth a sixpence. In their haste to get to the altar most of them wont stop to learn any business properly; and the few who do, by the very act, become worth having as wives, and thus are pretty sure to get husbands, who, of course, would not let them continue at their trade, even if they were willing to do so, which never happens. Thus, good female workers are always scarce, and poor ones superabundant. Of course then, while the former are well paid, the latter are miserably paid, and always must be until we can contrive to change female nature or escape the laws of political economy. Madame DEMOREST employes about two hundred girls and women, at wages ranging from a dollar and a half a week to twenty. The cheap ones she can get any number of; the dear ones -- and she says it is a general complaint -- have "never been so difficult to obtain." Well, we have no idea of undertaking to change either female nature of the laws of political economy, and so we suppose we shall have to give it up. KINGLAKE is right. This subject of woman is very terrible.
headline: {'main': "Women's Work and Wages.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Women's Work and Wages.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: About 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon a man, whose name is unknown, entered a hotel known as the St. Nicholas, situated at the corner of Broadway and One Hundred and Sixteenth-street. He went into the bar-room, which is situated on the first floor in the rear, and in a short time he got into an altercation with the barkeeper, whose name is HENRY ALLEN. The result of the quarrel was that the unknown man seized ALLEN and cut him severely in several places with a rigger's knife. Deputy Sheriff JAMES E. MERIAM was at the time riding by the hotel in a stage. He heard loud cries of "murder." and thinking that assistance would be needed, he sprang from the vehicle, and went speedily to the bar-room. He found ALLEN down and the unknown man evidently trying to take his life. Mr. MERIAM rescued Mr. ALLEN from the grasp of his assailant, when the latter turned upon the Deputy Sheriff, and made a fierce attack upon him. It is reported that as a matter of self-preservation, believing himself to be in imminent danger, Mr. MERIAM drew his pistol, and shot his antagonist dead on the spot. The deceased was, probably, a longshoreman. This is thought to be the case, from some instruments which were found in his possession. Coroner NAUMANN will hold an inquest at 9 o'clock to-day, at the Thirtieth Precinct Station-house.

abstract: An intense excitement was created in Broadway, near Broome-street, about 2 o'clock yesterday morning, by an unprovoked and brutal assault upon a naval officer, JAMES B. SMITH -- some say a Captain -- by a huge brutal fellow, JAMES MURRAY, who claims to be a mate of a vessel. The latter attacked SMITH, a man half his size, beat and terribly disfigured him with brass knuckles, but was badly whipped and punished himself. He at the conclusion of the affair fled, but was chased and arrested by Officer FENTON of the Eighth Precinct. The Officer, JOHN B. SMITH, was intoxicated as was his assailant. The prisoner had two subordinate officers with him, who without interference witnessed the assault. Sergt. ELLLWORTH of the Eighth Precinct, to which all the parties were brought, locked up the burly ruffian MURRAY. On the word of honor of SMITH (who said he lived at No. 87 Prospect-place, Brooklyn,) and his two comrades, who said they would appear against MURRAY in the morning. Sergeant ELLSWORTH, instead of locking him and them up, as he might have done, as witnesses, let them go. They all deceived him and Officer FENLON, did not put in an appearance, and the ruffian, MURRAY, was, of course, discharged. The falsehood of these officers deserves the severest reprehension; it was a poor return for the kindness and courtesy shows them by Sergeant ELLSWORTH, Officer FENTON and others, and the uniform they wore was disgraced by it. If they are at this station the matter should receive further attention from their superior officers.

abstract: Neutrality--Alexandra Case Before Parliament; Alexandra, the, before Parliament
snippet: Neutrality--Alexandra Case Before Parliament; Alexandra, the, before Parliament
lead_paragraph: In the beginning of the discussion between Great Britain and the United States with regard to the rebel privateers, the Times, and some of the Ministry, publicly, claimed that a foreign country had nothing to do with their execution of a municipal act, like the Enlistment act. It was constantly asserted, even by high officials, that "England could not change her laws at the suggestion or direction of any foreign Power;" that the Foreign Enlistment act was purely local, and belonged to themselves alone. The usual haut en bas tone of the Tory Press was mimicked by English commercial men, and we were often treated to such phrases as "Laws cannot be changed in England as they are in the United States, in a moment;" "Mobs do not rule in Great Britain," and "We must obey law, you know!"

abstract: Artist's Fund, 4th Annual Exhibition
lead_paragraph: The fourth annual exhibition of the Artists' Fund Society, which is now open at the Derby Gallery, in Broadway, is not only the beat display they have made, but for interest, variety and general excellence has not been surpassed in New-York for several years. Beside the seventy paintings sent by members to be sold for the benefit of the fund, a large number of fresh pictures have been contributed by other artists. Several very valuable paintings have also been kindly loaned by their owners to add to the attraction of the exhibition. The fund pictures are to be disposed of at auction, Dec. 21, at the gallery. Every member contributes a picture, to be sold for his annual dues, which is the same for each, and whatever of surplus there may be is returned to him, so that painters of established reputation may take the benefit of the very liberal feeling manifested, and consequent high and often extravagant prices obtained on these occasions.

abstract: Piracy, Alexandra; Argument in Court of Exchequer
snippet: Piracy, Alexandra; Argument in Court of Exchequer
lead_paragraph: In the Court of Exchequer on the 5th, the Attorney-General said that in the case of the Alexandra, which was an information arising out of the seizure of the ship Alexandra, on the 5th of April last, by the Crown, for the violation of the Foreign Enlistment act, he had humbly to move their Lordships for a rule to show cause why there should, not be a new trial on the ground of misdirection by the learned Judge, and also on the ground that the verdict was against the evidence. When he spoke of misdirection, he must be understood to include in that the omission to give a proper direction, and also giving a direction which might in one sense be justified, but which had a tendency to mislead, and might have misled the jury. The learned gentleman then stated that the information was filed by the Crown on the 25th May last, on the seizure of the vessel, which took place in the yard of Messrs. MILLER & SON, shipbuilders, at Liverpool. There were ninety-eight counts in the information, that number being rendered necessary by the rather complicated structure of the clause of the Act of Parliament on which the information was founded. In substance to charged the persons whom he would mention with various acts against a certain section of the Foreign Enlistment Act. The persons charged in the record were these: The members of the firm of MILLER & SONS, the builders of the vessel, and in whose yard she was when she was seized; the firm of FAWCETT & CO., manufacturers of machinery at Liverpool, who came forward as the claimants of the vessel; the firm of FRAZER, TRENHOLME & CO., who were proved to be the general agents for the business of the Confederate States at Liverpool; a person named Capt. BULLOCK, the special agent for the business of those States; and a person named TESSIER, who was also employed in that business. Those persons, together with others not known, were charged in every count of the information with different acts in violation of the Foreign Enlistment Act. The separate counts were founded on the language of the seventh section, which was directed against the "equipping, furnishing, fitting-out, or arming" of a ship or vessel, or attempting to do so, with the intent of employing such ship or vessel in the belligerent service of a foreign people or state against persons with whom her Majesty was not at war. The learned Counsel then pointed out that the words "equipping," "furnishing" &c., were employed in the disjunctive sense, and observed that the Crown did not charge "arming" in the information.

lead_paragraph: A meeting of property holders upon the line of the upper part of Seventh-avenue, was held yesterday afternoon, at the office of Mr. McCLAVE, in Pinestreet. The object of the meeting was to push forward a movement, now some two or three years in abeyance, for widening that part of Seventh-avenue which leads from the top of the Central Park toward the Harlem River. abstract: By the arrival of the City of Baltimore at Cape Race, yesterday morning, we have four days' later news from Europe. There are no specially important features reported. Lord PALMERSTON had made a speech at the Lord Mayor's banquet,...
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the City of Baltimore at Cape Race, yesterday morning, we have four days' later news from Europe. There are no specially important features reported. Lord PALMERSTON had made a speech at the Lord Mayor's banquet, in which he deplored the American war, and said England would have interfered, but for the belief that it would have been in vain. The French Emperor's proposal for a European Congress attracted much attention, but no answers had yet been received. The English Cabinet were considering it.

abstract: Of all diseases, there is none more prevalent, deleterious, and yet more neglected, than Catarrh. Few realize the fatal consequences of neglecting it, and, consequently, are not cognizant of how many diseases to which it is inducive.
lead_paragraph: Of all diseases, there is none more prevalent, deleterious, and yet more neglected, than Catarrh. Few realize the fatal consequences of neglecting it, and, consequently, are not cognizant of how many diseases to which it is inducive. It is truly surprising that, of a disease so prevalent, and exercising such pernicious effects on the system, so little should be known by both professional and non-professional. It is much to be regretted that the medical faculty should have paid so little attention to it, or otherwise much suffering would have been relieved, and undoubtedly many might have been saved from a premature grave. But, nevertheless, it is a fact that cannot be denied, hundreds, yes, thousands, being living witnesses to this fact, and how many that are gone none can tell. In consequence of their total ignorance of it, and exerting themselves in no way to gain more information on the subject, hundreds of nostrums, in the shape of snuffs, have sprung up like mushrooms, as the panacea for the disease in all its stages; and, worse than this, these very snuffs have been recommended by physicians. Not willing to admit their ignorance of the disease, the patient is dismissed when applying for aid, with the answer that "Catarrh can never be cured." Try a little snuff, says one; a little fine salt and sugar, says another; snuff up a little cold water, says a third. If these remedies are not prescribed, it is either neuralgia or the effects of a cold, which will soon wear away. Alas! how many there are that wear away before the cold does! Being a regular Physician myself, and at one time a general Practitioner, nothing disrespectful is intended to the general practitioner, as, feeling that their services are but too little appreciated, it would be foreign to my object to wish to make the slightest imputation, but in a work like this, where the health, comfort, and even lives of thousands are at stake, it is not only impossible to avoid, but absolutely necessary to criticise, even though it be harshly. It will be seen from this that really nothing that could be beneficial has been done. Consequently there are many that believe that the disease can never be cured, added to which, their having been told by those in whom they naturally placed confidence, that "Catarrh can never be cured." has tended to make them more positive in their opinions. It must be remembered by such that this is a progressive age. Science has made and is making gigantic strides. Many things that could not be done when they were boys, and which had one hinted of being ultimately done, would have brought down the ridicule of those before whom he should have been so foolhardy as to venture the assertion, have been accomplished. The sciences of both Medicine and Surgery have not been behind hand, but have kept pace with the other branches of science. How many operations in by-gone times, now performed with facility and success, were then looked on as not only impracticable, but absolutely impossible. Why then may I not ask, should not more have been learned of Catarrh and an effectual method of treating it?

abstract: In the case of MALCOLM CAMPBELL and JAMES CAMPBELL, the brothers who are charged with shooting WM. KETELTAS, at No. 32 East. Thirty-first-street, on Wednesday night previously reported in our columns the accused were a rested on Thursday...
lead_paragraph: In the case of MALCOLM CAMPBELL and JAMES CAMPBELL, the brothers who are charged with shooting WM. KETELTAS, at No. 32 East. Thirty-first-street, on Wednesday night -- previously reported in our columns -- the accused were a rested on Thursday night by Roundsman GANNER, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct. According to the Ponce returns they were arraigned before Justice Kelly at the Jefferson Market Police Court, and held to bail to answer in the sum of $1,000. Our reporter yesterday afternoon was told, by a clerk of the Police Court, that the papers in the case could not be seen. The clerk at the same time said on Wednesday a sister of the CAMPBELLS committed suicide at No. 11 East Thirtieth-street. No report of this suicide has come to the notice of the reporters from the Coroner's office, although two days have since elapsed.

abstract: In the  morning papers of Thursday it was stated that, as one of the Dry Dock stages was going up town, the driver had some dispute with a passenger, an elderly gentleman,...
lead_paragraph: In the morning papers of Thursday it was stated that, as one of the Dry Dock stages was going up town, the driver had some dispute with a passenger, an elderly gentleman, named HUGH CLANCY, about the fare. Failing to agree, the driver stopped the stage, dismounted, dragged the passenger out at the door, struck him repeatedly and severely about the head, and finally knocked him down, his head striking the curbstone. No one seems to have interferred -- no policeman seems to have been present or to have been called. Mr. CLANCY was taken home, where he died of his injuries; and it was added that the police were looking for the driver. Yesterday morning it was announced that the driver had been found, arrested, and held to bail in the sum of $1,000!

abstract: Our special correspondent with the Army of the Potomac writes, under yesterday's date, some particulars of the cavalry skirmish last Wednesday. It resulted from a desire of the enemy to feel our entire front; and a body of their infantry crossed the Rapidan in the night-time, for the...
lead_paragraph: Our special correspondent with the Army of the Potomac writes, under yesterday's date, some particulars of the cavalry skirmish last Wednesday. It resulted from a desire of the enemy to feel our entire front; and a body of their infantry crossed the Rapidan in the night-time, for the purpose of cutting off the First Michigan cavalry, which was doing duty near Germanna Ford. Major BREWER, commanding the Union force, was too wideawake, and the plan of the rebels would not work. After skirmishing an hour or two, they returned to the opposite bank of the river. Similar movements on the part of the rebels all along our front were alike futile. A flying rumor also reaches us from Washington, that Gen. LEE is falling back on Richmond, and that our cavalry have occupied Madison Court-house. The news is not confirmed and is probably untrue.

abstract: Hon. WM. D. KELLY, of Philadelphia, delivered a lecture last evening in the large hall of the Cooper Union, on "The Duty of the Hour," under the auspices of the Womens' Loyal National League. He declared that the duty of the present was not emancipation preeminently, for the people of the States where Slavery existed were already acting in the matter; put that it was to take measures for the education and elevation of the freedmen, and to obtain and impart to others a just and adequate idea of the destiny of our country.

abstract: The United States vs. 1,382 Boxes of Sugar.  This action was brought to forfeit the goods for an alleged violation of the Revenue laws. The case was tried before a jury, and a verdict for the defendant rendered on May 29, 1863.
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. 1,382 Boxes of Sugar. This action was brought to forfeit the goods for an alleged violation of the Revenue laws. The case was tried before a jury, and a verdict for the defendant rendered on May 29, 1863. A motion for a certificate of probable cause was thereupon made by the United States District Attorney at the same term, which, after various adjournments, was argued before the Court on June 12, and an order denying the motion was made by the Court dated June 16, 1863, and filed June 24, 1863.

abstract: Already upward of one hundred men, under magnetic or propulsive influence of seven hundred and seventy-seven dollars, cash in hand paid, have volunteered under the new call, Think of it -- enough to make a wife and family comfortable for a year and more. The Supervisors' Committee are wide awake, energetic, earnest. They deal in greenbacks exclusively, and they pay them down, and protect the recruit from the sharks and brokers afterward. The Committee want many more men, but from indications will not want any in three weeks from date.

abstract: -- Lieut.-Col. N.B. Bartram, late of the Seventeenth (two years') New-York Volunteers, has been appointed Lieutenant-Colonel of the Eighth United States Regular colored troops, now forming near Philadelphia. Col. B. is a resident of Portchester, Westchester County. He passed successfully a very thorough examination before the Military Examining Board in Washington, of which Gen. Casey is President. The Government has made choice of a brave, and meritorious-officer.

abstract: Orders for sailing next Monday have been issued to the Russian fleet. 'Tis well; liberality, hospitality, friendship have been exhausted upon the representatives of the Czar, and a continuance would naturally make them so commonplace as to, as naturally, make them appear valueless. There is an old adage about "too much of a good thing," &c., and it is applicable in this case. During the visit of the Russian Admiral and his officers to this port, they have not only afforded an opportunity for us to evidence our appreciation of the friendly disposition of their own Government, but they have undoubtedly made hosts of warm and permanent friends. On all occasions they have evinced the kindest feeling, and the kindest and most courteous deportment. They will be parted with less regretfully, not that we no longer wish to have them with us, but that the repertoire of hospitality has been exhausted. With the noble old Admiral and his gallant officers and crews will go the best feelings of the public with whom they have so ingratiated themselves. The fleet go to Fortress Monroe, where it iwnters for gunnery practice.
