abstract: The People vs. Peter V. Husted. -- The order on its face is an order of the Supreme Court. This order is brought up as and incident on certiorari to bring up proceedings in the matter of Adelaide M. Husted, an infant, &c., on habeas corpus. (3 R.S.p. 892 sec. 85.) By this statute no certiorari shall be issued in habeas corpus cases until a final determination shall have been made by the officer. The proceeding then brought before us is not reversable on certiorari until a final adjudication as to the custody of the infant. We think the writ of certiorari should be quashed.
lead_paragraph: The People vs. Peter V. Husted. -- The order on its face is an order of the Supreme Court. By this statute no certiorari shall be issued in habeas corpus cases until a final determination shall have been made by the officer. The proceeding then brought before us is not reversable on certiorari until a final adjudication as to the custody of the infant. We think the writ of certiorari should be quashed.

abstract: The demonstrations made toward the eastern boundary of Texas, so long persisted in as to convince the people of the whole country that the blow at the rebel Trans-Mississippi Department was to be struck on the Sabine, were, of course, Feints to draw the attention of the enemy. While MAGRUDER was massing all his forces in the eastern part of the State, BANKS was making ready to cross the Gulf of Mexico, and possess the Rio Grande frontier, thus closing and holding the back-door of the Confederacy.

abstract: The members of the Artists' Fund Association have, at present, at the Derby Gallery, one of the most attractive, as well as one of the most excellent art exhibitions ever offered to the public in this city. Beside the legitimate contributions to the fund, quite a number of celebrated pictures have been loaned to grace, the rooms, among which we should be remiss if we did not mention ROSA BONHEUR's "Horse Fair," which now can be seen for the first time in New-York in all its true splendor. The public will bear the repetition of the statement, that four years ago, certain artists, including most of the celebrities, associated themselves together for the purpose of raising a fund to benefit the families of artists needing pecuniary assistance, or artists themselves aged or invalided, and to accomplish this most desirable object, they agreed to contribute annually one picture each, of a value of not less than fifty dollars, the pictures thus obtained to be exhibited, and finally sold, the proceeds to be put in the common fund. The pictures now offered form the fourth exhibition, at the close of which, they will be sold, as proposed, to the highest bidder. The contributions, as a matter of course, are of small size, and consequently are most popular; for our private dwellings, with rare exceptions, have no eligible places for large canvasses. The subjects are largely landscape, with a few figure pieces; the prevailing impression left upon the mind by their study, is, that they are all capitally finished, all are pretty, all are desirable. There are none that startle with their vigor or thought or reckless execution; there are none that we wot of, that even in their careful mechanical execution, fall absolutely below the intellectual character of genuine art.

abstract: Social Evils in Great Cities
lead_paragraph: The great social evils of modern civilization have attracted and are continually attracting the most earnest consideration of thoughtful minds. The ever-increasing poverty and ignorance of large cities, the inequality of conditions, the little chance afforded to vast numbers of people of ever gaining even the common goods of life, and the fearfully explosive nature of a population which has no solid interest in the public welfare, and yet is moved by all the passions of the lowest humanity -- are enough to excite the utmost anxiety in all who regard the security of society. It is not to be wondered at that innumerable plans for "social reorganization" should have been brought to birth in this century, many of them weak enough and impracticable, but all springing from a profound sense of social wrongs and inequalities, and an intense desire to raise up the lowest classes. The idea of the "Association of Labor" has entered into the laboring mind of Europe, and has brought forth marvelous fruit already in the industrial classes. The wonderful prosperity of continental Europe, the last few years, has descended also to the working-people, and many social evils among them have been corrected. In England, however, it is doubtful if any considerable effect is produced on the mass of ignorance and poverty accumulated in the large cities, by all the humanity and Christianity of the age.
headline: {'main': 'The Social Evils of our Large Cities.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Social Evils of our Large Cities.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -Our correspondent in Western Virginia furnished yesterday an account of the late expedition of Gen. AVERILL's cavalry, and his victory over the illustrious "Mudwall JACKSON," near Lewisburgh and the main ridge of the Alleghany Mountains. The telegraph had given us various items about this expedition, but the whole thing had previously been quite incomprehensible. The expedition was very neatly and successfully conducted, and the battle with "Mudwall" was quite a gallant affair. The latter was licked fearfully, and only escaped by the grease on his heels. The whole State of West Virginia is now entirely freed from rebels, and JACKSON will probably betake himself to East Tennessee, whence he issued a few months since. He got his title of "Mudwall" from the fact that in all his fights in East Tennessee he ensconced himself in a muddy ditch -- the "last ditch," we should surmise.

abstract: Labor Movement, the
lead_paragraph: In vast communities the price of labor is not governed by the number of population, but largely by the number of producers; but in certain strata, or lines of labor, in that community, it is entirely governed by the number that occupy the especial field for it. Thus in China or Dahomey, the labor of the stalwart man may be only valued at three cents per day, yet it is no argument of an overplus; but if in some particular walk the operatives were earning six cents, and it required no further intellect or application than ordinary labor to enter upon that walk, it is a reasonable suggestion that the lower order of labor would rush into it, and, as a consequence, unless the demand was enormous, bring the wages down to their own standard. If the profession requires both intellect and application, it then holds good that few become proficients, and the wages are proportionately high. The less intellect required to achieve labor, the better it will consequently be paid.
headline: {'main': 'The Labor Movement.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Labor Movement.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: POLYTECHNIC ASSOCIATION OF THE AMERICAN INSTITUTE. -- The regular weekly meeting was held on Thursday evening -- S.D. TILLMAN in the chair: Professor GARVEY, Secretary. During the half hour devoted to miscellaneous business, a slide valve, the invention of a German engineer, of this City, was exhibited to the Association, and called forth a lengthy and interesting discussion. It was referred to a Special Committee to examine and report. A lengthy paper upon magnetism was also read, and after a brief discussion, it was the opinion of those present, that the writer had made no new discoveries.

abstract: The conspiracy -- for it is all that -- to raise the price of coal, and keep it high, will affect the public beyond cooking and supply of heat in dwelling-houses, stores and factories. The Trustees of the public gas works have been compelled to give notice that "the price of gas consumed on and after Jan. 1, 1864, will be two dollars and fifty cents per thousand cubic feet, with a discount of five per cent. if paid within five days after presentation of the bill, subject to the United States tax." The present price is $2 25 per thousand cubic feet, less one-ninth discount for prompt payment within five days. At present, with this deduction of one-ninth, the price of gas is $1 96 per thousand feet; the new scale will make it $2 35, which is a serious increase. Of course, such an advance will be felt by all consumers. At the same time, it must be allowed that it is not more than circumstances warrant, the price of coal being more than double what it was three years ago. The public must bear it, while the railways and the coal venders grow wealthy out of the public loss. -- Philadelphia Press, Nov. 17.

The Trustees of the public gas works have been compelled to give notice that "the price of gas consumed on and after Jan. 1, 1864, will be two dollars and fifty cents per thousand cubic feet, with a discount of five per cent. if paid within five days after presentation of the bill, subject to the United States tax." The present price is $2 25 per thousand cubic feet, less one-ninth discount for prompt payment within five days. At present, with this deduction of one-ninth, the price of gas is $1 96 per thousand feet; the new scale will make it $2 35, which is a serious increase. Of course, such an advance will be felt by all consumers. At the same time, it must be allowed that it is not more than circumstances warrant, the price of coal being more than double what it was three years ago. The public must bear it, while the railways and the coal venders grow wealthy out of the public loss. -- Philadelphia Press, Nov. 17.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- Mr. MARETZEK's prosperity always begins at the wrong end of the season. A dozen such houses as that which greeted "Don Giovanni" on Friday night would be the making of his management, but alas! there are not a dozen nights remaining, and if there were, we are quite sure that the lieges would be found wanting. The charm of MOZART's chief d'oeuvre lays in its imperishable melodies. A half-dozen of these touch the popular heart, and leave an affectionate impress that time cannot remove. Everything else in the work is relative in its merit. The instrumentation is remarkable for the period, dealing generously with the instruments that were then in vogue. But for the present generation, accustomed to vehement polyphonic combinations, it is necessarily a little tame. This remark applies, but in a less degree, to the concerted pieces. MOZART, however, is always felicitous when dealing with the voice. Of choruses there are none worth speaking of, except a few shouts for liberty, and a musical instance of mob violence on the subject of an outraged damsel. The libretto need not be discussed. It is one of the few things spared by the French Revolution that might have been swept away without injury to literature or to morals.

abstract: GREAT WAR MEETING AT THE BROOKLYN ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- A great war meeting was held at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Friday night, under the auspices of the Kings County War Fund Committee. The object sought to be attained was the encouragement of volunteering for the army, and to indorse the action of the Board of Supervisors in appropriating money for bounties. The building was filled from top to bottom. The meeting was called to order by Hon. E.A. HAMBERT, who nominated A.A. LOW, Esq., as Chairman, and the following resolutions were read by Hon. JAS. HUMPHREY, and adopted.

abstract: A correspondent writing from Brest, France, says: Dr. RICHARDSON, from the Kearsage, took passage in the Asia, for Boston. The Florida's machinery was nearly repaired, and she would be ready for [???]a on the 1st or 2d of November. The Admiral in command has informed the Captain of the Kearsage that it had been reported to the Minister of Foreign Affairs -- Mr. DROUYN DE LHUYS -- that that gunboat kept steam up ready to follow the Florida, and he was instructed to prevent by force any attempt to pursue the pirate, until twenty-four hours had elapsed. In case of blockade, the Kearsage was ordered to keep over a league outside the headlands of the Island of Ushant to the north, and the Rocky Islets to the south. As this was twenty miles off from the inner channels, which made between the island and the reefs, to the north and south, it was thought th Florida would escape without being seen. M. DROUYN DE LHUYS had responded to the protest against admission of a new crew for the Florida, that the same number of men which left would be admitted." -- Boston Transcript, Nov. 17.

abstract: For November, from Le Follet
lead_paragraph: Although the Winter toilettes have scarcely begun to make their appearance, we are able to give some very decided information as to what will be fashionable for the coming season. High bodies will be exclusively confined to morning dress. For at home, dinner, or evening dress, fichus or lace vestes will be worn over low bodies. The veste camai, or trimmings placed on the body so as to imitate it, is still much in vogue. Many corsages for neglige dresses will be made with postillons basques, especially those trimmed in jacket fashion, so as to form a waistcoat in front.

abstract: The London Gazette publishes a dispatch from Earl RUSSELL, dated Oct. 20, addressed to the British Ambassador at St. Petersburgh. It is short, and commences by stating that Her Majesty's Government have no wish to prolong the correspondence with the Russian Cabinet for the mere purpose of controversy, and concludes by asserting that "the Emperor of Russia has special obligations with regard to Poland, and that the rights of Poland are contained in the same instrument which constitutes the Emperor of Russia King of Poland."

abstract: Schuchardt  Gebhard vs. Reimerset al. This was an action to make the defendants liable upon a bill of exchange drawn by them on Seibring  Son, of London, for  784 6s, 5d., and accepted by the latter. The plaintiff received about half the amount of the bill from Seibring  Son, and Seibring  Son then failing, the plaintiff discharged them from all further liability on the bill by erasing and canceling their acceptance.
lead_paragraph: Schuchardt & Gebhard vs. Reimerset al. This was an action to make the defendants liable upon a bill of exchange drawn by them on Seibring Son, of London, for 784 6s, 5d., and accepted by the latter. The plaintiff received about half the amount of the bill from Seibring & Son, and Seibring Son then failing, the plaintiff discharged them from all further liability on the bill by erasing and canceling their acceptance.

abstract: JOHN N. ANDREWS, "of Virginia," who took such an active part as leader of the July riots, and who has since been confined in Fort Lafayette, is about to be tried before the United States District Court. United States Marshal MURRAY, in accordance with instructions, notified District-Attorney A. OAKEY HALL that the prisoner would be placed at his disposal, if he desired it, in order that he might be tried first by the State Courts. To this notification Mr. HALL replied in a very curt note that "he declined being a party to the scheme for putting a man twice in jeopardy for the same offence." The word "first," used by the Marshal, was evidently misunderstood by Mr. HALL. The truth is, the United States Courts propose to try ANDREWS for treason, but as he has also been guilty of the crime of riot, which is an offence against the laws of the State of New-York, the Government merely offered the State authorities a chance to try the prisoner "first" for the violation of their laws. It is difficult to see how the prisoner could be put twice in jeopardy for the same offence, if the District-Attorney had accepted the offer. ANDREWS meantime remains in Fort Lafayette.

abstract: The prize Steamer Ella, which arrived at Boston on Thursday, was captured off Wilmington, 15 miles north of Fort Fisher, Nov. 10, at 8 P.M. The Houqua fired two shots at her, one of which struck her, when she hove to and surrendered. She got ashore two nights previous, but succeeded in getting off by throwing overboard part of her cargo. The Daylight was in sight at the time of the capture. The Ella had a crew of about twenty men, and her cargo was on account of the rebel Government. This steamer was built in New-York, and is new, her engines having been constructed in Brooklyn, in 1863. Her original name was the Republic, and she was intended for a Sandy Hook tug-boat. She was sold to parties in St. John, N.B., for $70.000, and sailed under a British register, but was really owned by Southerners. Her purser, who belongs in Alabama, is said to have owned half of the steamer. She can make about 12 miles per hour. This was her first attempt to run the blockade. Capt. SWASEY, who was in command of the Ella, belongs in Rhode Island.

abstract: -- Josiah Quincy, of Boston, and the recently deceased Lord Lyndhurst, were both born on the night of May 21, 1772; the same physician attended their entry into the world; he was called from one house to the other to attend to this duty. He was Dr. Joseph Warren, who, three years afterward, fell at Bunker Hill. Josiah Quincy was educated at Cambridge, in Massachusetts, and John Leighton Copley, afterward Lord Lyndhurst, was educated at Cambridge, in England.

abstract: It is not to be expected that the gigantic task of organizing and bringing to perfection, even in its minor details, an army of a million of men can be accomplished in the turn of a finger; but there are many things which are apt to be deferred, or dismissed as minor, when they may be fundamental. Of this kind is the paying of our soldiers. We are all wrong in the system, and must reform it. If we cannot propose one ourselves that shall be better, then let us imitate the European modes, which have been tested by long experience, and have worked satisfactorily. We must regard the soldier as we would the mechanic and laborer, in the payment of his earnings. He may not be, it is true, in an obligation to support himself or his family from day to day on what he receives, having his own food, clothing and general care, sick or well, provided for him by the Government, but he may, nevertheless, have just as urgent calls upon him as though he had. He may have wife, children, or relatives, at home, looking eagerly for a portion of his pay, to keep them alive. To them it is a matter of desperate importance that they should not only receive it promptly, but within short periods. Imagine the mechanic or laborer obliged to wait several months for the payment of his work. The effect upon him would be crushing. He either could not do it at all, and would degenerate into sloth or crime, or he would be obliged to find a capitalist, who for a heavy profit would advance money or provision upon his labor. This would be the case with the soldier, who is sometimes kept unpaid for several months, if he were so placed that he could offer his pay-roll for sale, or if brokers would buy it, but there is no such market for the rank and file, though necessity sends a large per centage of the commissioned officers to the brokers, who buy their assigned pay-rolls, at a shave of from five to ten per cent. a month. This should not occur, if it were only for the simple reason that, really, a commissioned officer is not well enough off with his pay to afford it. It he lives in proper manner, the amount is closely calculated to take him through, and that five or ten per cent. cannot be spared, to say nothing of the manifest injustice of its going into the hands of a usurer.

abstract: Struggles for Naval and Colonial Power
snippet: Struggles for Naval and Colonial Power
lead_paragraph: The American public is not paying that attention to the operations of French Emperor that the development of his policy deserves. In the Atlantic Monthly for November, under the above caption, we find a remarkably intelligent and interesting paper, pregnant with important facts, foreibly grouped together and tersely stated, which go far to show that France to-day, in point of development of her naval resources and power, and of her territoral acquisitions, is taking the leading position among the nations of the eastern hemisphere. The French conquest of Mexico is no sudden freak of an ambitious monarch, but simply a development, in the settled line of policy, which the present Emperor is pursuing with great vigor and cat-like secresy, -- a policy which has already created French possessions in every quarter of the globe, and is planting the germs of empires among the ruins and desolation of almost forgotten countries.
headline: {'main': '"The French Struggle for Naval and Colonial Power."', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': '"The French Struggle for Naval and Colonial Power."', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Emperor Napoleon's Speech on
lead_paragraph: More than a third of NAPOLEON'S speech at the opening of the French Chambers, was devoted to the delicate subject of the Russo-Polish difficulty. France, be it known, never makes war for an "idea," save against Powers like Austria or Mexico; when confronted with such an antagonist as Russia, she only arms to vindicate her honor, or repel threatened aggression. Now as neither the honor nor the interests of the Emperor of France is involved in the Polish Question, it is of course no affair of his in particular, but an ecumenical question which concerns Europe at large. Before Europe, however, engages in a war to compel Russia to respect the rights of Poland, his French Majesty thinks that one more proposition ought to be made to the Northern Collossus. GORTSCHAKOFF having somewhere in his dispatches intimated that Russia would offer no objection to a general conference, if it were authorized to set at rest all the questions which agitate Europe, as well as the Polish question, NAPOLEON recommends that this concession should be turned to account if possible, and made the basis of a pacific arrangement. He is disposed to take GORTSCHAKOFF at his word, and offer to submit to the arbitrament of a European Congress all the other questions that trouble Christendom, if the Czar will only consent to submit the settlement of that which relates to Poland to the same tribunal. If ALEXANDER accedes to this proposition, the peace of Europe may, in the opinion of NAPOLEON, be preserved; but should the Czar refuse to accept the ultimatum, then, according to the Emperor, the sole alternative of Europe will be silence or war.

abstract: Wednesday evening last, Deputy Prov.-Marshal B.F. MANIERRE, Commissioner KIRBY and Surgeon WOODWARD, of the Eighth District, were the recipients of a very handsome compliment from the clerks in their department. An elegant dinner was engaged at No. 764 Broadway, at which there was no lack of substantials and delicacies, and which was enjoyed by a large number of the friends of the gentlemen. During the evening large and handsome photographs of the members of the Board were presented to each of said members.

abstract: THOMAS NAST, whose vivid and vigorous representations of many a serious scene and pathetic incident of the rebellion are well known to all subscribers of the illustrated journals, excels no less in catching the comic phases of the struggle and giving them pictorial form. There seems to be a vein of pure humor in his pencil, which he is industriously working to his own advantage and to the amusement of the public. In addition to the series of comic, mirth-making productions which pleased the town so much some months since and which yet have not run themselves out, Messrs. E. & H.T. ANTHONY have recently published another series of Mr. NAST's masterly witticisms, being caricatures of eminent persons that possess the uncommon merit of being as chaste as they are facetious.

abstract: An effort is to be made at the next annual meeting of the stockholders of the New-York Central Railroad Company to divest it of the management by which its immense power and influence has, for many years past, been turned into political channels. The facts which prove the complicity of the present directors in various schemes of intrigue and action wholly outside of its mere commercial purposes, as well as the numerous errors of their financial control, are presented in a circular which will be soon, if it has not been already, addressed to the parties in interest.

abstract: CASE OF ABORTION IN GRAND-STREET. -- A woman named Mrs. LETITIA ROBERTSON, residing at No. 264 Grand-street, died on Saturday from injuries caused by an abortion produced at her own hands. An inquest has been held in the case, at which Mr. CHARLES ROBERTSON, the husband of deceased, stated that his wife had been in very delicate health; that she had been pregnant a number of times, and had on two occasions taken medicine to produce an abortion. Some two months since, believing herself enceinte, she felt very bad, and took blood root and tanzy to produce an abortion. Finding these to fail, she undertook to make a surgical operation, and used an instrument for that purpose, which punctured the membranes and caused a hemmorhage, from which she died in five minutes. Dr. WOOSTER BEACH made a post-mortem examination, from which it was apparent death was caused as above stated. A verdict was rendered in accordance with the facts.
lead_paragraph: CASE OF ABORTION IN GRAND-STREET. -- A woman named Mrs. LETITIA ROBERTSON, residing at No. 264 Grand-street, died on Saturday from injuries caused by an abortion produced at her own hands. abstract: If any special proof were needed of the truth of the general conviction that the interests of the Stockholders in the Central Railroad had been systematically sacrificed to the private, views and interests of its principal officers, it may be found in the action of the Directors at their recent meeting. In order to stem the current of sentiment on this subject among the stockholders, they have decided to divide five per cent. in February, instead of three and a half as heretofore. Does anybody believe they would have done this but for the movement which some of the leading stockholders had started to change the management? No one doubts the ability of the road to make such a dividend; and three-fourths of those who own stock in it and know anything about it, fully believe that if its business were managed like that of every other large corporation in the country, -- if its officers were paid for their services in some recognized and legitimate way, arid not by the concession of the privilege of furnishing its supplies on their own terms, it would easily pay a good deal more.

abstract: My Farm of Edgewood; Thoreau, Henry D.; Excursions
snippet: My Farm of Edgewood; Thoreau, Henry D.; Excursions
lead_paragraph: There is little risk in predicting for Ik Marvel's latest work a popularity exceeding even the fervor of reception which he has heretofore met with from the public. Not all men are sentimental, and even of those so tinged, the impression rarely dominates the entire life, but is confined to the human spring, the season of buds and flowers that knows no second youth. There generally comes a time when the Reveries of a Bachelor are exchanged for the realities of the married man, when the visions of Dream Life fade into the light of common day, and when the ornamental Lorgnette is replaced by the more serviceable spectacles; but the taste for a country life pervades most classes and ages of mankind, especially those who do not lead it. As thousands read Walton's Angler, who never touched a rod and line, so My Farm at Edgewood will be studied by thousands ignorant of the smell of guano, and, like the author's city visitor, (page 258,) unable to distinguish between a Devon and a short-horned cow, or a Muscovy duck and a Bremen goose. Every one keeps a corner in his heart for the sentiment of the country and country life. Men who live and all but die in offices where, like Kit's blackbird in the Old Curiosity Shop, they can actually see a piece of sky, if they "look up and twist their heads round a little," solace themselves with the idea of a possible future, a brief day of grace ere the final balancing of the great books, when the mind shall be gently attuned to harmony with the sights and sounds of nature, and shake off some of the clinging rust of the fetters of daily City life. To all these innumerable farmers in idea, My Farm at Edgewood, will be a treasure, and to the smaller number who have achieved a realized ideal it will be equally valuable. We have here indeed in it, a prose Georgic, a work that avoids no portion of the sober truths of the subject, but, while grappling with them, invests them with the hues of a brilliant fancy and the associations of a cultivated mind. Mr. Marvel (as it pleases him to be called) is a man whom the pleasures of foreign travel and the dignity of official rank in the Queen City of the Adriatic were unable to wean from a longing for an old-fashioned New-England home, and his book is a record of the steps he took to procure such an abiding-place, and the measures of improvement he adopted when it was once secured. Under four heads: "The Search and the Finding;" "Taking Beins in Hand;" "Crops and Profits;" "Hindrances and Helps" -- the reader is made acquainted with the result of the author's plunge into the ocean of Farm Life, shares his sober joy as the fair creation of his hands widens to his view; inspects his private balance-sheet of profits and losses, and by many a sparkling sentence and speaking trait, observed and noted with the pen of a master in the art of writing, has a foretaste of the rocks ahead, in the shape of imperfect help, unsympathizing neighbors, and the vis inertia of a dead and senseless routine that scorns improvement as visionary, and looks with distrust on attempts at progress, as akin to ruin. In spite of all drawbacks, the author's decision is largely in favor of the mode of life he has adopted, and the great question "will it pay?" is answered in a manner to satisfy the sober and moderate capitalist, who does not look for his only return in the shape of bank interest, but is willing to allow a market value for healthful occupation, sound slumbers, untainted air, and wholesome food. To give a more detailed account of a book in the hands of every one is superfluous. The writer is justly reputed perhaps the meet careful and finished of our literateurs, and My Farm will certainly not detract from his reputation. If we were to "hint a fault," it would be a slight complaint at the excess of foreign allusion. There is something too much of the "picked man of countries" who cannot enjoy or praise a native scene without making it a peg to hang a reference on, to something like or unlike abroad. This, however, is mere matter of personal impression, and is probably pleasing to many. The getting up the book shows a fine eye for the esthetics of publishing, and is in keeping with the attractiveness of its contents.

abstract: -- The anxiety to hear from Gen. BURNSIDE's army is intense  but we are still unable to gratify it by any definite intelligence. Nothing has been received since the 19th. We have information, however, that Gen. Sherman's force on the 10th inst. had reached Tullahoma, having crossed the Tennessee River at Florence, Ala. Tullahoma is on the Nashville and Chattanooga Railroad, forty-three miles north of Stevenson. The route of Gen. SHERMAN's march pointed in the direction of Loudon, the point where LONGSTREET crossed the Tennessee in his movement against BURNSIDE. Gen. SHERMAN's trains were moving toward Dunlap and Decatur, Tenn., which points are on the nearest route to Loudon. The distance from Tullahoma to Loudon is about one hundred and forty miles. By this time Gen. SHERMAN must be well toward his destination, and if LONGSTREET remains north of the Tennessee much longer he may find himself between two fires.

abstract: One of Gen. BANKS' Staff officers writes to a friend at Washington that a large quantity of cotton was captured near Brownsville, and expeditions had been sent up the Rio Grande to gather in all they could find. It is thought that 250,000 bales will be thrown into the market by the occupation of Texas. The Union men of Brownsville, who hailed with delight the capture of the place by our forces, are forming themselves into defensive organizations, and rendering valuable service as scouts.

abstract: -- Notwithstanding the talk of other candidates for the Speakership, we doubt whether there will be any considerable opposition to SCHUYLER COLFAX. He is universally conceded to have all the qualifications for the post in a very eminent degree, and his claims to the distinction are in many respects decidedly superior, to those of any other member. He is perfectly familiar with the rules of the House, is quick and ready in applying them, and has an unfailing courtesy and kindness of manner, which is of infinite service in controlling the stormy elements with which the Speaker very often has to deal. It will not be forgotten moreover, that he has already waived his claims and declined to be a candidate when he was certain of a powerful and zealous support, because he was unwilling to be instrumental in bringing about a protracted contest. We are inclined to think that his election will be promptly and generally conceded as eminently fit and proper.

abstract: Railroads, Management of
lead_paragraph: As the City promises to be very soon intersected on every street by railroads, thus driving omnibuses and every other species of public conveyance out of the field, and reducing the inhabitants to complete dependence on the cars, the regulation of the traffic in these vehicles becomes every day of greater and greater importance. There is already a line in every one of the avenues; there is one across the City from east to west, and there is very little doubt that before very long there will be one in Broadway. Upon not one of these is there one rule enforced, having for its object the comfort of the passengers. The Companies supply them with shelter from the rain, and are prevented from charging more that five cents fare, but beyond this, the traveling public is completely at their mercy. There is no regulation as to the number of the cars that shall be run; none as to their size; none as to the number of seats; none as to the number of passengers they may carry; none as to cleanliness or ventilation. The Legislature grants the right to lay tracks on the street, and fixes the fare at five cents, and there all control over the matter ends.

abstract: Half the quarrels of the world grow out of simple misunderstandings. More than half the verbal disputes which vex the public ear, and disturb the public judgment, grow out of the fact that the parties engaged in them differ in regard to the meaning of certain words, -- whereas, if they could agree upon that, they would find that they did not differ essentially in regard to the thing itself. We find rather a striking instance of this in the contest going on as to whether we desire the "Union as it was," or not The Democrats everywhere have been making great use of this phrase as a special watchword; while a good many friends of the Government, more zealous than wise, have been helping them to get up an issue upon it.

abstract: -- The first train which will run directly through to Washington, without changing cars, will leave Jersey City this (Monday) morning, at 7 o'clock. As yet, there is a double track only a portion of the way, but it is expected that an additional one will be completed the entire distance early next season. The railroad companies have made considerable improvement in their cars, and new and powerful engines have been added, to the lines for the purpose of attaining greater speed, and at the same time accommodate more passengers. The trip is to be made in ten hours.

abstract: We published yesterday a list of the names of the last batch of paroled Union prisoners sent down James River by the rebels, and forwarded to Annapolis. Dr. SLOAN, who kindly furnished the roll to the TIMES, says, in a note accompanying it, that the spectacle of these prisoners was a sad and terrible one, even to those who have been accustomed to woeful sights ever since the war began.
lead_paragraph: We published yesterday a list of the names of the last batch of paroled Union prisoners sent down James River by the rebels, and forwarded to Annapolis. Dr. SLOAN, who kindly furnished the roll to the TIMES, says, in a note accompanying it, that the spectacle of these prisoners was a sad and terrible one, even to those who have been accustomed to woeful sights ever since the war began. Six died on the way, and two others as soon as they got into the hospital; and it is estimated that out of the whole 350, comparatively few will ever recover from the effects of their inhuman and devilish treatment at the hands of the rebels. Nine of the bony corpses were placed in front of the pulpit in the chapel at Annapolis, where funeral services were held previous to carrying them to the soldiers' cemetery; and Dr. SLOAN says that the sight brought tears to many an eye -- "not," he adds, "that we saw so many locked in the cold embrace of death, but that we saw these, our comrades and brothers, the fallen victims of rebel barbarity -- literally starved to death." As some of those who were able were hobbling off the boat, a sympathetic lady gave vent to her feelings, and expressed her joy that they were among friends again, to which two or three replied -- "Madam, don't pity us; we are the best lot; pity the thousands we have left behind -- forty-three on an average are dying every day."

abstract: The Stage Drivers, who leagued the other night to demand an increased rate of pay from their employers and obtained their object, met yesterday at the corner of Eleventh-street and First-avenue. MICHAEL FITZSIMMONS, President of the Association, took the chair, and JOSEPH CHANLER acted as Secretary. Resolutions were passed thanking the stage proprietors for so readily granting the advance required of them, and, after the transaction of some preliminary routine business, a committee was appointed to draft a Constitution and By-laws for the future guidance of the Association.

abstract: Thanksgiving, Proclamation of Nov. 26
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY, the 26th inst., having been designated by the President of the United States, and by the Governor of this State, as a day of Thanksgiving and Prayer, it becomes the duty of every good citizen to refrain from all secular employments on that day, and to devote it to appropriate religious exercises.

abstract: New-York Central Management
lead_paragraph: The appointment by the authorities at Washington of Major-Gen. JOHN A. LOGAN to the command of the Fifteenth Army Corps gives great satisfaction to the Army of the Mississippi and all Union-loving citizens. He is a worthy successor of Gen. SHERMAN, and the position he is about to assume has been nobly won. Resigning his seat in Congress to take command of the Thirty-first Illinois regiment, raised in Southern Illinois -- or Egypt, as it is called -- thus sundering the ties of family and his social relations with a portion of his political friends, he, without doubt, saved the southern portion of the State from bloodshed and murder.

abstract: Another call is made on the patriotism and humanity of this, the representative city of the nations The mothers, sisters, daughters of those brave soldiers who now lie wounded, sick and suffering, make the appeal; it will be responded to cordially, generously. The Twenty-second of February has been designated as the day when the Great Fair under the auspices of the United States Sanitary Commission will open here. To this Fair it is expected that every profession, business and trade will contribute freely, liberally. Anything salable, be it ever so triffling, or ever so huge, will be gladly received; let every one who can give aid in the work. It is suggested that each of our benevolent literary and other societies be represented; that our generous firemen, our brave militia, our patriotic Police force and each of the departments of the City Government have their separate departments in the Fair; in short, that a generous rivalry be entered into between all organizations and between all classes of citizens to make the Fair "great" in itself and splendid in its results. It is none too early to commence. Let individuals talk the matter over in their different societies and among their friends. Organize for the work -- the sooner the better -- with earnestness and zeal.

abstract: COPPERHEADISM IN ELIZABETH. -- The City Council of Elizabeth, N.J., have just put themselves to the trouble of exhibiting their Copperhead sympathies in a very small way. The New-Jersey Journal, which is published in Elizabeth, has recently changed hands, passing into the control of Mr. FRED. W. FOOTE, an earnest supporter of the Government, as editor. The loyalty of Mr. FOOTE'e predecessor was by no means above suspicion, and the City Council did all they could to assist him in the dissemination of his peculiar views, by authorizing the regular publication of the reports of their proceedings in the Journal. No sooner had it passed out of his bands, and into those of Mr. FOOTE, than they withdrew their patronage, and ordered the publication of their proceedings in a Rahway paper, the only recommendation of which is, that its editor opposes the Government and all its measures. The affair has created quite a stir in the quiet village of Elizabeth, but the Journal is still published, notwithstanding the efforts of the Council to suppress it.

abstract: RECRUITING IN BROOKLYN. During the past week, some sixty recruits have been sworn in and sent to Riker's Island. On Saturday, twelve enlisted. The prospects are that there will be a large increase during the present week. As no Surgeon has yet been appointed for Gen. SPINOLA'S headquarters, a good deal of difficulty is experienced in procuring the examination of recruits.
lead_paragraph: RECRUITING IN BROOKLYN. -- During the past week, some sixty recruits have been sworn in and sent to Riker's Island. On Saturday, twelve enlisted. The prospects are that there will be a large increase during the present week. As no Surgeon has yet been appointed for Gen. SPINOLA'S headquarters, a good deal of difficulty is experienced in procuring the examination of recruits. The Bounty Committee of the Board of Supervisors, which heretofore met at 9 o'clock, A.M., each day, and adjourned at 12 o'clock, noon, will from this date meet at 10 and adjourn at 1 o'clock. Should there be a rush of recruits in the afternoon, they will remain until all the cases are disposed of. The Committee which proceeded to Washington for the purpose of ascertaining, definitely, the number of men required, are expected home to-day.

abstract: Mr. MAX MARETZEK enters upon the last week of his Fall management to-night. Does the public thoroughly understand that after Saturday next we are to have no more Italian opera until the Spring? The final performances will be unusually interesting. To-night we are to have "Don Giovanni," for the second and last time. This announcement will suffice to fill the house to its greatest capacity. Whether it be love of MOZART or greed for a work in which three prima donnas appear that leads to this result, we shall not stop to inquire; the fact remains that "Don Giovanni" always "draws." The attendance on Friday night was larger than on any previous evening of the season.

abstract: By the arrival of the America at this port yes-  terday, we have European files three days later than those previously received. The proposed Congress engrosses much attention. The Queen had received an autograph letter from the Emperor NAPOLEON on the subject, and the Cabinet was to consider the answer on the 17th.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the America at this port yes- terday, we have European files three days later than those previously received. The proposed Congress engrosses much attention. The Queen had received an autograph letter from the Emperor NAPOLEON on the subject, and the Cabinet was to consider the answer on the 17th. The proposition had been addressed to fifteen Governments, and it was rumored that Prussia and Austria were favorable to the proposal. Italy had already responded. Lord PALMERSTON's speech at the Guildhall banquet was remarkable for nothing in particular. He said, among other things, "that the combatants are slaughtering each other by hundreds of thousands, and carrying on a contest, the result of which it is impossible to foresee, and the end of which now, after more than two years' duration, he would be a bold man indeed, who would venture to predict." No change had yet been made in the French Embassy at St. Petersburgh. The Liberal Press of Italy unanimously applaud the Emperor's speech. The Emancipation Society of Glasgow had memorialized the Foreign Office, with reference to the rebel steamer Canton, building at that place, and a favorable reply had been received.

abstract: Events every now and then occur in almost all countries, which reveal the very superficial nature of modern civilization and humanity. The wild animal in human society which has been so long domesticated that we had almost forgotten its existence, suddenly shows its claws and fangs.
lead_paragraph: Events every now and then occur in almost all countries, which reveal the very superficial nature of modern civilization and humanity. The wild animal in human society which has been so long domesticated that we had almost forgotten its existence, suddenly shows its claws and fangs. The barbaric blood which ethnologists tell us still betrays itself in the most refined stocks, unexpectedly reveals itself to the world in some terrible acts of ferocity and cruelty. In many of these instances we are not surprised. When the New-York mob hangs innocent boys and men and burns asylums, we see that such are the natural fruits of long ages of oppression, destitution and ignorance in the Old World, which we, in the New, must reap. When the Southern officers deliberately insult and starve our unfortunate prisoners, we see that this is the legitimate result of Slavery, and that nothing else ought to be expected. Even the blowing of Hindoo rebels from British cannon, though it shocks, does not so much astound us, because we remember the atrocities which had roused up the baser passions of the English soldiery. But there are actions at times which seem to thrill the pulse of all mankind with horror, and which call forth an instinctive cry of condemnation from every civilized people. Especially is this the case where the connivers and perpetrators have been holding themselves up as the especial guardians of civilization, and have been preaching for a long period with holy indignation against trivial offences, committed by their neighbors.

abstract: Edward Weston et al. vs. James Wright et al. -- On the 6th day of February, 1858, one James W. Phillips, of the City of New-York, conveyed to the defendant Wright, who resided in the State of Alabama, one fourth part of the ship Neptune's Car, by a bill of sale in the usual form, which was on the same day duly acknowledged and recorded in the office of the Collector, of Customs of this port, pursuant to the act of Congress. The remaining three-fourths of the ship were owned by the other defendants -- two of whom (owning one-half) were and had for a long time been ship's husbands.

abstract: Upon application yesterday afternoon to Mr. District-Attorney HALL, reporters were allowed to examine the papers in the case of Miss CHARLOTTE CAMPBELL, the young lady who died at No. 11 East Thirtieth-street, on Tuesday evening of last week, under very mysterious circumstances, an account of which has appeared.
lead_paragraph: Upon application yesterday afternoon to Mr. District-Attorney HALL, reporters were allowed to examine the papers in the case of Miss CHARLOTTE CAMPBELL, the young lady who died at No. 11 East Thirtieth-street, on Tuesday evening of last week, under very mysterious circumstances, an account of which has appeared. The testimony in the case is quite brief. The following are the names of the gentlemen who composed the Jury of inquest at the time it was held by Coroner RANNEY, viz.: Isaac B. Conover, Henry Mathews, Samuel Reynolds, Bartholomew O'Conner, Dr. H.D. Ranney (brother of the Coroner) and Mr. Samuel D. Brettman, in whose house Miss C. died. The only witnesses whose testimony was taken were Mr. MALCOLM CAMPBELL, who is a brother of deceased, Mrs. Dr. BRETTMAN, whose house it is alleged the deceased was visiting at the time of her death, and Dr. WILSON PATTERSON, who was called in when it was discovered that the young lady was dying. The testimony in the case went to show that Miss CAMPBELL, the deceased, had been unwell for several weeks past, and that at times she seemed very nervous and melancholy. On the day preceding the evening of her death, she had been making preparations for a visit to Washington, which her physicians had recommended with a view to restore her health.

abstract: GETTYSBURGH, Pa., Friday Evening, Nov. 20, 1863. The dedication of the National Cemetery,  which passed off so auspiciously here yesterday, has been followed to-day by a most lamentable occurrence which has spread gloom over the village of Gettysburgh, and added one, and perhaps two more victims to those deadly missiles which were hurled over this town, filling the air like hail-stones in a storm, on the 2d and 3d of July last.

abstract: The announcement that the Russian fleet was to leave the harbor yesterday, caused considerable excitement in naval circles, and a great number of United States naval officers, as well as several of our citizens, assembled on the Battery in the afternoon to witness the exit of the squadron. Indeed, a tugboat, crowded to excess with spectators, was plying between the ships for several hours, conveying on board several of our citizens of Russian birth, and some distinguished Americans. All the forenoon each vessel of the fleet was a scene of unusual bustle. Meat, provisions, groceries, &c., were brought aboard in immense baskets. Several boats disputed the most convenient place to the ship's side. Washwomen came on in dozens with wash-clothes; and finally, several Russian and American citizens went on board to pay their respects -- all these visitors tending to crowd the ships to such an extent that locomotion was rendered impossible. About 2 o'clock in the afternoon, however, it became apparent that the amount of business to be done was too great to enable the ships to go, and the Admiral determined to let them remain over night. Meantime, the bustle and excitement continued, and at 4 o'clock in the afternoon an entire squadron of "bum"-boats and runners' boats studded the stream. It is understood that two of the vessels will remain in the harbor -- the Admiral's ship and another -- and that the remainder of the squadron will leave. It is stated that Admiral PAULDING will send the Navy-yard tugboat, with naval officers on board, to escort the fleet out of the harbor.
lead_paragraph: The announcement that the Russian fleet was to leave the harbor yesterday, caused considerable excitement in naval circles, and a great number of United States naval officers, as well as several of our citizens, assembled on the Battery in the afternoon to witness the exit of the squadron. lead_paragraph: There was a large and brilliant gathering at the New-England Rooms last evening, to celebrate the anniversary of the Soldier' Relief Association. Speeches were made by Maj-Gen. SICKLES, Rev. Dr. OSGOOD, Prof. HITCHCOCK and Rev. Dr. VINTON, Mr. WM. M. EVARTS presided. The Superintendent's report exhibited an immense amount of good accomplished by the Association on very limited resources, and the Treasurer's report showed the necessity of increased efforts to aid the institution on the part of its friends and the public.

abstract: Swindlers; Sentence of J. N. Stetler
snippet: Swindlers; Sentence of J. N. Stetler
lead_paragraph: The sentence of JOHN K. STETLER, of Philadelphia, by Court-martial, to five years' imprisonment in the penitentiary for supplying the army with adulterated coffee is the first instance, we believe, of any account, of the practical enforcement of the law which passed Congress last year, making such frauds on the army penal, and triable by Court-martial. Though the good work has commenced late, we trust that it will now be followed up with the sternest rigor. The amount of iniquity of this nature which has been practiced upon our soldiers is beyond calculation. In the early part of the war it was the most rampant evil affecting the service, and though it has been largely reduced since, it still prevails to a scandalous extent. So long as the system of opening contracts to general competition is maintained -- and it is the only correct system -- dishonest men will often get contracts, and no plan of inspection, however well devised, can of itself always insure against fraudulent supplies. The amount to be inspected is too vast to admit of minute examination; and moreover, even were this otherwise, the urgency of the demand is often too great to allow time for it. No management for detection can alone remedy the evil; there must also be management for prevention. The severe penal act passed by Congress was just what was needed. It enabled the army to protect itself by subjecting every contractor without exception to military law. We have thought it strange that this power has not been more frequently exercised. The present sentence we hope is an earnest of a new order of things.

abstract: New-York Pilot Commissioners vs. Vanderbilt; Harbor Encroachments
snippet: New-York Pilot Commissioners vs. Vanderbilt; Harbor Encroachments
lead_paragraph: The Board of Commissioners of Pilots vs. Cornelius Vanderbilt. -- This action is brought by the Commissioners of Pilots against Commodore Van- derbilt under the act of 1860, by which authority was given plaintiffs to prevent encroachments upon the harbor of New-York, and to give notice to any person obstructing the harbor to remove such obstruction within a certain time, and providing that any per- son so notified who shall disobey such notice shall be liable to a penalty of $25 a day for each and every day that it shall remain after notice. Plaintiffs allege that in the year 1860 Commodore VANDERBILT entered upon the waters of New-Yok harbor, at a point south of Pier No. 1, and outside of the line recommended by the Commissioners, and built or put there an obstruction in the nature of a pier filled in with stone, the same being unauthorized by law and wholly without the exterior line. Plaintiffs notified defendant to remove said obstruction within five days, and such notification not being complied with, they bring this action to recover the penalty of $25 a day for each and every day from the 10th day of November, 1860, up to the day of trial. The defendant claims at the time of the Battery extension there was a small pier south of Pier No. 1, and inside of said Battery extension; that by a resolution of both branches of the Common Council defendant was authorized to build and extend said small pier parallel to Pier No. 1 as far as the exterior line of the proposed Battery extension; that by order of said resolution defendant sunk a crib filled with stone within the exterior line of the Battery extension; that before said pier was finished defendant was restrained by an injunction afterward made perpetual from proceeding with said structure, that all that he did was done under the authority of the Mayor, Aldermen and Commonalty of the City of New-York, and defendant is not liable for the penalty; defendant further alleges that said obstruction was not outside the extreme line of the harbor fixed by law; that he had no recollection of receiving any such notice as that required by law. The amount of the penalties sought to be recovered, is over $27,000. A motion to dismiss the complaint was made on the ground of the insufficiency of the notice given to Mr. Vanderbilt, it being claimed that the notice had not been shown to be the act of the Board of Commissioners of Pilots, but only one of its members. Case still on.

abstract: NIBLO'S GARDEN. Mr. and Mrs. BARNEY WILLIAMS commenced their Metropolitan engagement here last evening. The house was densely crowded, and the reception bestowed on these favorite artists was in the highest degree flattering.
lead_paragraph: NIBLO's GARDEN. -- Mr. and Mrs. BARNEY WILLIAMS commenced their Metropolitan engagement here last evening. The house was densely crowded, and the reception bestowed on these favorite artists was in the highest degree flattering. Three capital pieces were on the programme, the most important being the "Fairy Circle" a closely knit little drama, filled with picturesque effects and displaying the peculiar merits of Mr. and Mrs. BARNEY WILLIAMS to decided advantage. The piece will be remembered by their patrons. It has been played frequently, and always to the acceptance of the public. On the present occasion it gained new interest from the very generous way in which it has been placed upon the stage by Mr. WHEATLEY. The scenery and costumes are both excellent. Some of the best names of Mr. WHEATLEY's company appear in the cast. Miss ADA CLIFTON made a small part interesting, and Mr. SHEWELL gave importance to the character of Robert O'Niel.

abstract: It is to-day affirmed and denied that the Army of the Potomac is once more on the move, and the furnishing with which it is said to have started ten days' provisions would indicate serious business. The first part of the business will, of course, be to find LEE and his force and give them battle.
lead_paragraph: It is to-day affirmed and denied that the Army of the Potomac is once more on the move, and the furnishing with which it is said to have started -- ten days' provisions -- would indicate serious business. The first part of the business will, of course, be to find LEE and his force and give them battle. As we have no information as to the present position of the rebels, all attempts to reason on the subject are vain. We rest under the belief, however, that a vigorous march on the part of Gen. MEADE toward Richmond will bring up LEE somewhere in front of him. Indeed, the latest rumors place LEE's army at Hanover Junction, midway between Frederickcsburgh and Richmond. It is at least not improbable that his right rests at that point, where the railroad from Gordonsville, occupied by the rebels in force, crosses the Fredericksburgh and Richmond road; and it is not unlikely that in the event of Richmond being menaced, he will draw in on the position named, to contest the passage of the North and South Anna Rivers.

abstract: New-York Central Management; Mr. Corning
lead_paragraph: The great question at issue between the shareholders in the New-York Central, and its officers, is this: Shall such officers, who are only the servants of the owners of the road, be held to the rules which are essential to success, not only on all similar works, but in every relation of responsibility and trust -- rules which forbid the use of position or occasion for personal advantage or emolument; or shall such servants be an exception, and be allowed to prostitute their places to their own personal and selfish ends?

abstract: A new and successful plan for highway robbery was initiated during the late political campaign by the thieves and murderers of the City. Quite a number of cases occurred wherein it was not only successful in the matter of robbery, but where the victims were very badly injured. The villains emboldened by their successes during riot week in attacking and robbing everybody whom they met, from whom they thought spoils could be secured, adopted the following ingenious plan. Five, six, sometimes more of them, would assemble in a body on the occasion of political parades, fall into the ranks and march along as part and parcel of the party; watching their chance for a victim, one of them would rush from the ranks and strike him as though he had offered an insult to the procession, and on the instant the others would spring to the assault; the man would be knocked down, beaten and robbed of all valuables about him in a moment, and the whole affair be considered as a "political row." Thus did these murderous scoundrels make the different parties the cloak for their villanies. They operated the same way at the different political meetings outside of Cooper Institute. It was a shrewd plan, and until recently was not developed to the Police authorities; so soon as known prompt measures were adopted to prevent it. "Political fights" are now considered synonymous with "highway robbery" -- those engaged in them highwaymen. Processions hereafter, will be so attended that this class of villains using them as a cloak will be promptly arrested. It would be well if the different parties would make a note of these facts, and on any occasion of a disturbance on the route of their marches, or at their meetings attribute it to the class of thieves mentioned, and promptly aid in their arrest. On one occasion, during the late canvass, a gentleman was knocked down and robbed on Broadway, badly beaten also, and yet despite his assertion of robbery, those who were really participants in the procession, and who crowded to the scene, were particularly excited against him because of the blatant assertion of the thieves that he had insulted the procession as it passed. Of course, had they known the fact they would have promptly turned upon and severely but justly punished the villains. Let them aid the Police in arresting and unmasking these highway robbers during the present local campaign, should they show themselves.

abstract: Bramlette, Gov., of Kentucky, on Loyalty
snippet: Bramlette, Gov., of Kentucky, on Loyalty
lead_paragraph: Gov. BRAMLETTE, of Kentucky, was solicited by the friends of Gov. SEYMOUR to deliver speeches in this State during the late canvass. At first it was understood that he consented; but subsequently the arrangement fell through, and a reason was assigned for it that evidently was given merely to save appearances. We will not say that it was discovered that Gov. BRAMLETTE could do Gov. SEYMOUR no good, but if anybody doubts that Gov. SEYMOUR would have caught a Tartar, let him learn how the Kentuckian serves Copperheads at home.

abstract: THE MATTER OF JOHN WHITE. -- Mr. WHITE, an account of whose arrest as charged with various crimes was published on Monday, makes a statement that the whole report is incorrect, except in regard to his arrest in this City; he says that, on hearing he was then discharged, and alleges that the motive of the prosecution, on the subsequent arrest, is to make money, which he will show before the Courts. Meantime he wishes fair play and no prejudgment by the public.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will ...
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: OULD AND MEREDITH.  Col. WHITELEY'S mission on behalf of the imprisoned newspaper correspondents in Richmond has been only partially successful. The difficulty in this case, and indeed in the whole matter of ex- changes, results from the hostile relations and the irreconcilable personal animosity of the two Commissioners, OULD and MEREDITH.

abstract: About 1 1/2 o'clock this morning some stir was created in the vicinity of Nassau and Beekman streets by the report of pistol-shots. A deserter, whose name was not ascertained, attempted to escape from the Provost Guard, in whose charge he was. Three shots were fired at the fleeing fugitive, sundry policemen's billies hurled at him, without harm; but he was finally captured at the corner of Spruce and William streets -- a whole man, and may serve for a target in the army of the Potomac in future.

abstract: Letter to Richmond Examiner
lead_paragraph: The caustic letter of JOHN M. BOTTS to the Richmond Examiner, shows that that gentleman's intellect remains clear amid the confusion and desolation that surround him. BOTTS is not a confessor after the style of Parson BROWNLOW or ANDREW JOHNSON, who hurls defiance at the rebels from the soil which they claim. Nor does he desire to become a refugee from his native State, and operate actively against the rebellion, as so many noble southerners have done. But while residing upon a debateable ground which is alternately within the lines of one and the other army, and which is continually haunted by guerrillas, he does not fail to maintain a certain kind of indifference, and does not scruple to lay bare with a skillfully handled knife, some of the foul and fetid sores of the Southern Confederacy. He undoubtedly occupies ground, morally as well as physically, which is eminently precarious to his own person. It is very likely that the rebel authorities may make some of the charges he mentions in his letter, a pretext for seizing him and depriving him of his liberties, as they have done before. It is well that Mr. BOTTS does not succumb before the rebellion; but it would be better if his Unionism, if such it may be called, were of a more positive type, and that then his farm, or at least himself, were safe within the Union lines.

abstract: We have news that the battle between the armies of GRANT and BRAGG, which has been threatened for some days, was opened yesterday morning, and lasted all day. The fighting was immediately in front of our position at Chattanooga, in the valley which forms a sort of cul-de-sac between Missionary Ridge and Lookout Mountain, some six or eight miles northwest of the late battleground of Chickamauga. It is here that the body of the rebel army has been planted. We suppose that undoubtedly our army was the attacking party, and that Gen GRANT ordered the assault. An attack was designed for a week ago last Sunday, but for good reason it was ordered to be temporarily postponed. The forces mentioned as having been engaged are those of Gens. THOMAS and SHERMAN. If this statement is literally accurate, it indicates that Gen. SHERMAN's column, which was previously reported as moving in the direction of East Tennessee for the relief of Gen. BURNSIDE, had been quickly wheeled round and down to Chattanooga, at the order of Gen. GRANT. HOOKER, too, will, doubtless, have a hand in the affair. We hardly suppose that the rebel column of LONGSTREET, which has been fighting BURNSIDE up at Knoxville, has had time to join itself to the army of BRAGG, though it was reported a day or two ago that it had withdrawn from Gen. BURNSIDE's front.

abstract: The news from Chattanooga, this morning, is of great interest, although the details are so blind in many respects that no clear idea of the operations can be obtained. The movement which took place on Monday, the 23d inst., looks very much like a very heavy reconnoissance for the ...
lead_paragraph: The news from Chattanooga, this morning, is of great interest, although the details are so blind in many respects that no clear idea of the operations can be obtained. The movement which took place on Monday, the 23d inst., looks very much like a very heavy reconnoissance for the purpose of developing the enemy's position and intentions. The divisions of Gens. WOOD and SHERIDAN, of GRANGER's corps, were engaged. Gen. HAZEN's brigade, supported by Gen. WILLICH's, attacked the enemy and drove him from his rifle-pits, capturing 200 prisoners, and occupying Orchard Ridge, the only high ground between our position and that of the enemy. The whole movement was completely in view from the lines of both armies. One dispatch says that deserters reported that the rebels were falling back, on Chickamauga Station, and closes by asserting that hard fighting is inevitable to-morrow, unless the rebels fall back during the night. A later and special dispatch from Washington brings the cheering intelligence that fighting was going on all day yesterday, and that our troops had forced the enemy back at all points. No particulars are given.

abstract: It would be a great comfort if the persons to whom we are indebted for the dispatches from Chattanooga would write in a way not to be utterly unintelligible. The country is really very much interested to know what takes place at that important theatre of military operations; ...
lead_paragraph: It would be a great comfort if the persons to whom we are indebted for the dispatches from Chattanooga would write in a way not to be utterly unintelligible. The country is really very much interested to know what takes place at that important theatre of military operations; but it is very hard to form any correct idea of the late transactions from any accounts thus far received. It appears that previous to the battle reported this morning, BRAGG had been falling back from the line he till lately held in the immediate front of Chattanooga, and had begun a retrograde movement back of Chickamauga Station. There is nothing, however, to show whether this action was in consequence of an offensive demonstration on the part of Gen. GRANT, or whether it was voluntary on the part of BRAGG, and in execution of a previously formed design. A reconnoissance on the 23d revealed the rebels as occupying the position at Missionary Ridge and the intervening heights. Thereupon Gen. THOMAS pushed forward a part of Gen. GORDON GRANGER's corps, consisting of the divisions of WOOD and SHERIDAN; two important knolls, half way between our line and Missionary Ridge, were carried by a brilliant charge, and the whole position up to the foot of that ridge was gained. A battle was stated to be imminent yesterday, "unless the rebels should withdraw during the night," and it is the engagement that was thus foreseen and preannounced that is now reported to be in progress.

abstract: Among the many home-truths told by JOHN M. BOTTS, in his letter to the Richmond Examiner, he said: "There is not one of those who aided to bring this war on, that would do it, if, with their prevent experience, it had ...
lead_paragraph: Among the many home-truths told by JOHN M. BOTTS, in his letter to the Richmond Examiner, he said: "There is not one of those who aided to bring this war on, that would do it, if, with their prevent experience, it had to be gone over again, or if they could have foreseen what has followed." This is literal fact. There is not a rebel of any responsibility whatever who dare tell Mr. BOTTS that he here says the thing which is not. Every man of them knows in his heart that the calculations upon which the rebellion was started have utterly failed, and that nothing but the fact that they are in the fight keeps them to the fight. Could things be put back to the condition they were in on the week when ABRAHAM LINCOLN was elected President of the United States, the rebel conspirators, from JEFF. DAVIS down, would sooner walk straight into their graves than have knowingly encountered the misery and the humiliation which this war is entailing upon them and the people which trusted them. It is not in human nature, unless when stark mad, to plunge into such a sea of calamity and disgrace, with a knowledge of its real character.

abstract: At a meeting of the Supervisors, yesterday, a petition was received from the principal hotelkeepers, asking that policemen be detailed to their hotels, to protect them from "hotel thieves." Messrs. PURDY, STEWART, SHOOK and ROCHE, were appointed a Committee to confer with the ...
lead_paragraph: At a meeting of the Supervisors, yesterday, a petition was received from the principal hotelkeepers, asking that policemen be detailed to their hotels, to protect them from "hotel thieves." Messrs. PURDY, STEWART, SHOOK and ROCHE, were appointed a Committee to confer with the Ponce Commissioners on the subject. By resolution, the Clerk was directed to warn all election officers of the penalties for any kind of neglect of their duty. This step is taken to prevent, if possible, the mixing up of matters in making out returns. A resolution was adopted thanking Gov. SEYMOUR for promptly appointing a State Assessor for this end of the State, to fill the place of the late THOMAS ADDIS EMMETT. Mr. BLUNT reported a resolution to appropriate $277,248 64 from the riot damages indemnity fund, to pay the regular and special militia employed to restore and maintain order during and subsequent to the riot. The resolution also provides compensation for personal injuries to the Police. It was adopted. Adjourned to Monday next, at noon.

abstract: A Copperhead festi  val was held in Bergen County, N.J., last night, at which the principal orator was FERNANDO WOOD. His voice is still for peace. "There can be no such thing as rebellion in this country." "Suppose," said he, "NewYork chose to secede, who dare attempt to ...
lead_paragraph: -- A Copperhead festival was held in Bergen County, N.J., last night, at which the principal orator was FERNANDO WOOD. His voice is still for peace. "There can be no such thing as rebellion in this country." "Suppose," said he, "NewYork chose to secede, who dare attempt to prevent her; and Virginia has the same right as New-York." He believed that "when the President called for troops, if but one State Governor had done his duty, the war would have been stopped; for with 100,000 under LEE threatening Washington, neither STANTON nor LINCOLN would have had courage enough to turn round and face the fire they would have felt in the rear." We suppose that if New-York were to attempt to break up the Government, it would be apt to get into the same kind of difficulty that Virginia has got itself into; and we suppose that if Gov. SEYMOUR had threatened the rear of STANTON and LINCOLN while LEE was threatening their front, the rear of Gov. SEYMOUR would have been attended to by the people of New-York. The whole thing is perfectly simple, as Mr. WOOD will perceive.

abstract: Reception at Brooklyn Academy of Music
snippet: Reception at Brooklyn Academy of Music
lead_paragraph: The welcome in this City to Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER, was given at the Academy of Music last evening, by a very large assemblage. On the appearance of the reverend gentleman, accompanied by Mayor OPDYKE, he was enthusiastically greeted. Mayor OPDYKE, who presided, introduced him in a few exceedingly handsome and appropriate words, which were received with much applause. The address of welcome was made by WILLIAM CURTIS NOYES, Esq., after which Mr. BEECHER addressed the audience as follows:

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- To-night GOUNOD's "Faust" will be produced for the first time in New-York. It is a grand romantic opera, involving in its interpretation all the resources of the Academy. Mr. MARETZEK has spared no expense, and has been prodigal of labor in the bringing out of this very important work. GOUNOD is a French composer, who, in "Faust" at least, has won a success which Europe has not been slow to indorse. Since the days of MEYERSEER's "Robert le Diable," there has been no opera that combines inspiration and learning in so remarkable a manner. "Faust" has created a popular and artistic sensation in all the cities where it has been played. If it fails to do so here it will not be the fault of Mr. MARETZEK, who has been liberal in all that can contribute to the success of the mise en scene and music. There is, however, no ground for apprehension. The composition is beautiful, and to-night will witness one of the memorable successes of the age. The following artists are in the cast: Miss Clara Louise Kellogg, Mlle. Sulzer, Miss Stockton, Signer Mazzoleni, Signor Biachi, Signer Yppolito, and Signor Colletti. Mr. Max Maretzek presides in the orchestra.

abstract: This time-honored anniversary was appropriately noticed yesterday by our citizens, and from all the public buildings and many private housetops the Stars and Stripes floated gaily in the breeze. The Veterans of 1812 were out in full force, (ten in number,) and paraded the streets in their antique costumes, feeling, as jovial and frisky as when in their boyish days they saw the red-coats evacuate the City forever. The first company Washington Continental Guard paraded through Broadway and several other principal thoroughfares, under command of their old Capt. DARROW, now holding the position of Lieutenant-Colonel of the Second regiment N.Y.S.M., attached to the Army of the Potomac.
