abstract: Robinson, >amp;c., vs. Flint, >amp;c.; Railroad Contract
lead_paragraph: Lester L. Robinson, Silas Seymour and Alvin C. Morton vs. Edward P. Flint, James P. Flint, George H. Kellogg, William G. Gliddon, John A. Gliddon and J.M.S. Williams. -- This is a case of some interest from the large amount involved, the allegations of fraud against well-known merchants, and the eminence of counsel engaged on each side. The plaintiff, comprising the firm of Robinson Seymour & Co., in the year 1854 entered into an agreement with the Sacramento Valley Railroad Company, whereby they agreed, for the sum of $1,800,000, to construct and equip the entire road of said Campany, and also agreed to assume a contract previously made by the Railroad Company with the Boston agents of Thompson & Forman, of London, for 2,000 tons of railroad iron of T. & F.'s manufacture, or some other manufacturers of equal celebrity. The defendants, comprising the firms of Fluict, Peabody & Co., and Gleddon & Williams, had guaranteed the full performance on the part of the Railroad Company of all the stipulations in the above contract with the agents of Thompson & Forman to as full an extent as if said defendants had been the sole purchaser of the iron, and the defendants also agreed with the Railroad Company to receive the iron at Boston and ship it to San Francisco, and they did receive the whole of the 2,000 tons, of which they shipped to San Francisco 491 tons. The plaintiffs having assumed this contract, one of them visited Boston to ascertain the market price of such railroad iron, and whether the defendants were in a condition to carry out the above contract, so that plaintiffs would be bound by their contract with the Railroad Company to take that particular iron, although the contract price and charges greatly exceeded the then market value of such iron in Boston by a difference, as plaintiffs ascertained, of $32 per ton. Plaintiffs then applied to the defendants and stated that they were ready to carry out the original contract made by the Railroad Company, provided the iron originally purchased was still on hand in Boston, and not otherwise. Thereupon, as plaintiffs allege, the defendants, with intent to cheat and defraud the plaintiffs, and to induce them to enter into the contract for the iron at a price greatly exceeding its market value, falsely represented and stated to the plaintiffs that the identical iron originally imported was then on hand in Boston piled up in warehouses where it had been kept on storage from the time of its importation under the original contract of purchase. Whereas, as the plaintiffs allege, the whole 2,000 tons, except the 491 tons shipped to San Francisco, had been sold to other parties and no part of the same was then on hand in Boston, and plaintiffs claim that they were thus created and defrauded and induced to enter into a contract to pay for this iron, and did pay for it a much larger sum than it was worth, and much larger than they would have paid had they known the truth in relation to the iron. That when this iron was delivered in San Francisco, it proved not to be the iron originally imported, nor was it manufactured by Thompson & Forman, but was iron of a poor quality of many different patterns, and not worth exceeding $35 per ton. That by reason of the poor quality mentioned, and especially by reason of its not being the original iron contracted or in the first instance by the Railroad Company, the Company refused to pay plaintiffs the contract price agreed upon for building the road, but deducted therefrom $50,000, and plaintiffs claim that, by reason of the above facts, they have been damaged, and have lost the sum of $171,000, for which sum, with interest, they seek to recover.

abstract: Richter, J. P. F.; Levana
lead_paragraph: The increasing popularity of JEAN PAUL's works is evidenced by the handsome editions now issuing, in rapid succession, from the house of TICKNOR & FIELDS. The present volume is the fifth of the series. In the absence of any indication of the translator's name, we presume it is a reprint of an English version, issued anonymously in London in 1848, and which has now become scarce. While struggling with the difficulties that beset his earlier career, it is well known that RICHTER was for a time engaged in the education of youth, both as private tutor and as a school teacher, at Schwarzenbach. At a later and happier period, when he had become a husband and father, and had tested his knowledge, by the holier discipline of parental joys and sorrows, he developed the principles of education which had guided him, in the present work. Named from Levana, "the motherly goddess, who was formerly entreated to give a father's heart to fathers," it is consecrated to the inculcation of the great truths of "Home Education," the training of the mother, the family and the household, in opposition to the pedagogic theories of system-mongers. Intensely German in its conception, and professedly fragmentary in its treatment, it is scarcely fitted for continuous perusal; but it is a book that cannot be opened without disclosing words to ponder on -- passages of the highest beauty, pregnant with deep and intense feeling, and profound knowledge of human nature. "A mother's heart -- the sun that gently warms and dries the dew-drops of early tears," on the opening page, is the first sentence our eyes light on, and how beautiful it is. To English readers German humor is generally a sealed book in an unknown tongue, and JEAN PAUL seems never so much beneath himself as in his comic vein, but some trifling incongruities of this kind should never deter the reader from an intimacy with the sterling excellences of a book almost unique in its scope and character.

abstract: The year that is drawing toward its close has been filled with the blessings of fruitful fields and healthful skies. To these bounties, which are so constantly enjoyed that we are prone to forget the source from which they come, other have been added, which are of so extraordinary a nature that they cannot fail to penetrate and soften even the heart which is habitually insensible to the ever-watchful providence of Almighty God.
lead_paragraph: The year that is drawing toward its close has been filled with the blessings of fruitful fields and healthful skies. To these bounties, which are so constantly enjoyed that we are prone to forget the source from which they come, other have been added, which are of so extraordinary a nature that they cannot fail to penetrate and soften even the heart which is habitually insensible to the ever-watchful providence of Almighty God. In the midst of a civil war of unequaled magnitude and severity, which has sometimes seemed to invite and provoke the aggressions of foreign States, peace has been preserved with all nations, order has been maintained, the laws have been respected and obeyed, and harmony has prevailed everywhere, except in the theatre of military conflict, while that theatre has been greatly contracted by the advancing armies and navies of the Union. The needful diversion of wealth and strength from the fields of peaceful industry to the National defence, have not arrested the plow, the shuttle or the ship. The ax has enlarged the borders of our settlements, and the mines, as well of iron and coal as of the precious metals, have yielded even more abundantly than heretofore. Population has steadily increased, notwithstanding the waste that has been made in the camp, the siege, and the battle-field; and the country, rejoicing in the consciousness of augmented strength and vigor, is permitted to expect a continuance of years with large increase of freedom.

abstract: The official dispatches from Chattanooga this morning give definite information concerning the recent very important movements there. The result of the three days' fighting is a decided and magnificent victory. The operations on Tuesday were of a very important character. Gen. HOOKER, with about three divisions of troops, ...
lead_paragraph: The official dispatches from Chattanooga this morning give definite information concerning the recent very important movements there. The result of the three days' fighting is a decided and magnificent victory. The operations on Tuesday were of a very important character. Gen. HOOKER, with about three divisions of troops, carried the point and north slope of Lookout Mountain, with comparatively small loss, capturing 2,000 prisoners. Gen. SHERMAN crossed the Tennessee above Chattanooga early, Tuesday morning, and carried the northern end of Missionary Ridge, in which he was assisted by Gen. THOMAS, who made a vigorous attack on the enemy's centre, piercing it and driving the rebels in great confusion across Missionary Ridge and Chickamauga Creek. We have taken from 5,000 to 10,000 prisoners, and it was expected that Gen. HOOKER would intercept the flying rebels at Rossville. Gen. GRANT telegraphs that our loss is not heavy, and that his success is complete. Our line now seems to be formed thus Gen. HOOKER on the right, holding Lookout Mountain; Gens. PALMER, HOWARD and GRANGER in the centre, between Lookout and Missionary Ridge; Gen. SHERMAN on the left, with his right on the ridge, and his left resting on Chickamauga Creek. All the troops behaved admirably.

abstract: A Suggestion
lead_paragraph: While there is no doubt that the public will be gratified by the success of the movement which the workwomen of the City have undertaken to procure an increase of wages, it is, nevertheles, but right to warn the women themselves that no rise of wages procured by a strike will effect a permanent improvement in their condition. Even if the increase which they now ask be accorded them, they will be no better off than they were two years ago, if so well, and nobody will assert that their lot two years ago was an enviable one. What they will now gain will be all swallowed up by the rise in the price of food and clothing, and the proportion of their income to their expenditure will remain precisely as it was before. The life of the seamstress will still be laborious, unhealthy, badly paid, and no strike, or "combination," or "Union," will ever make it otherwise. We have no doubt that a large number of those who attend the meetings, and listen to the speeches, fancy that when they have got a "constitution and by-laws" they will never see hardship again, but there never was a more miserable delusion, and they will find it out before very long.

abstract: -- A crowded and select audience assembled at Niblo's Saloon on Monday evening, to witness a series of tableaux vivants, gotten up by a party of young ladies and gentlemen of this City, for the benefit of the Sanitary Commission. The entertainment was strictly a private one, and was very creditable to the originators. The programme was as follows: "The signing of the Abdication by Mary Queen of Scots; "The Game of Life;" "Death of Queen Margaret;" "The Elopement;" "Where ignorance is Bliss, 'twere folly to be wise." The Brigands, comprising four scenes: 1st, "The Entrance;" 2d, "The Theft;" 3d, "The Alarm;" 4th, "The Rescue;" "Players' Scene from Hamlet;" "Joan D'Arc;" "The Gipsey Camp;" "The taking of the White Vail;" "The taking of the Black Vail;" and six scenes from "Cinderella." The groupings were excellent and reflect creditably upon the manager. The interval between the different tableaux was somewhat lengthy, but it was apologized for by one of the members of the company in a neat speech in which he craved the indulgence of the audience on the ground that the company being amateurs and having to change their costumes and scenery so often they could not proceed with as much celerity as professional artists. Altogether the entertainment was well gotten up and carried through, netting a handsome amount. The audience left well pleased and assured that they had done some good to the cause of our sick and wounded soldiers.

abstract: Taylor, Bayard; Hannah Thurston
lead_paragraph: If familiarity with the actual universe were a disqualification for venturing on the ideal, few writers would labor under such disadvantages in the composition of a novel as BAYARD TAYLOR. "The Herodotus of the Modern World," there is scarcely a clime on the earth's surface where he has not penetrated and surveyed with his own eyes the habitudes of "all sorts and conditions of men." Happily, his new book proves that his sight is not wearied with seeing, nor his impressions of familiar things deadened, by his intimacy with the strange and foreign. It is confessedly a picture of certain developments in American life that the author considers have escaped the attention of cotemporary writers, bound together by the inevitable thread of alove-story, but relying less on the interest of a plot than on the truthful picturing of the characters met with in the country life of the United States, and the habits and associations habitually surrounding them. In this line Mr. TAYLOR has developed a new talent that will surprise the readers of his travels. There is a life and individuality about his portraits and a careful minuteness of delineation that stamp them at once as realities, and Seth Wattles, Rev. Mr. Waldo and their associates, are at once admitted as friends for life -- people whom we surely must have known somewhere. Spiritualism, philanthropy woman's rights, and the other hobbies of the day, all play a part in the development of character and incident. We have too much consideration for novel readers to abridge the story of the book and leave them the pleasure of tracing how the heroine softens down from the ultra-social reformer into the happy wife and mother. It is very rare for an established author to break new ground with such assured success as Mr. TAYLOR has done, and we predict a series of novels from his pen outnumbering the formidable array of his Travels.

abstract: Last evening soon after 8 o'clock, a boat containing twelve men from one of the Russian war vessels in the harbor, was run down by the ferry-boat Jersey City, of the Cortlandt-street line, while she was nearing the slip. All the sailors were thrown into the water and seven of them are believed to have been drowned. The other five were rescued by the crew of the ferry-boat.

abstract: The Battle of Tuesday
lead_paragraph: The official and other dispatches of this morning indicate that the action of Tuesday was reopened yesterday morning, and after brisk fighting, our forces under HOOKER and SHERMAN, got complete possession of Lookout Mountain, Missionary Ridge and all the points in dispute; and five or perhaps ten thousand rebels have been taken prisoners. BRAGG, the everlasting retreater, has succeeded in retreating at least a short distance, though it can hardly be said as yet that he has succeeded in anything, for operations are still in progress. If BRAGG falls back as far as the railroad junction at Dalton, which would be his first strategic stopping-point, it will give Gen. GRANT a beautiful opportunity to "bag" the swarm of greybacks who are operating against Gen. BURNSIDE, and if it be impossible to catch and overwhelm BRAGG's army, he will doubtless turn his attention to the other. Gen. GRANT's strategy and manoeuvreing in the two days' action has been beautiful in the extreme, as well as successful.

abstract: It is rumored that DROUYN DE LHUYS is drawing up an explanatory document, comprising the different questions which the Emperor intends to submit to Congress; in the meantime the English journals appear to be generally taking a view adverse to Congress. The Globe, Ministerial, opposes it. The Daily News and Morning Herald also oppose it, and agree that if it is held unfavorable results will ensue. The Times inquires what England will have to do in the Congress, should it ever prove more than an ideal conception, and points out that there is no place for England in it, all the honors being monopolized by France. The English Cabinet held meetings to consider upon the subject. The result has not transpired and other meetings is fixed for the 16th.

abstract: -- Between 11 and 12 o'clock last night a fire broke out on the third floor of the tenement house No. 35 Mulberry-street, occupied mostly by Italian organ-grinders. The flames soon extended to No. 37, same street, and before the fire could be extinguished these two buildings were nearly destroyed. The latter building was a large tenement house, and was occupied by many families. Building No. 35 Is owned by the Valentine estate, and is damaged to the amount of about $1,500. The loss to the inmates could not be ascertained. Several of them barely escaped with their lives.

abstract: Letter on Colored Volunteers
lead_paragraph: The "New-York Association for Colored Volunteers," formed at a meeting called by Peter Cooper, Gen. Sickles, Wm.C. Bryant, Gen. John Cochrane, Henry J. Raymond, Wm. Curtis Noyes, Wm.E. Dodge, David Dowd, David Dudley Field, and many other citizens -- of which meeting Gen. WM.K. STRONG, late of the army, was President -- took prompt measures for ascertaining the views of the National and State Governments concerning the conditions on which colored troops might be enlisted under the President's Proclamation for more volunteers. Gen. STRONG was requested to telegraph the War Department, and Mr. JAMES RODGERS went to Albany to learn the views of Gov. SEYMOUR on the subject.

abstract: It has been stated that the iron-clad Dictator would be launched on Thanksgiving Day. We are requested to say that this is not so, as the launch will not take place till Saturday, the 28th inst. No tickets of admission to the vessel can be given, as the ship-house is only large enough to accommodate the workmen making the launch. Only a few officers of the United States Navy will be admitted into the ship-house.

abstract: The London Times publishes a project for peace in America, by a Northern gentleman writer. He says if the war is to go on for a time, from mere momentum, perhaps, it must be let alone; but it should be turned as soon as possible from a war of attempted conquest to a war for limits and terms of settlement. He suggests that negotiations be opened at once with the Richmond Government for such settlements, and for making a more formal recognition. One of the matters for discussion -- the Confederates of course to be recognized de jure -- must be the navigation of the Ohio and Mississippi; and in the event of Maryland joining the South, the Susquehannah and Chesapeake are to be free, with a common tariff for the two Confederacies.
lead_paragraph: The London Times publishes a project for peace in America, by a Northern gentleman writer. He says if the war is to go on for a time, from mere momentum, perhaps, it must be let alone; but it should be turned as soon as possible from a war of attempted conquest to a war for limits and terms of settlement. He suggests that negotiations be opened at once with the Richmond Government for such settlements, and for making a more formal recognition. One of the matters for discussion -- the Confederates of course to be recognized de jure -- must be the navigation of the Ohio and Mississippi; and in the event of Maryland joining the South, the Susquehannah and Chesapeake are to be free, with a common tariff for the two Confederacies.

abstract: New-York Central; Mr. Corning's Position
lead_paragraph: Mr. CORNING by no means restricts the use of his position to supplying his road with the materials used in its management and repairs. Every occasion is alike prostituted to fill his already over-gorged purse. We will give an example from a score we have at hand. At the time of the consolidation, the owners of the Schenectady and Troy Railway were eager, of course, like good Hindoos, to be absorbed in the great totality, and to exchange their gross dross for fine gold. The road had proved itself to be the veritable elephant. For eleven weary years it had netted a heavy loss -- the cost of running far exceeding earnings. Not a cent was ever realized or expected on its capital. Its cost was about $700,000, but was purchased of certain parties, with a view of including it in the consolidation, for about $150,000. Mr. CORNING was not a party to this purchase, but undertook, for one-sixth part of the profits that might be realized, to engineer the poor outcast into the safe haven of consolidation, He got it reported by the Committee, but when the subject came up before the convention of the respective companies, the imposition was so palpable, that it was, upon the motion of Mr. H.B. GIBSON, of Canandaigua, stricken off the list of roads to be included. Mr. CORNING, nothing daunted, succeeded, in the absence of Mr. GIBSON, in getting the matter of this road recommitted, and at an adjourned meeting at Albany succeeded, by the use of tactics, of which he is a consummate master, in getting a favorable report, which brought the Troy road into the concern at a higher price than had been previously named, and higher than its actual cost. The price paid was $650,000 in Central stock, of which Mr. CORNING received $100,000 worth at the time, about $120 per share. The profits of the transaction that went into his pocket were fully $75,000. The Central Company at the same time assumed the payment of bonds to the amount of $100,000, loaned by the City of Troy to the Troy Road. This transaction, consequently, engineered by Mr. CORNING, and without whose aid it could not have been accomplished, cost the Company $750,000, and was just so much taken out of the pockets of the stockholders for the benefit of Mr. CORNING and his associates.

abstract: Barratt, Walter; Old Merchants of New-York
snippet: Barratt, Walter; Old Merchants of New-York
lead_paragraph: That often-quoted individual, "the oldest inhabitant," is at last discovered, "aut diabolus aut" -- WALTER BARRETT, or the gentleman who writes under that well-sounding pseudonym. Were fancy portraits, in THOMAS HOOD's style, now in fashion, our author would be fittingly represented by a sort of cross between Methuselah and the Calculating boy, so unfailing is his individual recollection of all that has happened on our Island, so intimate his knowledge of dates, figures, and even the street number of the houses occupied by his heroes. Though some may think a work of this nature merely panders to a diseased appetite for personal gossip, we are inclined to take a broader view of its claims to notice. The circumstances under which New-York has, within our own lifetime, risen from a petty provincial town to its present status of the largest commercial port in the world, and the third in population among cities of Christian civilization, are entirely exceptional, and have no parallel in ancient or modern history. The social and economic changes incident to such a transformation will be of the highest interest to the future philosophic historian, who will be thankful for the contribution to the knowledge of the subject contained in these volumes. In all former commercial countries, Venice, Genoa, Holland, England, the mercantile aristocracy has been enduring and permanent -- hereditary, in fact -- as much so as the lands and titles of the nobleman. The London Directory of 1863 records many names that figured in its first issue, (of which only two copies exist,) for 1677. Among bankers the instances are well known of the flourishing firms of STONE, MARTIN & CO., who represent an uninterrupted succession the house of Sir THOMAS GRAHAM, the princely Elizabethan merchant; Messrs. HOARES, of Fleet-street, with whose predecessor of the same style OLIVER CROMWELL kept his "running cash" account, or Messrs. CHILDS & CO., who had for a partner (and probably far from a "silent" one) the famous SARAH, Duchess of Marlborough. Other branches of commerce can show as deeply rooted stems, going back for two or three centuries. Unlike these hereditary magnates of the Exchange, the merchants of New-York have been, with scarcely an exception, the founders of their own fortunes, and their princely revenues are the work of their own hands. To these men and their successful enterprise, and not to the noisy politicians, the unexampled growth of the City is due, and it is fitting that they should not pass away without a record like that which our author seems supremely qualified to furnish. What DAVID VALENTINE is among the material antiquities of Manhattan, WALTER BARRETT is in relation to the human interests of the same olden time. The need of such chroniclers is peculiarly felt among us, because, from the shifting nature of its population, there is in New-York almost a total absence of the current tradition that connects the present with past times in smaller and slower moving communities. Mr. BARRETT intimates that his budget is far from being exhausted, and we hope to see many other volumes from his pen, equally bristling with facts and figures as the present.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. PRODUCTION OF GOUNOD'S OPERA OF "FAUST." The "Faust" which M. GOUNOD has set to music, is not the exuberant dramatic production of GOETHE, nor the simple, time- honored legend used by SPOHR.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- PRODUCTION OF GOUNOD'S OPERA OF "FAUST." -- The "Faust" which M. GOUNOD has set to music, is not the exuberant dramatic production of GOETHE, nor the simple, time- honored legend used by SPOHR. It is the melodrama of MM. BARBIEE and CARRE, which was placed last season at Niblo's Garden. The work, it will be remembered, retains many of the most striking situations of the original poem, but its plan, and its denouement, are different. Those who are familiar with the works of the great German poet, will perceive at once -- from the synopsis which accompanies our remarks on the music -- where the several divergences take place. M. GOUNOD's opera was produced in Paris nearly ten years ago. Its success was immediate, and its popularity has ever since been on the increase. Last night saw its production on the boards of our Academy, and witnessed a new success for the composer.

abstract: The men of Gen. SICKLES' command have combined to present to him a very handsome acknowledgment of their estimate of his merits as a soldier and as their commander. It is a camp carriage built by Messrs. WOOD & CO., and to be seen at their establishment No. 596 Broadway. In its general outline it resembles an English landau, but it has been very greatly Americanized, and is quite original in its construction and design. The wheels are painted a rich carmine, while the body is covered with imitation rattan'd work, technically known as "sham cane." The lining is of blue silk of the newest style, and the workmanship artistic in all its details. The part inside the carriage, ordinarily used for the front seat, is transformed into the most perfect escretoire. There are seven drawers, one extending completely across the carriage, for maps, &c., and the whole extending half way up the heighth of the carriage. From the top of this desk a lid turns down, forming the table upon which to write, and disclosing an apartment for pens, ink, etc. The drawer fronts and desk lid are of rosewood, inlaid with gold and silk trimmings, the escutcheons and keys to each drawer being of good metal, and richly embossed. A "rumble," or projecting seat in the rear of the carriage, furnishes room for two orderlies, while under the lid is a spacious larder, divided into compartments for "creature comforts." The "dickey seat" is the most perfect one of the kind ever exhibited in this City. It is set up upon scroll brackets, and was designed by Mr. WOOD, senior member of the firm. This seat is movable at pleasure, and affords an opportunity of driving a la Daumont, or postillion.

abstract: The steamship North Star, from Aspinwall Nov. 17, with $229,978 in treasure from California, arrived yesterday, bringing mails from South America and the Pacific Coast. The war between Guatemala and Salvador has ended, and BARRIOS, President of the latter Republic, evacuated the City of Salvador on the 26th ult., when the Guatemalian forces took possession. News from Quito to Oct. 31 fully confirms the report that war between New-Grenada and Ecuador is inevitable. Gen. FLORES (Ecuadorian) is reported to be on the frontier with 5,000 men, and MOSQUERA has gathered 3,000 to oppose them.

abstract: -- A flag-of-truce steamer came up to City Point on Saturday, with over one hundred tons of freight, on board, consigned to the prison authorities for distribution among the Yankee prisoners. When the steamer left Fortress Monroe, Capt. MULFORD was waiting there, with the steamer New-York, for the arrival of the Confederate surgeons, who were hourly expected from the North. The New-York was expected to reach City Point last evening or early this morning, with the surgeons on board.

lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: From Chattanooga the news grows more and more cheering. Gen. GRANT has achieved the greatest success of the war. He telegraphs officially that our captures amount to fifty-two pieces of artillery, three thousand prisoners, five ...
lead_paragraph: From Chattanooga the news grows more and more cheering. Gen. GRANT has achieved the greatest success of the war. He telegraphs officially that our captures amount to fifty-two pieces of artillery, three thousand prisoners, five thousand stand of arms and ten standards. Yesterday, the rebel army was in full flight for Dalton, Ga., burning the bridges to prevent pursuit, and destroying their depots, stores and every thing that could impede their retreat. Still later dispatches represent our pursuit as vigorous in the extreme. Gens. SHERMAN and THOMAS crossed the Chickamauga yesterday forenoon, and, at 5 o'clock last night, Gen. HOOKER was reported at Ringgold, Ga., full fifteen miles from the battle-field. Another battle was regarded as not improbable.

abstract: No man, woman or child in the vicinity of the Five Points went to bed hungry last night. The only card of invitation necessary to obtain a good dinner was a clean face, and if any little one had not this prima facie evidence of a holiday about her, kindhearted ladies were on hand with soap and towels to secure it.
lead_paragraph: No man, woman or child in the vicinity of the Five Points went to bed hungry last night. The only card of invitation necessary to obtain a good dinner was a clean face, and if any little one had not this prima facie evidence of a holiday about her, kindhearted ladies were on hand with soap and towels to secure it. At the Ladies' Mission, on the site of the Old Brewery, 500 children belonging to the school and Sunday School, sat down to a substantial dinner, supplied by the liberality of our large hotel proprietors and private citizens. The children were not only provided for internally, but externals were looked after, every boy and girl receiving a new suit of clothes; and this was not all, for through the kindness of some of the wholesale toy dealers in Broadway, Maiden-lane and John-street, the Superintendent, Mr. SCHAFFER, was enabled to give every member of the school a beautiful present. The hotels have given nobly to this Thanksgiving dinner. Mr. CROOK, No. 74 Chatham-street, gave a monster loaf of bread -- a "swamp angel" -- which, although it weighed 300 pounds, was not in the least bit heavy. Every good thing was abundantly provided, and hundreds of bright, clean, happy little children blessed the benevolent givers.

abstract: The True Policy Toward
lead_paragraph: There is a class of men who stick to the idea that something positive must be done by the Federal Government to end Slavery. Even the issue of the Emancipation Proclamation, a military measure for military ends solely, does not satisfy them. They want civil power exercised, and would gladly have even a breaking down of State lines and a reconstruction of the Government itself, as the only effectual means of destroying the institution of their special abhorrence.

abstract: Late accounts from the Arkansas River represent that the country is subject to frequent incursions of rebel conscripting squads, and that the citizens have been compelled to band together for mutual protection. abstract: Gen. GRANT has made another splendid haul of artillery from the rebels. He captured on Wednesday fifty-two cannon -- the largest number, if we remember aright, taken from the rebels in any field action of the war. On GRANT's magnificent march up to Vicksburgh, before he invested that place, he captured sixty pieces of field artillery -- thirty-six of them being taken at the action on the Big Black; and when Vicksburgh surrendered over 300 cannon fell into his hands. GRANT's losses in guns, throughout his career, have been trivial.
lead_paragraph: Gen. GRANT has made another splendid haul of artillery from the rebels. abstract: The Day's Observances
lead_paragraph: It is doubtful whether any day of Thanksgiving has been so generally, so purposely observed as yesterday. It broke upon us bright, clear and beautiful, and it really did seem as though Heaven designed participation with the prevailing happiness. At an unusually early hour all business was suspended, and long before the appointed time the several churches were filled to overflowing by those anxious to hear the words of religion and of loyalty-Yesterday they were made, as will be seen by the reports of the sermons we publish, almost synonymous terms. There appeared to be a general disposition to make the day one of thanksgivings, one of reverential enjoyment.

abstract: The high character, scholastic attainments, erudition and social qualifications of American Clergyman, are in strong contrast with the narrow prejudices and limited resources which have marked the history of other nations, and of earlier periods of the world. Coming directly in contact with the theories of the most enlightened minds, as well as the customs of common life, they are ...
lead_paragraph: The high character, scholastic attainments, erudition and social qualifications of American Clergyman, are in strong contrast with the narrow prejudices and limited resources which have marked the history of other nations, and of earlier periods of the world. Coming directly in contact with the theories of the most enlightened minds, as well as the customs of common life, they are better calculated to judge of popular opinion and current ideas, than any other class of men. Their influence is unbounded. Their opportunities for directing practical reforms and progressive developments impose many obligations. In acknowledgment of the many complimentary indorsements and favors which DR. DRAKE has received from Clergymen in behalf of his PLANTATION BITTERS, he has directed his Agents, Messrs. BARNES & CO., No. 202 Broadway, N.Y., to present a bottle gratis, to every Clergyman who may personally call during the remainder of this year, 1863.

abstract: The first regiment of negro soldiers that has appeared in this City, was encamped yesterday in front of the City Hall. The regiment was from Washington, and the negroes were mostly of the Maryland stock. The fighting capacity of the men really appeared to be excellent. In stature, they were smaller than the average of white regiments; in complexion, they were generally quite dark. In style, they did not quite equal some of our fancy holiday regiments; but for hard, serviceable work in the trenches, on the march or in the field, they seemed to have spirit and intelligence, as well as muscle. Many thousands of people visited the place where they were encamped during the day, and instead of jeers or violence toward the black doula of their country, there were almost universal expressions of admiration and applause.
lead_paragraph: The first regiment of negro soldiers that has appeared in this City, was encamped yesterday in front of the City Hall. abstract: New-York Central; Mr. Corning's Grasping Hand
snippet: New-York Central; Mr. Corning's Grasping Hand
lead_paragraph: Into whatever department of the Central we look, we always find the grasping hand of Mr. CORNING ever busy in promoting his own advantage. Everything has to bend to his insatiable avarice. He is the pivotal point around which the road, with all its ramifications, revolves. He will not brook the least restraint upon his will or his schemes. A notable instance of this occurred some years ago. For some time after the consolidation, the utmost looseness prevailed in the manner in which supplies for the road were furnished. Each official ordered whatever he pleased, and his order was deemed sufficient evidence, without any other proof, that the articles were needed for, and were used on the road. The accounts then received the initials of Mr. VIBBARD or Mr. CORNING, and were handed over by bushels to the committee on accounts to be passed by them. The committee saw the impropriety and wrong of all this, but what could they do? It happened, luckily, that Mr. CORNING made a visit to Europe, and during his absence they had sufficient influence with the Board to get a system adopted that effectually protected the Company. Every person using or disbursing supplies was required to return regular and frequent statements of the amount of materials or supplies on hand, and the amount required in his Department, so that it could be seen at a glance whether his requisition was a proper one, and whether the articles furnished had been judiciously expended. A purchasing agent was also appointed. All these reforms stared Mr. CORNING in the face when he came home. He was excessively angry, complained to the Committee that he had been grossly insulted by their interference, and set himself about to neutralize, as far as possible, their action. How far the checks that were adopted to prevent fraud or wastefulness in the ordering or use of supplies, have been abrogated, we cannot tell; but the purchasing agency was other discontinued, or it is now little, if anything, more than a go-between between Mr. CORNING and the Company. The Committee did their best to vindicate their conduct in the matter, but nothing could appease Mr. CORNING's wounded pride or his resentment at the interference with his prerogatives, and it was not long before some of the Committee, most resolute for reform, were left out of the Board.

abstract: At the Wooster-street Synagogue, services were held at 3 o'clock, embracing the usual afternoon prayers, conducted by Rev. S.M. ISAACS, the Prayer for the Government and appropriate hymns, after which an address was delivered by MYER S. ISAACS, Esq., son of the minister.
lead_paragraph: At the Wooster-street Synagogue, services were held at 3 o'clock, embracing the usual afternoon prayers, conducted by Rev. S.M. ISAACS, the Prayer for the Government and appropriate hymns, after which an address was delivered by MYER S. ISAACS, Esq., son of the minister. He commenced with a reference to the peculiar significance of the present day of thanksgiving, observed as it was by all Americans, wherever resident, in response to the recommendation of the Executive. It was a grand spectacle, an entire nation united in offering up incense on an altar of a religion all alike profess -- thanksgiving and praise to the Supreme Being. Divesting themselves of social, political and religious distinctions, superior to the division of sentiment engendered by sectional ideas and antagonistic theories, they assembled in their respective places of worship, to pour forth praises to Him enthroned on hish. Actuated by these considerations, his audience had gathered together in their house of God, that they too might join in the grand anthem swelling upward to celestial heights. Israelite and Christian grasped each other's hand in cordial confidence, working together, fighting together the battles of the Union, pouring their blood on the battle-field in friendly rivalry for country's sake. There was no trace of religious intolerance or sectional feeling in the proclamation of the day; we were called upon to observe it as Americans, acknowledging special obligations to Heaven for the providences so graciously displayed in the progress of our struggle for national existence, and not unmindful of His divine favor in the daily blessings unintermittingly showered upon us, whose value we often fail to diiscern until we are deprived of them.

abstract: Rev. WILLIAM ROBERTS, Pastor of the Thirteenth-street Welsh Presbyterian Church, delivered a short discourse, founded on the devout declaration of the Psalmist. "Not unto us, O Lord, not unto us, but unto Thy Name give glory, for Thy mercy, and for Thy truth's sake." Psalm cxv., 1.
lead_paragraph: Rev. WILLIAM ROBERTS, Pastor of the Thirteenth-street Welsh Presbyterian Church, delivered a short discourse, founded on the devout declaration of the Psalmist. "Not unto us, O Lord, not unto us, but unto Thy Name give glory, for Thy mercy, and for Thy truth's sake." Psalm cxv., 1. He observed that in returning thanks to the Lord, we ought to renounce all claim to, and participation in the glory, and ascribe it wholly to the Father of mercies. This constitutes the essence of pure gratitude and praise. And in entreating Him for deliverance from our present national troubles, our sole motive should be the glory of His Name, resting assured that He will honor them, who honor Him. Are the internal resources of the country fully adequate to our emergencies; have we been blessed with an abundant harvest; has the King Corn triumphed over King Cotton; is the intriguing counsel of the rebel leaders likely to be frustrated and abolished; is the sentiment of loyalty gaining the ascendency in the land; are our armies and navies achieving triumphant victories; is the nursing-cradie of the rebellion on fire, and likely to be reduced to ashes; have we lately obtained splendid victories at Chattanooga through our valliant soldiers under Gens. THOMAS, GRANT, HOOKER, &c., let us exclaim with feelings of profound gratitude, "Not unto us, but unto Thy Name give glory." We may gratefully acknowledge the services of men as instruments; but let us supremely honor the Great Arbiter of all events, regarding all others as means employed by HIM. More of God and less of the man. Do the signs of the times tell us that tyranny, oppression and Slavery, mental and physical, are on the eve of abolishment? Let us thank God and take courage. Do England and France refrain from recognizing the Confederate States as a Government, and from interfering in our civil quarrels? Whatever may be their motives, let us give the glory to God. Whether they are influenced by their enacted laws of freedom, or by principles bearing on self-preservation and safety; if the disturbed state of Europe restrains them; if the insurrection in Poland, or the peril attending the aggrandizement of power in Mexico retard their progress in this direction; if the arrival of the Russian fleet in our harbor has had any influence upon them; if the orations of Rev. H.W. BEECHER have been the means of enlightening their minds concerning the righteousness of our cause -- let us give the glory to HIM, who emphatically declares "I will not give my glory to another, nor my praise to graven images."

abstract: When Maj.-Gen. GRANT officially announces, as he does under date of Wednesday night, that his army has achieved a "complete victory over Bragg," the country will give to the statement such full degree of faith as has always been commanded by the dispatches of that officer.
lead_paragraph: When Maj.-Gen. GRANT officially announces, as he does under date of Wednesday night, that his army has achieved a "complete victory over Bragg," the country will give to the statement such full degree of faith as has always been commanded by the dispatches of that officer. For Gen. GRANT's modesty is as great as his genius; and in estimating the extent and scope of his former victories, he has never erred in attributing to them a magnitude not justified subsequently, but has been inclined rather to underestimate their value. It seems that the battle which Heaven crowned with this victory was far greater than appeared in the dispatches of yesterday; for Gen. GRANT says that on Wednesday the "battle lasted from early dawn till dark in the evening," and the large captures of artillery, small arms and prisoners, furnish proof that our gallant troops did their work well. It was no mere strategic success that Gen. GRANT gained, though no one could have read the dispatches of yesterday without seeing in the strategy the hand of a consummate master of scientific war; but beside this there was the heroic struggle front to front; and it was this combination of courage and skill that gave us the victory.

abstract: Communications of
lead_paragraph: In that particular district where operations are now being conducted, Gen. GRANT has no permanent line of water communication. He may use portions of the Tennessee and Cumberland Rivers during a portion of the year. But he cannot get steamers over the Muscle Shoals at any time, and over Harpeth Shoals in the Cumberland, only during very high water. At all other times he must depend on the railroad line to Louisville, now stretching from his front to his real base of operations, the weary distance of three hundred and fifty miles.

abstract: At the same hour that the BLUNT ratification meeting was held in Wall-street, yesterday, the friends of C. GODFEEY GUNTHER for Mayor, held a ratification meeting in Hanover-square. The meeting, which was highly respectable in point of numbers and character, was called to order by GEO. MCLEAN, who nominated for President EDWIN J. BROWN, Esq. Mr. BROWN, on taking the chair, thanked the audience for their compliment, and introduced as the first speaker Mr. THEODORE E. TOMLINSON. Mr. TOMLINSON spoke with great earnestness of the corruptions of our City Government, and the necessity of a thorough reform in its administration. The people were now afforded an opportunity to effect this much desired reform, by voting for Mr. GUNTHER, a man of the highest honor and integrity, who would administer the affairs of the City with the same regard for economy and justice as he would administer his own private affairs. Every man who had any interest in law and order, and the economical administration of the affairs of the City, he claimed should vote for Mr. GUNTHER, since it was only by so doing that the election of BOOLE, the "ring" candidate, could be prevented.

abstract: -- One prominent feature of BRAGG's discomfiture is the undoubted absence of nearly all his cavalry, under WHEELER, which he sent with LONGSTREET in the advance upon Knoxville. BRAGG is thus almost at GRANT's mercy. The value of well-trained cavalry in a retreat is incalculable. Without it the infantry force must stop, deploy, form line of battle, and employ great skill in falling back every time the pursuing force comes up. But with a cavalry rear-guard, the infantry force need only be on the alert, and has far greater opportunities to assist the artillery and transportation in getting off.

abstract: -- Those of our citizens who feel an intelligent interest in our system of Public Schools will do well to give special attention to the qualifications of the candidates they are asked to support for School Commissioners. The character of the Board of Education for the next two years depends on the Commissioners to be elected. As a matter of course, each political party has its own candidates in nomination, and in most of the Wards we are inclined to think both parties have paid somwhat more regard than has been usual to the necessity for selecting men of character and intelligence for this responsible position. But wherever either party has failed of its duty in this respect, the individual voter must apply the remedy. Nothing can excuse a citizen for voting for an ignorant, unprincipled or reckless man to have control of the Public School System of this City. And special care should be taken by every one who appreciates its value, and the necessity of maintaining its character at the highest possible point, to vote for no unfit man for the place, no matter what political party may have put him in nomination.

abstract: It can scarcely be necessary to remind those who are anxious for a reform in the Government of our City, that the only way to secure it is by electing honest, upright and capable members of the Common Council. The substantial power of the City Government rests in their hands. The Mayor is powerless in presence of an adverse Common Council, and all his efforts to put a check on a corrupt and lavish expenditure of the public money will be utterly fruitless, unless he has the support of its members. The only way to secure a Board which shall serve the public instead of the private interests of political jobbers, is by disregarding all considerations but those which relate to personal character and fitness for the place, and by voting for the best men in every instance, without regard to political or party relations. This will not always accomplish the object desired, but one thing is very certain -- if this will not, nothing will.

abstract: A special Washington dispatch, published in this journal last Monday, furnished to our readers and to history a remark which the President had made on the Sunday preceding, to the effect that the "ensuing two weeks would be the most momentous period of the rebellion." At the end of the first week, it would seem that the remark is not far out of the...
lead_paragraph: A special Washington dispatch, published in this journal last Monday, furnished to our readers and to history a remark which the President had made on the Sunday preceding, to the effect that the "ensuing two weeks would be the most momentous period of the rebellion." At the end of the first week, it would seem that the remark is not far out of the way. The resplendent and sweeping success of Gen. GRANT over the chief army of the rebellion, and at the most important military point of the South, the crossing of the Rapidan by the Army of the Potomac, under Gen. MEADE, and the imminency of a general battle with the other great army of the rebellion -- these are the events of the week, and they are events which, even in their present development, are not surpassed in magnitude by those of any week of the war. The one campaign, that of Gen. GRANT, is well on toward consummation; and the other, that of Gen. MEADE, is well begun, and the auspices are cheering for its success.

abstract: The Atlantic Monthly (Boston: TICKNOR & FIELDS) presents few special attractions in its present number, always excepting LONGFELLOW's charming poem, "The Birds of Killingworth," which is enough to redeem any magazine from the charge of medicerity. It is a New-England idyl, finished in the poet's best manner, and enlivened with sketches of the characters of a New-England town of the past, and heightened with the human interest of a brief love story. AGASSIZ on "Internal Structure and Progression of the Glacier," is of course above criticism. Mr. TUCKERMAN's "Something About Bridges,' a gathering of story and incident that stamps him as Pontifex Maximus. There is little else for remark. "Literary Life in Paris" reads like a translation from the French -- a sketch of HENRI MURGER's career, in the usual exaggerated style about authors and garrets; the writer does not know how to spell LABLACHE's name. GEORGE W. CURTIS contributes a critical sketch of LONGFELLOW, apropos to the publication of his new volume "The Way-Side Inn," rather a work of supererogation at the present time. We stare to see a careful scholar like Mr. CURTIS write "Chaucer's Canterbury Tales were told at the Tabard at Southwark." The usual critical notices complete the number, which is scarcely an average one.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamer Corsica at this port yesterdy, we have later advices from Havana, Nassau, and Santo Domingo. The revolution in the latter island presented no new features. Everything was quiet. At Nassau, N.P., the blockade business had assumed increased activi- ty. A dozen vessels were in port, bound on this trade. A rumor was current at Havana that the sloop-of-war St. Louis had sunk the pirate Georgia, off Canary Islands.

abstract: --Though those removed from the actual field of operations find it hard to sit in judgment upon the actors, righteously, yet sometimes it is harder to account for the policy, or no policy, that allows certain things to exist. In this way we are brought to wonder at the operations of MOSEBY's moss-troopers. There are but a few hundred of them, all told, and yet, though we are not led to believe that the band consists of anything but ordinary material, they have been suffered for a great while to annoy the Army of the Potomac, attacking outposts, cutting off supplies, stealing horses, and playing the spy generally, at very small cost to themselves. There is no reason why this handful of men should not long since have been hunted down by their own plan. Fire should eat fire, and if we have the cavalry that is represented on the other side of the Rapidan, volunteers should be called for to form a band of the same style, to hunt down these fellows, by following them into their very lurking places. If we cannot wipe out a few hundred guerrillas now, we certainly cannot expect quick success when the war will be almost entirely a guerrilla one.
lead_paragraph: --Though those removed from the actual field of operations find it hard to sit in judgment upon the actors, righteously, yet sometimes it is harder to account for the policy, or no policy, that allows certain things to exist. abstract: Financial Shock, the Coming
lead_paragraph: It is not to be denied that there is latent through all American society a vague dread, if not an expectation, of a coming financial or monetary "crash." Despite the wild speculations on the Stock Exchange, the mass of the community are dealing very cautiously. They carry everything snugly, as if at any moment a tremendous gale might break over them. Mr. BEECHER only uttered the exact truth when he said in Manchester that never in our whole history was so much cash business transacted by our merchants and retailers. Even the West, which has been wont to strain credit to the utmost, is now buying and selling for cash to an unprecedented degree. The long credits to the South which once rendered large branches of mercantile affairs so uncertain, are, of course, entirely at an end. The large floating capital of the country, which is ordinarily seeking every venture-some channel of speculation and enterprise, is now being absorbed by the safest and most permanent investments, such as railway bonds and Government securities. Taking the country through -- always excepting the stock-markets of New-York and Boston -- there is probably less reckless speculation than has been the case for years.
headline: {'main': 'The Coming "Financial Shock."', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Coming "Financial Shock."', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: It is not worth while to disguise the fact that our City election, which takes place next Tuesday, excites much less interest than it deserves. This will always be the case when the State canvass in November is at all heated and earnest, for the political enthusiasm of the community becomes then so much exhausted that the next contest, coming close upon its heels, must inevitably be much tamer and less exciting. On this account we consider it a serious misfortune for the City that the Charter election takes place only a month after the State canvass.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The performance of "FAUST," last night, was so near perfection that criticism can barely refer to it, except in terms of unlimited praise. All the hesitation of the first night had disappeared, and the artists did ample justice to themselves. The house was crowded, and the audience indulged in many encores, limiting them, it seemed, not by their desires, but by the painful necessity of allowing the performance to come to an end.

abstract: Rev. JAMES H. BROWN, of Milford, Penn., has been appointed by the President Chaplain of the Hospital at Beaufort, S.C. Mr. BROWN is a young man, held in highest esteem in his vicinity, and will bring to his position the zeal, earnestness and kindness of heart eminently fitting him for it. During the recent election in Pennsylvania, Mr. BROWN, who was zealously a Unionist, was deprived of his vote by the concerted plan of Copperheads who kept the Tax Collector out of the way, so that the paltry sum of 30 cents, which was necessary to be paid for taxes before voting, he could not pay the Collector despite his all-day search fur him. The position he now assumes is one where he can work much good, and where he will.

abstract: The meeting last evening at the Cooper Institute, was a grand gathering of the Democracy. The indorsement of FRANCIS I.A. BOOLE for Mayor by the unterrified, was enthusiastic. The inside of the lower hall was gaily festooned with flags and mottoes, such as "Our Union must and shall be preserved." "Our Country now and forever." The hall was crowed by an audience who were loud in their cheers for their favorite candidate.
lead_paragraph: The meeting last evening at the Cooper Institute, was a grand gathering of the Democracy. The indorsement of FRANCIS I.A. BOOLE for Mayor by the unterrified, was enthusiastic. The inside of the lower hall was gaily festooned with flags and mottoes, such as "Our Union must and shall be preserved." "Our Country now and forever." The hall was crowed by an audience who were loud in their cheers for their favorite candidate. On the outside of the building processions lined the street from almost every Ward, in the City, passing and repassing the doors, which could no longer admit delegations; bands of music, euphonious and otherwise, discoursed divers airs, and altogether it might be considered a great turnout.

abstract: -- Among Messrs. LITTLE & BROWN's announcements of new books is one that promises to reflect credit on their enterprise and on' the Boston Press. we refer to a new collection of Old English Plays, in ten volumes, to be edited by Prof. J. RUSSELL LOWELL. Every one interested in early English literature is acquainted with the collection that takes its name from DODSLEY, the publisher, and of which the last edition by COLLIER is now a scarce and covetable book. But little critical taste went to the selection in the first instance, and now the republication of the entire works of many authors sampled in it has much abridged its value. It will be an easy matter for Prof. LOWELL to excel his only predecessor and bring together a collection from the scarcer and hitherto inaccessible Elizabethan Dramatists that will delight every reader of taste, and be received with acclamation both here and in England. It is remarkable that the study of old English literature seems to follow the poet's "path of empire," and finds its greatest encouragement in the West; certain it is that the mother country has at present no critics engaged in the study that can compare in loving familiarity with the elder worthles of our tongue, and delicate tact for discriminating their beauties, with Prof. J.R. LOWELL, Prof. CHILDS and GEO. P. MARSH. The works of the latter are well characterised by The Reader as the most valuable of recent contributions to the study: "Mr. MARSH has made the study of our older literature, at first hand, a labor of love, and has brought a strong power of independent thought to bear upon it. The result is a series of disquisitions full of instruction, which no one can neglect without being in arrear of the best cotemporary knowledge of the subject."

abstract: The country will be horrified anew at the new revelations made of the continued and ceaseless atrocities practiced by the rebels upon our prisoners in the South. The statement which we publish to-day has been drawn up and submitted to the authorities by Surgeons who have just been released from the rebel dungeons.
lead_paragraph: The country will be horrified anew at the new revelations made of the continued and ceaseless atrocities practiced by the rebels upon our prisoners in the South. The statement which we publish to-day has been drawn up and submitted to the authorities by Surgeons who have just been released from the rebel dungeons. We would to Heaven we could doubt any of these statements, but when they come in this authentic form, sustained by the names of honorable and responsible professional gentlemen, and confirmed by the statistics and other evidence which they furnish, we can no more doubt them than we can doubt the evidence of our senses when we see the attenuated victims of rebel savagery tottering into our hospitals, from which most of them soon totter into the all-relieving grave.

abstract: The call, addressed to the merchants, tax-payers, and all irrespective of party, who desire to promote the interest of municipal reform, to meet in front of the Custom-house, Wall-street, on yesterday afternoon, to ratify the nomination of ORISON BLUNT for Mayor, met with a cordial and numerous response. The meeting was one of the largest ever held in Wall-street, and was characterized by more unanimity of feeling than is usually manifested at such gatherings. At the hour of commencing, the street in front of the Custom-house was filled, and the number for some time continued to be augmented. On the balcony were many prominent citizens, identified with the best interests of the City.
lead_paragraph: The call, addressed to the merchants, tax-payers, and all irrespective of party, who desire to promote the interest of municipal reform, to meet in front of the Custom-house, Wall-street, on yesterday afternoon, to ratify the nomination of ORISON BLUNT for Mayor, met with a cordial and numerous response. The meeting was one of the largest ever held in Wall-street, and was characterized by more unanimity of feeling than is usually manifested at such gatherings. At the hour of commencing, the street in front of the Custom-house was filled, and the number for some time continued to be augmented. On the balcony were many prominent citizens, identified with the best interests of the City.

abstract: The Union Convention of the Seventh District, composed of the Twelfth, Nineteenth and Twenty-second Wards, have renominated JAMES H. WELSH, the present incumbent, for Police Justice. In personal character, integrity and intelligence, he is the man for the place. To the rioter, rowdy and loafer, justice at his hands would be certain. Unlike Justice CONNOLLY, his Tammany opponent, he would not jeopardize the interests and safety of citizens by temporising with ruffians. Unlike Justice CONNOLLY, he would not in his judicial position conciliate or mollify those for whose punishment that position was created. By every rule by which to judge of the fitness of men for so important a position, JAMES H. WELSH is infinitely the superior of Justice MICHAEL CONNOLLY. The official career of the latter and his constant opposition to the conservative action of the police is well known to the public; perhaps one of his recent acts is not. That act was his leniency to a man who entered a restaurant during riot week, and, with a companion, demanded free liquor and free food; on the proprietor refusing, he set upon and beat him. Justice CONNOLLY was not in favor, as, substantially, he expressed himself of making much of what he considered a common "porter-house fight," and was indignant at Justice WELSH, who urged a full measure of punishment for the scandalous outrage. Thus did Justice MICHAEL CONNOLLY view an outrage perpetrated during the week of terror, when porter-houses, as well as private residences, were being threatened and sacked in all directions. Porter-house keepers and all other housekeepers in the Twelfth, Nineteeth, and Twenty-second Wards, should understand from this how much protection they will have should MICHAEL CONNOLLY be reelected. Though a brewer of malt, he evidently has no objection to his patrons being mauled. "Only a porter-house light," gentlemen, that's all -give drink and food free, and you'll escape a beating Every taxpayer in this district, every respectable citizen, should cast party aside and see that Justice MICHAEL CONNOLLY is not reelected to a position which, by such decisions, furnishes no safety to either their families, their persons or their property. It is not the time now to take men for judicial positions in this City who even wink at the rioter and the rowdy, much less close both eyes on them. Let the law-abiding and law-wishing citizens of the Twelfth, Nineteenth and Twenty-second Wards give, for their own sakes, this matter the consideration it deserves. If they do, JAMES B. WELSH will be elected, the legitimate object of the judicial position preserved, and the safety of themselves and property at all times assured. Capt. JAMES BRYAN, who was first nominated by the Union party, has withdrawn in favor of Justice WELSH, and gives to him a hearty support.

abstract: John Underwood vs. John Green. -- This was an action to determine the rights and powers of the City Inspector and his subordinates, as to the seizure and removal of dead animals. Under a literal construction of the ordinance authorizing the removal of dead animals as well as other nuisances, it has been the custom of defendant, as contractor with the City, to station men at the several railroad depots, with orders on the arrival of cattle trains to seize all animals that may have died on the way. As these dead beasts have considerable value, Mr. Green has been reaping handsome profits from this arrangement, with a corresponding loss to the unlucky owners. About a year ago a train arrived at the Hudson River Depot, having upon it hogs belonging to the plaintiff, Underwood. By some accident, forty-two of them had been suffocated on the way down. Mr. Green's deputies, familiarly known among cattlemen as the "turkey buzzards," delighted with so large a haul, pounced on the hogs and carried them off. They were worth, for soapfat, &c., $252, Judge LARBOUR held that, under the Constitution, neither the Legislature nor the City Councils had the right to authorize the seizure of private property except for public use, or when the same had become a nuisance and detrimental to public health; that, to construe the ordinance literally was unreasonable, inasmuch as such a construction would authorize the seizure of slaughtered cattle, or of dressed animals brought to the City for sale, as being "dead animals;" that the hogs in question were private property and were not shown to be a nuisance, and that plaintiff was entitled to a verdict. Therefor verdict for plaintiff $269 64. The question will probably be carried up.

abstract: -- For some time a gang of men have been engaged in stealing horses in Maine and running them to Vermont, and, on their returns taking to Maine horses stolen in Vermont. Investigations were carried on quietly, and it was ascertained that two men named ROBERTS, supposed to belong to Lewiston, Me., were connected with the gang. Recently, a woman known to be the wife or mistress of one of these men, hired a house in the village at Bradford, Vt. The detectives became aware of this, and kept a lookout for visitors to the house. On Monday the premises were searched, and four men, who had reached the village the previous night on foot, were found concealed there. The brothers ROBERTS were of the number -- the other two gave the name of SMITH, and say they belong to Maine. It is probable that the four will be taken to Maine for trial. They are all young men.

abstract: The news from the Army of the Potomac this morning is of a highly important character. Gen. MEADE's army began its advance yesterday morning, in three columns, and by daylight this morning had successfully crossed the Rapidan at three places, Culpepper, Jacob's Mills, and Germanna Fords. The enemy offered very little resistance, and fell back from the river. After crossing the river our columns each took a different route, all converging on the Orange Court-house road. Yesterday firing was heard all day at Rappahannock Station, but no particulars had been received in Washington up to midnight. The troops were in splendid spirits, and shouting, "GRANT and victory!"
lead_paragraph: The news from the Army of the Potomac this morning is of a highly important character. Gen. abstract: Gen. EWING, in command of the District of the Border Department of Missouri, has issued an order looking to a partial resettlement of the counties on the western border of Missouri, depopulated by a previous military order of the same General. Loyal persons removed by the operations of that order, with some exceptions, are permitted to return, on condition that they at all times give active assistance in the discovery and pursuit of rebels and guerrillas. Such will be furnished with permits and safeguards, which are not to be violated by the military, under the severest penalties. For the prevent, permits will not be given to individuals owning no lands or crops, nor to persons to live in the timber at a greater distance than three miles from a military station, nor to persons having near relatives in the rebel service. A condition of returning is that the men of the district question form themselves into military organizations, each company to comprise not less than thirty, who are to be armed, clothed and provided by the Government, as active militia of the State. The form of the permit and safeguard is appended to Gen. EWING's order.

abstract: -- Experiments of an important nature have just been made at the fortress of Carlberg, in Sweden, upon the respective merits of armor-plates made in England, France and Sweden. Messrs. JOHN BROWN & CO., of Sheffield, sent two plates, one 12 feet by 2 feet 6 inches, and one 6 feet by 3 feet 8 inches. Messrs. PETIN, GUADET & CO., of Lyons, sent two plates, each of 7 feet 6 inches by 3 feet 3 inches.

abstract: Capt. JOURDON, of the Sixth Precinct, yesterday arrested CHARLES DOWNEY, on a warrant issued by Coroner NAUMANN, which charges DOWNEY with having in May last caused the death of SOPHRONIA HANNEGAN, by throwing boiling water upon her. The victim died from the effects of the scalds soon after. An inquest was held on the body at the time and the jury rendered a verdict against him. DOWNEY made his escape and nothing could be learned of his whereabouts until yesterday. He was taken before Justice DOWLING, at the TOMBS, where, after a preliminary examination, he was committed on the charge of murder.

abstract: There is a matter of interest in relation to the late draft and the enrollment connected therewith, which has lately been disposed of by the Provost-Marshal-General, in Circular No. 101, issued Nov. 17, 1863, which is of much interest to our readers, and has, as yet, not generally been made public. By this order, the Provost-Marshal-General directs, "that the Boards of Enrollment in each District shall have the printed lists of the names and residences of all persons enrolled in each Sub-District, prepared, and exposed to public view in at least five places, and in as many more as the Board may deem necessary." These lists are to be printed in alphabetical order, and public notice is to be given of the same in the newspapers. The order further provides That any person so enrolled has the privilege of appearing before the Board of Enrollment up to the 20th day of December next, and show to the members thereof that he is not, and will not be, at the time filed for the next draft, liable to military duty on account of either "alienage, non-residence, unsuitableness of age, or manifest permanent disability." After the 28th December no cases will be heard by the several Boards.

abstract: CINCINNATI, Friday, Nov. 27. We have some reports from Knoxville which  seem to indicate that Gen. BURNSIDE is perfectly secure in his position. The rebel cavalry are now in the country lying between Cumberland Gap and Knoxville, but no damage has been done to our communications with Gen. BURNSIDE as yet.

abstract: We publish this morning a series of very interesting letters from a correspondent who has had excellent opportunity to investigate the new condition of the negroes in the Southwest, their military organization, and the operations of the Government plantations, under the free-labor system. The facts set forth show the nature of the vital changes which the system of Slavery and its attendant social state are undergoing. Slavery perishes, and society changes so rapidly and radically that the return of peace will find many of the elements and features which distinguished the South in past years, gone forever. The accepted solution of the question, "What shall we do with the emancipated slaves?" receives additional clearness from our correspondent's experiences. So crude and undisciplined are the habits and personal, resources of the blacks that to make them soldiers seems a necessary preliminary to making them freemen. The discipline, knowledge and experience thus acquired, will aid them vastly when thrown upon their own resources.
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning a series of very interesting letters from a correspondent who has had excellent opportunity to investigate the new condition of the negroes in the Southwest, their military organization, and the operations of the Government plantations, under the free-labor system. The facts set forth show the nature of the vital changes which the system of Slavery and its attendant social state are undergoing. Slavery perishes, and society changes so rapidly and radically that the return of peace will find many of the elements and features which distinguished the South in past years, gone forever. The accepted solution of the question, "What shall we do with the emancipated slaves?" receives additional clearness from our correspondent's experiences. So crude and undisciplined are the habits and personal, resources of the blacks that to make them soldiers seems a necessary preliminary to making them freemen. The discipline, knowledge and experience thus acquired, will aid them vastly when thrown upon their own resources.

abstract: The first annual ball of the New York Painters' Association takes place at this popular hall to-morrow evening. The Committee of arrangements feel sanguine of having every thing that can be done to promote the pleasure and enjoyment of their guests.
lead_paragraph: The first annual ball of the New York Painters' Association takes place at this popular hall to-morrow evening. The Committee of arrangements feel sanguine of having every thing that can be done to promote the pleasure and enjoyment of their guests. Tickets to the number of eight hundred have been disposed of already, and doubtless many more will be sold at the door. It is the desire of those having the matter in charge that all gentlemen should be accompanied by at least one lady. With the music of the Seventh regiment band in Irving Hall on a fine evening, the affair cannot fall to prove a success.

abstract: Fault-finders and ill-informed persons frequently complain of the unsatisfactory results of all the battles and campaigns of this war. They say that none of our officers have yet destroryed an army of the rebels, and that
lead_paragraph: Fault-finders and ill-informed persons frequently complain of the unsatisfactory results of all the battles and campaigns of this war. They say that none of our officers have yet destroryed an army of the rebels, and that our greatest victories have simply and always ended by the defeated enemy retreating a short distance, reforming his lines, recruiting his ranks, and preparing for the next onset, in which the chances of success might be on one side or the other, but in which, whatever side might beat, nothing would be settled.

abstract: The identity of the dead soldier who was found on the bloody field of Gettysburgh, with the picture of his three pretty little children tightly clasped in his hands, has been ascertained within a day or two.
lead_paragraph: The identity of the dead soldier who was found on the bloody field of Gettysburgh, with the picture of his three pretty little children tightly clasped in his hands, has been ascertained within a day or two. The wide publicity given to the touching circumstance through the medium of the Press, produced the desired result. The name of the deceased was HUMMERTON, and his widow and three children reside at Portville, Cattaragus County, New-York.

abstract: A correspondent at Queenstown denies the correctness of the report that the Captain of the Federal steamer Kearsage took on board a number of men as stokers, and that he threatened to disobey the orders for his departure. On the contrary, he complied with the utmost promptness with the request in
lead_paragraph: A correspondent at Queenstown denies the correctness of the report that the Captain of the Federal steamer Kearsage took on board a number of men as stokers, and that he threatened to disobey the orders for his departure. On the contrary, he complied with the utmost promptness with the request in the dispatch of Admiral Sir LEWIS JONES. A number of the officers were that evening at the theatre in Cork, and a party of them intended to pay a visit to Blarney Castle next morning, but on the receipt of the dispatch Capt. WINSLOW sent them word that they were wanted on board immediately, and so the ship departed.
