abstract: It may not be known that our late marine visitor, the British ship-of-war sutlej, entered our harbour in a huff and leit in a very dissatisfied frame of mind. On entering the harbor she neglected to obey the port regulations by bringing to, and Alcatraz accordingly.
lead_paragraph: It may not be known that our late marine visitor, the British ship-of-war sutlej, entered our harbour in a huff and leit in a very dissatisfied frame of mind. On entering the harbor she neglected to obey the port regulations by bringing to, and Alcatraz accordingly fired an 11-inch shell across her stern -- an insult her Britannic Majesty could not brook, albeit the shell was an empty one. The Admiral rather growlingly demanded an explanation of Gen. WEIGHT, which the General courteously gave, indorsing the half-shell action of Alcatraz firing, however. The Admiral was not satisfied, and wrote another letter, stating his conviction that a boat should have been sent off to board him and ascertain the august nature of the vessel before firing a shot across her royal wake. Before Gen. WRIGHT's second reply was penned and sent, the Sutlej sailed, and the matter may yet he made the subject of diplomatic correspondence. -- San Francisco Bulletin.

abstract: Palmerston, Lord, False S??? Against
lead_paragraph: An attempt, as everybody knows, is being made at this moment to fasten upon Lord PALMERSTON an imputation which would, under any circumstances, be a very painful one, and which, if proved, would hardly fail to have for a man of his age the most disastrous consequences. Society, let it be ever so indulgent, and English society is very indulgent, is not likely to wink at the follies of a veteran of eighty-four. The middle classes insist upon at least a show of morality in public men. And the Queen has been long famed for her rigid and inexorable attention to the purity of the Court. So that we may presume that if it were fairly proved that the Nestor of English statesmen had forgotten what he owed to his years, name, and position, he would close his career in something worse than obscurity.

abstract: However much our oft-intercepted public correspondence may amuse the enemy, they inflict no serious wound, nor are their contents of the slightest importance. What does possess some weight, is the fact that a large cargo of saltpetre and other munitions of the army were intercepted at the same time.
lead_paragraph: However much our oft-intercepted public correspondence may amuse the enemy, they inflict no serious wound, nor are their contents of the slightest importance. What does possess some weight, is the fact that a large cargo of saltpetre and other munitions of the army were intercepted at the same time. The loss of cargoes has become not less frequent lately than the loss of dispatches, and hurts a great deal more. But we shall soon be proof against even these injuries. The Confederacy is daily becoming more and more independent of Europe. Nearly all the things which we need are now manufactured in the South, and the quantities supplied both to the Government and to the people, are already sufficient to lower the price of goods procured through the blockade. In another year the South may laugh at the blockade. In the beginning of the war we depended on Europe for every shoe, for every pound of powder -- almost for every new gun. The demand of the people for the ordinary articles of civilized life was equally imperious. Had the blockade been as close in the first two years of the war as now, we might have had a much worse time of it than is commonly supposed. Under the demand, manufactories sprang into existence in the South. But, although established with unexampled rapidity, they could not meet all our wants in a year; they are even yet insufficient; but they will very shortly be complete, and then we may cease to be troubled about intercepted letters or cargoes, and can carry on a war of defence indefinitely, as well without as with, the recognition of the European Powers.

abstract: POSTPONEMENT OF THE LAUNCH. -- The announcement that the iron-clad Dictator would be launched yesterday, caused quite a large number of persons to assemble at the Delamater Iron works, where the ship was on the stocks. There being some imperfection, however, in the grease with which the ways were covered, the vessel could not be struck off in the short space during which full tide lasts. She will probably be floated off at the first full tide.

abstract: East, Failure of Rebel Resource
lead_paragraph: The rebel journals say truly enough that their Government never appreciated the importance of East Tennessee to the Confederacy until they had lost it. Their former want of appreciation is shown by the feeble resistance they made to the advance of Gen. BURNSIDE; and their subsequent change of mind is indicated by their desperate efforts to recover what, by that advance, they had lost. Not to dwell at present on the military view, and on the incalculable strategic value of such points as Cumberland Gap, Knoxville, Cleveland and the line of the East Tennessee and Virginia Railroad, it is beyond doubt that the mountainous regions of Eastern Tennessee and of Southwestern Virginia are of essential value to the rebels in the furnishing of resources for maintaining the war.

abstract: We are happy to see that the objections brought against certain portions of the Bible are about to be met by leading theologians of the Church of England in a very practical way. If a false and unfair system of interpretation has been applied to the text of Scripture, the best way of confuting it is to apply a true
lead_paragraph: We are happy to see that the objections brought against certain portions of the Bible are about to be met by leading theologians of the Church of England in a very practical way. If a false and unfair system of interpretation has been applied to the text of Scripture, the best way of confuting it is to apply a true and legitimate one. The honor of originating the plan is due to the Speaker of the House of Commons, who consulted several of the Bishops on the subject, and the Archbishop of York, at his instance, undertook to organize a plan for producing a commentary which should "put the reader in full possession of whatever information may be requisite to enable him to understand the Word of God, and supply him with satisfactory answers to objections resting upon misrepresentation of its contents." The plan has received the sanction of the Primate. A committee, consisting of the Archbishop of York, the Bishops of London, Lichfield, Llandaff, Gloucester and Bristol, Lord Lyttleton, the Speaker, Mr. Walpole, Drs. Jacobson, and Jeremie, takes the general supervision of the work. Rev. F.C. Cook, preacher at Lincoln's Inn, will be the general editor, and will advise with the Archbishop of York and the Regius Professors of Divinity at Oxford and Cambridge upon any questions which may arise. The work will be divided into eight sections, the first of which will consist of the Pentateuch, a difficult subject, and will be edited by Prof. Harold Browne, Revs. R.C. Pascoe, T.F. Thrupp, T.E. Espin, and W. Dewhurst, contributing. The historical books will be consigned to Rev. G. Rawlinson, editor, and Revs. T.E. Espin and Lond Arthur Hervey, contributors. Rev. F.C. Cook will edit, and Revs. E.H. Plumptre, W.T. Bullock and T. Kingsbury will annotate, the poetical books. The four Great Prophets will be undertaken by Dr. MCCaul as editor, and by Revs. R. Payne Smith and H. Rose as contributors. The Bishop of St. David's and the Rev. R. Gandell will edit the twelve Minor Prophets, and the Revs. E. Huxtable, W. Drake, and F. Meyrick will contribute. The Gospels and Acts will form the sixth section; the first three Gospels will be edited by Prof. Mansel, the Gospel of St. John by the Dean of Canterbury, and the Acts by Dr. Jacobson. The editorship of St. Paul's Epistles is appropriately assigned to Bishop Ellicott and Dr. Jeremie, with Dr. Gifford, Prof. T. Evans, Rev. J. Waite, and Prof. J. Lightfoot as contributors. To the Archbishop-elect of Dublin and the Master of Balliol is assigned the rest of the sacred canon. This really promises to be a work second only in importance to the LXX, or the English version made by the older of King JAMES. Perhaps it will be quoted as "the XXX." The names of the editors and contributors, while they insure of hodoxy, give promise that the comment thus put forth a most with the sanction of the Church of England as a body will not be the utterance of any narrow school or section of it.

abstract: We publish this morning an interesting budget of foreign news received by the Arabia vid Boston, being the details of what came epitomized over the wires from Halifax. Among the latest items are accounts from St. Petersburgh, which
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning an interesting budget of foreign news received by the Arabia vid Boston, being the details of what came epitomized over the wires from Halifax. Among the latest items are accounts from St. Petersburgh, which state that in well informed circles the belief is held that Russia will now be less disposed to consent to the proposed Congress than she would have been some months ago, as the situation in the interval has greatly changed. The statement that Russia has assented must therefore be regarded as quite premature, if not entirely devoid of foundation. The Russian papers publish an imperial ukase, ordering the formation of twelve new regiments of infantry, each containing three battalions, to form the Third reserve corps. In France the former custom of the Emperor's Ministers to meet every Friday, at a dinner given by each in turn, which during the Summer has not been observed, was to be regularly resumed on the 13th, and the Minister of State was to be the host at the first meeting. The Yellow Book, containing the diplomatic documents, was to have been distributed on the 14th to the members of the Senate and the Legislative body. The latest bulletin respecting the health of the King of Denmark is dated Copenhagen, Nov. 14. It says; "The erysipelas spread yesterday over the King's whole face, with increasing fever, and continued with slight delirium. No accession of the erysipelas took place last night. Having obtained a little sleep, His Majesty is rather better to-day."

abstract: -- There has been almost a total cessation, throughout the State of Missouri of late, in the work of arson and murder which rebel bushwhackers and guerrillas have carried on for the last two years. Not since the rebellion broke out has the State enjoyed such a degree of quiet. This is doubtless owing in part to the fact that some of the local rebel leaders, such as PRICE and MARMADUKE, have been driven out of the State and far south of the Arkansas River, while others, like JEFF. THOMPSON, have been caught and caged, and still others have repented them of their evil ways. But due credit must also be given to the policy of firmness and conciliation adopted by the commander of the Department, Gen. SCOFIELD. He has not scrupled, on occasion, to issue orders as stringent and severe as have been issued by any General in the field, as witness his various orders and measures concerning bushwhackers and steamboat burners, but he has not embroiled himself nor his army in the disputes between the various factions which have raged so fiercely and belligerently during the year, and he has avoided, so far as possible, every occasion and ground of quarrel. He has had a very difficult part to act; for his bitterest opponents have not been the avowed rebels, but those professedly loyal to the powers that be in Washington. The various factions have been at swords' points with each other, and it almost seemed at one time as if civil war between them could not be avoided. But Gen. SCOFIELD has succeeded not only in reducing the avowed rebels to peace and quietness, but in mollifying the fury of the factions, and calming the agitated passions of the hour. The victories won in the field secure honors and applause to our successful Generals, but the more laborious and harassing, and not less successful efforts of administrators like Gen. SCOFIELD, also demand recognition from a patriotic people and a well-served Government.

SCOFIELD has succeeded not only in reducing the avowed rebels to peace and quietness, but in mollifying the fury of the factions, and calming the agitated passions of the hour. The victories won in the field secure honors and applause to our successful Generals, but the more laborious and harassing, and not less successful efforts of administrators like Gen. SCOFIELD, also demand recognition from a patriotic people and a well-served Government.

abstract: From returns received at the Assistant ProvostMarshal-General's office, it appears that the number of soldiers enlisted in this City, under the new call for volunteers, during the past week, has been about eight hundred. This includes those returned to the
lead_paragraph: From returns received at the Assistant ProvostMarshal-General's office, it appears that the number of soldiers enlisted in this City, under the new call for volunteers, during the past week, has been about eight hundred. This includes those returned to the Assistant Provost-Marshal's recruiting offices and those enlisted at Mr. BLUNT's recruiting office in Broadway. As the recruiting business was not fairly in operation until Monday last, this is considered a very encouraging result for the first week. Capt. MCGEE, of the Sixty-ninth N.Y.S.M., now attached to Gen. HAY's office, has just returned from a visit to his regiment under Gen. MEADE, and brings with him a written document, signed by every officer and soldier of the Sixty-ninth, pledging themselves to reenlist for three years at the expiration of their present term of service. The Sixty-ninth now numbers about seventy men. Under the recent orders of the War Department, they will be allowed a furlough of forty days between the expiration of their present term and the time of their reenlisting. On reenlisting, they will be entitled to the Government bounties, and Capt. MCGEE has procured from Mr. BLUNT a promise that they shall also receive the $300 bounty offered by the Board of Supervisors. Capt. MCGEE says that the Sixty-third and Eighty-eighth, from this City, have also signified their intention to reenlist for three years, and he has no doubt many other New-York regiments will do the same. Gen. HAYS yesterday received the following dispatch from the War Department in reference to the enlisting of negroes in this State:

abstract: It is good for any people, at any time, truly to thank our Heavenly Father for his blessings. For then this day's sun would go down upon the wrath of no man or woman of the land.

abstract: The "Union" is not restored, and will never be. If it had been, the Irish soldiery, after their work was done, would have been thrown aside like any other broken tool cheated, as usual. And the green flags the torn on many a battle-field, and the bones of those who were to liberate Ireland whiten the plains
lead_paragraph: The "Union" is not restored, and will never be. If it had been, the Irish soldiery, after their work was done, would have been thrown aside like any other broken tool cheated, as usual. And the green flags the torn on many a battle-field, and the bones of those who were to liberate Ireland whiten the plains of the continent from Galveston to the Potomac. It is pity of them; yet they deserved their fate. They were prompt to carry fire and sword into the peaceful abodes of a people who had never wronged them, and to make an Ireland of these Confederate States, that they might redeem their own. It was a crime sure to bring its own punishment. Ireland doubtless will be, and ought to be, emancipated from English dominion, but not this way.

abstract: It may not be amiss to caution the public against over-sanguine estimates of the recent victories of the Union arms. There seems to be no doubt that GRANT has achieved a very brilliant success, and has defeated BRAGG's army, which was the main strength of the rebellion in that quarter. It is not yet certain, however, that he has so routed and broken it as to prevent it from taking the field again, though it is not likely that its old strength can ever be renewed. BURNSIDE is still in a position of danger, though our latest advices indicate his ability to hold his ground until aid can reach him. MEADE, moreover, has commenced a movement against LEE, from which we may reasonably anticipate the best results, though it is well to remember that LEE is a much more formidable opponent to deal with than BRAGG.

abstract: There will be an extra performance at the Academy of Music to-night, for the benefit of Mr. MAX MARETZEK. Such an announcement would be meanly received if it did not suffice to fill the establishment from pit to roof. Mr. MARETZEK's energy during the past two months has been unexampled. He has produced several new operas and revived a dozen of acceptable old ones. In the last week of his season he treated his patrons to GOUNOD's "Faust" -- a work which will be repeated for his benefit to-night. If Mr. MARETZEK had been able to bring this important work before the public at an earlier period of the season, he would have gained a rich reward for his enterprise. The work has leaped already into popularity. The performance on Friday night was enthusiastic. All the leading morceaux were encored. It is significant, too, that on Saturday Mr. THEODORE THOMAS gave a selection from the opera at his popular matinee, whilst in the evening the Arion Society, at their grand vocal and instrumental concert, sang the soldiers' chorus of the 4th act with immense success. On the same night, too, Mr. S.B. MILLS played at the same entertainment LISZT's famous arrangement of the waltz in the second act. If Mr. MARETZEK could remain at the Academy for a month longer, he would have no occasion to change his programme. The "Faust" furore would carry him safely through to Christmas. This, unfortunately, is no longer possible. To-night we are to hear the opera for the last time. This, and the circumstance that the impresario is a favorite with the public, will, we are sure, fill the house to overflowing. If it does not, nothing we can say will contribute to that end.

He has produced several new operas and revived a dozen of acceptable old ones. In the last week of his season he treated his patrons to GOUNOD's "Faust" -- a work which will be repeated for his benefit to-night. If Mr. MARETZEK had been able to bring this important work before the public at an earlier period of the season, he would have gained a rich reward for his enterprise. The work has leaped already into popularity. The performance on Friday night was enthusiastic. All the leading morceaux were encored. It is significant, too, that on Saturday Mr. THEODORE THOMAS gave a selection from the opera at his popular matinee, whilst in the evening the Arion Society, at their grand vocal and instrumental concert, sang the soldiers' chorus of the 4th act with immense success. On the same night, too, Mr. S.B. MILLS played at the same entertainment LISZT's famous arrangement of the waltz in the second act. If Mr. MARETZEK could remain at the Academy for a month longer, he would have no occasion to change his programme. The "Faust" furore would carry him safely through to Christmas. This, unfortunately, is no longer possible. To-night we are to hear the opera for the last time. This, and the circumstance that the impresario is a favorite with the public, will, we are sure, fill the house to overflowing. If it does not, nothing we can say will contribute to that end.

abstract: The Union defeat in this City, a month ago, ought to secure a Union victory to-morrow. It realized nothing then, and yet guarantees everything now, if we will but do our duty. Not one distinctive Union candidate was elected on the general City ticket, and yet it was demonstrated that this was not from want of abilty, but from the lack of system
lead_paragraph: The Union defeat in this City, a month ago, ought to secure a Union victory to-morrow. It realized nothing then, and yet guarantees everything now, if we will but do our duty. Not one distinctive Union candidate was elected on the general City ticket, and yet it was demonstrated that this was not from want of abilty, but from the lack of system atic and well directed effort. There was nothing of that thoroughness in detail on which the efficiency of a popular canvass so much depends, and, what was even worse, there was an absence of that faith necessary to give any movement its proper impetus, any blow its rightful effect. Mozart and Tammany had so long ruled the City that it was almost taken for granted that it was simply labor lost to right them. Our people had been so long used to their arbitrary power, that they had acquired very much the same sort of submissive spirit that keeps a European community quiet, even under a most unwelcome yoke. The outrageous abuse of that power by the attempt to make such a men as MCCUNN a high Judge over our liberty and property, stung us into a spasm of resistance, like some European emeute -- rather the effect of despair than the prompting of hope. And yet, this wild, striking act of the day came very near laying the tyranny in the dust. It is now seen that the merest additional trifle of wise, discriminating effort would have done the business for MCCUNN, and that it would have cost not much more to have served out the other special favorites. Mozart and Tammany, though not knocked from their feet, were yet dreadfully staggered. If the true men of the City will only make another onset to-morrow, with the right concert and determination, their enemy, it is very certain, will get a quietus, for this year at least.

abstract: It will be seen by a card in our advertising columns, that ANSON WILLIS has withdrawn in the Eighth District in favor of Judge QUACKENBUSH. There are two Democratic candidates in the field, ANDREW LEARY, the McKeon nominee, being a man not likely to be bought or coaxed off, as he runs to rebuke and defeat what he considers the corrupt and discreditable practices of his own party. Judge QUACKENBUSH has proved his fitness for this place by faithful, upright and effective service in it; we trust he will be reelected.

abstract: This District, embracing the Eighteenth and Twenty-first Wards, has a large Democratic majority, and the chances are that the Democracy will carry it for all their candidates, unless a concentration be made in it of the votes of those who seek a new and better order of things. For the office of Civil Judge, Mr. GEORGE C. BARRETT, of the firm of BARRETT, BRINSMADE & BARRETT, well known lawyers in Wall-street, has been placed in nomination by several of the Anti-Machine Democratic organizations, and also by the Independent Tax-payers' Association. He is indorsed by our leading lawyers of all parties, in a card published elsewhere, as one eminently fit for the position he aspires to fill. It is in itself a healthy sign when men such as DANIEL LORD, WM.M. EVARTS, JAMES W. GERARD, MURRAY HOFFMAN, RICHARD O'GORMAN, &c., &c., all unite in an effort to secure fit occupants for the Judicial Bench. Mr. ROBERT D. LIVINGSTON, one of the Tammany nominees, is a lawyer of good repute, and would, if elected, make a fair Judge. The same may be said of Ex-Judge FONDA, who is in nomination by the Citizens' Association, which is only strong, however, in one of the Wards of the District, thus giving him little chance. Mr. BOIES, the Union nominee, is little known at the Bar, and there are indications that he will not be supported by the bulk of his party. Mr. T.J. MCCAHILL., another of the Tammany nominees in this District, is unknown to legal fame in any manner entitling him to Judicial honors. It is for the citizens of the Eighteenth and Twenty-first Wards to select that candidate best fitted who appears to have most chance of an election.

abstract: -- On Saturday evening, about 6 o'clock, a man named MICHAEL RYAN, employed in putting down waterpipes in Newark-avenue, near Sixth-street, Jersey City, in a state of intoxication, drew a knife and attacked a fellow-laborer. The man succeeded in making his escape, when, RYAN attacked a lad eleven years of age, named JAMES FALLEN, and stabbed him in the arm. A number of citizens attempted to arrest RYAN, when he made a furious assault upon them and they were forced to run away. The assailant then proceeded to his residence, corner of Newark-avenue and Sixth-street, where he was subsequently arrested by Officers MCDONOUGH and NUGENT, and committed to the City Prison. The injured boy was conveyed to the home of his parents, but up to last evening the physicians were unable to stop the flow of blood, and it was thought he could not recover. The authorities declined to accept ball.

abstract: The health of the President is reported better. The Washington Republican, of Saturday, says: "The fever from which he has suffered has left him. Thursday and Thursday night his suffering was chiefly from severe pains in the head. Yesterday, and the day before, he was not permitted by his physician to hold any interviews even with the members of his Cabinet. It is hoped that in a day or two he will gain sufficient strength to resume his official duties."

abstract: About 7  o'clock yesterday morning a tragical affair occurred at No. 380 Grand-street, in this City, which, from all accounts, is of more than ordinary importance. The facts of the case, so far as we have been enabled to learn them, are as follows: ...
lead_paragraph: About 7 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning a tragical affair occurred at No. 380 Grand-street, in this City, which, from all accounts, is of more than ordinary importance. The facts of the case, so far as we have been enabled to learn them, are as follows: Mr. TIMOTHY MCEVOY, of the firm of MCEVOY & BROTHERS, merchants, doing business as clothiers at No. 380 Grand-street, for some cause best known to himself, determined to murder his wife. With this view he obtained a six-barreled revolver, and while alone with his wife in the parlor, at the time above-named, he drew the weapon and fired three shots. One ball passed through her left arm, another struck her cheek, near her right eye, causing the blood to flow very freely. The eve is, however, believed to be uninjured. The third shot missed its aim, the bullet lodging in the wall. Mrs. MCEVOY, whose Christian name is MARY, fell to the floor as soon as the shots were fired, and her husband, believing that he had killed her, started forthwith for the Tombs Police Court. When he entered the latter place he very excitedly exclaimed: "Capt. DOWLING;" meaning the Judge, "I am your prisoner, I have murdered my wife, and I wish to be committed to the Tombs." Judge DOWLING being temporarily absent from the bench, his clerk, Mr. MCGRATH, questioned MCEVOY as to the crime to which he pleaded guilty, but beyond the admission above stated he seemed disposed to preserve a strict silence.

abstract: -- Mr. P.D. KILLDOFF, of No. 1,160 Broadway, yesterday made complaint at the Tombs Police Court, of an outrage which was perpetrated on his two little girls, during the latter part of the past week. It seems that the children were returning from school, when a woman enticed them into an alley-way running out of Forty-fourth-street, and stripped them of almost all their clothing. The impudent thief made her escape, and has not yet been arrested, although several policemen have been in pursuit of her. This mode of robbing children of their clothing has, it is said, been extensively followed in the upper Wards of the City.

abstract: From the Army of the Potomac we have full details of operations up to Saturday morning, ten o'clock. The crossing of the Rapidan was very successful. On Friday the columns moved according to previous orders, so as to form line of battle north and south, right resting on the Rapidan, and facing toward Orange Court-house. In getting into position during the day, there was consider
lead_paragraph: From the Army of the Potomac we have full details of operations up to Saturday morning, ten o'clock. The crossing of the Rapidan was very successful. On Friday the columns moved according to previous orders, so as to form line of battle north and south, right resting on the Rapidan, and facing toward Orange Court-house. In getting into position during the day, there was considerable heavy skirmishing, and on the right a portion of the Third corps, under Gen. FRENCH, had quite a brisk engagement with EWELL's corps, losing five hundred in killed and wounded, but holding its own, and capturing nine hundred prisoners. As our line stood then, the Third corps was on the right, supported by the Sixth corps, the Second corps in the centre, and the Fifth corps, supported by the First on the left. During Friday night the enemy retired a short distance, and on Saturday morning, at 9 o'clock, our army was a mile and a half beyond (west of) Robertson's Tavern, or within about ten miles of Orange Court-house. The indications were that LEE would fight, and he seemed to be selecting his own ground. In that case a battle probably occurred yesterday.

abstract: The Victories at
lead_paragraph: In the history of the military operations that have thus far marked the progress of the war, Gen. GRANT's operations of last week stand out in distinct relief as the one example, on either side, of a victory followed up, and rendered decisive by the complete rout of the enemy. It is this unique fact which forms the most striking characteristic in a success so magnificent in all the features of its planning and execution. Indeed, in the estimate of the great weight of debt under which Gen. GRANT has laid the nation by this victory, it is not easy to say whether we should set most by the material gain to the Union arms of this great blow inflicted on the enemy, or by the moral gain to the whole country of this inspiring example of unwonted military vigor and power. At a stroke, Gen. GRANT has brushed away the cobwebs of military pedantry, (dignified by the name of prudence,) which would make us believe that the pursuit of a defeated foe has become an impossibility; and in a country which accumulates in itself every condition unfavorable to pursuit (thus making it the more glorious) has ground to powder and scattered to the winds a great army of the rebellion, a week ago intrenched in a position so formidable by nature and art as to seem absolutely unassailable.
headline: {'main': 'The Union Victory in Georgia.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Union Victory in Georgia.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: THE DICTATOR. -- Yesterday, as was intimated to the party who were disappointed the day previous in not seeing the Dictator go into the water, another unsuccessful attempt was made to launch the vessel. About 11 o'clock a large number of persons assembled at the Delamater Iron Works, foot of Thirteenth-street, and a few moments after that hour eight powerful tugs, assisted by the large Norwich freight-coat City of New-London, began to attach their hawsers to the Dictator. The combined strength of all the steamers was not sufficient to move the vessel but two feet and a half, when she stuck. After making several efforts, all of which proved unavailing, the tugs withdrew, leaving the Dictator still unlaunched. Another attempt will be made to launch the vessel this morning.

abstract: Quartermaster Gen. MEIGS, in his lively account of the three days' conflict before Chattanooga, mentions the notable fact that in Gen. HOOKER's fight up the slopes of Lookout Mountain, "much of the battle was fought above the clouds, which concealed him from our view, but from which his musketry was heard." There is on record at least one parallel to this in the campaign of NAPOLEON in the Carnic Alps, in 1797. The battle of the Col de Tarvis, March 22, 1797, was fought above the clouds -- the artillery thundering in the very laboratory of storms and arsenal of the electric batteries -- while the cavalry charged and performed their evolutions on the ice, and the infantry floundered to the attack through snow three feet thick.
lead_paragraph: Quartermaster Gen. MEIGS, in his lively account of the three days' conflict before Chattanooga, mentions the notable fact that in Gen. HOOKER's fight up the slopes of Lookout Mountain, "much of the battle was fought above the clouds, which concealed him from our view, but from which his musketry was heard." There is on record at least one parallel to this in the campaign of NAPOLEON in the Carnic Alps, in 1797. The battle of the Col de Tarvis, March 22, 1797, was fought above the clouds -- the artillery thundering in the very laboratory of storms and arsenal of the electric batteries -- while the cavalry charged and performed their evolutions on the ice, and the infantry floundered to the attack through snow three feet thick.
